The fact that the tea comes to me hot and I can immediately consume it without reheating is very convenient,” said Patnaik.

Title: CAA protest in Guwahati: BJP, Aasu spar over ‘migrants’ in Assam
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Protest rally against the amended Citizenship Act in Guwahati

GUWAHATI: On a day when BJP national working president JP Nadda held a mega rally in Guwahati in support of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, All Assam Students’ Union (Aasu) and its allied organisations responded by staging a massive show of strength at Neherubali in Nagaon district on Saturday.

At the Guwahati rally, organised on the eve of the launch of BJP’s “CAA-2019 Jan Jagaran Abhiyan”, Nadda said CAA didn’t allow any fresh influx and gave citizenship to only persecuted migrants, who had already come and settled in the country.

“We should understand that by this Act, Modiji is giving citizenship to only those persecuted on religious grounds and who have come here before December 31, 2014.”

At the Aasu rally, its chief adviser Samujjal Bhattacharyya said: “We are against granting citizenship to illegal Hindu Bangladeshis, and illegal Muslim Bangladeshis. In Assam, there is no place for communalism and fundamentalism.” He cautioned CM Sarbananda Sonowal against not paying heed to indigenous people, who want protection from illegal migrants.

Title: Kolkata priests in cassocks to march against CAA
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Priests from the Kolkata Diocese of the Church of North India (CNI) will hit the city streets in their white cassocks on January 20 to protest against CAA and NRC.

The Roman Catholic Church under the Archdiocese of Kolkata had organised a similar walk on December 26.

Clergy from suburbs, including the Barrackpore Diocese, will join in the January 20 march, singing hymns in English and Bengali, highlighting how Jesus “never supported divisive acts” and had urged Christians to stand united during crises. Kolkata Bishop Paritosh Canning expects the entire clergy to turn up at the march along with principals of schools that are under the administration of the diocese.

Representatives of the clergy will submit memorandums to Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee and governor Jagdeep Dhankhar after the march; copies will be sent to PM Modi and President Kovind.

Title: Isro signs pact with astrophysics institute to set up optical telescopes
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: Indian Space Research Organisation has inked a pact with Indian Institute of Astrophysics (IIA) to pave the way for collaboration in establishing optical telescope facilities under Project ‘NETRA’ for tracking space objects. The agency has also tied up with NIT-Karnataka to set up a regional academic centre for space to promote research in space technology.

Under the Rs 400-crore NETRA’ project, an early warning system is being set up in space to detect debris and other hazards that could pose a danger to Indian space assets like satellites and experimental platforms. Like other space powers, NETRA will give the country its own capability in space situational awareness.

A memorandum of understanding (MoU) between Isro and IIA for space cooperation in space situational awareness and astrophysics was signed by Isro scientific secretary R Umamaheswaran and IIA director Annapurni Subramaniam at the Isro headquartes in Bengaluru on January 2. The MoU will boost tie-up between Isro and IIA in setting up optical telescope facilities for space-object tracking, studies related to space weather , asteroids and other near earth objects, an Isro statement said.

In another development, Isro has set up a regional academic centre for space at the National Institute of Technology (NIT-K) at Surathkal in Karnataka’s southwest Dakshina Kannada district. Under the agreeement signed at Surathkal on Friday , the centre will conduct joint research and development in space technology applications to meet the needs of space programmes.

Isro will provide Rs 2 crore grant annually to NIT for R&D projects and promotional activities through the year. A joint policy and management committee will guide the centre in optimal utilisation of the research potential, infrastructure, expertise and experience of the space agency and the autonomous institute. Students of BTech and MTech will be involved in one-year short-term research projects and 2-4-year-long-term projects in advance space programmes. Intellectual property rights generated in projects will be jointly owned by Isro and NIT.

Title: Anti-CAA protests: When ‘Million March’ brought Hyderabad to a halt
Content:
The huge crowd that gathered at Indira Park to denounce Citizenship Amendment Act in Hyderabad on Saturday.

#CAAProtest || Sea of people at #DharnaChowk to participate in #HyderabadMillionMarch against #CAA_NRC_NPR. Many pe… https://t.co/Px9koRrHGH — TOI Hyderabad (@TOIHyderabad) 1578134147000

#CAAProtests || All roads leading to #DharnaChowk including Telugu Talli flyover are choc-a-block as thousands join… https://t.co/Lyxvq1K9ET — TOI Hyderabad (@TOIHyderabad) 1578132986000

#CAAProtest || People continue to join the #MillionMarch even as 30 mins more are remaining in the permitted time b… https://t.co/vx2HwUMBJY — TOI Hyderabad (@TOIHyderabad) 1578135796000

HYDERABAD: Heeding the call for a ‘ Million March ’ given mainly by 40 small organisations in Hyderabad, thousands of people swarmed the city’s Dharna Chowk on Saturday afternoon to protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). Holding nothing but the Tricolour in their hands, the protesters brought the city to a standstill.In sharp contrast the bustling old city of Hyderabad was virtually emptied out as most of the residents gathered at the protest venue. A large number of students and people from other districts too joined the march in what was one of the biggest anti-CAA protests in the city since the amended law as passed.Addressing the massive gathering, at least two of the speakers said Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao should make his stand clear on NRC and also ensure that it is not implemented in the state. “KCR should clear his stand before voting for municipal election in the state on January 20,” said Majlis Bachao Tehreek (MBT) leader Amjadullah Khan. TRS had voted against CAA in both houses of parliament.Former minister in undivided Andhra Pradesh and senior Congress leader Mohammed Shabbir Ali said, “I have not seen such a massive public convergence in Hyderabad without the involvement of any political party, particularly the ruling TRS-AIMIM combine to mobilise crowds.”Another Congress leader V Hanumanth Rao told the gathering, “We have all created history by voluntarily gathering here. There could be at least two lakh people here from Hindu, Muslim, Sikh, Christian and other communities. This should send a clear message to the RSS and BJP that they will never succeed in turning secular India into Hindu Rashtra.” The protest call was given by Muslim organisation Tehreek Muslim Shabban. Parties like Congress, CPI, CPM and the Popular Front of India too supported the event.

Title: We’re target of UP’s vilification campaign: PFI
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

NEW DELHI: Amid reports of UP government requesting the Centre to ban Islamic outfit Popular Front of India for its alleged role in the violence during the protests over the Citizenship Amendment Act, PFI has issue a public statement rejecting all allegations and claiming that the outfit was a target of a “vilification campaign” being carried out by UP government and police against them. PFI has said that if at all a ban is imposed on them in any state or by the Centre they will challenge it in the court of law.

PFI vice chairman O M A Salam challenged the government claiming it will not be able to find anything “inflammatory” in PFI literature and slogans. “We will fight this political vendetta through legal and democratic means,” Salam added.

He cited PFI’s ongoing legal battle in Jharkhand High Court over the ban reimposed by the state in 2018. “In February 2018, the BJP government in Jharkhand cited this unfounded and absurd reason of ‘IS influence’ for imposing a ban on the organisation in the state. Jharkhand HC had lifted the ban a year after it was first imposed in 2015. The state reimposed the ban and we have challenged it in the court. We hope to get justice from the HC,” he added.

When asked about the perception of PFI being an extremist organisation and that its funding was considered suspicious, Salam said, "PFI only works for India and gets funding from India." On public disclosure of its sources of funding, Salam said, “We are a registered organisation and all details about our funds are provided in the income tax returns. The IT department would have all our details so we are not hiding anything,” he added.

“To divert the attention of the people from from the police atrocities, the UP police and government are now targeting PFI. PFI state ad-hoc committee convener Wasim Ahmed and committee members Qari Ashfaque and Mohammed Nadeem are arrested on fake charges of planning the violence. This police action in fact seems to be a follow-up of the baseless allegation levelled by state deputy CM that PFI is behind all untoward incidents,” a statement by the organisation read.

“We are very confident that members of our organisation and other activists who are arrested will soon be released through the courts as the UP police will fail miserably to prove the charge against them,” the PFI statement asserts.

TOI reported on Saturday that UP’s request seeking a ban on PFI, coupled with inputs from Assam police pointing to PFI cadres role in fanning the December 11 violence in Guwahati during the anti-CAA protests and a 2017 dossier by NIA detailing PFI activists’ alleged role in four terror cases, have bolstered the Centre’s case for moving afresh to proscribe the outfit.

Title: CAA protests: Activist Sadaf Jafar, Darapuri & 11 others get bail
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Sadaf Jafar

LUCKNOW: Activist and actor Sadaf Jafar and former IPS officer S R Darapuri were granted bail on Saturday along with 11 other accused in connection with the violence that erupted during the December 19 protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act in the city.

The prosecution admitted during arguments that investigations so far had found no clear evidence of Sadaf’s specific role in arson and that an investigation was still under way to collect more evidence.

Additional district judge S S Pandey, while granting bail, considered the prosecution’s admission that they lacked proof of Sadaf’s role in arson and took cognisance of the medical reports of police personnel injured during the protests, stating “it was evident the injuries were not grievous in nature”. The court directed the accused to furnish two sureties of Rs 50,000 each and a personal bond.

The court in its order on Sadaf stated: “The accused will cooperate and appear before the investigating officer as and when required and will not participate in any criminal activity or influence witnesses. Without going into the merits of the case and considering the nature of offences and circumstances of the case, the grounds for bail are enough.”

Sadaf was arrested from the anti-CAA protest site at Lucknow’s Parivartan Chowk on the evening of December 19 while she was live-streaming events. Later, an FIR was lodged against 33 people, including Sadaf, at Hazratganj police station. Before her arrest, she posted critical videos accusing police of inaction during the clashes. Those who got bail on Saturday also included a Rae Bareli-based lecturer and activist, Pawan Rai Ambedkar.

In her bail petition, filed with the assistance of senior advocate Harjot Singh, Sadaf said police nabbed her while she was filming the violence and helping cops identify miscreants. She also said police had not been able to find evidence of her involvement in the violence.

Government lawyer Deepak Yadav , while opposing the bail plea, said Sadaf violated prohibitory orders and was arrested from the spot where violence was taking place. Sadaf was charged with rioting, attempt to murder, assault, criminal intimidation, disobedience of a public servant, voluntarily causing hurt to a public servant, arson and criminal conspiracy under various sections of the IPC, Sec 3/4 of the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act of 1984 and Section 7 of the Criminal Law (Amendment) Act, 1932.

Title: Attack on Sikhs in Nankana justifies CAA: BJP
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: Citing the attack on Sikh pilgrims at Nankana Sahib in Pakistan, BJP on Saturday claimed the incident justifies the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA).

“Those sitting on dharna in Shaheen Bagh or staging protests in other parts of the country like Kerala against CAA should take a cue from the Nankana Sahib incident about how minorities are unsafe in the neighbouring countries,” BJP spokesperson and Lok Sabha MP Meenakshi Lekhi said. Lekhi said the Nankana Sahib incident is an illustration of the kind of persecution minorities in Pakistan face and why they need citizenship in India.

Union housing and urban affairs minister Hardeep Singh Puri said the violent mob that besieged the Nankana Sahib Gurdwara on Friday had threatened to change the name of the holy place to “Ghulam-e-Mustafa”. “Do those who are opposing the CAA need more evidence of oppression of minorities in Pakistan,” he asked.

Lekhi also questioned Navjot Singh Sidhu ’s silence on the incident. “I do not know where Sidhu paaji has fled? Even if after all this, he wants to hug ISI chief, then Congress should look into it,” Lekhi said.

Title: Ali Fazal performs his boyfriend duty as he clicks stunning pictures of ladylove Richa Chadha!
Content: The news of Bollywood actor Sushant Singh Rajput being found dead in his Mumbai apartment on June 14 rattled the entire nation. While the Mumbai Police tried to probe in the case from all angles, they even questioned several people in connection to the actor's demise. But with Sushant's father filing an FIR against Rhea Chakraborty and others, the case ultimately was handed over to the CBI by the Supreme Court. And it is since the day CBI stepped in and started with their probe that new shocking revelations in connection to the mysterious death of Sushant have have started cropping up.

Title: 2 killed, 6 hurt in four accidents
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kolkata: Two persons, including a senior citizen, were killed and six were seriously injured in four accidents in the city between Friday afternoon and Saturday morning.

A 73-year-old man from Hazra Road was run over by a minibus when the vehicle skidded on the rain-soaked road around 8.30pm on Friday. The victim, Velzee Patel, was trying to cross the road to get home when the accident happened. “The minibus was plying on the Deys’ Medical-Howrah route and moving towards the east. The incident took place between Hazra law college and Garcha Road crossing. Profusely bleeding, Patel was taken to CNMC Hospital, where he was declared brought dead. The Gariahat police have arrested the bus driver and seized the vehicle,” said an officer.

Another death was reported from the accident-prone Central Garden Reach Road around 4.45am on Saturday. Sohail Alam, 39, was on a scooterette when he was run over by an unidentified vehicle, possibly a truck, near a dock Port gate under the South Port police station. Alam, a resident of Ripon Street, sustained multiple injuries and was declared brought dead at SSKM Hospital.

In another accident, reported from the Kingsway-Strand Road crossing around 10.30pm on Friday, a south-bound truck hit an app cab, injuring the two cab passengers — Sohail Ahmed and Md Kalamuddin, both 25 years old. The duo was taken to SSKM Hospital with face and chest injuries, from where they were later discharged. Local police seized both vehicles but the truck driver fled.

Near Uttar Panchannagram, an east-bound car collided with a north-bound car around 11.30pm on Friday. Four occupants of the north-bound car were injured and had to be treated at Ruby General Hospital. Both cars, along with the drivers, were taken to the local police station.

Title: Daily wagers block road over e-memos, 21 detained
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Protesters say for a turn at a distance of 250 metres, they have to take a U-turn 1.5km away

Rajkot: Angry with e-memos issued by traffic police for wrong side driving, 100-odd commuters staged a chakka jam (road block) in front of Juna Kuvadava Road police station near fruit market in Rajkot on Saturday. At least 21 protesters were detained by the police.

The commuters, mostly labourers earning daily wages, were extremely incensed when they received e-memos each worth Rs 1,500.

Most of them complained that they were issued e-memos for driving on the wrong side on Juna Kuvadava Road.

“If we have to go towards Greenland Chowkadi or Navagam from Juna Kuvadava Road, we have to take the U-turn that comes after one and a half kilometre near Patel Vihar. However, if we drive in the wrong side, we can take the turn after driving for just 200-250 metres,” explained one of the commuters.

“Most of us are daily wagers belonging to the lowest rung of the society, and if we have to pay Rs 1,500 for an e-memo, how will we survive. We can’t afford that burden. Hence, when we received the memos, we had no option but to stage a chakka jam to register our protest,” said another commuter.

The road block resulted in huge traffic jam with scores of vehicles lining up to 2.5km for nearly two hours. The agitators also raised slogans against the traffic police before they were detained. The 21 agitators detained were and booked them for rioting also.

Title: 10 candidates secure 100 percentile in CAT
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kozhikode: Ten candidates have secured overall 100 percentile in the results of the Common Admission Test (CAT-2019), declared by Indian Institute of Management, Kozhikode ( IIM-K ), for admissions to 20 IIMs and over 115 other management institutions in the country.

Continuing with last year’s trend, all 10 toppers are men and are from the engineering/technology background. Of the 10 candidates who made it to the 100 percentile league, six are from IITs, two candidates are from NITs, one candidate is from Jadavpur University, according to the release issued by IIM-K, the organizing institute for CAT-2019.

Maharashtra has the most number of toppers with four of the ten 100 percentilers hailing from the state and the remaining candidates are from Jharkhand, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Telangana, Uttarakhand and West Bengal.

As many as 21 candidates have scored an overall 99.99 percentile and 19 of them are from the engineering/technology background. According to sources, the highest women percentile in CAT-2019 is 99.98 from BITS Pilani hailing from Vadodara, Gujarat.

Professor Shubhasis Dey, convener of CAT-2019, said this test had seen the highest number candidates appearing for the exam in the last 10 years. This year 2,09,926 candidates appeared. This includes 75,004 women, 1,34,917 men along with five transgender candidates.

CAT-2019 was conducted in two shifts on November 24, 2019 at 376 test centres spread across 156 cities in the country.

IIMs will now release their shortlists for subsequent admission processes based on, among other things, the CAT 2019 scores.

Director of IIM-K Professor Debashis Chatterjee, said: “This year’s CAT examination was one of the smoothest exams held in recent years. IIM Kozhikode feels privileged and expresses its gratitude to all stakeholders on behalf of all 20 IIMs for seamless conduct of CAT 2019. I also take this opportunity to congratulate all successful aspirants and wish them luck for the remaining stages of the exam.”

Candidates can download their official CAT 2019 scorecards by logging onto the CAT 2019 website, www.iimcat.ac.in.

Title: Love for gambling turns Rajkot homemaker into a thief
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Ekta Bhimani in police custody

RAJKOT: Her addiction to gambling made this simple housewife turn into a thief, said police on Saturday. Cops arrested Ekta Bhimani, a resident of Bhaktinagar in Rajkot , from her parental home in Satya Apartment at Nikol in Ahmedabad on Friday.

Ekta had allegedly stolen gold jewellery worth Rs 5.6 lakh from her trader husband, Ankit Bhimani’s house and had also pawned it at a financial firm to avail money to pay off her debts before fleeing to her parents’ house.

During interrogation, Ekta confessed to being addicted to gambling after she came in contact with her aunt-in-law in Rajkot, who was a habitual gambler.

“During Shravan, Ekta lost Rs 15 lakh to Alka, wife of Imran Menu, in gambling. As she did not have money to pay the amount, she decided to steal the jewellery along with the jewellery that her parents had gifted her for her wedding,” said an official from Bhaktinagar police station.

In his statement, the husband alleged that last month Imran along with a few aides had come to his house, demanding Rs 12 lakh that Ekta had lost in gambling. When Bhimani refused to pay the amount, Imran and his associates allegedly pelted stones at his house.

“Imran also allegedly threatened to kill Ankit, if he did not get the amount,” added the official.

Title: Bihar: Clouds may disappear today
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Overcast skies continued to make people shiver on Saturday. Weathermen have claimed that the cloud cover will clear by Sunday followed by dense fog cover in early morning hours and plunge in night temperature over the next two three days.

In its daily weather bulletin issued on Saturday, Patna Meteorological Centre stated that light rainfall occurred at one or two places across the state and moderate rainfall at some places during the past 24 hours.

As far as temperature readings are concerned, morning minimum in Patna was recorded at 11.8 degrees C, three notches higher than normal. Maximum temperature, on the other hand, was recorded at 18.3 degrees C, three notches lower than normal.

At 10.5 degrees C, lowest minimum temperature in the state was recorded at Sabour in Bhagalpur district.

Patna Meteorological Centre has predicted that minimum and maximum temperature in the city would hover in the range of 11-12 degrees C and 20-21 degrees C till January 7.

The weather in the state is expected to turn rainy from January 8 onwards under the influence of a fresh western disturbance, the weather systems originating from Mediterranean Sea, Red Sea and Caspian Sea, which cause snow and winter rainfalls in northwestern Indian subcontinent.

Title: Patna University girls bag 31 of 40 gold medals
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Altogether, 1,735 scholars successfully completed their courses in 2018-19

PATNA: Girls outsmarted boys by bagging as many as 31 out of 40 gold medals awarded to the toppers of postgraduate (PG) examinations of 2019 at the annual convocation of Patna University (PU) held at Bapu Sabhagar on Saturday.

Altogether, 1,735 scholars successfully completed their courses in 2018-19. Of them, 1,016 candidates received their degrees in person. As many as 109 of them were PhD degree holders. Incidentally, this was the third PU convocation within a year. The last two convocations were held on January 21 and May 30, 2019.

Governor-cum-chancellor Phagu Chauhan and Indira Gandhi Open University vice-chancellor (VC) Nageshwar Rao gave away the medals to the toppers and degrees to the PhD scholars. PU VC Rash Bihari Prasad Singh distributed the degrees to PG scholars.

The toppers, who were awarded gold medals in the faculty of humanities, are Sunil Kumar (Hindi), Areeba Akhtar (English), Kajal Kumari (Sanskrit), Kajal Kumari (Maithili), Sneha Bhakat (Bengali), Mohd Mansur Rahman (Arabic), Abid Karim (Persian), Yusuf Shakil (Urdu), Lalit Kumar (philosophy), Sujit Kumar (MJMC) and Kumari Abhilasha (music).

Faculty of social sciences toppers include Puja Kumari (history), Priya (political science), Ankita Kumari (home science), Naveen Kumar (Ancient Indian history), Shweta Sagar (sociology), Shubha Saurabh and Surbhi Sinha (economics), Anuradha (psychology), Smriti Prakash (geography), Ankita Singh (personnel management and industrial relations), Ashwini Kumar (rural studies), Shaista Shamim (social work), Naina (women’s studies), Debashish Pandit Paul (library and information science).

The gold medallists of science department are Minali Singh (physics), Rishika Kumari (chemistry), Divya Prasad (zoology), Nisha Bharti ( botany ), Ehraz Zia (geology), Madhvi Raj (mathematics), Shambhawi Singh (statistics), Amarjeet Kumar (biochemistry), Sadaf Jahan (biotechnology), Nigar Fatima (environmental science), and Nisha (MCA).

Other gold medallists include Prishita Akananksha (commerce), Arushi Singh (MBA), Mahvish Fatma (law), Mamta Kumari and Chanda Rani (education).

Pritisha Akanksha (MCom) and Chanda Rani (MEd) were awarded ‘RNP Barial Gold Medals’ for securing highest marks among girls.

Title: ECR: Ro-ro service between Sheikhpura and Begusarai soon
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The East Central Railways (ECR) is likely to start ro-ro (roll-on/roll-off) service between Sheikhpura and Tilrath in Begusarai from February.

A decision in this regard was taken at a meeting between the officials of the state transport department and the ECR earlier this week. According to them, loaded trucks will now be directly carried by railway wagons to their destinations.

Transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal told this newspaper on Saturday that the ro-ro service will reduce the movement of heavy vehicles on the J P Setu between Digha and Sonepur.

“Traffic on the J P Setu has doubled after a ban was imposed on the movement of heavy vehicles on the Rajendra Setu in Begusarai in December last year. The National Highways Authority of India had taken the decision in view of the bridge’s dilapidated condition,” Agarwal said and added the district transport officers would provide certificates, stating the weight of the trucks to be carried by railway wagons.

At the recent meeting between transport department and ECR officials, it was decided that ro-ro services would also be started between Mokama and Begusarai and Bihta and Begusarai soon.

Sources claimed that the ECR would provide the necessary infrastructure and facilities for starting the ro-ro service.

ECR’s chief freight traffic manager, Sanjay Kumar, said special ramps to load and unload trucks and lorries would also be made available at Sheikhpura and Tilrath.

“We are trying to reduce the pressure on the J P Setu by introducing ro-ro service from February. The cost of transportation depends on the distance covered, but it usually costs anywhere between Rs 3,000 and Rs 4,000 per truck of 15 tonnes,” Kumar added.

Earlier, in 2016, the ECR had started ro-ro service between Bihta and Turki in Muzaffarpur . It was, however, stopped after some time.

Title: Kalidas Mahotsav to give rich treat
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Nagpur: Kalidas Mahotsav , the first major cultural feast of new year, that will provide a rich treat of classical and semi-classical dance, and singing performances by artistes of repute, will begin at Suresh Bhat Sabhagruh at 6pm on Sunday.

The three-day event will have a blend of theatre and classical performances every day. The theme of the festival is ‘Vikramovarshiyam’, written by poet Kalidas.

The inaugural performance will be given by Sukirti Uike, a classical vocalist. This will be followed by Bharatanatyam performance by Arupa Lahiri. Eminent singer Mahesh Kale will be the last to perform.

The second day of the festival will commence with ‘Panchatatva’, a cultural manifestation of five elements of the universe, to be presented by Saptak. The programme has been conceptualized by Renuka Deshkar. Shailesh Dani and Swati Bhalerao will arrange music and dance performances, respectively as part of this event.

This will be followed by sitar recital by Samanvay Sarkar and Kathak performance by Sharwari Jemnis.

On Tuesday, Mohanto will present Odissi dance, to be followed by classical vocal performance by Nuran sisters. The festival will conclude with the performance of vocalist Aditya Khandwe.

Entry to the programmes is free.

Title: 10-day international trade fair begins in city
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

PATNA: Over 15,000 products, ranging from handicrafts and cosmetics to furniture and clothes, have been put up for sale at the third edition of the India International Mega Trade Fair (IIMTF) on the premises of Gyan Bhavan. A large number of security personnel have been deployed at the venue to manage the crowd.

The 10-day fair, which was inaugurated by state industries minister Shyam Rajak on Saturday, will conclude on January 13. One can drop by the fair between 12pm and 8pm and there is no entry fee being charged.

Rajak congratulated the organizers of the IIMTF for the success of the first and second editions. “This fair is a diverse platform for countries that wish to showcase their art and culture. I welcome all the participants to Bihar,” he said.

Altogether six countries — Afghanistan, Thailand, Bangladesh, Iran, Malaysia and Dubai — as well as 10 Indian states — West Bengal, Bihar, Jharkhand, Uttar Pradesh, Punjab, Delhi, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Gujarat and Rajasthan — have taken part in the fair this year.

Bangladesh’s deputy high commissioner Toufique Hasan and Patna mayor Sita Sahu were the guests of honour at the inaugural event of the IIMTF. Hasan said, “I am elated that Bangladesh is part of this international fair.”

While foreign products like Afghan dry fruits, Iranian jewellery, Thai flowers and perfumes from Dubai are attracting visitors, domestic items like silk saris, terracotta statues, handicrafts and shawls are also in demand at the fair. They are available in a range of Rs 350 to Rs 1,20,000.

Visitors can also gorge themselves on food items from different corners of India at the IIMTF.

Title: Man booked for raping woman friend
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Surat: A 37-year-old woman was allegedly raped multiple times by her friend in her house in Limbayat area of the city on Saturday. She was rescued by locals and police as the accused had escaped after tying her and locking the house from outside. The woman shouted for help following which locals contacted police who rescued and shifted her to a hospital.

Mohammad Soheb alias Gudde Siddiqi was booked under Indian Penal Code for rape and assault at Limbayat police station. The complainant has alleged that she was attacked with a knife and her hands and legs were tied with a rope by the accused before he raped her four times. The accused is on the run.

The woman separated from her husband a few years ago and lives with her four children. The woman, who became friends with the accused a few months ago, did not wish to continue the relationship and this had angered him.

Title: Four including a woman held during liquor raids
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Rajkot: Four persons including a woman were arrested with 1,332 bottles of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) worth Rs 3.66 lakh during different raids in Rajkot on Saturday. The raids were concucted at Kotharia Road, Nanavati Chowk , Madhapar and Shivajinagar localities.

In Kotharia Road, Faruq Khalifa (24) was arrested with 816 bottles of rum worth Rs 81,600. “We had received a tip-ff that Khalifa had stored the liquor cache in his house in Tirupati Society, following which we raided his house and arrested him with the rum bottles. During his interrogation, Khalifa said that as the demand for rum during winter was high, he had decided to store rum bottles,” said an official from Kotharia Road police station.

The second raid was conducted on the road between Nanavati Chowk and Rameshwer Chowk, where 240 IMFL bottles worth Rs one lakh were seized from a mini truck. “Vishal Garenia (35) was carrying the liquor cache in a mini truck and was scheduled to pass by the road. Following this lead, we kept a watch on the stretch and intercepted the truck whose registration number we had already obtained. Garenia was arrested with the liquor cache,” said an official from Rajkot crime branch.

During his interrogation, Garenia said he had procured the liquor supply from Gordhan Vekaria, following which the police have booked him and launched a manhunt for him.

In Ambedkarnagar of Madhapar locality, a woman bootlegger was arrested with 156 IMFL bottles worth Rs 75,000. “The accused, identified as Ganga Parmar (45), said that her son Viththal Parmar had procured the liquor bottles, following which we have launched a manhunt for Viththal,” said an official from Gandhigram police station.

The last raid was carried out at Shivajinagar where Vijay Bhalia (31) was arrested with 276 IMFL bottles worth Rs 1.10 lakh. “During his interrogation, Bhalia said he had procured the liquor cache from one Hanif Mandhara, who too has been booked,” said an official from Thorala police station.

BOOTLEGGER SENT TO JAIL UNDER PASA

A noted bootlegger was sent to jail under Prevention of Anti Social Activities Act (PASA). Police said the accused, Priyank Mehta, a resident of Char Maliya Quarter at Nana Mawa Chowk in Rajkot, was arrested for bootlegging liquor bottles in Padadhari and booked under PASA.

Title: Surat: Teen gang-raped multiple times, six detained
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

Title: 2 Patna University students arrested for attack on cops
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Police on Saturday arrested two students of Patna University (PU) from two hostels for their alleged involvement in the attack on two constables, Santosh Kumar and Rajesh Paswan, at Krishna Ghat under the Pirbahore police station area in the city on Thursday.

The two constables were thrashed when they attempted to stop few youths from passing lewd comments on girls and playing objectionable songs on their cellphones.

SHO of Pirbahore police station Rizwan Ahmed Khan said the arrested PU students were identified as Pratyush alias Amarkant and Alok Kumar.

He said Pratyush and Alok were inmates of Patna University’s Minto Hostel and Jackson Hostel, respectively. The SHO added that Pratush was an accused in a murder case lodged with Pirbahore police station. “He had recently come out of jail on bail. The injured constables and some eyewitnesses had identified the two PU students,” the SHO said.

SI’s stolen pistol yet to be recovered: Police have so far not been able to recover the service pistol, seven bullets and cellphone of sub-inspector Chandrayan Marandi (58) which were stolen after he fell unconscious following an accident near Gosaitola sump house under the Patliputra police station area in the city on December 1 last year.

Bank robber identified: Police on Saturday claimed that the criminal who had looted Rs 9.12 lakh from the cash counter of the Station Road branch of United Bank of India on December 31 has been identified.

City SP (central) Vinay Tiwary said the criminal was identified on the basis of human intelligence collected by police. “We cannot reveal his identity for the time being for the sake of investigation. All we can say is that he is a drug addict,” Tiwary said.

The criminal, who was armed with a pistol, had barged into the bank at 3.04pm on Tuesday. He had looted the money in just two minutes and fled towards Kankarbagh in a city bus.

Title: Faiz was born, studied and married in India. To call him Pakistani is a misnomer, says his grandson Ali Madeeh Hashmi
Content:
With Faiz Ahmed Faiz’s 1979 poem Hum Dekhenge becoming the subject of a controversy, Sonam Joshi spoke to Lahore-based psychologist Ali Madeeh Hashmi, who is Faiz’s grandson and author of his authorised biography

What is your reaction to IIT Kanpur setting up a panel to investigate whether your grandfather’s poem is “anti-national”?

How do you think Faiz would have reacted?

The IIT professor’s complaint relates to two specific lines: Jab arz-e-Khuda ke kaabe se/Sab but uthwaye jayenge” and “Bas naam rahega Allah ka”. Could you put these in context?

A lot of articles refer to Faiz as a Pakistani poet. How strong were his ties with India?

Why do you think Faiz’s poetry continues to remain relevant nearly 35 years after his death?

From being imprisoned for four years during the 1950s to living in exile in Beirut from 1978-82, what was Faiz’s relationship to the state?

The reaction is mainly amusement, or perhaps bemusement might be a better word. While we have, for a long time, been used to certain aspects of Faiz’s poetry being censored or outright banned in Pakistan, to have it happen in India is rather astonishing. As to whether the poem is ‘anti-national’, yes, it absolutely is. Faiz was not a ‘nationalist’; he was an ‘internationalist’, a believer in the ideal of the people of the Indo-Pak subcontinent being brothers and sisters, who needed to make common cause against their enemies. Not just that, he linked the struggle of our people to the struggle of common people all over the world for justice, economic and political equality. It is a pity that a prestigious institution like IIT Kanpur has initiated this ludicrous inquiry. But this has given us, the Faiz family, a chance, once again to declare unequivocally that we stand, not just with the ordinary people of Pakistan but of India as well. The struggle of the students of Jamia, AMU and IIT is our struggle too.With his verse: ‘Kat te bhi chalo badhte bhi chalo baazu bhi bahut hain sar bhi/bahut chalte bhi chalo ki ab dere manzil hi pe daale jayenge’ (Let the amputations begin/The Hydra of our resolve, our revolution/Bears many arms, wears many heads... We will rest only when we’ve reached our Motherland’s true court).Faiz used a lot of religious imagery and symbolism in many of his poems and these two lines refer to (a) the Prophet Muhammad’s breaking the idols inside the ‘Ka’aba’, revered as the House of Allah and (b) referring to the concept of ‘Tauheed’, or oneness of God, a core belief in Islam. As a monotheist religion, Islam sets itself in opposition to polytheistic belief systems and ‘but-shikan’ (‘idol-breaker’) is often thought of as a person who upends traditional values and beliefs to usher in a new era. But ‘idol’ in poetic parlance can mean any number of things: a cruel beloved, a tyrannical ruler, or even one’s own self which must be cleansed of impurities to achieve union with the divine. We are surprised that the IIT professor who filed this complaint is not familiar with this elementary fact. Perhaps IIT Kanpur should add a course in poetry and the humanities to its curriculum.Well, ‘Pakistani’ is a misnomer. He was born in 1911 in India, went to school and college in India, started his first job in Amritsar , got married in Srinagar in 1941 and fought in the Indian Army in the Second World War. He only became ‘Pakistani’ when he was 36, in 1947. And all his life, he retained a deep love and affection for the people who live in what is now ‘India’. He never saw the ordinary people of both countries as separate and certainly not as enemies. He never became embroiled in the rather superfluous debate about whether Partition was ‘right’ or ‘wrong’, and he never bought into the ‘us against them’ narrative either.He answered that himself and the exact quote is ‘Bhai, na Pakistan ke halaat badlain gay, na hamari nazmain purani hongi’ (‘Neither will Pakistan’s conditions change, nor will my poems age’). Professor sahib at IIT Kanpur along with PM Modi-ji are proving that the same applies to India as well.In 2016, MAMI festival banned the screening of a movie he wrote, and two years later, your mother was not allowed to attend an event in Delhi after being invited. Why does Faiz rankle the establishment?Because his poems challenge tyranny and oppression, and since he has not situated his poems in a particular time or situation, they resonate with all people who are struggling for justice and equality.He was not against state authority as such, only against the oppressive authority of states. You have to remember that for Faiz and many of the stalwarts of the All India Progressive Writer’s Association, India’s freedom struggle from the British was also a struggle for economic and social equality. What they wanted was not just an end to British rule but an end to tyranny and exploitation. When that didn’t happen in either India or Pakistan, Faiz felt the work of Independence was incomplete.

Title: Believe in work, not publicity: CM Nitish Kumar
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar at Khagaria on Saturday

PATNA/BEGUSARAI/KHAGARIA: Playing down the issue of the Jal Jivan Hariyali tableau failing to make the cut for the Republic Day Parade, CM Nitish Kumar said on Saturday that he believes in work, not publicity .

“Hum Prachar me Nai, Balki Kam Mein Vishwas Rakhte hain,” Nitish said in Begusarai while addressing a public gathering on the first day of the sixth phase of his JJH Yatra.

He added: “Some people are unnecessarily talking about the proposed theme of JJH for our tableau not being showcased in the Republic Day parade. There is no meaning of such questions. There are many other works being done in different parts of the country, which will be showcased in the Republic Day Parade. Many things associated with Bihar have also been shown at the parades in the past. There is no need to worry about it.”

Nitish appealed to the people of the state to ensure their participation in the human chain being organised by the state government on January 19 to spread awareness on JJH, anti-dowry, anti-child marriage and liquor prohibition initiatives. The 16,200km human chain initiative aims to cover the entire state.

“Only those who understand the concept of JJH will adopt it and we will work together to make it successful,” Nitish said.

Nitish also mentioned Microsoft founder Bill Gates appreciating the JJH work being done in Bihar, even as many developed countries such as France, England and US are still not taking climate change seriously.

The CM visited Saadpur panchayat in Sahebpurkamal block and reviewed various projects related to rejuvenating village water bodies, plantation and rain water harvesting schemes. He also inspected a revamped pond spread across 22acres with intensive plantation all around it.

He also inaugurated a new government school building built at a cost of over Rs1 crore. The CM met members of women’s self- help groups (SHGs) and handed over cheques worth over 19 crore for their capacity building.

From Begusarai, Nitish went to Khagaria in the afternoon, where he laid the foundation for 250 development schemes worth Rs 2,200 crore during a 'Jagrukta Sammelan' at Telihar village under Beldaur block in Khagaria district. The CM also inaugurated 126 schemes worth Rs73 crore for the district.

Three RJD functionaries arrested in Begusarai: At least three district functionaries of RJD were arrested in Begusarai for trying to create disturbances at the CM’s public meeting held as part of the ‘Jal Jivan Haryali’ campaign on Saturday.

Police said district president of RJD, Mohit Yadav, Youth RJD’s Ram Krishna Patel and student’s wing leader Kailash Yadav were taken into custody while proceeding towards the venue of the CM’s meeting with banners and placards against the CAA.

A team led by SDPO Sanjiv Kumar intercepted them. Earlier, they had organized a protest march against the CAA at Balia in Begusarai district .

The SHO of Town police station, Amrendra Kumar Jha, said RJD functionaries were arrested with banners and posters against CAA. A case was lodged against them for causing hindrance in discharge of official duty and other sections of IPC.

Title: Patna: ‘Crime against women won’t be tolerated’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Upendra Kumar Sharma

PATNA: The 2008 batch IPS officer, Upendra Kumar Sharma , who took charge as Patna ’s senior superintendent of police (SSP) on Thursday, has made it clear that crime against women will not be tolerated. In an interview with TOI’s Sheezan Nezami, he talks about his priorities. Excerpts:

What will be your priority as the SSP of Patna?

As a police official, crime control and maintenance of law and order are my duties. However, issues like crime against women, dowry death , murder, dacoity, communal tension, loot and chain snatching will be given top priority and dealt with seriously. The deputy superintendent of police will be asked to supervise such cases.

Earlier, you were posted as the City SP. Is there a difference in the nature of crimes then and now?

The only difference is that social media and cybercrime had not spread their tentacles back then. Besides, movies, which portray harassers as heroes, have polluted the minds of youngsters today. A number of them hail from well-to-do families and are not involved in crimes for fulfilling their basic needs. Instead, they want to buy expensive cellphones and gadgets.

What steps will you take to strengthen your team and set an example for other districts?

We will ensure that innocent people, especially youngsters, are not sent to jail as it can ruin their future. We will try to maintain transparency and reach a crime spot on time.

Crime against women is a major concern everywhere. How will you deal with complaints of sexual harassment, eve-teasing and stalking?

Crime against women will not be tolerated. I urge women and young girls to be strong and come forward to lodge FIRs.

Patna is a hub of private coaching institutes. Some girls, who come here from distant places to peruse higher education, often fall prey to harassment. How will you ensure their safety?

As of now, I have not visited any such area, but will do so soon. We will identify the vulnerable areas and ensure the presence of cops there.

Can Patnaites freely go outside without having to worry about their cash, jewellery and other costly items at home?

This is a major challenge for us, but we will keep an eye on theft and dacoity accused who have been set free after serving jail term. We will also try to ensure that the number of such cases goes down.

Title: Rajgir safari: A nature lover’s paradise this
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Under construction site at the upcoming nature safari at Rajgir

PATNA: Adventure-lovers from the state now need not go to Rishikesh to enjoy zip-lining or flying fox activities, as the state environment, forest and climate change department is coming up with various recreational amenities in the upcoming nature safari at Rajgir in Nalanda district .

The nature safari, spread over an area of around 500hectare, is located in Jethian valley between Rajgir-Jethian pathways. Department’s principal secretary Dipak Kumar Singh said the motive behind developing the nature safari is to bring people close to nature and make them realize its importance. “Most of us hardly find time to observe nature and spend some time amid trees and birds. Rajgir Nature Safari is being developed for this purpose,” Dipak told TOI.

Conservator of forests, Patna division, Gopal Singh said there will be facility of unpaved path, which will be used for walking inside the safari. “Another attraction will be canopy walkways or treetop walkways, in which bridges will be made between the treetops and people can enjoy the scenery from the top and get a view of the surrounding. There will be a butterfly zone and relaxation sheds,” he said.

People will also be able to camp in the midst of nature as the forest department will provide tent houses. “Accommodation facility is being developed on raised platforms with capacity to accommodate 100 people at any given time,” said the forest official.

Sources associated with the project said that minimum construction work is being done to avoid any adverse impact on the green cover. As of now, almost 20% of the work has been completed, which includes demarcation of the area, putting up gates and identification of area for putting up tents. The hills, which will have 300-metre-long zip-lining facility, have also been selected and soil testing process has been completed for the same. The project is expected to be completed by March next year.

“Since the nature safari is coming at a distance of 4km from the upcoming zoo safari in Rajgir, tourists will be able to visit both the facilities without travelling much,” said Gopal. The zoo safari, spread across 480 acre is expected to get completed in August this year. Animals in this safari will be kept in big enclosures and people will be taken around in closed vehicles to see them.

Title: CAA: BJP plans to reach out to three crore people in Bihar
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

State BJP president Sanjay Jaiswal

MOTIHARI/BIHARSHARIF: State BJP president Sanjay Jaiswal said here on Saturday that the party will organise a statewide campaign to create awareness on Citizenship (Amendment) Act and National Register of Citizens (NRC) from January 5 to 15.

Chirag Paswan, president of BJP ally Chirag Paswan , on the other hand, said at Biharsharif that CAA is not against the rights of any Indian and all NDA constituents are strongly with it.

“The opposition parties are unnecessarily creating confusion over CAA as there is nothing in it which would go against the interest of any Indian. The NDA partners are very clear about it and they stand in solidly with it,” Chirag said.

Asked about seat-sharing in NDA for the upcoming assembly elections, Chirag said, “No discussion has taken place yet but one thing is certain that the alliance will fight the Bihar assembly elections under the leadership of Nitish Kumar .”

Jaiswal, on the other hand, said party functionaries and workers will go to more than 3 crore houses in the state to apprise people about CAA and inform them that that the law does not take away citizenship of any Indian, rather it only grants persecuted minorities from four select countries the Indian citizenship. “Some opposition parties are misleading the minorities,” Jaiswal said at Motihari.

Title: Police arrest dreaded criminal in Bhagalpur
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

BHAGALPUR: A special investigation team (SIT) constituted by Bhagalpur SSP Ashish Bharti to probe the murder of general secretary of Kali Maharani Mahanagar Central Committee (KMMCC) Chiranjeevi Yadav alias Dhuri Yadav, arrested a dreaded contract killer, Suraj Tanti, on Saturday.

Dhuri was shot dead by motorcycle-borne criminals on November 4 last year. The incident occurred when the deceased was on way to a cowshed from his residence at Urdu Bazar under the Tatarpur police station area here.

Police sources said Dhuri was probably killed over a personal enmity. He also had criminal antecedents, they added. Dhuri was engaged in organizing Kali puja and social activities in the locality apart from doing land dealings. An FIR related to Dhuri’s killing was lodged by his brother Shishupal Yadav on November 5.

Later, Bhagalpur SSP Ashish Bharti formed an SIT headed by city DSP Rajvansh Singh and SHOs of Tatarpur, Sabour, Jogsar, Jagdishpur, Industrial Area and Barari police stations along with other police personnel from IT wing.

Later, dreaded gangster Ajay Mishra, Kishore Yadav, Raj Kumar Yadav, Suman Mandal, Rajram Singh, Abhimanyu Singh, Suraj Yadav and Birju Yadav were arrested by the SIT in connection with Dhuri’s murder. However, five other accused and two sharpshooters, whose sketches were released by the SIT, are still on the run. Suraj Tanti, who was arrested on Saturday, is also a sharpshooter.

Bhagalpur SSP Ashish Bharti said the arrested criminals were being interrogated. “We have released the sketches of the shooters on the basis of information provided by eyewitnesses,” the SSP added.

Title: ‘Give rural students exposure to science so that they can learn new methods’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kamal Singh, P Siwaswaroop and Pramod Padole at the inauguration ceremony of ‘Salters’ camp’, at VNIT, on Frid... Read More

NAGPUR: Popularization of scientific ideas and activities among students, especially from rural schools, is important as they can learn new methods and get exposure to the modern world, said Kamal Singh, former vice-chancellor of Amravati University, at Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT), on Friday.

She was addressing the opening session of the three-day ‘Salters’ camp’ organized as part of ‘Sankalp’ initiative launched by the department of chemistry of VNIT in association with the regional centre of Indira Gandhi National Open University (Ignou) to mark the diamond jubilee celebrations.

The programme is being conducted by Royal Society of Chemistry (RSC), London, the apex body of inventions and technologies related to chemistry. It’s Indian chapter is situated at Bengaluru.

P Sivaswaroop, director of Ignou, Pramod Padole, director, VNIT, and Saraswati Vidyalaya principal S Prabhuraman were present.

Singh said science plays a major role in life and undertaking such campaigns to give students with rural background a chance to acquire new skills will prove beneficial in the larger interest of the country. About 75 students of Std IX from zilla parishad, NMC and schools from nearby districts explored the scientific world of experiments and learning.

The camp will have exciting activities like practical demonstrations, forensic analysis, fun and health science, physical fitness lectures and campus tour. Students will also get a chance to explore life at VNIT.

Sivaswaroop said, “Science is essence to life and no activity is possible without it. It is necessary for young minds to develop interest in the subject for which participation in such educative camps is essential.”

In his address, Padole spoke about the importance of students taking part in scientific activities in their early years of schooling. He said, “Young students have the capacity to recognize and think out of the box. What they need is proper guidance. Salters’ camp will help them think better.”

Saraswati Vidyalaya principal S Prabhuraman coordinated with government schools to ensure their students participate in the event.

Prabhuraman said, “I am in touch with civic schools and education officials so that students get maximum exposure . It is important for children to be part of such scientific endeavours as it helps to kindle their interest in science.”

Suresh Umare, head of the department of chemistry and coordinator, VNIT, made the introductory remarks.

Vaishali Gujar from Saraswati Vidyalaya conducted the function while Chayan Das proposed a vote of thanks.

Title: Leopards kill two children, injure another in four days in south Gujarat
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Surat: Three children were attacked by leopards at different locations of south Gujarat in the past four days, resulting in death of two of them. The three children of sugarcane farm labourers were attacked by the leopards near their huts in open fields.

Kishan Pintu Vadvi, 5, was declared dead during treatment in a hospital on Saturday afternoon. He was attacked at around 9am in a sugarcane farm near Bharan village of Anleshwar taluka in Bharuch district. The big cat caught the boy and began to drag him when some labourers shouted and chased it. The leopard left the boy and escaped. Vadvi suffered injuries in neck and shoulder. His body was sent for postmortem at Kim Civil Hospital. Vadvi’s family had come from Rapapor village of Nandurbar district in Maharashtra to work in the fields.

On Thursday at around 7pm, Shivani Shankar Mahla, 4, was attacked by a leopard in a sugarcane farm near Patal village of Mandvi taluka in Surat district. The girl was playing near her hut when the leopard attacked her. It was trying to drag her into nearby bushes when her mother returned after fetching water. She chased the leopard which left the child and escaped from the spot. Mahla family was handed over a cheque of Rs4 lakh by the state government as compensation for the girl who died on Saturday. Mahla family had come to work in sugarcane farms with other labourers from Madalbari village of Dang district.

Earlier on Wednesday, Lalsing Keshar Malche, 7, a resident of Navapur in Maharashtra, was attacked by a leopard in a farm near Areth village of Mandvi taluka in Surat district at around 7pm. The leopard tried to bite the child’s head and drag him. Some labourers were successful in chasing away the leopard. Some hair and skin from the child’s head got peeled off. Malche is under treatment at a hospital and his health is stable, forest officials said.

“Seven teams with three forest officials in each team are camping near Bharan village and seven cages have been placed to cage the leopard. We have started the process to pay a compensation of Rs4 lakh to the victim’s family,” said K Shashikumar, chief conservator of forests, Bharuch.

“We have instructed villagers and sugar factories to shift labourers to safer locations near the villages. So far, we have shifted 20 families of labourers to safer locations to prevent attacks on them,” said Puneet Nayyar, deputy conservator of forests, Surat.

No compensation paid to injured boy

Lalsing Keshar Malche, who suffered head injuries when he was attacked by a leopard near Areth village of Mandvi on Wednesday, is yet to receive any compensation from the state government. The boy is under treatment at a hospital. “We are yet to pay compensation to the boy. It will be paid soon,” said Puneet Nayyar, DCF, Surat.

Sugarcane labourers easy target

Sugarcane labourers come from tribal areas of south Gujarat and Maharashtra in the harvest season. They build their huts with plastic sheets and bamboo sticks in the farms. They keep moving from one farm to another and villages in groups until the harvest season lasts. This has been the practice since decades for harvesting of sugarcanes by sugar factories in south Gujarat. “After lion poaching case of 2007 in Saurashtra, Gujarat government had issued a directive making ‘pucca’ shelter mandatory for labourers sleeping in the farm. However, this directive only exists on paper,” experts say.

Patal is just 12km away from Vareli

Patal village of Mandvi taluka in Surat where a four-year-old girl was killed by a leopard is 12km from Vareli village where a leopard was shot dead in 2011 after it turned man-eater. Twelve humans died in 2010-11 in leopard attacks while six leopards were killed during the same period by humans.

Govt officials to discuss leopard attacks on Jan 6

Ahmedabad: Senior officers of forest department and other government departments will discuss leopard attacks in a meeting to be held in Gandhinagar on Monday. Sugarcane farmers and mill owners will also attend the emergency meeting which has been convened after a series of leopard attacks in the districts of south Gujarat.

“We will ensure that labourers coming from other states or other parts of Gujarat get proper shelter. Usually these labourers are made to sleep in the open. This makes them easy prey for the leopards,” said Gujarat minister for forests and environment Ganpat Vasava in Gandhinagar on Saturday. He added that the state government will be setting up one rescue centre each in Surat and Dang to house the captured leopards. So far, 60 leopards have been caged in south Gujarat of whom 25 were involved in attack on humans.

Title: SVNIT student scores 100 percentile in CAT
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Surat: A student of Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology (SVNIT) scored 100 percentile marks in Common Admission Test (CAT) 2019 for admission in Indian Institutes of Management (IIMs), results of which were announced on Saturday. He is believed to be one of the 10 highest scorers in the country.

Rishi Mittal, a fourth-year student of bachelor’s of technology (BTech) course in civil branch, has got 241.45 marks out of 300. Out of two tests, he scored 100 percentiles in data interpretation and logical reasoning and 99.99 in quantitative ability.

Rishi plans to take admission in any of the top IIMs after clearing interview. “I wish to study finance but things will get clear after I get admission,” Rishi told TOI.

Son of IT consultant Satish, Rishi’s family stays in Mumbai. He prepared for CAT 2019 conducted in November while staying in hostel. He appeared in the examination in Mumbai.

Title: Corpn’s multiple-tray aerators to be operational in a month
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Trichy: The trial run of the multiple-tray aerators established by the Trichy Corporation at Srirangam to improve the quality of drinking water was conducted recently and following its success, the facility is going to be inaugurated in a month. Since complaints were raised by residents about the poor quality of the water supply, the civic body opted to install multiple-tray aerators to reduce the high iron content in the drinking water by oxidizing the dissolved metals before supplying to the households.

Two collector wells of the corporation located over the Kollidam river bed have been catering to the drinking water needs of Ponmalai and Ariyamangalam zones. Recently, Ponmalaipatti locals under Ponmalai zone raised complaints about the poor quality and brownish colour of the water supplied through the pipelines. But such complaints did not surface in K Abishekapuram and Srirangam zones. The civic body studying the water quality supplied to Ponmalai had found that high iron content from the collector well I and collector well II on Kollidam river bed was causing water colour to change.

To overcome the trouble, the civic body along with the TWAD board and commissionerate of municipal administration (CMA) opted for the aerator facility for treating the water. Subsequently, in June 2019, the corporation launched the civil work for the multiple-tray aerators at a cost of Rs 1 crore. The aerators established for a diameter of 12 metres is a fountain-like structure, which will bring the water extracted directly in the contact of air, causing the oxidization process that will remove the high iron content in the water.

“90% of the installation work is over and the trial run was satisfactory with the aerators managing to remove the high iron content in the water,” an official source said. The 60 MLD capacity aerators, established between the two collector wells and a major sump to treat the water, were designed by the TWAD board. Though similar aerator facilities were established in Coimbatore, Dindigul and Theni districts, the corporation sources said that aerators are massive in terms of the water capacity.

Title: After onion, tomato price in the red with three-fold hike
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

dsfsffdsf

Bhopal: After onions, it is the turn of tomatoes. Tomato prices are now threatening to derail the household budget. Owing to widespread damage to the crop following prolonged cold wave and hailstorms that have hit Madhya Pradesh, the prices of tomato have gone up threefold from Rs10 to Rs30 per kilogram in the last one week.

Tomato crops have been damaged in most parts of the state as well as the country. The damage is 30% to 90%, depending on the district and the weather condition. Many farmers have started uprooting the plants to prepare the farm for sowing onions or some other vegetables.

For the past many days, the state has been reeling under intense cold wave conditions. The farmers tried to protect their crops by lighting bonfire but in vain, said Mahendra Singh, a big farmer in Shivpuri district.

“ I have not been able to save my crop and the damage has been extensive. Almost 90% of the tomato crop has been damaged. There was hardly any sunlight for days together which damaged the the crop”, he said. A crate carrying 22 kilogram to 25 kilogram of tomato is now being sold at Rs500, he said, adding that the prices are likely to go up further in the upcoming days once the present stock in mandis across the state is exhausted.

Shivpuri is located in Gwalior division and is close to Sheopur district of Chambal division. This region is facing an extremely harsh winter , which is having an adverse impact on tomato crop. In Chhindwara district, farmers have started uprooting the tomato plants. “There has been more than 50% damage to the crop”, said Lakshman Markan, a local farmer. Mahendra Hapad, another farmer in Jhabua, said: “Almost 30% of the crop has been damaged and I have lost all hopes to protect the crop as the weather continues to remain adverse”.

Rajendra Singh, a vegetable wholesaler in Bhopal, said: “Tomato prices are surging and the rise in prices will continue in the coming days too.”

Title: Ballot papers found scattered on road in Perambalur dist
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Trichy: As many as 115 ballot papers used in the recently concluded rural civic body polls were found abandoned in Perambalur district on Saturday. Officials in the district administration maintain that the abandoned ballot papers were counted on January 2.

Perambalur district has four blocks with 8 district councillors and 76 union councillors. Perambalur went to polls in two phases each on December 27 and 30. The votes were counted on January 2 and results declared the next day.

The pink ballot papers were noticed by locals of Odhiyam village on Saturday morning along the road connecting Sithali with their village. The ballot papers had the sealed of both the voters and election officials on duty at Pudhuvettakudi panchayat.

On information, Kunnam taluk officials rushed to the spot and recovered the 115 abandoned ballot papers that are found belonging to voters from 125 and 127 parts of the electoral roll Pudhuvettakudi panchayat.

Revenue department officials inquiring the incident said that the ballot papers were counted before the results of the panchayat was declared. “The block development officers (BDOs) are investigating the incident. We are yet to ascertain how the 115 ballot papers alone landed on the road,” an official with Perambalur district administration said.

Title: Various events to mark oriental meet
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Nagpur: A three-day All India Oriental Conference (AIOC) has been organized by Kavikulguru Kalidas Sanskrit University at Suresh Bhat Sabhagruh from January 10 in which a variety of programmes will be held.

The event will kick-start with ‘Saraswat Yatra’, to be taken out at 3pm from Reshimbagh to Krida Chowk, on January 9. The inaugural ceremony will be held at 10am on January 10.

Various institutions from India and Asian countries will present cultural programmes like Bharatanatyam, dance dramas like ‘Maharashtra Darshan’ and others, yoga practical, ‘Striyashcharitam’ a Sanskrit drama and ‘Andhra Natyam’ on January 10 and 11. Tentative time of the programmes is 10am.

Other programmes include national ‘kavi sammelan’, research paper and green team presentations, and national ‘shastrarth parishad’. Special lectures, publication of 100 books in English, Hindi, Marathi and Sanskrit, will be held.

Book exhibition at Reshimbagh ground will be the major attraction. Renowned publishers of the country will put on exhibition and sale rare books on Sanskrit, linguistics, fine arts and translated literature from other languages and guides. Books on competitive examinations, guides for NET-SET and Marathi, Hindi and English literature will also be available.

Dipak Kapade, librarian, KKSU, said, “This is a platform to promote Indian culture and it is a proud moment to see nearby countries taking part in the events.”

Title: 15 protesters still in jail, serious charges on three
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Varanasi: Fifteen anti-CAA protesters are still in jail . Of these, Manish Sharma, Anoop Shramik and SP Rai, are facing serious charges and police plans to take them on remand for questioning.

Altogether 59 persons were arrested, of which 56 were granted bail on January 1. While 44 were released from the District jail by Friday, papers of others are being verified to ensure their release.

Among other sections, the trio has been booked under sections 153 (wantonly giving provocation with intent to cause riot), 153 B (imputations, assertions prejudicial to national integration) and 506 (criminal intimidation) of IPC. They were arrested for distributing pamphlets in Lanka area on December 18, calling upon people to gather at Beniabagh on December 19 in protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and the National Register of Citizens (NRC). The Lanka police said it was trying to take them on remand for interrogation, as they have allegedly been identified for using the phone numbers listed on the pamphlet. “Investigations are in progress to identify more persons involved in it,” Lanka Inspector Bharat Bhushan Tiwari told TOI on Saturday.

The three, along with several others were arrested on December 19 and 20 while taking part in a protest in Beniabagh and Bajardiha. All were booked under sections 147 (rioting), 148 (rioting, armed with deadly weapon), 149 (unlawful assembly), 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), 332 (causes hurt to a public servant), 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty), 341 (wrongful restraint) of IPC and 7 CLA Act.

On January 1, the court of additional sessions judge SK Pandey had granted bail to 56 jailed persons and ordered their release on the submission of two bonds of Rs. 25,000 each.

As many as 15 persons were released on Thursday, while 39 were released on Friday.

Other than the trio, 12 other persons are still in the jail due to shortcomings in legal formalities or involvement in other cases. Defence lawyer Anil Kumar Singh said there are some errors in the release order of the nine persons and are being rectified after verification.

Title: Immovable property of RJD MLA to be attached
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

ARA: First additional district and sessions judge-cum-special judge for POCSO cases R K Singh on Friday ordered attachment of immovable property of RJD ’s Sandesh MLA Arun Kumar Yadav.

Arun, accused in a case related to sexual exploitation of a minor girl, is on the run. Special public prosecutor for POCSO cases Saroj Kumari said the court has asked the Bhojpur DM and the SP to attach the immovable property of the accused MLA.

Earlier on September 13, the court had issued a non-bailable arrest warrant against the MLA. As he did not surrender, the police seized the MLA’s movable property at his village, Lasadhi, on September 22.

Police have already arrested four accused in the case and filed chargesheet against them. The Sandesh MLA, however, is still at large.

Police sources said the minor girl was thrown into sex racket in Patna by a woman, Anita Devi, who lured her on the pretext of providing education and employment. Anita has already been arrested by the police.

Anita, who is currently lodged in Ara jail along with three other accused, allegedly acted as an agent for the mastermind of the sex racket, whose nickname was ‘jija’, a resident of Patna. Police sources said Anita had thrown many girls into sex racket. The girls were used to be sent to Patna, Uttar Pradesh and other places.

Police sources said Anita and her accomplice, who is also lodged in Ara jail, had chased the minor girl up to her house on July 18. The girl had reached her home from Patna after escaping from her tormentors. Police had arrested Anita and her accomplice on the same day when the family members and the neighbours of the girl raised an alarm.

Title: Row over share of booty led to undertrial’s murder, say cops
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

PATNA: The daylight murder of an undertrial prisoner in the Hajipur district jail on Friday could have provided a good ‘masala (plot)’ for a Hindi blockbuster movie. Under a well-hatched conspiracy, a local ‘goonda’ was hired by a professional criminal, facilitated to go inside the prison on charges of committing a petty offence and finally the ‘target’ was hit with a 9mm pistol from a point blank range, leading to his instant death.

After unsuccessful bid on the life of a 30-year-old undertrial prisoner Manish Kumar alias Teliya earlier in May last year, the alleged mastermind behind the first-of-its-kind murder inside the four walls of the prison, Anu Singh (26), also an accused in the infamous 2017-gold loot case in Rajasthan’s Jaipur, changed his strategy to eliminate a member of the interstate gang led by one Subodh Singh of which he also once happened to be a part.

Anu, a resident of Rambhadra Nagar locality under the Hajipur town police station in Vaishali district, was unhappy with the deceased, Manish Kumar, for allegedly siphoning off a lion’s share in the loot of around 90kg of gold from two different places at Jaipur in Rajasthan, Asansol and Barrackpore in West Bengal and Nagpur in Maharashtra in the last couple of years.

Anu had promised Rs 10 lakh to the shooter, Raja Babu, a resident of Tisiauta in Vaishali district, for killing Manish inside the jail on Friday. During interrogation, Raja said the weapon, which was used in the killing of the undertrial prisoner, was provided to him by Anu. Raja was sent to jail on charges of plotting robbery under Garaul police station area of the district on November 2 last year.

“Anu was keeping a close eye on Manish ever since the latter survived the murderous attack on him on the Hajipur civil court premises in May last year,” Raja told the interrogators.

According to Hajipur sub-divisional police officer (SDPO) Raghav Dayal, Anu also had grudge against Manish for ‘leaking’ information to the senior officers of the special task force (STF), which led to the killing of three of the gang members in an encounter near Hasanpur diara under the Mahnar police station area in Vaishali district in March last year.

Those killed in the police encounter were identified as Manish Singh alias Ranveer, a resident of Raghopur (Vaishali), Md Abdul Imran alias Raj Kumar, a native of Muzaffarpur and Md Abdul Aman alias Tiwari from Samastipur. An AK-47 assault rifle, a Bareta pistol, a revolver and live cartridges were seized from the encounter site.

Police investigations revealed that nine people have so far been killed in Vaishali district alone due to differences over distribution of share among the members of interstate gang in the loot of about 90kg of gold from Rajasthan, West Bengal and Maharashtra since 2016.

Police sources said a noted marble dealer, Sushil Kumar Singh (45), was shot dead in front of his shop near Paswan Chowk under the Hajipur Industrial police station on March 15 last year. A close relative of a mukhiya Mukesh Singh was also killed recently. The third murder took place in Bengaluru. “All the three were killed allegedly by the goons of Anu Singh for duping the latter of money which they had promised to give him after selling the gold earlier looted from different parts of the country,” a senior police officer said on the condition of anonymity.

During interrogation, Anu confessed to the crime and disclosed that five-six more people were on his hit list for duping him of money. A fresh case has been lodged with the Hajipur sadar police station against Anu and his accomplish Raja in connection with Friday’s prisoner murder case.

Manish, a resident of Teliya village under Rajapakar police station in Vaishali district, was arrested by the Bidupur police in a case lodged under various sections of Arms Act and Excise and Prohibition Act on February 5, 2019.

SHO of Hajipur sadar police station Rohan Kumar said, “In May last year, Manish had survived a murderous attack when he was taken to the local civil court for appearance in a case. Two police personnel had suffered serious injuries in the firing then. The name of Anu had also figured in the attempt to murder case.”

Anu was brought to Hajipur from Rajasthan’s Jaipur for his appearance in a case last year. However, the mastermind of the gold loot cases outside the state, Binod Singh, and a few other members of the gang are still lodged in the Jaipur jail, police sources said.

Jailer among five cops suspended: Five police personnel, including Hajipur jailer Yunush, have been put under suspension for dereliction of duty. IG (prison) Mithilesh Mishra said a probe is underway to ascertain how the illegal weapon got inside the Hajipur district jail to eliminate an undertrial prisoner. “A special team has been set up to look into the matter,” Mishra added.

Title: Man kills wife and two kids in Sitamarhi, held
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

SITAMARHI/PATNA: One Kamlesh Chaudhary (38) was arrested while trying to flee after killing his wife and two children at Bajpatti Got village under the Bajpatti police station area in Sitamarhi district on Saturday.

The deceased were identified as Shila Devi (36), Praveen Kumar (6) and six-month-old Manju. SHO of Bajpatti police station Ajay Kumar Mishra said the other two kids of Kamlesh, who were also in the room at the time of the incident, had a narrow escape.

According to police sources, Kamlesh would often fight with his wife and other family members. The incident came to light around 6am on Saturday when Kamlesh tried to escape from home when his family members confronted him.

Sitamarhi SP Anil Kumar said Kamlesh killed his wife, son and daughter between 12am and 1am after a fight with his wife. “He used a sharp weapon to kill his wife and kids when they were asleep. First he stabbed his wife to death and then slit the throat of one of his sons, Praveen, when he tried to raise an alarm. Kamlesh also strangled his six-month-old daughter,” the SP added.

“Kamlesh has no medical history. Prima facie, it appears the incident was the result of a family dispute. According to family members, Kamlesh is of violent nature who would often beat his wife and others in the family,” the SP said.

Police have recovered the weapon used in the crime. A forensic science laboratory team Muzaffarpur has collected samples from the pot for investigation.

“Kamlesh’s another son Naveen Kumar (10) and daughter Sapna (11) were also in the room when the incident occurred. They are in shock after the incident,” the SHO said.

He added that Kamlesh had warned them not to make noise or else he would kill them too. “Around 6am when Kamlesh’s brother tried to wake him up, there was no noise from inside the room. The family members broke open the window and were shocked to find bodies of Shila and her two kids. Kamlesh tried to escape when his brother raised alarm. However, the villagers caught hold of him. He was later handed over to police,” the SHO said.

Title: Bihar special assembly session on January 13
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar
