PATNA: A special session of the Bihar legislative assembly will be convened on January 13 to ratify the Constitution (One Hundred and Twenty-Sixth Amendment) Bill that proposes to extend reservation for SC/ST in the Lok Sabha and state assemblies by another 10 years, Speaker Vijay Kumar Choudhary said here on Saturday.

“The Constitution (126th Amendment) Bill was passed by the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha on December 10 and 12, respectively, last year. The provisions under the Bill will be effective from January 25, 2020. As per Article-168 of the Constitution, the Bill must be ratified by at least 50% of the state assemblies before its implementation. In this context, the assembly secretariat has received a formal request from CM Nitish Kumar . Hence, a special session of the assembly has been called on January 13,” the Speaker said.

The Indian Constitution provides for reservation of seats for scheduled castes (SCs) and scheduled tribes (STs) and representation of the Anglo-Indian community by nomination, in the Lok Sabha and legislative assemblies of certain states. This has been provided for a period of 70 years since the enactment of the Constitution and will expire on January 25, 2020. The Bill seeks to extend the reservation for SCs and STs by another 10 years till January 25, 2030.

“During the special session, the members of the House will hold discussion on a state government’s proposal to ratify the Bill,” Choudhary said.

Title: Vandals desecrate Mahatma Gandhi statue in Lathi town
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Locals protesting against the desecration of Gandhiji’s statue at Lathi on Saturday

RAJKOT: Mischief mongers in Lathi town in Amreli district allegedly desecrated a statue of Mahatma Gandhi on Friday night.

Bapu’s statue was one among the many statues erected by Dholakia foundation at the Hari Krishna lake. After knowing about the vandalism, the administer of the foundation made a representation to the police urging it to increase vigil and arrest the antisocial elements.

The vandalism also irked the farmers and traders of the locality. The caretaker of the garden, Kanu Patel told TOI: “The antisocial elements broke the statue into 13 pieces. This is not the first time. A few months ago too miscreants damaged the statue of former president Dr Abdul Kalam. They also uprooted nearly 100 plants. We are tired of these vandals and want police to take strong action against them.”

This garden has been developed by Surat diamantaire Savji Dholakia in 600 bigha land. Dholakia hails from Dudhala village located 2km away from Lathi. Dholakia foundation has been managing the public garden which has no entry gate. Even the forest department celebrated the Van Mahotsav here. Plantation of tress have been done on 300 bigha land, while the remaining land has statues of various gods and goddesses along with eminent personalities.

The foundation has accused the police of not taking the issue of repeated vandalism seriously. Talking to media persons, sub inspector of Lathi police station, V P Gohil said, “We will soon nab the perpetrators and increase patrolling in nearby areas.”

Title: Patna: March deadline for AIIMS-Digha highway
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The first 2km of the road starting from AIIMS-Patna is a two-lane semi-elevated road, the remaining stretch is... Read More

PATNA: Vehicular movement on the much-awaited Digha-AIIMS elevated highway is likely to begin from March this year. One lane of the 11.9km road will, however, become operational from February, said Sanjay Kumar Agarwal, managing director of Bihar State Road Development Corporation Limited (BSRDCL), the executing agency of the project.

While the first 2km of the road starting from AIIMS-Patna is a two-lane semi-elevated road, the remaining stretch is elevated four-lane road.

The road, which will connect J P Setu in Digha, will not just reduce travelling time but also act as connectivity for people going to Sonepur from Phulwarisharif or AIIMS in southern parts of the city.

“After the construction of the elevated road, vehicles coming from north Bihar will have a hassle-free journey,” a BSRDCL official said.

The ambitious project, which entails an expenditure of Rs 1,231.06 crore, was initially targeted to be completed by March 2018. Chief minister Nitish Kumar had launched the project in November 2013. A BSRDCL official said the delay was due to financial problems faced by the agency responsible for the construction of Digha-AIIMS elevated road.

Sanjay Kumar, chief general manager of BSRDCL said more than 97% of the construction work was complete. “The remaining 3% work will be completed as soon as Gammon India, the firm responsible for construction work, resolves its financial issues. The process will not take more than two months,” he said.

Meanwhile, BSRDCL officials also said that construction of a railway overbridge (ROB) at Khagaul was another cause for the delay. “We have got the no-objection certificate from the railways for the construction of ROB on the eastern side of existing ROB at Khagaul. Train movement on the tracks may be affected during the construction period,” said BSRDCL MD Agarwal.

Meanwhile, a 12.27km-long two-lane road has been constructed underneath the Digha-AIIMS elevated road along the Digha-Danapur canal. The road serves as connectivity for people coming from Phulwarisharif or AIIMS and going to Digha.

Title: Kolkata: Musa attacks jail warder with pipe, gets solitary confinement
Content:
Mohammad Masiuddin alias Musa

KOLKATA: A little more than two years after he attacked a warden of Alipore central jail and slashed his throat, Mohammad Masiuddin alias Musa — who was earlier questioned by FBI for his alleged links with the Islamic State (IS) and who remains one of the top security threats in Kolkata — carried out a similar attack on the head warder of Presidency Correctional Home on Saturday morning. He later claimed all his actions so far have been “pious”.Police said Musa, from Birbhum’s Labhpur, assaulted Amal Karmakar around 11am inside the high-security cell 7. “Musa attacked Karmakar with a PVC pipe that was fitted to the outlet of a basin inside cell 7. The on-duty head warder sustained severe head injuries and had to be treated at the jail hospital. He was later discharged. Doctors, however, have asked him to be admitted to a government facility and remain under observation for some time,” a jail official said. He added that at the time of the attack, Musa was scheduled to be taken out for a morning walk.“On the basis of letter of complaint by Suprakash Roy, the superintendent of Presidency correctional home, a specific case under IPC sections 332 (voluntarily causing hurt to deter public servant from his duty) and 324 (severe hurt) was registered against Musa. He has two cases — an attempt to murder a warden in 2017 and an NIA case pertaining to terror activities — lodged against him. The cases are on trial or are pending before the additional district and sessions judge’s court in Alipore and the chief judge city sessions court respectively,” said DC (South) Meeraj Khalid.The security personnel at the central lock up are now taking no chances even though Musa has been put in solitary confinement. “He is being monitored every minute and the guards have been briefed accordingly,” a source said.Musa is usually brought to any local court in a “convoy” with two to three police vehicles shadowing the police van amidst tight security comprising Kolkata Police commandos. “After Pulwama and the fast-changing geo-politics in Kashmir, we don’t wish to take any chances till our proposals are accepted,” said a jail department official.In July 2016, CID arrested Musa with help from GRP at Burdwan station while he was travelling in the Howrah-Viswabharati Fast Passenger train. Cops had also seized a firearm and a knife from him.After CID took over the case, investigators found that Musa was planning to kill people in Birbhum. He confessed that he was in touch with some of the IS handlers since 2014 through various chat platforms, networking sites and apps. Gradually, he had recruited a few members in India and became their handler.In its final charge sheet, NIA said Musa and his aides had planned to send signals about the presence of IS in India. They had also identified locations, like Mother House in Kolkata, to target foreign tourists. During interrogation, Musa never showed any remorse or repentance.

Title: Delhi model urinal complex near Central bus stand a damp squib
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Trichy: A model urinal complex set up by Trichy corporation behind the Central bus stand here has been remaining inaccessible to the public despite it being much touted as emulating a success story in the national capital. The result: passengers arriving at the bus stand continue to urinate along the compound walls of the two-wheeler parking lot.

“Most of the time, the urinal either remains locked or unmaintained. This forces the passengers to pee along the bus stand’s compound wall,” S Sivakumar, a TNSTC employee said. It was in January 2018 that the corporation installed the compact urinal model for men at the rear entrance of the congested bus stand on VOC road which was in an unhygienic condition because of rampant urination by passengers. Set up at an estimated cost of Rs 5 lakh with the urinal cabin furnished with LED lights and exhaust fans, it was based on a similar one in New Delhi. Unlike the other partially covered urinals for men in the bus stand locality, the model urinals offer privacy as it is completely covered.

The corporation also allowed private companies to display their advertisements atop and on the sides of the urinal and used the revenue to maintain the complex, a first-of-its-kind expenditure model in the city. However, two years down the lane, poor maintenance of the facility and lack of sensitisation among the passengers have rendered the project useless.

Locals of ward 45 falling under K Abishekapuram zone rue that open urination has returned to VOC road after a brief period because of this situation. Though it was meant to be expanded to the other three zones of the civic body, the poor maintenance of the facility has failed to gain public support. “The urinal complex requires maintenance and efforts are under way to make the public facility operational again,” an official source with Trichy corporation told TOI.

Title: State IAS officers’ body waits for a chief
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bhopal: The Madhya Pradesh IAS Officers’ Association is functioning without a president after the resignation of additional chief secretary Gauri Singh.

Singh’s application for voluntary retirement was accepted by the state government on Monday. Office-bearers of the association will now have to elect or nominate a new president, but when this will happen is unclear. Office-bearers of the association declined to say anything on the issue.

The IAS service meet is likely this month. If the association doesn’t get a president by then, it would be probably the first time that the meet will take place with anyone at the helm. Bureaucrats from the entire state attend the meet, which is generally opened by the chief minister.

The Madhya Pradesh IAS Association was in the news thrice last year. In April, it complained against former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan to the Election Commission for allegedly threatening the Chhindwara collector after Chouhan’s chopper was denied permission to land after 5pm. In October, it wrote to the chief secretary to express strong resentment against investigating agencies going to the press “without completing investigation”. The trigger for the complaint was believed to be media reports of EOW investigating complaints of alleged corruption in Smart City tenders worth Rs 300 crore, and an IAS officer being named in some reports. And in November 2019, an RTI reply revealed that the MP government had asked the association to pay over Rs 34 lakh in rent dues for its two premises at a posh colony in Bhopal, or face eviction.

Title: Pondy bypoll: Cops register case against MLA Johnkumar
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Puducherry: Police registered a case against Congress MLA A Johnkumar on Friday on charges of suppressing information on his assets in an affidavit submitted by him while filing nomination papers to contest the Kamaraj Nagar bypoll in October last year.

The Odiansalai police booked Johnkumar under Section 125-A (penalty for filing false affidavit) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951. The police action came after chief judicial magistrate V Damodaran directed them to register a case against Johnkumar and launch investigations on December 5 following a petition filed by S Selvamuthurayan.

Johnkumar’s efforts to get the order of the chief judicial magistrate set aside failed as second additional sessions’ judge M Suba Anbumani dismissed his revision petition on December 20. The judge dismissed the petition pointing out that the CJM’s direction is an ‘interlocutory order’ and ‘no revision can be preferred against the interlocutory order’.

Selvamuthurayan in his petition contended that Johnkumar, while filing the affidavit, suppressed details about a 2.4-hectare land bought by him in June 2017. He said Johnkumar started selling the property after converting it into 353 plots and that Johnkumar purposely suppressed information about the property presently valued at more than Rs 4.5 crore in the affidavit.

Selvamuthurayan regretted that the election and police departments failed to initiate any action on their written complaints against Johnkumar in October last. He said he was left with no option but to approach the court requesting a direction to police to register a case against the MLA.

Johnkumar claimed that it was unnecessary to mention the property in question in the affidavit he filed on September 30 last year since he had executed a settlement deed of the property in favour of his daughter on August 15, 2019. He further said the deed has been pending for registration before the Thirukanur sub-registrar since then.

If convicted the MLA can be punished with imprisonment for a term, which may extend to six months, or a fine, or with both.

Johnkumar was elected on a Congress ticket in 2016 from Nellithope. He resigned to enable V Narayanasamy, who did not contest the polls but was elected as the Congress legislature party leader, to contest elections and become chief minister.

He was rewarded for giving up his seat and was nominated as the Congress candidate for the Kamaraj Nagar by-poll in 2019 when the seat became vacant after V Vaithilingam resigned and successfully contested the 2019 Lok Sabha polls. He secured 14,782 votes and defeated All India NR Congress (AINRC) candidate Bouvanesvarane by 7,170 votes.

Title: Traffic diversion for Vaikunta Ekadesi fest
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Trichy: On account of Vaikunta Ekadesi festival at Sri Ranganathaswamy temple in Srirangam in Trichy on January 6, Trichy city police has issued a detailed traffic diversion plan in the city for January 5 and 6. The traffic diversion will come into effect from 8 pm on January 5 and will continue till 8 pm on January 6.

The buses plying from Chathiram bus station to Srirangam will go via Anna Statue, Mambala Salai, Thiruvanaikovil junction, Check Post no. 6, Panjakarai Road, Ambedkar Nagar, Singaperumal Kovil bus stop, Nelson Road, Gandhi Road to reach Srirangam bus stand and in return the buses will go via Amma Mandapam, Mambala Salai, Anna Statue to reach Chathiram bus stand.

Buses plying through Lalgudi and Mannachanallur route will have to take a diversion from Anna Statue, Mambalasalai, Thiruvanaikovil junction, Check Post no. 6 to reach Kollidam bridge. In return direction, the buses will come via Kollidam bridge, Ambedkar Nagar, Singaperumal Kovil bus stop, Nelson Road, Gandhi Road, Srirangam bus stand, Amma Mandapam, Mambala Salai, Anna Statue to reach Chathiram bus stand.

Buses plying in Perambalur, Ariyalur, Thuraiyur and Cuddalore area will be diverted from Anna Statue to Y Road. The buses will return via Kollidam bridge, Odathurai road to reach Chathiram bus stand. VIPs should park their vehicles at Anna Statue, Mambala Salai, Ammamandapam Road, Ragavendra Arch, Thiruvallur Street, West Chithrai Street. The parking facilities for the vehicle with pass have been allotted at Panjakarai Road, North Mottai Gopuram, North Chithirai Street.

Traffic diversion is applicable for the vehicles of devotees from Karur, Madurai, Pudukottai, Thanjavur, Chennai, Salem and Ariyalur. The diversion will be at check post number 7 for Karur. Palpannai for Madurai, Pudukottai and Thanjavur. And Y road junction for Chennai, Salem and Ariyalur buses. The police also appealed to the senior citizens and differently-abled people to take the route from Thiruvanaikovil junction, , Devi theatre back side. TNN

Title: First smart toilet nears completion
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Trichy: The city corporation is busy constructing the city’s first smart toilet through a Chennai-based firm as part of efforts to eliminate open urination along Allithurai Road adjacent to Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Government Medical College Hospital (MGMGH). Utilising Internet of Things (IoT) technology, the pay and use toilet facilitates automatic cleaning every 30 minutes.

Corporation sources said that the smart toilet is being established at a cost of Rs 10 lakh. The entire sanitary complex spread over less than 100 square feet is a single slot solid concrete mould, thus making the assembling process swift compared to the conventional reinforced cement concrete construction work. The building can endure all types of weather for at least 50 years and is furnished with LED lights, CCTV cameras and sensors for automatic cleaning. While three urinals and one toilet complex for men are painted blue, the toilet complex for women which is equipped with incinerator and sanitary napkin vending machine is painted pink.

“Once every 30 minutes, there will be a voice announcement about the automatic flushing and cleaning process,” a representative of the firm executing the project said. The toilet is touted to prevent vandalism. If any disruption is made to the facility, the sensors will alert the officials in-charge through IoT devices. Subsequently, the CCTV cameras at the entrance of the complex will capture 20 photographs at a time to identify the accused.

“The pressure pump atop the sanitary complex will enable flushing and cleaning to the required extent for encouraging people to use the facility,” official sources added. Using the urinals is likely to be made free but not the toilets. Sanitary napkin vending machine will provide a napkin for every Rs 5 deposited. Trichy corporation plans to open the sanitary complex in a week. “Such projects should be welcomed but their maintenance and sustainability should be ensured. It should not head the same way as that of the poorly maintained model urinal on VOC road,” S Harish, a resident of Thiruvanaikoil added.

Title: Scores of Sikhs in city protest against Pakistan for attack on Nankana Sahib
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Members of Sikh community protest against attack on Pakistan’s Nankana Sahib Gurudwara and Sikh devotees

Varanasi: Scores of people from the Sikh community staged a massive protest at Gurubagh Gurudwara on Saturday against the attack on Pakistan’s Nankana Sahib Gurudwara and the Sikh devotees on Friday.

Gurdwara Nankana Sahib, also known as Gurdwara Janam Asthan, is the located near Lahore in Pakistan where the first Guru of the Sikhs- Guru Nanak, was born.

In a large gathering at Gurubagh Gurudwara, the protesters raised slogans against Pakistan and its Prime Minister Imran Khan and condemned the attack on Nankana Sahib by a violent mob.

After offering prayers at the Gurudwara, the demonstrators including their leader Ajit Singh Bagga said, “We prayed that Imran Khan be bestowed with good sense so that he takes proper action against those involved and ensures safety of Sikhs in Pakistan.” They also asserted that Prime Minister Imran Khan must apologise for failing to prevent the attack.

They said the target on the Sikh community was unfortunate was unfortunate and demanded the intervention of Prime Minister Narendra Modi to ensure safety of Sikhs in Pakistan.

Title: Pondy pollution panel warns units operating without consent
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Puducherry: Puducherry pollution control committee (PPCC) has warned of strict action against industrial and other units, including hotels and automobile servicing and wastewater stations, operating without valid consent from the committee under the Waste (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974, and Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981.

The committee warned that it will initiate appropriate legal action against the units that fail to comply with the legislation. The action may lead to prosecution and closure of the units besides disconnection of electricity, water supply and other essential services to the units.

PPCC member secretary, in a notice on January 3, directed all entrepreneurs of hotels, lodges, restaurants, dhabas, banquet halls, banquet premises, marriage halls, automobile service stations, workshops and other industrial units operating without the committee’s permission to apply for consent to operate under the relevant legislation within 15 days.

The member secretary said it has come to the notice of the committee that several units have been operating without complying with environmental norms and standards causing environmental pollution.

Title: 10 civic bodies to be fined for not submitting CZMP
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Goa has been struggling to prepare its draft CZMP and has asked the central government for some relaxations in... Read More

PANAJI: The state environment director Johnson Fernandes has asked the director for panchayats to withhold salaries of officials of nine panchayats for failing to submit their draft Coastal Zone Management Plans ( CZMP ) within the prescribed deadline .

Fernandes said that despite being given extended time up to December 31, 2019, the panchayats have not submitted their plans. Cuncolim Municipal Council (CMC) has also not submitted its CZMP, which has been brought to the attention of the directorate of municipal administration for similar action.

Fernandes’ orders state that salaries of secretary and sarpanch should be withheld for non-compliance in the case of village panchayats of Xeldem, Raia, Sanvordem, Verem, Betki, Uccassaim, Colvale, Sircaim and Bastora. In the case of the CMC, its chief officer and chairperson will be penalised.

“A compliance report on the action taken may be submitted to the office of principal secretary environment,” Fernandes told directors for panchayats and municipal administration.

Goa has been struggling to prepare its draft CZMP and has asked the central government for some relaxations in CRZ norms given the state’s unique ecosystems. It is still waiting to hear from the Centre in this matter.

The state has, in the meantime, asked and received an extension up to January 31, from the National Green Tribunal to submit its draft CZMP.

Based on this extension, the deadline for local bodies to prepare their respective CZMPs was extended from December 20, 2019, to December 31, 2019.

“As per the approval of the government, directives were issued in terms of Section 5 of the Environment Protection Act, 1986, to all local bodies to prepare their own CZMPs for onward submission to the National Centre for Sustainable Coastal Management, Chennai, so as to assess the suggestions and objections and prepare the draft CZMP for the state,” Fernandes told directors of panchayat and municipal administration.

Title: Invite Fomento for talks in 1 week: Court
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

MARGAO: The South Goa district and sessions court, Margao, on Saturday, directed the Margao Municipal Council (MMC) to invite Fomento for reconciliation talks in the Sonsoddo matter, if it so intends, within a week.

Fomento is the concessionaire of MMC’s garbage treatment plant (GTP) at Sonsoddo.

If both parties fail to come to the negotiating table to settle the arbitration amount pertaining to termination of the concession agreement, the matter will be heard for final arguments on January 21 by the court.

The prevailing arrangement at Sonsoddo, including that of payment of Rs 1 lakh per day by MMC to Fomento for processing the waste, would continue until further orders, the court said.

MMC’s contention is that the agreement mandates the civic body to cart away only the “excluded waste” while the inerts (post processed residue of nearly 15% of the waste) should go into the sanitary landfill . Fomento has maintained that 900 tonne of rejects lying at the plant is “excluded waste” and should be carted away by the MMC.

The Goa State Pollution Control Board, which was directed by the court to analyse samples of the waste piled up in the GTP at Sonsoddo, is yet to submit its report. The analysis will determine whether the waste constitutes “excluded waste” or “inerts” as defined in the concession agreement between Fomento and MMC. Fomento has submitted the analysis report by a private laboratory.

Title: Delhi: Why traders don’t want to shift from Walled City to these two market hubs
Content: NEW DELHI: A rusted board proclaims that the deserted and broken road leads to Delhi Development Authority’s chemical market in Narela . Inside the 72-acre market complex, single-storey buildings under various stages of construction dot the area, while many structures already built are firmly shut.Conceptualised in 1980, the market is a part of DDA ’s Integrated Freight Corridor (IFC). Divided into two parts, it was created to accommodate chemical traders operating from Tilak Bazaar in Khari Baoli of the Walled City . Apart from the chemical traders, merchants dealing in spices, dry fruits, electrical goods, automobile parts, etc, were also expected to shift to the IFC. The traders, however, are not keen on moving in anytime soon.“The space in Narela is huge compared with the Walled City, but traders are not keen to come here. I have constructed a shop-cum-godown, but I cannot operate from here alone,” said a trader . “The shops came up in the last one year. Power connection and streetlights were provided four months ago. While sewer connections are being provided, there is no water supply,” he added.DDA started allotting the plots to chemical traders in 2001. While 650 plots have been allotted, construction of shop-cum-godowns started just a year ago. Traders had to shut their shops in the Walled City from January 1, 2019, following Delhi high court’s orders.Though most structures are ready or nearing completion, traders said they would not shift till DDA provided the necessary infrastructure.“There are no water and sewer connection. The biggest issue is the lack of security. The area is desolate and you can’t stay here after dark,” said Pradeep Gupta, president, Chemical Merchants Association (CMA). The lack of security is evident from the huge trenches in the vacant plots where soil has been dug up and stolen.Sushil Goel, a CMA member, said DDA created the infrastructure, like roads, in 1996 and it needed to be refurbished. “The 50 square metre plots are not sufficient for storing chemicals. DDA was to auction 200 square metre warehouses, but it hasn’t done so till date,” Goel said.Gupta added that DDA had only allowed single-storey structures, which were not sufficient to build an office and storage facility.“We have arranged for water from Delhi Jal Board and just need to put in place the distribution system,” DDA vice-chairman Tarun Kapoor told TOI. “Pipelines had been laid, but due to erratic construction they got damaged. We will now lay the pipelines again where construction is complete. Water is needed for these shops to get fire clearance,” he added.In another part of the city, Ghazipur IFC, where paper traders from Chawri Bazaar were supposed to shift, is partially operational. Compared with the comparatively smaller shops-cum-godowns in Narela, the two-storeyed buildings constructed by paper traders are imposing. However, even here only half the buildings are open for business.Anil Gupta, secretary of Ghazipur Welfare Association and a member of Paper Merchants Association, tried to set an example by moving in, but now regrets the decision.“I had installed two air-conditioners at a height of 17 feet. Some people came here and beat up the guard and stole the ACs. Security here is a huge concern. The vast area is open from all sides and many streetlights are non-functional,” he said.“People often break into the buildings and steal whatever they can. Also, the stench from the Ghazipur landfill is unbearable,” said Sarvnath Singh, the caretaker of a building.Another trader alleged that goons from nearby areas came every 2-3 months to extort from them.Navin Jain, another trader, said that the market’s location was convenient, but the 400 plots allotted by DDA since 2006 were not enough to accommodate all paper traders of Chawri Bazaar.

Title: Trichy: 3 arrested for cheating job aspirant of Rs 1 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The city police arrested three people including two women on charges of cheating a job aspirant of Rs 1 lakh on the false assurance of getting a job in Singapore, here on Friday.

The airport police arrested S Ramasamy, 52, from Karaikudi in Sivaganga district, his wife R Latha alias Latha Meenakshi, 42, and K Tamil Kodi, 38, from Wireless road, on Friday for cheating G Sathishkumar, 23 of Kamaraj Nagar near airport.

Tamil Kodi had introduced Sathishkumar to Ramasamy and his wife in October 2018. Sathishkumar was an employee at an outsourcing agency at Trichy international airport. Tamil Kodi offered Sathishkumar a job at Ramsamy’s restaurant in Singapore. In his complaint, Sathishkumar alleged that Ramasamy assured to take him to Singapore for employment in his restaurant. He also gave his passport to Ramasamy and deposited Rs 1 lakh in Ramasamy’s account between October and November 2018 in three instalments.

The trio also enacted a drama as if they were processing for his job abroad by taking him to a private hospital in Trichy for his health check-up as a prerequisite for visa process. As there was no response from the trio about the job even after days, Sathishkumar demanded his money back. Although Ramasamy assured to return his money in June 2019, it was not fulfilled.

Sathishkumar alleged that he realised he was taken for a ride when he came to know three colleagues in his company had also paid money to Ramasamy through Tamil Kodi for a job, but were also cheated. The police arrested the three and they were remanded them in judicial custody.

Title: BHU biased in interview for assistant professor, say Hindi-speaking aspirants
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

A group of students, led by research scholar Mrityunjay Tiwari, held a demonstration on Saturday on the campus... Read More

VARANASI: Close on the heels of a controversy over the appointment of a Muslim professor at BHU ’s Sanskrit Vidya Dharm Vigyan faculty, aspirants appearing for interview to the posts of assistant professor at Ancient Indian History department on Saturday alleged bias against Hindi-speaking candidates.

Interviews were held on Friday for one post of assistant professor each in general, SC and OBC categories at the department of Ancient Indian History, Culture & Archaeology.

A group of students, led by research scholar Mrityunjay Tiwari, held a demonstration on Saturday on the campus and submitted a memorandum to the registrar claiming that Hindi-speaking candidates were discouraged to take part in the interview.

Candidates alleged that Hindi-speaking candidates were not properly interviewed by the panel and were asked to leave within 2-3 minutes with the “advice” to learn English too.

According to recommendation sheet of BHU’s recruitment and assessment cell, 27 candidates out of 112 were shortlisted for interview in unreserved category, 14 out of 48 in SC category, and 11 out of 51 were shortlisted in OBC category.

BHU spokesperson Rajesh Singh said the interview was conducted as per prescribed norms. “Since BHU is one of the centres of excellence in the country, it is obvious that candidates are supposed to know English too. Foreign candidates also apply for posts in BHU. The interview was conducted in unbiased manner,” he added.

BHU campus witnessed a month-long protest after a Muslim candidate, Firoz Khan, was appointed assistant professor at Sahitya department in SVDV faculty in November last year. The agitation was called off after Khan joined the department of Sanskrit in the faculty of arts after qualifying another interview.

Title: Rekindling the love for comic books
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Trichy: When technological advancement and communication gadgets are alienating children from reading books, a private school in Trichy is trying to rekindle interest among children by exposing them to comic books.

Collection of over a 1,000 Tamil comic books, among which a few are over three decades old, adorn a room dedicated exclusively for comics in Bharathi Matriculation Higher Secondary School in Trichy.

The collections include popular comic books of yesteryears like Lion, Muthu and Indrajal, Mandrake the Magician – in Tamil and many more. Some of them were sold for Rs 1 and Rs 1.25 in those days.

An avid comic collector from Trichy, K Balakrishnan, principal of the school has been preserving these books over these years.

During those days, reading books or playing sports were among the limited leisurely activities for children and comic books helped me visualize. Now that stories are available in visual 3D format, comic books have taken a backseat, says Balakrishnan.

By making these comic books available for students, we have decided to rekindle the reading habit among children which has come down drastically. Balakrishnan has dedicated a room exclusively for comic books in the school. While he had displayed his collections in the school last week for the public, there wasn’t much of a reception.

While there are a few comic collectors across the state, Balakrishnan said that they have decided to meet in Trichy next month to create awareness on comic reading with their collections.

“Reading such stories will help children visualize the stories that they read which will eventually help them become more creative. Our objective is to create awareness among parents on the benefits of comics,” he said.

Terming 80’s and 90’s to be the golden era of comic books, L Venkateswaran, 44 from Chennai says that advent of visual media has taken away the attention of children from comics.

While stories fascinate children, there are numerous storytelling websites these days. Owning over a 500 comic books, Venkateswaran says these comic books are a tool for him to make his children learn Tamil as they are not taught Tamil in school as it is Kendriya Vidyalaya.

Title: Over 5L migrant workers enroll under Awaaz scheme
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The number of migrant labourers, who have enrolled for the state government’s Awaaz scheme , has crossed five lakh. As on January 4, the health insurance scheme launched for migrant labourers by the labour and skills department had 5,00,113 members.

The highest enrolment is in Ernakulam (1,08,645), followed by Thiruvananthapuram (60,077). Other districts which added to the numbers include: Kollam (24,705); Pathanamthitta (23,890); Alappuzha (36,924); Idukki (19,442); Kottayam (32,578); Thrissur (41,208); Palakkad (24,651); Malappuram (29,477); Kozhikode (42,450); Wayanad (11,545); Kannur (28,723); and, Kasaragod (15,798).

The project provides free treatment through government hospitals. As many as 56 hospitals, including medical college hospitals and the regional cancer centre, have been empanelled under the scheme. Members between 18 and 60 years of age will get free treatment worth Rs 25,000 and life insurance cover of Rs 2 lakh.

Title: Tamil outfit members lock shops of north Indians for ‘taking away job opportunities’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Trichy: Members of Tamil Desiya Katchi ‘locked’ up several shops run by north Indians in a few central districts including Pudukottai on Saturday. They were demanding that people from northern states like Rajasthan vacate shops as they were affecting the employment opportunities of locals.

They put locks on five shops in Mela Rajaveethi in Pudukottai town and seven shops in Pattukottai in Thanjavur district.

They also left pamphlets asking the state government to evict north Indians by asking them to vacate.

The pamphlet also added they will not hesitate to resort to violence if they don’t shut shop and return.

Cases have been booked against the party members in Pattukottai, Thanjavur and Pudukottai districts based on the complaints from the shop owners.

“The presence of north Indians is on the rise in commercial areas of every town especially for trading activities. While they are into every other business right from plastics products, jewellery, food and beverages, north Indians hawkers have been slowly occupying road side space as well,” said R Tamil Nesan, president of Tamil Desiya Katchi.

Tamil Nesan also blamed traders from north India for smuggling banned gutka products into the state in connivance with local politicians and officials.

Title: CG Road won’t be dug for 20 years: Vijay Nehra
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vasant Tirodkar

AHMEDABAD: No sooner did the civic body undertake some demolition to prune the newly constructed crossroads on the 2.6km-long CG Road — along Parimal, Girish Cold Drinks, Stadium, and Panchvati — to widen junctions for traffic smooth flow, doubts were raised by CG Road stakeholders as to whether the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) was confident of its design.

On the other hand, the AMC has issued a statement that the pedestrian-centric Rs32 crore refurbishment of CG Road will not be dug up by utility companies or the civic body for the next 20 years! That’s the guarantee the Ahmedabad Municipal Commissioner Vijay Nehra gave to CG Road stakeholders. “The traffic junctions were pruned around the corners for a smooth left-exit. Apart from that we have made it clear that with special underground duct line and a chamber constructed every 30 meters for utility companies — cables, optical fibre — for repair works no digging will be allowed for the next two decades,” says Nehra. A senior AMC West Zone official, however, added that the power line and gas lines have independent passages. But these assurances have yet not allayed doubts of CG Road shopowners on issues like parking.

Vice-president of CG Road Shopowners’ Association, Vasant Tirodkar says, “We have been asked by AMC to wait till January end before the design is explained to us. We have no idea as to how the parking space for visitors and 15,000 temporary and permanent employees on CG Road will be arranged.” He adds, “A bus service for ferrying shoppers was envisaged some time back for Navarangpura multi-level parking, but AMC asked us to pay for these services. None of the members showed willingness to pay.”

Title: I don’t like being called an icon: Shanta Gokhale
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

When it comes to introducing an author like Shanta Gokhale to friends, there are a few ways to go about doing that. The most basic way would be to tell them that she is the ‘mother’of art critic Girish Shahane and actor and former host of TV show Surabhi, Renuka Shahane. But that’s like saying that Mt Fuji is some mountain in Japan. The ideal way as her fans and readers would like it would be to introduce Gokhale as the author of two Marathi books, Rita Welinkar and Tya Varshi, of which Rita Welinkar is a book so seminal, it is recommended reading in colleges. She is a playwright – the plays she has written include Avinash, Dip and Dop and Rosemary for Remembrance; a noted translator; has penned screenplays for films and documentaries; and has been a columnist as well. Her most recent work is her autobiography, One Foot in the Ground: A Life Told Through the Body. At 80, Gokhale continues to keep doing what she does best: Write. In an interview she recently gave to TOI, Gokhale spoke about her creativity- filled life:

Your novel Rita Welinkar is studied in colleges today. When it first came out, did the book – with its story about a woman choosing to love a married man – shake up society?

At the time I wrote it, the subject of Rita Welinkar was in a way edgy but it wasn’t, in its manner of writing, in your face because I was just writing how I felt; I was never conscious of opposing something. When that happens, people don’t see a book or its subject as a threat. So no, it didn’t shake up society or anything. People who read it thought it was a different angle, differently written, and it was more or less well-received by the public. But the fact is it has remained on the shelf, people continue to read it even today.

You have said earlier that you had an obscenely happy childhood. Did writing come easily to you as that happy child?

Frankly, yes. It always did come easily to me. It always starts in school with essays and you find that you are topping in class, and you always get very good marks for your essays. And then, an interest in writing is building up. And then you try your hand at various forms of writing and hone in on certain forms that you can do well. It’s not difficult, but it is when you seriously decide that you want to write that the trouble begins because then you are not writing for your pleasure, you are practicing an art and that art has certain traditions, certain demands and if you can’t fulfil them, then you can’t call yourself a writer.

You have written in your autobiography about having parents who thought marriage was not necessary...

Absolutely. My father didn’t even say, ‘If you don’t want to (get married)’. He just said, ‘Why do you want to get married and have babies and all that? Come stay with us. Teach, read, write. Why do you have to get married? ’

How liberating was it to lead a life where getting married wasn’t the be-all and end-all?

We were strictly middle-class and yet, my father had this dream of sending us abroad, to England, to study. I was 16-and-a-half when we went. He sat me down at the time and said, ‘I am spending more than I can afford to on your education because I think education is the most important thing, but I am not going to spend a paisa on your wedding and neither I nor your mother will go around looking for a bridegroom for you.’ You want to marry, find your own man. Later, I paid for my own wedding because I agreed with my father.

As a writer with a repertoire as rich as yours, do you ever look back at all that you’ve achieved or do you just move on to the next project?

I think I just move on. Very rarely do I look back as such. There is always something new to do which I haven’t done before. So that’s something to look forward to rather than look back at what I have already done. It is not overwhelming, and constantly, one is aware of writers who have done so much more. For eg, the writer Vijay Tendulkar wrote 28 plays in all apart from columns, short fiction, journalistic articles. I have not been that kind of writer. I think, also as a woman writer, home and children take up a lot of time. Time becomes a concern, space becomes a concern. Had I been a male writer, I’d have written much more. It is only in these last 20 years or so that I have had time for myself, to write what I like as much as much as I like.

How do you like it when society puts you on a pedestal and calls you an icon?

I don’t like it at all. First of all, I kind of heard that this seemed to be the place I was put into. I was embarrassed and I was thinking, ‘Really? Why? What for?’ But then, over the last two or three years, I have begun to think that by the time you come to a certain age, people who are giving awards are thinking, ‘It is time we gave her an award!’ When the award is given and I am introduced, I hear the list of things I have done, and then I feel ‘Okay! ’ I keep thinking of people who have done so much more and so much better. Yeah, I guess there are people who have done so much less and so much worse, so maybe, maybe… but it embarrasses the hell out of me.

Title: ‘Acquiring knowledge is a life-long process’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Trichy: Laying emphasis on the need to continuously improve one’s skills and keep oneself updated, Joint Secretary of University Grants Commission (UGC), Shakeel Ahmed, said one must strive to acquire knowledge throughout one’s life. Addressing graduates at the graduation day at Jamal Mohamed college (JMC), Trichy, on Saturday, he said education is about opening up the mind to accept new ideas and to evaluate them for achieving progress.

He lauded JMC for imparting quality-oriented and value-based education. Ahmed said children should grow up facing challenges in life. “Today parents are trying to shield their children from problems and harsh realities of life. They think that exposing them to problems will hamper their studies, but education should be attained through life’s experiences,” he said.

Asking students to develop a positive attitude, he advised them to stay away from negativism. Citing the example of Wright brothers who invented aircrafts, he said if they had accepted the theory that any object heavier than air couldn’t be flown in the air, they would never have invented aircrafts.

He asked students to give back to the society to ensure the country was on par with the developed countries in the world. Education is about increasing the confidence of an individual to dream and to translate that dream into reality. Referring to Tamil poet Avvaiyar’s words, he said whatever they had learnt so far may be just handful and what remains to be learnt is as vast as the universe.

Title: Anuradha Paudwal dismisses claims by Thiruvananthapuram woman
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Anuradha Paudwal

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Singer Anuradha Paudwal has dismissed the claims made by a 45-year-old Thiruvananthapuram resident that she was the singer’s daughter who was abandoned soon after birth. Responding to the claim made by Karmala Modex , that she has filed a petition before district family court here to establish the ‘truth’ about her parents, Paudwal said that she was yet to receive court notice. If I did receive court notice, then I would face it legally, she said.

She also said that Karmala may be under some delusion. Paudwal was responding to TOI’s queries on the claims by Karmala.

On Wednesday, Karmala, a resident of Varkala, made shocking claims while addressing a news conference here. She said that she was the daughter of Anuradha and husband Arun Paudwal, but raised by her foster parents Ponnachan and Agnes. According to her, Anuradha and Arun handed her over to Ponnachan and Agnes soon after her birth in 1974 in Karnataka . Ponnachan revealed the truth about her birth a few years ago on his deathbed. He told her that both families were known to each other and Anuradha and husband decided to give up the baby as it was not possible for them to raise the baby owing to her busy schedule. Ever since, she had been trying to contact the singer, but in vain.

As a final resort, she filed a petition before the district family court here to legally make the singer admit their relationship. She also said in the news conference that she was ready to undergo even a DNA test to prove her claims.

In her petition filed before the court, Karmala has also sought appropriate compensation for the childhood she lost under her foster parents, who could not support her studies beyond Class X owing to financial crisis.

The court has scheduled her case for hearing on January 27.

Title: SP pushes for booth management
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Allahabad: With an eye to 2022 state assembly polls, Samajwadi Party (SP) on Sunday launched a training camp for its cadre to strengthen its booth management.

SP leaders urged workers to approach households to strengthen the party’s base. They said that workers could play a vital role in strengthening the party.

Senior SP leader and former minister Shailendra Yadav said, “BJP is misleading the country. SP’s ideology would boost the country’s unit and ensure progress for every section of the society.” He also said that the BJP-led Union and state governments have failed on all fronts including employment, education, health, inflation and farmers problems. tnn

Title: 1 1 booked for grabbing education dept’s land in Mau district
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

VARANASI: Eleven people, including two medical practitioners, were booked on Saturday for grabbing the land of education department in Shahadatpur locality in Mau district .

After receiving a complaint from the office of district inspector of schools (DIoS), Kotwali police lodged an FIR against Sushila, Badami , Nidhi, Krishna Kumar, Anita Rai, Sharda, Vidyavati Singh, Dr Ajay Singh, Nirmala, Dr Sanjay Singh and Manoj Singh under sections 434 (mischief by destroying or moving any landmark fixed by public authority), 447 (criminal trespass) of IPC and under the Prevention of Damage to Public Property Act.

District magistrate, Mau, Gyan Prakash Tripathi said he visited government library in Shahadatpur locality on Swadeshi Cotton Mill Road last week after receiving a complaint about encroachment on education department’s land by 11 people.

“Taking serious note of the issue, officials of land revenue department were engaged for proper measurement of land after which the complaint was found to be true,” he said, adding that the removal of illegal encroachment has begun.

Title: Attipetty to be made Servant of God
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kochi: Yet another Keralite is on the path to sainthood as the Catholic Church has decided to declare Archbishop Joseph Attipetty as Servant of God, marking the commencement of the cause for his canonization, on January 21.

Mar Attipetty was the first person from the local community to be made Archbishop of Verapoly. Marking the commencement of the Universal Catholic Church’s canonical process for sainthood, the official declaration would be made at St Francis Assisi Cathedral, Broadway, Ernakulam. This coincides with the 50th year commemoration of the prelate’s death.

Archbishop Attipetty was born on June 25, 1894 in the Cruz Milagris parish of Kurisinkal, Ochanthuruth on the island of Vypeen across Cochin Harbour. He was consecrated Archbishop at the age of 39, taking over the reins from Archbishop Angel Mary Perez-Cecilia, a Spaniard who was the last in the long line of Carmelite prelates of Kerala, starting in 1659 with Joseph Sebastiani, the first Vicar Apostolic of Malabar.

“During the 36 years of his regime, the archdiocese made magnificent progress in the field of higher education, health care, growth of religious congregations, social welfare measures and overall development. He died on January 21, 1970. His mortal remains were interred at St Francis Assisi Cathedral,” an official communique from the Church stated.

Archbishop Joseph Kalathiparambil, Metropolitan of Verapoly Province, would officiate at the thanksgiving mass in which he will make the official declaration. A decree from the Vatican Congregation for the Causes of Saints will be read during the holy mass, in which various bishops, laity and the religious would attend.

A tribunal for the cause of sainthood will be constituted by Archbishop Kalathiparambil soon for taking the process forward. Fr Andrews Alexander, a Capuchin friar and an expert on canonisation, is the postulator for the cause of Attipetty.

An organising committee for the starting event of the canonization process was constituted in a meeting held at the Verapoly Archbishop’s house on Thursday. Archbishop Kalathiparambil is the patron of the committee, Monsignor Mathew Kallingal and Monsignor Matthew Elanjimittam, vicar generals of the archdiocese, are the chairpersons, Monsignor Joseph Padiyaramparambil, rector St Francis Assisi Cathedral, is the general convenor, and Sherry J Thomas, general secretary of the Kerala Latin Catholic Association, is the joint convenor of the committee.

Title: Gold, silver stolen from locked house
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Trichy: Gold jewellery and silver vessels were stolen from a locked house near Navalpattu in the district. The crime came to light only when the occupants of the house returned on Friday.

According to the complaint from V Vasanthakumar, 43, working at ordnance factory Trichy (OFT), he and his family had gone to their relatives house in Thanjavur district on December 29. When they returned on January 2, he found the door broken open. They checked inside and found 27.5 sovereigns of gold jewellery and 1kg silver vessels stolen from a wooden bureau in the house.

Acting on the complaint, the Navalpattu police visited the house. The police said that the burglars gained entry into the house by breaking open the lock on the front door. Forensic experts collected finger prints from the house. The police have registered a case and launched the investigation.

Title: Walls of trench collapse at power project site; 1 dead, 2 injured
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Varanasi: A foreman was killed while an electrician and a labourer suffered serious injuries as they were buried in mud after walls of a trench collapsed of an under construction power power generation unit in Obra in Sonbhadra district on Sunday morning.

Body of the deceased identified as Ravindra Sahu (47) of Haryana was sent for postmortem and other injured — Ajay Kushwaha and Chhatradhari were being treated in district hospital.

Reports stated that some faults were noticed in the cables, laid 25-ft deep in earth at an under construction 1320 MW power generation unit in Obra. To repair the cables, a trench was created with the help of earth moving machines. Later, foreman Ravindra Sahu (47) of Haryana, along with electrician Ajay Kushwaha and labourer Chhatradhari entered the trench to repair the cables.

When they were busy with work around 9 am, the mud walls of trench collapsed and the trio got buried under debris. The incident led to chaos at the project site and hundreds of labourers, engineers and project officers gathered there while earth moving machines were engaged to remove the debris.

On getting information CO Obra Bhaskar Verma along with heavy police force also reached there. After exercising hard for over two hours all three were rescued and rushed to district hospital where Ravindra was declared brought dead, said Obra outpost in-charge Gopal Rai, adding condition of other injured persons was also serious.

Title: Man fined for ‘mice-ate-my-passport’ story
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bhopal: Here’s a reminder — your passport is government property and it’s probably a good idea to keep it with the family jewels. An applicant for a duplicate passport learnt this the hard way when he was fined Rs 5,000 for claiming that rats gnawed up his passport.

Officials explained that he was fined for carelessness in handling the passport. Regional passport officer Rashmi Baghel told TOI that when a passport is issued, it is expected that the holder takes care of it. “It is, after all, government property. If someone applies for a fresh passport in the ‘damaged category’, he has to pay a fine, along with the usual fee. In this case, a few pages of the passport had been completely gnawed away. He confessed that the passport was lying among his books and that his house was mice-infested. So, he had to pay a fine of Rs 5,000 for damage to government property as he failed to keep the document in a safe place where it won’t come to any harm,” said Baghel.

Such extreme cases, where entire pages of the passport are missing, don’t come very often, said Baghel. “A few months ago, another man came to us with his passport in tatters. He said he forgot to take it out of his pocket after travel when he dumped all his clothes in the washing machine,” she said. Jet-blasted and spun dry, most of the passport came apart in little bits.

“Passport is a serious document and should not be taken casually. The man whose passport got washed also had to pay a heavy fine as most of the pages went missing and there was severe damage to the front and back pages,” the RPO added. It’s so serious, in fact, that if someone applies twice under the ‘damaged’ category, they may be treated as a habitual offender and denied a fresh passport.

“Damage from water spill and ink stains are common. We get a lot of these cases, and we understand that mishaps happen. But cases where pages go missing are very serious as the applicant may be involved in some illegal activity. So, if the RPO finds that a person has applied for fresh passport under ‘damage’ category more than once, it can turn down the request because that person is not capable of taking care of a government document,” explained Baghel.

Title: Bengaluru techie scores 99.99 percentile in CAT, eyes IIM-A seat
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Sushant Sunil Thombre

BENGALURU: A city-based software professional, Sushant Sunil Thombre, has scored 99.99 percentile in the Common Admission Test ( CAT ) 2019, that holds key to the top management institutes of the country.

Ten candidates scored 100 percentile from across the country and one of them, whose details are yet to be known, is from Karnataka. Twenty one candidates have scored 99.99 percentile in the examination.

A native of Nashik, Thombre completed his engineering in electronics and communications from Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology (VNIT Nagpur) in 2018 and moved to the city to join a software firm.

“I put in at least two hours for studies on weekdays after work and more than four hours on weekends,” he said.

In the four months before exam, Thombre dedicated his entire weekends for preparations. “I opted for test series from TIME and spent three hours for the tests and remaining four to five hours in analysing it,” he explained. He hopes to get into either IIM-Ahmedabad or IIM- Bangalore.

Like Thombre, 18 other candidates who scored 99.99 percentile are from the engineering/technology background.

Title: Protesters seek relief for nun who left convent
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kochi: A group of protesters associated with the Kerala Christian Reformation Movement held a protest here demanding compensation for a nun who had left the convent a few months ago. The protesters held a symbolic collection drive for the rehabilitation of the nun in front of the St Joseph Provincialate convent of the Assisi Sisters of Mary Immaculate (ASMI) Congregation here on Saturday.

The protest was attended by the family of the ex-nun, Sr Delsy, as well.

Sr Delsy had left the convent as she felt uncomfortable with the lifestyle at the convent. She had joined the congregation at the age of 17 and was made a nun about four years ago.

Sr Delsy said that she took the decision to leave the congregation as she strongly sensed that she would become a victim of physical abuse.

“I took the decision to join the congregation out of a firm desire to serve God. However, my experience was horrible. I had to face mental torture. I wanted to do social work but they never let me do what I wanted, but made me do menial tasks. I thought that if I stayed there any longer, I would become like them, so I decided to quit,” said Sr Delsy.

Her father Thomaskutty P K said that the congregation offered them charity, but not compensation. “We were told by those in the Church that there are provisions to provide compensation or financial aids to those who decide to end their monastic life. However, when we talked with the Church authorities, they told us that they could give the money only as charity, if we wished to marry off our daughter. We are not wealthy, but we would find some way to help our daughter. We don’t want their charity,” said Thomaskutty.

Thomaskutty, a daily wager, added that he gave the share of money for his daughter to the congregation when she joined the convent. “She is nearing 30 and we do not have enough money for her marriage,” he said, adding that he has decided to continue fighting for his daughter.

TOI tried to contact the congregation, but the calls went unanswered.

Title: Relish natural taste with earthenware
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

artistry on display: The exhibition of terracotta products at Gandhi Bhavan is open from 10am to 8pm till Wedn... Read More

Thiruvananthapuram: The jugs that cool water without electricity, ‘meen chatties’ making curries that can leave lasting effect on taste buds and pots that make soft and tasty palappams are reminiscences of a humble past. If you want to have a look and grab a few of them, then head to a pottery expo at Kerala Gandhi Smarak Nidhi of Gandhi Bhavan, Thycaud.

The terracotta products on display and sale at the expo are the handiwork of artisans belonging to Kumbara community at Nilambur.

“We don’t know how long we will be able to keep up with this trade. In another 10 to 20 years, this trade will be vanished,” said Vijayakumari M of Anaswaram Kitchen Product and Murals, a self-help group of Kumbaras from Nilambur.

Around 500 families from Kumbara community at Nilambur still work as potters. The business has gone dull with the arrival of aluminium, steel and plastic in the kitchens. The organizers are expecting help and support from the government to preserve their craft.

The pottery exhibition is also the story of survival of 50 families who are still depending on their traditional livelihood to overcome the loss they suffered in 2019 floods.

“We organized this exhibition to popularise pottery. We are surviving with the craft we know,” Vijayakumari said.

“The products are so affordable. This is a great initiative and we need to support them”, said Satheeshan Nair, a customer.

More than 150 articles made of clay, starting from Rs 100 to Rs 17,000, are sold at the Gandhi Bhavan.

Curry pots, which are microwavable, phulkha chappathi pots, bowls, jugs, jars, candle stands, pen holders and murals made of terracotta are the main attraction of the exhibition.

The exhibition, which began on Thursday, is open to the public from 10am to 8pm till Wednesday.

Title: Govt bus driver, wife end life
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Erode: A driver with the Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) and his wife committed suicide by hanging from the ceiling of their house in Koogalur village near Gobichettipalayam here on Saturday morning.

The Gobichettipalayam police identified the deceased as M Karthikeyan, 38 and his wife Maheswari, 30. While Karthikeyan was a TNSTC driver, his wife was an anganwadi worker.

Police said neighbours had altered them as the couple didn’t come out of their house even after 12 noon on Saturday. “They knocked on the door, but there was no response. They called us in and we broke open the house only to find them hanging from the ceiling by using a dupatta.”

The bodies were sent to the government hospital in Gobichettipalayam for postmortem. Police have registered a case. tnn

Title: Mulling law against fishing boats from outside Gujarat: CM Vijay Rupani
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vijay Rupani

GANDHINAGAR: Chief minister Vijay Rupani on Saturday said his government was thinking of bringing a legislation to prevent “unauthorized, unregistered” boats of other states from fishing in the Arabian Sea along the coast here.

Rupani was talking to reporters after interacting with a group of fishermen in Gandhinagar under his Mann ni Moklaash (speaking from your heart) programme.

He said he had received representation from the state's fishermen on this and he had assured them of safeguarding their interests.

“One of the concerns of the fishermen is that unauthorized, unregistered boats from other states should be stopped (from fishing in the sea along Gujarat coast). Gujarat government has made a decision regarding this. If required, we will go ahead to make an Act on this," he said.

“We will prevent unauthorized fishermen (from other states) coming here for fishing activities and will take legal action against them," he said.

Rupani further said, “During the interaction with the fishermen, they said that they be considered at par with farmers as their activities are like farming. The farmers grow food grains in farms while fishermen take it from sea. So they also wanted credit card benefits like the farmers, under the state's Sagar Khedu scheme.”

“We are positive over their demand. We have assured them that we will talk to the central government on this," Rupani said.

Rupani said his government pays Rs 300 per day as compensation to fishermen from Gujarat who end up in Pakistan jails in case they inadvertently cross the international maritime border and are nabbed by agencies of the neighbouring country.

He said the government had also decided to pay Rs 2 lakh to the kin of fisherman missing in the Arabian sea, after lapse of a year.

Title: Goa: Depositors demand FIR against Mapusa Urban management
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Irate depositors with accounts in Mapusa Urban Co-operative Bank (MUCB) on Saturday demanded that the Economic Offences Wing (EOW) investigate the bank’s functioning.

MUCB’s customers, nearly 3.5 lakh in number, also said they plan to file an FIR against the management for financial irregularities.

At a meeting held in Panaji, depositors voiced concerns regarding their savings, which remain locked due to directives by the Reserve Bank of India ( RBI ). “Depositors demanded that the matter of mismanagement of public funds should be forwarded to the EOW to conduct a thorough investigation as is the case with the Punjab and Maharashtra Co-Operative Bank, where several members of the board of directors have been taken into custody,” they said in a statement.

The beleaguered bank fell into financial trouble after the management allegedly gave loans to persons of their choice without following due diligence and norms. The mining ban pushed the bank over the brink putting its financial assets in the red at the cost of funds of depositors, said customers.

The RBI has now set MUCB a February 2 deadline to find a solution to its financial woes. Depositors meanwhile are deciding their next move to initiate action against the management to recover deposits

Irate depositors and stakeholders also accused the bank’s chairman, board of directors and general manager of not taking customers into confidence. “Customers are entitled to know what’s happening, but instead, they are being kept in the dark,” a depositor said.

Title: Realtors, lawyers, medicos drawn to food business
Content: If one spends 20 years developing and making one’s real-estate business a success, the next big thing is often in the same or allied sector. But the love for food and viable business opportunity drove Ahmedabad-based realtor Tejas Joshi venture into the fine dining space. The vice-president of GIHED-CREDAI and managing director of Vivan Infrastructure, Joshi collaborated with Three Quarter Indian (TQI) through an equity-based stake, some six months ago."I am a foodie and it was always a dream to start off with a business in this sector. Through this collaboration, we have launched a rooftop multi-cuisine, fine dine restaurant. It is a promising business and with fast changing dynamics, youth getting increasingly drawn to eating out, there isn’t a better time to foray into this space," said Joshi. "Over the next year or so, we plan to expand to Vietnam and San Francisco, US too."Starting a restaurant is easy but turning it into a thriving business is a different ballgame. The love for food, coupled with Gujarati entrepreneurial spirit and a sharp business acumen to leverage the opportunities in the fast-changing food and restaurant industry have driven many from different professional spheres to starting their own restaurant business.Gujarat is home to many such success stories, where people have not just ventured into food-based startups; but also, concept-based cafes and fine-dining restaurants.While some smell good business opportunities, some wanted to fill a market gap. For instance, Ahmedabad-based opthalmologist, Dr Kamal Nagpal, founded Café Soul Square in 2013, with the idea of introducing overall wellness through food.One of the early entrants in the segment of cafés offering healthy food in Ahmedabad, Dr Nagpal said, "The idea was always to provide wholesome food, which is minimally greasy, has a lot of greens, uses whole grains, avoids using preservatives and chemicals; avoids using thickening agents and minimal or no use of processed foods. We bake our bread ourselves and use no premixes or processed foods at our café. Over time we did have to change our menu to suit the commercial palate and add other options as well, but the core focus of wholesome food has been retained over the years."The culture of cafés in Ahmedabad has grown tremendously over the past five years – a space which was ruled by national-level chains for over a decade till 2014. "Ahmedabad had many cafés that were operated as franchises of national chain of coffee shops. However, it lacked a café culture like metropolitan cities wherein one can go and hangout. Besides, my idea of a café was one that not just offered coffee, desserts and frozen food but also a full-fledged meal," said Devarshi Patel, who founded Café Mocha in 2014, after being a practising lawyer for five years.Patel, who also operated his family business in real estate, now runs three outlets of Café Mocha which include two in Ahmedabad and one in Gandhinagar.With Gujarat opening doors to foreign investors, multinational companies and startups have begun thriving in the state; as a result of which it drew an array of young professionals with increased disposable incomes. With entry of food delivery apps, experts say the number of people eating out and ordering-in food has multiplied over the years."With these apps, small players have also got an opportunity to grow, and can operate with limited capital as they get an easy access to the masses. We have also seen an array of cloud kitchens mushrooming in different parts of the city with the advent of food delivery apps," said Rohit Khanna, member, Food Entrepreneurs’ Alliance (FEA).

Title: ZP elections on party lines in March, says Godinho
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Panaji: Panchayats minister Mauvin Godinho on Saturday said that the zilla panchayat (ZP) elections, which are likely to be conducted in mid-March 2020, will be held on party lines.

“There is no change in the manner of conducting ZP elections. It will be conducted along party lines,” Godinho told TOI.

The upcoming ZP elections were discussed at the recent cabinet meeting. Sources said that if the government doesn’t want to conduct ZP elections along party lines, they will have to make a legislative change.

“How can we change the decision (to conduct ZP elections on party lines) when we (BJP) are the ones who started it (holding it on party lines),” BJP general secretary Sadanand Tanawade said.

In 2015, then chief minister Laxmikant Parsekar had decided to conduct ZP elections along party lines and accordingly, the Goa Panchayati Raj Act was amended in March 2015. The provision was, however, not extended to panchayat elections. At the time, Congress and NCP had decided not to field candidates on their party ticket in places where they had support of independent candidates. This time, Congress has already announced its intent to fight polls on party lines with the Goa Pradesh Congress Committee (GPCC) executive committee passing a resolution in favour. MGP too is in favour of going to the elections on party lines. One reason is that MGP wants to assess the political strength of various parties.

Prior to 2015, parties would back candidates or panels of their choice in civic polls in the absence of provisions in the act.

Gujarat, Karnataka and Maharashtra hold ZP elections along party lines.

There are 25 ZP members each in North and South Goa.

Title: ‘Entrust PSU with beach sand mining work’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state government should ensure that mining of mineral-rich beach sand found along the coast of Kollam and Alappuzha should be retained in the hands of the public sector undertaking Kerala Minerals and Metals Ltd (KMML), CPI leader and chairman of public undertakings committee C Divakaran said.

The mineral-rich beach sand is invaluable and can in a big way support the state’s economy. Since the recommendations for scientific mining of mineral-rich beach sand did not get due consideration, private mining lobbies have been trying to wrest control over this, and many a time, the government has acted soft on such attempts, he said.

He said that the chief minister also had in the assembly assured that the mining of mineral-rich beach sand would be retained with the PSU itself.

Under these circumstances, the government should take necessary steps to ensure that the mining remains with the PSU, Divakaran said.

Title: Notices served to 46 anti-CAA protesters for damage claims in Muzaffarnagar district
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

MUZAFFARNAGAR: A total of 46 notices have been served, so far, to protesters for anti-CAA violence in Muzaffarnagar district , the office of additional district magistrate (ADM) said on Saturday.

The notices did not mention any specific recovery amount. But, the “rioters” have been asked to appear in person before the ADM court to record their statements within seven days.

Similar notices are being sent to anti-CAA protesters in the state’s other districts where violence took place on December 20.

Sources said that the local administration had asked police to provide details of the alleged offenders who took part in damaging properties and vehicles after Friday prayers on December 20. Now, police have provided names and addresses of 46 individuals. Notably, all of them were already booked at Nagar-Kotawali police station and Civil Lines police station for vandalising public property.

ADM Amit Singh said on Saturday, “We have received 48 claims for damages to vehicles and property in which 46 notices have been sent after examining police reports. We have not disclosed the amount yet. It would be revealed after examination and assessment. For now, we have only sent notices to them for court appearance.”

The process is still on and final notices to recover the cost of damages will be slapped in the coming days, sources added.

Title: ‘Gujaratis reached US, but not IAS/IPS’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Gandhinagar: Deputy chief minister Nitin Patel, who is also the spokesperson for the state government, spoke about a need for Gujaratis to aspire to cracking the civil services and working in the Indian Administrative Service (IAS) and Indian Police Service (IPS).

Speaking at an Anjana Patel community event in Gandhinagar, Patel said: “Gujaratis have reached the USA but, unfortunately, are not seen as IAS, IPS or IFS officers in the Gujarat secretariat. In many states, local officers get prominence in their bureaucracy while we have very few Gujarati IAS/IPS officers.”

Patel said that Gujaratis have traditionally remained more focused on establishing a business or migrating to foreign countries for better prospects. “Seldom have Gujaratis focused on pursuing government jobs like youth in other states do. We don’t see much representation from Gujarat in the IAS/IPS, railway, banking or central PSUs such as ONGC. To ensure the state’s best interests, it is necessary that Gujaratis take up to government jobs by qualifying in competitive exams. I want to see the majority name plates at the secretariat of Gujarati officers,” he added.

Gujarat has only recently started warming up to UPSC exams. In the 2018 UPSC examination, 18 from the state had secured top positions, including one in the top 100.

Gujarat had a great run in the UPSC in 2017, when a record 43 candidates cracked the examination.

Not a cricketer to play 20-20, I’m a politician: Nitin Patel

Ahmedabad: The T20 World Cup may be scheduled for later this year but the format is ruling the narrative of Gujarat politics these days. Since the arrival of the year 2020, CM Vijay Rupani has at least twice invoked the rapid cricket format, saying that he is here to play the ‘whole series of 20-20 matches’ and he ‘is not afraid to play half way down to pitch to ensure the people’s work is done’.

This was read as the CM scotching rumours of him being replaced as CM, and underscoring for his detractors within the party that he is a decisive leader who is not scared of taking tough decisions.

This idiom was taken forward on Saturday, when deputy CM Nitin Patel was asked what he made of these remarks.

Patel dodged said that he did not want to react on such things. “In politics, opponents have tried to defeat me too, but they all failed. I am not a cricketer so I can’t talk of 20-20. I am a politician and am in public service since 1972-73.”

Patel tried to distance himself from the rumours of Rupani’s removal and him being considered for the CM’s post again. Some have taken his statement to mean that ‘Patel is trying to potray himself as different from Rupani’.

Title: Olive Ridley turtle nests at Morjim
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Panaji: The season’s first Olive Ridley turtle nest on Morjim beach was laid on Saturday. The arrival of a flippered visitor marked a delayed start to the nesting season that has already recorded two more arrivals in South Goa in the new year. “The turtle arrived at Morjim beach at around 3.30am on Saturday and laid 118 eggs,” a source said.

The first nesting was reported at Galgibaga beach on January 1. Another nesting was reported at Agonda beach the next day.

Morjim beach, which lies on the bank of the Chapora river, is where Goa’s modest turtle conservation effort begun in the late 1990s. During the 2018-19 season, 22 nests had been laid at Morjim and Mandrem and 1,500-odd hatchlings had been released from about 2,500 eggs.

While Morjim and Mandrem in North Goa have been designated turtle nesting sites, Agonda and Galgibaga in South Goa have also been granted similar status under the Coastal Regulation Zone notification, 2011.

A small strip of the southern part of Morjim beach has been earmarked as a turtle nesting site. Tourism activities, especially night illumination and noise, however, often disturb the reptiles.
