This story is from January 5, 2020

KANPUR: Kanpur Metro completed the casting of first pier of the 8.9-Km priority corridor being built from the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kanpur to Moti Jheel . The work ended on the last day of December.

In total, Kanpur Metro has to construct 295 piers for the viaduct and 198 piers for nine stations in the priority section.

Public relations department of UPMRC said the Kanpur Metro team has cast the first pier cap of priority corridor. It stated that the work was completed on the eve of New Year.

It also stated that team of UP Metro Rail Corporation has worked day and night to achieve this feat in just three months. “It is a wonderful achievement by the team of Kanpur Metro,” UPMRC managing director, Kumar Keshav. said while lauding the team.

With this, the construction work of Kanpur Metro is gathering pace. The construction agency is working day and night between IIT-Kanpur and Kalyanpur Metro route. For this, barricades have already been put from IIT-Kanpur gate and traffic has been diverted.

Also, the work at the Government Polytechnic for construction of Metro yard is going on. This bears importance for the fact that the Kanpur Metro would be stationed here for maintenance work.

It is expected that the work of construction of Metro yard would finish before the construction of pillars and the raised platforms to enable it to run.

The Kanpur Metro is expected to start running by the end of year 2021 or in January 2022. In the first phase, it will run between IIT-K and Motijheel in Swaroop Nagar. On this route, Metro will run overhead. Nine stations would be made on this route.

However, after commissioning of Kanpur Metro between the two identified ends, the work would be carried out further. In the first route, Kanpur Metro is to run up to Naubasta from IIT-Kanpur.

But, between Motijheel and Naubasta, while some stations would be elevated, others would be underground.

Title: Aligarh: Protest against attack on Nankana Sahib Gurdwara in Pakistan
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

AGRA: Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP) and Bajrang Dal workers staged a protest against Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan for attack on Gurudwara Nankana Sahib and Sikh devotees in Aligarh on Saturday.

They submitted a memorandum to the president of India through the local administration. They demanded assurance of safety and security of the Sikh community. They also burnt the effigy of Pakistan prime minister and the country’s flag.

Title: VMC panel givesnod to Sayajipura housing scheme for urban poor
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vadodara: The standing committee of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) gave a nod for the contract to complete work on the Sayajipura housing scheme for the urban poor on Saturday.

The work on the scheme has been on the hold for the past couple of years.

M V Omni Projects was awarded the Rs 11.57crore work in September 2015, but the company was unable to complete work due to financial issues after completing only 35 per cent work. The company had been paid Rs 4.06 crore by the civic body for the work done till then.

Only one contractor came forward to complete the project who quoted Rs 10.77crore for the work. VMC had estimated Rs 7.5 crore for the completion of the project, but after negotiation agreed to pay him Rs 10.46 crore.

Title: Don’t subject education to politics: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal attends the PTM at a Delhi government school on Rouse Avenue

NEW DELHI: Saba Parveen’s elder son has been studying in a Delhi government school on Rouse Avenue in central Delhi for four years. She described the school as a “khandahar”, or a ruin, when she admitted him in Class IV. “The school has changed for the better in a very short time,” said Parveen, now the proud mother of a Class VII student. She was at the school on Saturday to attend the parents-teachers meeting (PTM) organised across the city by Delhi government.

The PTM had run into a controversy after Union health minister and BJP leader Harsh Vardhan requested lieutenant governor Anil Baijal to postpone the event so as not to subject the children to the cold. The Aam Aadmi Party government responded by sticking to the schedule. In fact, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal himself was at the Rouse Avenue school to press the point.

“How can imparting good education to our children be a political gimmick?” Kejriwal wondered at the function. “We have been holding PTMs for two-three years now. Our rivals tried to end these PTMs, but I don’t think subjecting schooling and education to politics is justified.”

The CM had one-on-one interactions with parents and exhorted them to ensure that their children completed schooling and did not “leave midway”.

Gaurav Yadav, originally from Azamgarh in UP, whose two children study in the school, said the changes and improvements brought in Delhi’s education set-up were commendable. “I will vote for you again because I am very happy with the improvements,” he told Kejriwal. “My son, who could not read properly, is now fluent in both Hindi and English. Friends from other states also appreciate your work.”

A parent shared that he had moved his two children out of a private school to the government institution. Another parent, Dharam Veer Singh, said, “If my child bunks school, I am informed about it immediately by the teachers. They are more involved with our children now, and so are we.” He said the facilities and teaching in the government school at Anand Vihar that his daughter attends are equally good.

When deputy CM Manish Sisodia visited a school in Dwarka, he told the students, “Don’t be a dishonest doctor, engineer, officer or lawyer. And don’t forget your parents when you grow professionally.”

Title: CJ retires, Orissa high court stares at vacant judges’ posts
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

CUTTACK: Uncertainty over the filling up of vacancies in posts of judges in the Orissa high court looks to continue indefinitely as chief justice K S Jhaveri retired on Saturday without recommending any fresh names for appointment to the Supreme Court collegium. President Ram Nath Kovind has appointed Kumari Justice Sanju Panda as the acting chief justice of the high court.

The high court collegium had last recommended 10 names (four judicial officers and eight advocates) on May 7, 2019. But on October 3, 2019, the Supreme Court cleared the names of only one judicial officer and one advocate. Subsequently, the Centre endorsed the name of the judicial officer only.

The high court collegium, which recommends names for appointment of judges, comprises the chief justice and two seniormost judges. Chief justice Jhaveri had reportedly tried to hold collegium meetings to decide on recommendation of names on his last two working days. But the collegium meetings were not possible as both the seniormost judges remained absent on Thursday and one of them remained absent on Friday.

As the collegium failed to recommend names to the Supreme Court, the process cannot be undertaken for at least another six months. As per norms, the new chief justice cannot recommend names as part of the collegium before a lapse of six months from his assuming office.

The problem of vacancies in posts of judges in the high court has persisted as only three judges have been appointed in the past nearly five years. Consequently, the high court continues to function with 48 per cent judicial vacancy.

Though the high court has a sanctioned strength of 27, currently there are just 13 judges with the chief justice’s retirement.

Official sources said though 24 names were recommended by the high court collegium in the past two years, only three names were cleared by the Supreme Court collegium. And only two were endorsed by the Centre for appointment.

Persisting vacancies in large number have been creating difficulty in tackling the backlog and creating resentment amongst the advocates on matters not being taken up for months.

Title: Gujarat’s marine exports hit by foreign regulations, weather, competition
Content: Ahmedabad/Rajkot: After growing for three consecutive years, Gujarat’s marine exports in value terms declined by 5.33% in 2018-19. Stricter regulations in traditional markets like US and the European Union (EU), changing consumer requirements and evolving trade scenario have resulted in lower exports.Gujarat’s marine exports dipped to $798 million (approximately Rs 5,666 crore) in 2018-19 from $843 million in 2017-18, according to a report by Drip Capital, a US-based trade finance company.According to the Marine Products Exports Development Authority (MPEDA) under the Union ministry of commerce and industry, Gujarat’s marine exports in volume terms plunged from 3,12,568 tonnes in 2017-18 to 3,05,326 tonnes in 2018-19.The exports are likely to be lower in 2019-20 as extended monsoon and multiple cyclone warnings shortened the fishing season and led to a 40% decline in annual fish catch.“The EU and the US are major markets for Indian marine products. However, their regulations and import guidelines are very stringent. If one consignment is rejected, other buyers shy away from placing their orders,” said Rajan Kumar, a scientist at Central Marine Fisheries Research Institute (CMFRI), Veraval.Increase in countervailing duty by developed countries from time to time also affects Indian exports. Industry players opine that stiff competition from Vietnam and Thailand in shrimp exports has also affected marine exports from Gujarat.“Pollution has adversely affected our catch and led to lower exports. The industrial units on the coast of South Gujarat and Porbandar release untreated water into the sea causing a decline in fish catch,” added Bharat Modi, president, Porbandar Machimar Boat Association.According to the Directorate-General of Foreign Trade (DGFT) India exported nearly $6.3 billion (around Rs 45,000 crore) worth of marine products in FY19. Shrimp, frozen fish and mollusks are major export commodities, with shrimp contributing 71% of the exports.Gujarat ranks first and second in exports of fish and mollusks, respectively. The US market alone accounts for 50% of Gujarat’s fish exports. Coastal towns of Veraval and Porbandar are the two major centres of marine trade in Gujarat. Ribbon fish, cuttlefish, croaker fish, squid and shrimps are some of the popular varieties exported from here.However, the marine exports have grown at a compounded annual growth of rate 10% since fiscal 2015-16. Stating that much of the slowdown stems from EU and to an extent the US, the Drip Capital further recommends that Indian exporters should look at new and alternative markets for their shipments.Buoyed by a resurgent economy, China is likely to be the single largest market to tap into in the coming months. Additionally, other Asian markets like Thailand, Singapore, Hong Kong, Korea and Taiwan will also become increasingly important in the time to come. A fresh market is potentially opening for India in China in wake of the US-China trade war.

Title: Reservation for Agasthyakoodam trek to begin on Jan 8
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Forest department has invited applications for trekking to Agasthyakoodam hills, which will be permitted from January 14 to February 8. The reservation for trekking will begin on January 8.

The applications for visiting passes can be submitted through Akshaya centres or tickets can be booked online at forest department website www.forest.kerala.gov.in.

Reservation facility will be open from 11am on January 8. Only 100 persons will be permitted entry to Agasthyakoodam per day.

Those reserving tickets at Akshaya centre, should bring a copy of photo identity card of their team members. People reserving tickets online should include the identity card number in the online application. A maximum of ten people will be permitted in one ticket. Online ticket cost Rs 1,100. And an additional amount of Rs 50 for five-member group and Rs 70 for 10-member group will have to be paid for reservations through Akshaya centre.

Only those who are physically fit may apply and there will be no special consideration for women though women can apply for trekking. Children below the age of 14 year will not be permitted for trekking. tnn

Title: Indira Park gets security upgrade to ward off encroachers
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Indra Park is among the 5 parks in Sec’bad to come under EVDM wing

SECUNDERABAD: Indira Park , one of the city’s most popular parks , located near the Lower Tank Bund, will now also be a secure spot, thanks to Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation ’s decision to upgrade security at the site.

The reason behind the security upgrade has been attributed to the rise in the number of encroachments at the park. In addition to Indira Park, 46 other parks have been handed over to GHMC’s enforcement, vigilance and disaster management (EVDM) wing. The wing has been asked to deploy security and keep round-the-clock vigil in addition to installing high-end CCTV cameras.

Of the 46 parks, five major parks Indira Park, Sundariaha Park, Clock Tower Park, Bathukamma Ghat, and Green Stretch on Tank Bundcome under North Zone in Secunderabad .

“Since all these five parks are well-known tourist spots and witness heavy footfalls, it has become imperative to keep vigil from a security point of view. Moreover, hundreds of locals visit the park in the wee hours of morning to walk and exercise. There are chances that these parks may become centres for illegal activities. The EVDM wing has decided to take over to prevent such untoward activities,” sources in EVMD told STOI.

With regards to Indira Park a massive security upgrade has to be planned involving the development of private security as well as installation of adequate cameras. The park that is spread over 69 acres, houses a rock garden, a lake and has date palms and sandalwood trees. Adequate security will be deployed to see that no part of the park falls prey to encroachments, said the sources. “We are working on the modalities of appointing private security personnel and in a month or two, the security system will be implemented and updated in all these parks,” said sources in EVDM wing.

Viswajeeth Kampati, director of the EVDM wing, GHMC, “There is proposal to set up an Anti-Encroachment Cell to prevent encroachments in the city parks. A toll-free number will be allotted and citizens can contact us through the number if they spot any encroachments. We will kept the informant’s whereabouts confidential. The Cell will , most likely, begin to function in a month’s time.”

Title: Four hoodlums vandalize shops, two arrested
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: Four persons went off on a rampaging spree on Friday night beating up a trader in the Marimata No Khancho on Rajmahal Road and vandalizing shops.

The traders in the locality, which is a popular area for mobile phone accessories and electronic items, kept the market shut on Saturday to protest the vandalism.

According to the police, the four accused — Vishnu Kahar, Naval, Dhruv and Kishor — entered the narrow lane at around 9.45 pm armed with weapons and sticks. The hoodlums first went to the shop of one Mohandas Lakhani asking him why his shop was still open. Before Lakhani could comprehend the intention, Kahar broke the glass of a counter in the shop and then went to another shop where they broke a television.

The four then went to three other shops selling mobile phones and broke counters there too. When they entered another shop owned by Dhovaram Purohit for vandalism, Purohit intervened and was beaten up by them.

After traders came out and intervened, the four accused went away from the spot. The traders then quickly shut their shops and later decided to keep the market closed on Saturday to protest.

A rally was taken out on Saturday, after which Lakhani registered a complaint against the four goons at Raopura police station accusing them of assault, hurling abuses and causing damage. Based on the complaint, Kahar and Naval were arrested late on Saturday night while they are hunting for Dhruv and Kishor.

“We are grilling the two accused in our custody to know what spurted the vandalism. The shop owners also do not know the goons and the sudden vandalism surprised all the traders,” said a police official.

Title: CJ retires, Orissa high court stares at vacant judges’ posts
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

CUTTACK: Uncertainty over the filling up of vacancies in posts of judges in the Orissa high court looks to continue indefinitely as chief justice K S Jhaveri retired on Saturday without recommending any fresh names for appointment to the Supreme Court collegium. President Ram Nath Kovind has appointed Kumari Justice Sanju Panda as the acting chief justice of the high court.

The high court collegium had last recommended 10 names (four judicial officers and eight advocates) on May 7, 2019. But on October 3, 2019, the Supreme Court cleared the names of only one judicial officer and one advocate. Subsequently, the Centre endorsed the name of the judicial officer only.

The high court collegium, which recommends names for appointment of judges, comprises the chief justice and two seniormost judges. Chief justice Jhaveri had reportedly tried to hold collegium meetings to decide on recommendation of names on his last two working days. But the collegium meetings were not possible as both the seniormost judges remained absent on Thursday and one of them remained absent on Friday.

As the collegium failed to recommend names to the Supreme Court, the process cannot be undertaken for at least another six months. As per norms, the new chief justice cannot recommend names as part of the collegium before a lapse of six months from his assuming office.

The problem of vacancies in posts of judges in the high court has persisted as only three judges have been appointed in the past nearly five years. Consequently, the high court continues to function with 48 per cent judicial vacancy.

Though the high court has a sanctioned strength of 27, currently there are just 13 judges with the chief justice’s retirement.

Official sources said though 24 names were recommended by the high court collegium in the past two years, only three names were cleared by the Supreme Court collegium. And only two were endorsed by the Centre for appointment.

Persisting vacancies in large number have been creating difficulty in tackling the backlog and creating resentment amongst the advocates on matters not being taken up for months.

Title: SHO & SI found guilty of releasing illicit liquor truck against bribe, suspended
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bareilly: The SSP of Bareilly, Shailesh Pandey, has suspended the SHO of Bhuta police station Rajveer Singh, along with a sub-inspector (SI) Harikesh Singh, after they were found guilty of releasing a truck full of illicit liquor, after taking a bribe of Rs 2.5 lakh in October.

The issue came into light after the truck was caught by police of Bisalpur police station in Pilibhit district, when the truck driver revealed he had bribed an SI in Bareilly by transferring the money to the bank account of a person known to the latter. A probe into the complaint was carried out by ASP (rural) Sansaar, on the instructions of SSP Pandey. It found the SI guilty of accepting the bribe. The SHO was also suspended as he is responsible for all acts of officials working under his command. An FIR has been registered against both.

In the interim, the charge of Bhuta police station was handed over by SSP Pandey to Ravindra Singh. He also transferred 19 SIs and 103 constables from reserve police lines to various police stations in Bareilly as part of the order.

The incident was reported on the night of October 14 in Bhuta when SI Harikesh Singh was on highway patrol on Bareilly-Bisalpur state highway. He stopped a truck during routine checking and recovered IMFL smuggled from Haryana inside it. Instead of seizing the truck and arresting the driver, Harikesh demanded Rs 5 lakh from the driver, eventually settling for Rs 2.5 lakh. The driver spoke with the owner of the consignment and arranged Rs 1.82 lakh in cash, and transferred the remaining amount to a bank account Harikesh provided. The truck was released, but soon after it entered Bisalpur, adjacent to Bhuta, police again stopped the truck and seized the liquor consignment.

SSP Pandey told TOI, “Prima facie, we have direct evidence against SI Harikesh Singh that he accepted the bribe, which is why I have suspended him. There is no direct evidence against SHO Rajveer Singh, but he is in-charge of the police station, so he is accountable for his subordinate’s act. I have ordered filing of an FIR against both.”

TOI tried contacting SHO Rajveer Singh but he was not available for comment.

This is the fourth case from Bareilly in the past month, when cops were suspended for demanding bribe. On December 10, the SSP had suspended two SIs and two constables for seeking Rs 7 lakh from a village head in Aliganj. Two constables from the Dial 112 team were also suspended for demanding Rs 800 from a labourer for acting on his complaint. On January 2, the SSP suspended an SI and two constables for attempting to extort money from a mill owner, using CCTV footage as threat.

Title: Shortage of ICU beds concerns Vimsar docs
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Sambalpur: The Veer Surendra Sai Institute of Medical Sciences and Research (Vimsar), Burla, is facing an acute shortage of ICU beds. Though Vimsar is the biggest healthcare centre in this region, and has more than 1,000 beds, only 14 beds have ICU facility.

The shortage of ICU beds has prompted the Junior Doctor Association (JDA) of the hospital to express concern. “At least 10% of the total bed strength of the hospital should be for ICU patients. By that calculation, Vimsar should have at least 100 ICU beds,” said president of JDA, Sanjeev Mishra.

Mishra explained that many patients were referred to Vimsar’s ICU every day but were forced to go to private hospitals because of the lack of enough beds. “In private hospitals, the poor patients get denied government schemes. They are left to the mercy of god,” he said, adding that the union had drawn the attention of development commissioner Suresh Mohapatra to the problem.

Mishra also said the hospital authorities had the infrastructure to add six more ICU beds but weren’t being able to do so because of the absence of ventilators. “The authorities of Vimsar had asked the Odisha State Medical Corporation Limited (OSMCL) for the ventilators around three months ago but the machines are yet to arrive,” he said.

Dean in-charge and principal of Vimsar Braja Mohan Mishra said the tender process for the procurement of the ventilators had been completed. “However, we are yet to get the ventilators. We are hopeful that OSMCL will give us six machines at the earliest so that we can increase our ICU bed count to 20,” he said, adding that he had written to the government several times seeking at least 50 ICU beds.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Man diagnosed with rabies dies
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representational Image

BAREILLY: A 30-year-old man who was bitten by a stray dog some 40 days ago died on Friday evening while he was being taken to Lucknow for treatment.

The deceased was identified as Jhamman Lal Kashyap, a daily-wage labourer. According to his family, he was bitten by a stray dog when he was working in a field at Peepal Wali Gotiya village under Cantonment police station of Bareilly district.

Jhamman’s older brother, Suresh Kashyap, said he was administered anti-rabies vaccine after he was bitten by the dog. However, he could not say when he was given the anti-rabies shot or how many shots he had been administered. It is mandatory to be administered the first vaccine within 24 hours after being bitten by a rabid animal.

Soon he was taken ill and was undergoing treatment in a hospital at Rudrapur in Uttarakhand, where he was diagnosed as suffering from rabies , said Suresh. “He returned home on Thursday and his condition deteriorated. He was not eating properly and was avoiding drinking water. We took him to the district hospital in Bareilly, where doctors who examined him at the out-patient department said his condition was serious and referred him to higher facility in Lucknow.”

He added, “We were on way to Lucknow when my brother breathed his last in Shahjahanpur.”

The deceased is survived by four minor children.

Jhamman’s postmortem was conducted on Saturday. Dr RK Gupta, one of the doctors to conduct the autopsy, said, “The family claimed that Jhamman was diagnosed with rabies. However, we could not ascertain the cause of death during the autopsy. We have preserved the viscera sample.”

Title: Train gets delayed by six hours, Jual tweets his anguish
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bhubaneswar: The Puri-Hatia Tapaswini Express got delayed by more than six hours on Saturday due to technical snag, causing problem for passengers, including former Union tribal affairs minister and Sundargarh MP Jual Oram, who was travelling from Bhubaneswar to Rourkela. The delay upset Oram to such an extent that he tweeted about it and also tagged BJP colleague and railway minister Piyush Goyal to the post.

The train left Puri at 7.55 pm on Thursday and reached Angul at the scheduled time of 12.53 am. Trouble started soon after the train left Angul. It got stranded for over three hours after the engine developed a snag. It reached Boinda, the next station, at 4.55 am on Saturday. At Bamur station, the train stopped for a second time. This time it took more than tree hours to fix the engine problem. The train reached Rairakhol at 8.56 am, instead of its scheduled time of 2.10 am, a delay of six hours and 24 minutes. The train finally reached its destination Hatia, in neighbouring Jharkhand, at 5.35 pm, late by six-and-a-half hours.

Oram was travelling in AC first class along with P K Mishra, the Khetarpal Sampark Pramukh of RSS. Oram said the train got stranded for over six hours between Angul and Bamur stations. “I got down at Rourkela after the train left Bamur with the engine problem fixed,” said Oram, who reached Rourkela at 1.24 pm instead of the scheduled 7.25 am.

Pradeep Kumar, divisional railway manager Sambalpur, wrote in his official twitter handle that the train got delayed due to engine trouble. “Matter is under inquiry for further course of action. We sincerely regret the issue,” he added.

An East Coast Railway spokesperson said the train had to be stopped as smoke was coming out of the train engine. “We ran the train only after fixing the problem,” he said.

Title: Another market to go pedestrian-friendly in Delhi
Content:
Krishna Nagar market area

NEW DELHI: The Krishna Nagar market will get a new look from Monday with East Delhi Municipal Corporation (EDMC) starting to implement the project for pedestrianisation and parking management on a 1.3km stretch.The project includes restriction of vehicles on Lal Quarter Road (From Chachi Building to Ghondli Chowk) from 11am to 9pm, shifting around 441 vehicles parked on this stretch during the peak hour and a few neighbouring ones to other areas and allowing one-way movement of traffic on certain roads.“Now the movement of vehicles on Lal Quarter Road will be restricted permanently and to regulate the arrangements, we have engaged 10 guards. They will ensure that people do not park or drive vehicles on Lal Quarter Road. In case of violations, these guards will be allowed to arrange for towing of vehicles and informing the traffic police or corporation staff for challan as per norms,” said a senior EDMC official.Besides marking parking spaces using yellow paints, EDMC claimed to have added various facilities in the area. “We have installed benches, signage, planters, dustbins and ornamental lights after colouring these stretches. The idea is to make the place people-friendly,” said an official.EDMC standing committee chairman Sandeep Kapoor said alternative arrangements had been made for shopkeepers and residents. “Though many of these vehicles are unlikely to be there during the day, we have identified eight alternative sites for four- and two-wheelers on Satnam Road, at Central Park and along the boundary of a government school. Additional vehicles will go to the multilevel parking lot,” he added.“We will issue these vehicle owners stickers with the help of the residents’ welfare and market associations to distinguish them from the visitors’ vehicles, who will be allowed to park in multilevel parking lots,” said Kapoor.However, the implementation is going to be a challenging task as some traders, during the trial run, had opposed the idea of restricting vehicular traffic on the main commercial road. “People need to understand that the project is for their benefit and will only help to increase the footfall in future,” said a civic official. “We had several rounds of meetings with common people and the traders’ bodies, and expect full support from them. The project is being implemented on the direction of the Supreme Court,” he added.The traffic police will deploy the maximum number of staff to ensure minimum violation at the beginning. “They will provide assistance, including barricading the pedestrianised roads and ensuring one-way movement on connecting roads. Once the visitors and shopkeepers become habituated, the 10 security guards will manage the arrangements. They will be paid by the concessionaire who will run the surface parking lots,” said a civic official.EDMC will also talk to the market associations to start e-rickshaws from the nearby metro station to dissuade people from bringing their own vehicles. In the second phase, a parking management plan for the residential areas will be made.

Title: Ambheta village paints green landscapes for the high and mighty
Content:
Sameer Vashi

Surat: What is common to the world’s tallest building Burj Khalifa, Palm Jumeirah in Dubai and Nurai Island of Abu Dhabi? Apart from being iconic sites, they owe their greenery to a small village called Ambheta of Navsari district in Gujarat.For beautification and landscaping, these modern miracles have used trees, saplings and plants supplied by Samir Farms and Nursery located in this nondescript village of southern Gujarat.“Some of the trees for Burj Khalifa and the Dubai prince’s garden were supplied from our nursery. Even Kesar mango trees have been supplied there. We started exporting nursery products to Dubai 15 years ago,” said Samir Vashi, 44, owner of the nursery. “Nowadays, consumers ask for fully grown trees such as 10-year-old mango trees or coconut trees with fruits on them so that they can replant them. We grow such trees and supply them to end users,” Vashi said, adding, “We have supplied 3,000 such coconut trees for the Tiger Woods Golf Course in Dubai.”This fourth-generation plant nursery owner had never visited his family’s nursery before graduation. However, he has made his mark in the world of commercial landscaping.Even Bollywood celebrities like Amir Khan and Dharmendra and cricketers like Navjot Singh Sidhu and Yusuf Pathan have sourced plants from Vashi’s nursery. Corporate houses like Reliance Group also turn to Vashi for plants and saplings.Vashi’s nursery is spread over 150 acres on Gandevi Road in Bilimora taluka, some 60km from Surat city. The 300 workers here grow more than 3,000 plant varieties. The nursery also specializes in ready-to-be-replanted trees.Apart from big palm, coconut or mango trees, the nursery supplies saplings and plants for varieties like chikoo, mango, rose, mogra, lily as well as creepers like Madhumalti.The Vashi family has been running a plant nursery for 140 years and Samir’s father Anil received a lifetime achievement award from Indian Nursery Association in 2015.“The love for plants runs in our veins. Growing competition has kept us striving to achieve new landmarks,” added Vashi.Last year, Vashi started a new venture called Garden Art, which supplied nursery and artificial plants and indoor pots for beautification around the Statue of Unity, Kevadia.Samir said, “I visited an ITC hotel for the first time 20 years ago. It was my childhood dream to live in such five-star hotels and dine there. After watching the grand landscape and décor of that hotel, I decided to enter the profession full time.” He added, “Before that I had not visited our family nursery, but on my return, I went there and have stayed in the business since then.”“We don’t depend on export business and our focus is on the domestic market. At present I am exploring the possibility of importing a mango variety from South Africa which will do wonders in our climate,” Vashi added.

Title: Pilibhit: Couple accuses each other of killing 3-day-old daughter
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representational Image

PILIBHIT: The mysterious death of a three-day-old baby has brought the rift between a couple out in the open with each accusing the other of murdering the newborn. Police are awaiting the autopsy report before registering an FIR.

The police sent the body for an autopsy on Saturday after she was declared brought dead by doctors at the district hospital here.

On Friday evening, police were summoned by neighbours to a house in Kahshi Ram Awas Vikas colony near Eidgah under Sungarhi police station. They took charge of the body and took it to hospital.

When police went to the house, they found the couple, Mohammad Saqir Ansari and Phool Bi, squabbling over the baby’s death and accusing each other of murder. In fact, the uproar by the couple attracted neighbours who assembled at the house to find the baby dead. Someone informed police about the death.

According to Shaqir, he had gone to the market to make some purchases in the evening. When he returned home, she was dead. His wife was sitting by the body. He alleged that Phool Bi was mentally disturbed and had killed their daughter by strangling her. Denying the allegations, Phool Bi claimed that her husband had killed the baby.

Rajesh Kumar, SHO, said police were waiting for the autopsy report. Further action in the matter would be decided on the basis of the report’s findings, he added.

Meanwhile, a neighbour, Bablu, told mediapersons that he had offered to adopt the baby as her parents were poor and were incapable of taking proper care of the newborn. Shaqir, a rickshawpuller, was an alcoholic and spent most of his daily earnings on liquor. Shaqir had demanded Rs 15,000 for handing over the baby to Bablu so that he could use the money to get his wife treated for her mental ailment. Following the demand for money, Bablu dropped the idea of adopting the baby. The baby could have been saved had Sahqir accepted his adoption offer without demanding money, Bablu said.

Title: Sunny Leone, dosti & more used to ‘get support for CAA’
Content:
File photo

This is what BJP has been upto before asking for a missed call on #SupportCAA. https://t.co/spOJH2r915 — Abhishek Singhvi (@DrAMSinghvi) 1578148174000

NEW DELHI: 8866288662. That’s the phone number Amit Shah asked supporters on Friday to give a missed call to drum up support for Citizenship (Amendment) Act. Now several Twitter users, mostly from unverified handles, have been using a variety of dubious ways — asking for a date, offering free Netflix subscription, promising a free ride on a Merc — in their bid to make people dial that number.One Muralikrishna from Hyderabad posted on Twitter from the unverified handle, @MuralikrishnaE1, “Want free Netflix subscription for 6 months? Call 8866288662 and get Username and Password. Promotional offer, valid only for first 1000 callers. Try your luck.” Netflix India was quick to respond. “This is absolutely fake. If you want free Netflix please use someone else’s account like the rest of us,” the video streaming company posted from its official handle.Pawan Durani tweeted from his verified handle, “Those who want Virat Kohli to be nominated as the best cricketer of the year may give a missed call to 8866288662 #ICC”. He also retweeted and deleted later a tweet which said: Next two hours Sunny leone (sic) would be live, speak to her on 8866288662. At least one such user, Aanchal, who goes by the handle, @followanchal, is followed by PM Narendra Modi . She posted, “Akele ho? Mujhse dosti karoge?” followed by two red hearts and the aforesaid phone number.Congress politician Abhishek Singhvi took to Twitter to attack BJP. “This is what BJP has been upto before (sic) asking for a missed call on #SupportCAA,” he wrote around 8 pm while sharing several screenshots of users who had shared the number, while trying to pass it off as “jobs in HR”, among other things.BJP spokesperson GVL Narasimha Rao said many rogue elements in the opposition and anti-BJP forces in social media are out to discredit the party with cheap gimmicks. “BJP has over 120 million members. One call is enough to mobilise our supporters which has been demonstrated by our unprecedented success in 2019 parliamentary polls and huge participation of supporters in pro-CAA rallies all over the country,” Rao said.Another tweeple @__phoenix_fire_ wrote, “I am giving free ride on my merc…call…” A fun unverified account @WoCharLog joined the party promising, “Bina cheer phad ke bawaasir ka shartiya ilaaz. Call karein 8866288662 (Free treatment for hemorrhoids without surgery)” Some users claimed to have received Whatsapp forwards promising goodies if they dialed the number.

Title: Bareilly villagers protest against woman who filed rape compliant against 39 people
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Villagers alleged that the woman file a fake rape case after her husband was asked to pay Rs 2.5 lakh from the... Read More

BAREILLY: Nearly 50 villagers, including a few women, staged a protest outside the SP city’s office in Bareilly against a 32-year-old-woman of their village who had filed a rape case against 4 identified and 35 unidentified people in Bareilly’s Cantonment police station in December 2019.

The villagers alleged that the woman filed a fake rape case after her husband was asked to repay Rs 2.50 lakh borrowed from these 39 people. The protesters later met the circle officer Ashok Kumar and were assured of an impartial investigation in the case.

Earlier, the rape survivor had written to senior superintendent of police (SSP), Bareilly, Shailesh Pandey, claiming that the villagers are forcing her to leave the village after she had filed a rape complaint.

“Everyone in the village is aware that the woman’s husband is a drunkard, and that he had borrowed money from several people. He had promised to return the money after selling his property. But, when he sold his property and was asked to return the money, he used his wife to file a fake complaint. We all are ready to give our statement. Police must provide justice,” said Ajay Kumar, the village head.

Talking to TOI, SSP Pandey said, “The investigation is currently underway. We have assured them that the probe will be done on facts and proofs and ensured that no innocent person goes to jail.”

On December 17, the rape survivor met SSP Bareilly and filed a complaint where she claimed that she was thrashed and gang-raped by Amit, Shambhu, Chaman, and Pushpendra. She also alleged that these men also shot a video of the assault and later forced her to sleep with 35 others for the past one-year.

She had also alleged that one of the accused, Amit, stole Rs 50,000 from her house.

Based on the complaint, police later filed an FIR against Amit, Shambhu, Chaman, Pushpendra and 35 unidentified people under IPC sections 376-D (gang-rape), 392 (robbery), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt), 506 (criminal intimidation) and section 66 of the Information and Technology Act.

The rape survivor was later sent for medical examination, but none of the accused have been arrested so far. The police have not received the examination report as well.

On December 23, the survivor visited the SSP office and alleged that the villagers were forcing her to leave the village. Police later reached the village and spoke with the locals and asked them not to trouble her.

Title: ‘No change in our stand on CAA, NRC’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Odisha CM Naveen Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: The BJD’s stance remains unchanged on the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC).

A day after Kerala chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan wrote to 11 non-BJP CMs, including Odisha’s Naveen Patnaik , to mop up support against CAA, the ruling regional party here on Saturday said there is no change in its stated stand.

“As has already been stated by our chief minister, we support the CAA and oppose the NRC. There is no change in our stand,” BJD spokesperson and Rajya Sabha member Sasmit Patra told TOI on Saturday.

During a debate on CAB in Parliament, Patra and Lok Sabha member Sarmistha Sethi had sought to delink CAA and NRC while extending BJD’s support to CAA. Naveen had on December 18 announced that his party would not support NRC. In his letter, Vijayan drew the attention of CMs to the resolution passed by the Kerala assembly seeking the repeal of CAA on December 31 and requested them to consider similar steps. “The need of the hour is unity among all Indians who wish to protect and preserve our cherished value of democracy and secularism,” the Kerala CM wrote.

BJD insiders said from the time the Citizenship Amendment Bill (CAB) was introduced in Parliament, the regional party was very clear about supporting it as “the same has nothing against Indian citizens.” BJD insiders said the party doesn’t want to be part of the Congress-led campaign against CAA. As such people’s response to CAA in Odisha has not been adverse though minority community members have expressed their apprehension about NRC, he said.

Title: Computer lessons for specially-abled kids to begin on Monday
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bareilly: Specially-abled children suffering from hearing and speech impairment can learn how to use computers. Beginning this Monday, special computer classes will be held for these children, according to chief development officer Satyendra Kumar.

“I have personally met these children and some of them have a high IQ level. If they are provided with a good training, proper atmosphere and guidance, they can crack any level of competitive exam,” Kumar said.

According to the data available, there are 161 hearing impaired children in the age group of eight to 16 in Bareilly who have enrolled with the government-run school for specially-abled students.

Principal of the school, Balwant Singh, said they have hostel facility for 75 students. “As many as 35 specially-abled girls are enrolled at our school. They all are day scholars as we don’t have hostel facility for girls. Besides, we have 51 boys who are also day students,” he said.

Singh told TOI that they have a computer lab with 15 computers where the classes would be held.

CDO Kumar said two courses -- computer training and wood craft -- would be started at the school and students can register themselves in either course.

“These children will be given O-level computer training which is desired while applying for various government posts. We have roped in two private organizations to train the students and are also exploring employers so that these children can get a job as soon as they complete the training,” Kumar said. It may be noted that those who are 16 years old can be employed in non–hazardous jobs such as operating computers.

Classes for the first batch will start on Monday, the officer said.

Title: Oily deposits wash ashore at Miramar
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Panaji: Deposits of oily matter mixed with foliage and scattered in patches on Miramar beach had messed up stretches of the shore on Saturday, forcing tourists and walkers to negotiate away from the grease and dirt.

The thin layer of film had spread in linear patches and looked ugly with its dark colour, raising doubts among onlookers whether it was tar balls or coal residue mixed with oil.

The deposits did not seem to be remnants of an oil slick, as it had not spread in large patches but just scattered in small linear stretches with gaps every few metres. Foliage and debris floating in the sea had mixed with the filmy matter.

Goa’s coastline is usually plagued by the surfacing of tar balls from May onwards. Dumping of oil by rogue ships to empty their tanks or leakage from oil rigs has been attributed to the formation tar balls. They are blobs of petroleum formed due to weathering caused by churning of currents on high seas.

Some beaches, especially the long coastline of Salcete from Velsao to Mobor, has been severely affected by tar ball deposition in recent years.

But some experts shown photographs of the oily matter on Miramar beach declined to comment whether these are tar balls or not, expressing that it needs to be examined closely to determine its content.

Title: ‘No change in our stand on CAA, NRC’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Odisha CM Naveen Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: The BJD’s stance remains unchanged on the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC).

A day after Kerala chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan wrote to 11 non-BJP CMs, including Odisha’s Naveen Patnaik , to mop up support against CAA, the ruling regional party here on Saturday said there is no change in its stated stand.

“As has already been stated by our chief minister, we support the CAA and oppose the NRC. There is no change in our stand,” BJD spokesperson and Rajya Sabha member Sasmit Patra told TOI on Saturday.

During a debate on CAB in Parliament, Patra and Lok Sabha member Sarmistha Sethi had sought to delink CAA and NRC while extending BJD’s support to CAA. Naveen had on December 18 announced that his party would not support NRC. In his letter, Vijayan drew the attention of CMs to the resolution passed by the Kerala assembly seeking the repeal of CAA on December 31 and requested them to consider similar steps. “The need of the hour is unity among all Indians who wish to protect and preserve our cherished value of democracy and secularism,” the Kerala CM wrote.

BJD insiders said from the time the Citizenship Amendment Bill (CAB) was introduced in Parliament, the regional party was very clear about supporting it as “the same has nothing against Indian citizens.” BJD insiders said the party doesn’t want to be part of the Congress-led campaign against CAA. As such people’s response to CAA in Odisha has not been adverse though minority community members have expressed their apprehension about NRC, he said.

Title: Three injured in road accident
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Pilibhit: Three medical staffers, including two ANMs (Auxiliary Nursing Midwifery), sustained injuries when the bike they were riding on collided with a bicycle near Chaudhay Dhaba on Pilibhit-Basti national highway on Saturday morning.

The injured were admitted to the community health centre at Puranpur, but both ANMs were referred to SRM hospital in Bareilly in view of their critical injuries.

Chief medical superintendent of Puranpur community health centre Dr Chhatrapal said an ANM from Seramau sub-health centre Neeraja Gautam and her counterpart from Jograjpur sub-health centre were carrying vaccines on the bike of vaccine delivery man Mahendra Kumar when the accident took place.

The ANMs sustained head injuries and were shifted to Bareilly, while Mahendra was admitted to the district hospital in Pilibhit, said Dr Chhatrapal.

Puranpur kotwali SHO Ajab Singh said no FIR was registered in the matter.

Title: Central funds for restoration to turn the tide for Kapra lake
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Secunderabad: A butterfly zone, an inventory of birds and reptiles, and round-the-clock security are some of the measures envisioned for Kapra lake ’s revival. Residents were informed of the plans by forest officials during the first consultative meeting held on Saturday under the Centre’s initiative to protect wetlands across the country.

District forest officer, Medchal, Ashok Kumar said, “ Multiple agencies including the forest department, GHMC and irrigation department that will have to work together. Once other departments finish engineering work, we can proceed with plantation and creation of floating wetlands.” Kumar said that he would like to start work before the end of financial year.

Giving a tentative timeline of four months for civil work to be completed, VV Srinivas, assistant executive engineer, irrigation department, said, “We hope to finish work on bund-strengthening and drain diversion soon. Walking and cycling tracks will be developed."

At the meeting named ‘Wetland Mitra’, locals’ suggestions were sought over how Kapra can be rejuvenated. Residents suggested that storm-water be allowed to enter the lake through inlets and sewage water entering the lake be treated.

“We look forward to taking an active role in the revival work and in the maintenance of our Kapra lake. The colonies here are vested in the revival of the lake ," said Deepa Shailendra, who was at the meeting.

While appreciative of the Centre’s ‘100 days, 100 wetlands’ initiative under which Kapra is listed, locals voiced their concern over pending cases over a major portion of the lake.

“There is no water in the lake. While they are saying a Sewage Treatment Plant (STP) will be created to fill the lake with clean water, where is the space and funds for this plant?” asked Raju L Kanchibotla

A meeting on January 6 at Cochin will discuss wetland conservation. Officials say they will get a better idea on the way forward and availability of Central funds after that.

Title: Season’s first snowfall in Mussoorie & Nainital
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Mussoorie/Nainital/Dehradun: A thick white blanket of snow covered the state’s popular hill stations — Mussoorie and Nainital — on Saturday much to the joy of tourists who made a beeline for the hill towns to witness the year’s first snowfall in these places.

The snowfall in Mussoorie, which began in the morning, soon covered the entire town, including Mall Road and Landour. It intensified around 3 pm which was followed by a heavy spell for nearly two hours.

With the area near Mall Road receiving six inches of snow, many tourists could be seen enjoying the sight. A delighted Ajay Kohli, a resident of Kanpur, said that he was fortunate to be in Mussoorie. “My entire family is thrilled to witness snowfall for the first time in our lives. It is a mesmerising experience for all of us.” Notably, Landour and Lal Tibba reported about 8 to 10 inches of snow. Dhanaulti was under a white cover as well.

Meanwhile, the snow also caused delay in traffic movement with long queues of vehicles seen stuck on the roads between Picture Palace and Kincraig, and also Gandhi Chowk and Kincraig. Police said that they had to stop some tourist vehicles at Kuthal Gate, outside Dehradun.

Some of the tourists even had to leave their vehicles at Kincraig and go to Mussoorie in other vehicles or even on foot. In Nainital, too, there was a rush of tourists to witness the season’s first snowfall. Many tourists could be seen in Kilbury outside Nainital enjoying the snow-covered terrain and posing for selfies.

A number of places in the higher reaches of Pithoragarh, Rudraprayag, Chamoli and Uttarkashi districts reported snowfall as well.

Even though weather experts have forecast a let-up from cold wave conditions on Sunday, rain and snow along with cold breeze is expected to return on January 6. The weather is likely to clear from January 8 onwards.

“The weather will remain clear on Sunday. However, from January 6 onwards, Dehradun, Haridwar, Nainital and Udham Singh Nagar districts may witness hail and locations above 2,000 to 2,200 metres are expected to receive snow. We expect sunshine for a few days from January 8 onwards,” Bikram Singh, director of the regional meteorological centre, said.

Title: Survey to pitch for Unesco heritage city tag for Ayodhya
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Groundwork to pitch for coveted Unesco heritage city tag for Ayodhya, the land of Lord Ram, has begun. (File p... Read More

LUCKNOW: Groundwork to pitch for coveted Unesco heritage city tag for Ayodhya , the land of Lord Ram, has begun.

Ayodhya district administration has commissioned a survey to build a strong case for temple town.

Vice-chancellor of Ram Manohar Lohia Avadh University ( Faizabad ) Prof Manoj Dixit, who is also a member of the high-level team constituted to take the project forward, said: “Ayodhya is a confluence of faith. Ayodhya is as important to Hindus as Vatican is to Christians and Mecca to Muslims. The temple town has all the elements of a heritage city.”

“Ayodhya is the seat of religious leaders associated with Islam, Jainism, Buddhism and Sikhism which makes it extremely unique,” he added.

The initial proposal was prepared by Faizabad University and Asian Cultural Landscape Association, a body of landscape professionals dedicated to cross-disciplinary and inter-disciplinary study of cultural landscapes in both governmental and non-governmental organizations in 38 Asian countries.

The proposal has also been vetted by experts from BHU.

“Our contention is that the core of Ayodhya is a living heritage. It is a centre of both tangible and non-tangible forms of heritage and deserves to be a heritage city. Ayodhya fulfills seven out of ten parameters laid down by Unesco in its technical criteria for heritage city status,” said Sarvesh Kumar, secretary, ASLA, and a faculty member at Deen Dayal Upadhyay Gorakhpur University.

For example, in Unesco’s category of ‘Exhibiting interchange of human values in architecture and monuments’, the report said: “In (Ayodhya) city alone, there are around 2,000 Hindu shrines and temples, 100 Muslim shrines and mosques, five Jain temples symbolizing birth places (including that of first Jain Tirthankar Rishabhadev), five Sikh gurdwaras and Buddhist ancient sites. .”

Officials said field activities would begin as soon as the financial aspect of the exercise is worked out.

Content: Kangana Ranaut fans were in for a surprise on August 21 as the actress announced her arrival on Twitter. And within 10 days of her debut on the micro-blogging site, Kangana has clocked 1 million followers. Title: CM speaking language of Pak: Poonia
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Jaisalmer: BJP state president Satish Poonia launching an attack on chief minister Ashok Gehlot said that the CM is not advocating for Hindustan or Rajasthan, but is speaking the language of Pakistan. Poonia accused Gehlot of having a short-term memory and said that he does not remember what he had said earlier. He added that Gehlot is playing politics over the locust menace and the infants’ deaths in Kota. Poonia also added that the BJP has launched its public awareness campaign over Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA). He was speaking after a programme at Bhil colony, a colony of Pak displaced people. Poonia was in Jaisalmer as part of the party’s information campaign on CAA. He informed about the law to the people to remove their ‘misconceptions’.

Title: No constitutional mechanism for states to refuse CAA, says Himachal CM
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Dehradun: Himachal Pradesh CM Jai Ram Thakur on Saturday said that “there is no constitutional mechanism that allows states to refuse the implementation of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and deny lakhs of persecuted Hindu families their rights.” Thakur was in Dehradun to inaugurate the BJP’s outreach programme in Uttarakhand to garner support for the CAA which was recently passed by the Parliament.

Addressing the media, Thakur said, “The recent attack on the Nankana Sahib Gurdwara by an angry mob is the latest incident of the persecution of Hindus and Sikhs. But, the Congress believes in divisive politics and would oppose the law which helps Hindus.”

Defending the BJP’s stand on the CAA, Thakur said, “This law gives citizenship, not take away anyone’s citizenship as has been made out by Congress to create confusion. Our CAA campaign is aimed to expose the lie of Congress.” To a query about the reluctance of non-BJP state governments to implement the CAA, Thakur said, “There is no constitutional mechanism that allows the state government to invalidate and refuse the implementation of the CAA. The matter of the citizenship is exclusively the domain of the central government.”

On being asked whether all the states, including Uttarakhand and Himachal Pradesh, are willing to welcome new Hindu migrants from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan, Thakur, said, “In my state, there are not many Pakistani Hindu migrants but both Himachal and Uttarakhand would give citizenships by implementing the CAA.”

The state BJP unit in Uttarakhand has planned a two-pronged strategy on the CAA — one deals with awareness while the second one would be to facilitate the targeted migrant Hindu population.

BJP state president Ajay Bhatt who was present along with Thakur, said, “Our party cadre would cover all the 11,000 booths in Uttarakhand to bring awareness about the CAA and expose the Congress. Also, we have set up special groups to help out the migrant Hindus in all districts of the state.”

Title: Mid-day meal ration, LPG cylinder stolen from primary school
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

PILIBHIT: Unidentified men were booked on Saturday morning for allegedly stealing ration meant for mid-day meal and one LPG cylinder from the kitchen of a government primary school in Pajawa village on the intervening night of Friday and Saturday.

The theft came to light after staff visited the school in the morning, following which principal Sakshi Chaudhary lodged a complaint at Puranpur kotali.

“According to the basic education department’s rule, government primary schools are not provided with a security guard. The thieves broke opened the lock and fled with 40 kg rice, 30 kg wheat, a pressure cooker, utensils used in cooking food, crockeries and an LPG cylinder,” said Chaudhary.

Station house officer (SHO) Ajab Singh said an FIR was registered under section 379 (theft) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Title: 150 mohalla clinics to be opened today in Delhi
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

A mohalla clinic in Delhi (File photo)

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal will inaugurate 150 new mohalla clinics on Sunday , taking the total number of the neighbourhood primary health care clinics in Delhi to 450.

Officials said the state government’s mission is to ensure that every Delhiite gets free healthcare facilities within a radius of one kilometre of their homes.

“It has been our mission to provide high quality, free healthcare facilities to all residents of Delhi near their homes. We are now close to achieving this goal,” Kejriwal had said in October last year in a function organised near Sangam Vihar flyover in Timarpur to mark the opening of 100 such clinics.

Over the last five years, Kejriwal said, the number of mohalla clinics inaugurated is more than the number of primary health centres opened in the entire country. “Last year, the Australian government invited Satyendar Jain (health minister) to tell them about mohalla clinics, but he was not allowed to travel. Nonetheless, people still talk about our work all over the world,” he added.

Title: Sand mining complainant shot in Patna
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Police recovered the bullet-ridden body of one Pankaj Kumar (32) from Katarhi village under the Rania Talab police station area in Patna district ’s Paliganj sub-division on Saturday.

According to sources, Pankaj had lodged complaints with mines and geology department against illegal sand mining at his village, Janpara in Bikram block, some months back apart from filing several RTIs regarding the issue.

SHO of Rania Talab police station Indrajeet Singh said preliminary investigations revealed that Pankaj, who had gone to his maternal aunt’s residence on Friday, did not return home. “Residents of Katarhi village informed the police after spotting the body lying in a pool of blood along a road. Pankaj was shot in neck from a close range. An empty cartridge was also recovered from the spot. Pankaj’s body was handed over to his family members after post mortem at Paliganj sub-divisional hospital,” the SHO said, adding Pankaj owned a general store at the village. He said police have so far not received any written complaint from the family members as they were busy cremating the body of the victim.

Paliganj DSP Manoj Kumar Pandey said Pankaj used to post contents on his social media profile regularly against sand-laden trucks passing through his village, much to the inconvenience of common people and schoolchildren. “The spot from where the body was recovered is not the main road of the village. It’s a secluded place. It seems that someone close to Pankaj took him to the spot where the incident occurred.”

Title: Goa: A booze addiction case every two days at Mapusa rehabilitation clinic
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: The drug treatment clinic (DTC) at the North Goa district hospital at Mapusa , which also offers treatment and rehabilitation for alcohol addicts, sees at least one new case of alcohol addiction every alternate day.While the clinic currently has 400 listed patients undergoing treatment, experts say that the success rate of alcoholics overcoming their addiction was found to be higher among those who received support from family, friends and relatives. Apart from the 60-odd opioid users, the rest are all in for alcoholism.“We see at least one new addiction case every two days,” said Dashmi Mandrekar, a counsellor attached to the clinic who is alarmed about the growing number of people with disorders related to alcohol addiction. “Most are as young as 13 to 14 years when they start drinking. However, they seek medical help only after the ill-effects of excessive drinking start showing on their body and mind.”“Most of those being treated are in their early 30s. Our youngest patient though was a 14-year-old who was brought to the clinic by his parents after they discovered his addiction,” she said. After the initial couple of meetings, they lost contact with him for follow-up sessions. “It’s possible that his parents found it difficult to get him to the clinic,” she said.Depending on the severity of the addiction, a patient is admitted to the 10-bed ward reserved for treatment of alcohol-related cases. “They stay in the hospital for a week where they are watched for withdrawal symptoms and treated accordingly,” she said.Once withdrawal symptoms are treated, the patient is started on an anti-craving medication and deterrents. “The patient needs to visit the clinic once a month where the doctor examines their progress and adjusts the medication dose depending on the improvement seen,” she said.While a few succeed in beating their addiction is a year or two, in many cases, Mandrekar said, treatment continues for a few years, till they do not require to be on medication to stay away from alcohol.Self-motivation, experts say, is very important for success. At times, family members try hard to get the patient to the clinic, but success depends on the co-operation of the patient.The clinic’s medical officer and psychiatrist, Dr Ravindra Patil, said that sometimes, when family members fail to convince the patient to seek treatment, they even go to the extent of requesting clinic staff to forcefully detain the patient, which is not allowed.He narrates an incident where a mother, desperate to save her son from addiction, pleaded with the doctor to keep him tied to the bed to ensure that he doesn’t run away. “We had to tell her that we can’t do that and that her son needed to visit the clinic and stay on his own volition,” Patil said.To ensure better results, when a patient approaches the clinic or is brought in for treatment, a joint meeting is scheduled with the family. Here they are told about the importance of their motivation to help the patient stop consuming alcohol.Meanwhile, she cautions about the chances of addicts relapsing into the drinking habit. This, she said, is higher in the case of patients who are distanced from their families. “With adequate support from family members, some make a complete recovery. There are some who don’t even need to take medication to curb their alcohol cravings,” she said.

Title: UTC hikes fare of buses to Delhi, UP
Content: Dehradun: Uttarakhand Transport Corporation ( UTC ) has increased the fare of Air-conditioned, Janrath, and Volvo buses, which ferry passengers to UP and New Delhi.According to UTC officials, those travelling to New Delhi will now be charged Rs 15 to Rs 46 extra and those heading towards UP districts like Agra, Lucknow, or Meerut, will pay Rs 35 more.The hiked rates would come into effect from Sunday (January 5). Incidentally, the UTC move comes a day after UP transport corporation hiked the fares of their buses by 10 paisa per kilometre.The state transport body runs around 100 buses to and from Dehradun to Delhi on a regular basis.An average of 5,000-7,000 passengers travel in these buses daily. Similar number of buses are run on various routes to UP.

Title: NPR update in Bihar to begin on May 15: Sushil Kumar Modi
Content:
Sushil Kumar Modi

बिहार प्रदेश भाजपा कार्यालय, पटना में राष्ट्रीय जनसंख्या रजिस्टर (NPR)पर आयोजित प्रेस कॉन्फ्रेंस को संबोधित करते हु… https://t.co/Tojf0rZRFG — Sushil Kumar Modi (@SushilModi) 1578140691000

प्रेसवार्ता के मुख्य बिंदु https://t.co/EksYQummgU — Sushil Kumar Modi (@SushilModi) 1578141993000

PATNA: Deputy chief minister Sushil Kumar Modi on Saturday said no state can refuse to work on the National Population Register (NPR), adding that the process in the state will begin from May 15. He also ruled out any connection between the NPR and the National Register of Citizens (NRC).SuMo’s assertion comes in the wake of Bengal and Kerala governments halting all work related to the NPR. Taking the names of Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee and Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan, the deputy CM said, “No government has the courage to stop NPR exercise in their respective states.”He added: “There is a provision of fine and three years’ imprisonment for government officials who refuse duty related to Census work. Similarly, those who refuse their duty related to NPR, would face disciplinary action along with penalty of Rs 1000.”The deputy CM emphasised that NPR data would help in drawing up schemes to benefit people. “Questions like whether a person has a pucca house or not, or whether he owns a vehicle will help policy makers understand the needs and hence will help in formulation of better policies,” he told mediapersons at the BJP state headquarters here.SuMo said house listing and census will be done in Bihar in the first phase of NPR, which will be completed by May 28.When asked about Union home minister Amit Shah’s statement in Parliament regarding nationwide implementation of NRC, SuMo said Prime Minister Narendra Modi has clarified that NRC will not be implemented across the country and as PM, his statement gains primacy.Accusing the opposition of misleading, SuMo said people were first misled about CAA and now same is being done in the case of NPR. The deputy CM said the decision regarding NPR was originally taken by the UPA government in 2010 and in 2015 the data was updated by linking it with Aadhar. “Now only the NPR is being updated along with the Census,” he added.SuMo assured people, especially those from the minority communities, not to get influenced by the opposition. He said no proof will be required during the exercise related to NPR.The deputy CM also hit out at RJD and Congress for calling a bandh in Bihar against Citizenship (Amendment) Act, saying the state as such had no minority refugees from neighbouring countries, including Pakistan, Bangladesh or Afghanistan. He added that CAA would help the minorities of those three countries who had been facing atrocities.He cited the example of pelting of stones at Nankana Sahib Gurdwara in Pakistan. “CAA is to give protection to such people,” he added.On being asked about the resolution passed by the state assembly, recommending the Centre to conduct a caste-based Census, SuMo said he had made the same request.

Title: Sitarist Hameed Khan passes away
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

DHARWAD: Sitarist Hameed Khan passed away at the age of 69 at his residence in Malamaddi here on Saturday. He is survived by wife Fareeda, musician son Mohsin Khan and painter daughter Arma Khan.

A descendent of famous sitarist Ustad Rahimat Khan , Hameed served as the sitar teacher at Karnatak University’s College of Music located on the Karnatak College campus. Simultaneously, he was teaching sitar at Bharateeya Sangeeta Vidyalaya run by his family.

He had trained several foreign students who later joined hands with him in establishing the Kalakeri Sangeet Vidyalaya at Kalkeri village, off Dharwad .

Apart from teaching music, the school also provides formal education to underprivileged children besides providing them free food and shelter.

Hameed’s overseas disciples visit the school on rotation and guide children.

A large number of his disciples, music lovers and admirers paid their respects to Hameed at his residence.

Title: Ajmer dargah slams Nankana Sahib incident
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Members of the Sikh community protest against Nankana Sahib incident in the city on Saturday.

JAIPUR: Ajmer dargah has slammed the violence at Nankana Sahib in Pakistan by a mob. The body of Khadims (priest) have urged the hereditary priests of all shrines in the neighbouring country to publicly denounce the act by the extremist elements.

A video message released by former secretary of Anjuman Monia Fakhria, Syed Sarwar Chishti said, “It is terrible to read that how a bunch of goons have hounded the birthplace of Guru Nanakji for hours. It is unacceptable. Those seen in the viral video threatening Sikhs should be brought to justice.” Secretary of the Anjuman Monia Fakhria, Syed Wahid Hussain, said the incident was a disgrace to Pakistan who failed to provide safe environment to its minorities. “The Dargah demands that all Sufi shrines in Pakistan should stand up against the violent act by goons. Those who have threatened Sikh community are Satans,” he said. TNN

Title: Goa Medical College sees first kidney transplant of decade
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: The Goa Medical College ( GMC ) has successfully conducted its first live kidney transplant for the year, the 20th since 2011, on Saturday. The patient, who was suffering from terminal kidney disease , received the organ from his wife.

“The condition of both the patients is fine,” health minister Vishwajit Rane said.

The operation was conducted by a team of doctors from the department of urology and department of nephrology and anaesthesiology and was headed by Dr Madhumohan Prabhudesai (HoD urology) and Dr J P Tiwari (HoD nephrology).

“The patient was suffering from a terminal kidney disease,” dean Dr Shivanand Bandekar said.

GMC has been carrying out live kidney transplants since 2011 with 20 successful transplants done till date, including the Saturday’s surgery.

The tertiary hospital is yet to conduct cadaveric transplants to facilitate which it has recently set up the state organ and tissue transplant organisation (SOTTO) website to allow those in need of transplants to register on waiting lists.

In addition to this, a human leucocyte antigen (HLA) laboratory has also been set up at the GMC.

Stating that such transplants are a great boost to SOTTO, Prabhudesai said, “All 20 patients that underwent transplants at GMC are doing well. We hope to start our deceased donor transplant from this year onwards with the help of SOTTO,” he said.

“Through successful operations such as these, it is our vision to take GMC to great heights. We will conduct doctor trainings on organ transplants wherein our doctors shall travel to Spain. We will also hold annual symposia on organ transplants and orientation,” Rane said.

Title: Ashok Gehlot blames Centre for economy slide, price rise
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Ashok Gehlot

JODHPUR: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Saturday said the economy was going down as the central government had no knowledge about it.

“The Central government has no understanding about the economy. Prices have been rising in the country because of the policies of the government,” Gehlot said while addressing the inaugural ceremony of the National Tax Conference-2020 at the auditorium of S N Medical College.

Targeting Union Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman , he said even her husband had said that the state of economy in the country was not good and the government had no understanding of it.

Finance minister’s husband and economist Parakala Prabhakar had expressed concern over economic slowdown in October last year stating that the Narendra Modi government lacked strategic vision to address the challenge.

Gehlot further said the condition of the country is abject today and advised that the government should focus on core issues instead of issues like CAA and NRC.

“While prices of fuel and onions have been increasing in the country, Union home minister Amit Shah came here to generate awareness on CAA,” Gehlot said. He said majority was not always everything in a democracy and the government also needed to keep in mind the voice of the people.

Addressing tax practitioners and experts, he called upon them to work together for bolstering the dropping economy. “The country has been reeling under poor economy. Such phases keep coming and going. The efforts of improvement in GDP are imperative in such a situation and tax persons have a key role in it,” said Gehlot.

The chief minister also exhorted them to provide suggestions to the government so that they could be added in the next budget proposals.

Title: NH-58 project to be completed a month before deadline, says NHAI official
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The project involves a total of 23 structures, including bridges, flyovers and underpasses

HARIDWAR: The balance work of Muzaffarnagar- Haridwar section of NH-58, which connects the national capital with Uttarakhand , is expected to be completed by November 30, a month before the project’s December 2020 deadline, National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) officials said on Saturday. “Efforts are being made to complete the work by July-August. In any case, it will not be later than November 30,” said a senior NHAI official, who did not want to be named.

According to official sources, the NH-58 project, which started about a decade ago, involves total 23 structures, including bridges, flyovers and underpasses on the stretch from College of Engineering, Roorkee (COER) to Shantikunj, Haridwar. Of these, flyovers at Patanjali Yogpeeth and Singh Dwar near Gurukul Kangri University are almost complete. Construction of new flyovers is underway at Dudhadhari Chowk and Chandi Ghat. Work is yet to start on flyovers near Ranipur Roh and Premnagar Chowk.

Of the nine major bridges to be built on the highway, four are near Har-ki-Pauri. One will be parallel to the bridge opposite central control room (CCR), the second will run parallel to the cable bridge, the third will be on the new supply channel opposite the giant Shiva statue, while the fourth one will be near Sarvanad Ghat on old supply channel. Two major bridges at Bhimgoda and Dam Escape are under construction. Work on three major bridges at Ratamau, Ranipur Roh and Pathri is almost complete. The project also involves construction of underpasses at Sarai road, Sitapur in Jwalapur, Shantikunj and an area near Pawan Dham. One underpass near Patanjali Yogpeeth, two on Bahadarabad Bypass, one near Gurukul Kangri University, one opposite Kabir Ashram, near Singh Dwar are nearly complete.

Notably, work on widening the highway had initially been assigned to a company called Era Infrastructure. After the company caused inordinate delay, its contract was cancelled last year and a new contract was forged with Sam India Built Well. The new company started work in November 25 last year. According to the NHAI official, the project’s progress is being closely monitored by the central as well as state government. “The state administration is extending full support. Bills generated on monthly bases are paid promptly by the administration,” he said.

Title: Schedule for fourthphase of panchayat polls announced
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Jaipur: The state election commission (SEC) has announced the schedule of fourth phase of election to 1,954 panchayats to the post of sarpanch and panch on Saturday. According to the schedule, voting will take place on February 1 and counting will also be held on the same day.

The final voters’ list for the fourth phase of elections will be released on January 22. According to the draft voters’ list the total number of voters is 65,56,713 in which 34,38, 867 are men and 31,18,831 are women. There are 17 third gender also in the list.

The panchayat elections in the state are being held in four phases beginning on January 17. The second and third phase are scheduled on January 22 and 29 respectively.

Electronic voting machines (EVMs) are used for the election of sarpanches while ballot paper and ballot boxes will be used for panches’ election.

The election of panches to 1,954 panchayats comprising 18,914 wards were delayed due to the reorganization of panchayats announced by the government.

Title: Vehicles made before April 2019 can also be fitted with high security registration plates
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bareilly: Not just new vehicles, but even owners of old vehicles can get high security registration plate (HSRP) fitted on their vehicles, said the transport authority in a circular issued to Regional Transport Offices (RTOs). Everyone can get the advanced number plates installed on their vehicles by contacting their automobile dealers, said the circular.

Earlier, the ministry of road transport and highways (North) had made it mandatory for the vehicles manufactured on or after April 1, 2019 to be fitted with the tamper-proof HSRP.

Although HSRP is not mandatory for the vehicles manufactured before April 2019, RTOs have been directed to sensitise people about its benefits.

Confirming the receipt of the circular, senior assistant regional transport officer (ARTO), Bareilly, RP Singh told TOI, “The transport authority directed that all vehicles, including those manufactured before April 2019, could be fitted with HSRPs. Although HSRP is in not mandatory for the older vehicles, we advise vehicle owners to get it affixed, because it helps track lost or stolen vehicles. Thus, it helps curb vehicle thefts.
