The ministry had in 2018 directed that all vehicles should be fitted with HSRP. Meanwhile, in April 2019, a fresh direction was issued, asking RTOs to ensure compliance of the previous directions.”

According to information from RTO, HSRPs have a chromium hologram fixed on it using hot stamping method. Besides, a third registration mark, also a chromium hologram sticker, is affixed on vehicles’ windshields from inside. It has vehicles’ registration details and engine and chassis numbers, which makes the vehicle more secure from theft.

ARTO added, “As HSRPs are tamper-free, it helps track the lost or stolen vehicles. The HSRP and the third registration hologram are non-renewable and cannot be reused, because once taken out, the holograms are destroyed.”

According to officials, automobile sellers have tied up with manufacturing companies, and thus, one just needs to contact their respective dealers for the purchase and fitting of HSRP.

Besides, the registration certificate (RC) will not be issued if new vehicle owners fail to get HSRP fitted.

Title: BCG report adds fuel to an already-burning Amaravati
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vijayawada: With the Boston Consultancy Group (BCG) report proposing decentralised growth, the capital region continued to be on the boil for the 18th day on Saturday. Alleged police raids at houses of farmers created flutter in Velagapudi. Locals have alleged that police raided their houses at 3 am on Saturday and took away a farmer from the village to an undisclosed location and his whereabouts are still unknown.

Meanwhile, the police action against women on Friday led to a domino effect. Farmers resorted to a new form of protest on the day — they cleaned the shoes of police personnel and requested them to support them as they are protesting in a peaceful manner. They hit the streets from early morning, protesting against the BCG report. All shops and commercial establishments remained shut across the capital region following a bandh called by them.

Mandadam village has emerged as the epicentre of the protests with farmers taking out rallies and observing dharnas. Condemning police action against women, locals have decided to not cooperate with the police. They have decided not to provide drinking water to the police force deployed in the area. They asked them to remove their vehicles parked in front of their houses and shops and stopped police vehicles from entering their village.

A large number of farmers from Mandadam staged a sit-in at the Seed Access Road bringing traffic to a standstill for hours before cops moved them. Farmers from Tadikonda mandal also organised road blockades condemning police action. Women, meanwhile, at Thulluru village also held a huge rally to protest the police action against women.

Student unions also joined the protests of farmers on Saturday. They conducted rallies and dharnas across Krishna and Guntur districts. A protest programme by Students Federation of India (SFI) turned violent with police caning them at Dharna Chowk in Vijayawada. Students from various organisations held a rally at Tenali raising slogans against the three-capital proposal.

The Lorry Owners’ Association of Krishna district have extended its support to the agitating farmers. They, too, held a dharna at Dharna Chowk on Saturday.

Spokespersons for Amaravati Parirakshna Samiti said the BCG report is also on the lines of G N Rao committee. It appears that the decision to shift the capital was taken prior to the setting up of the committees and that they were later set up only to legitimise the decision, they said. They said the protests will be further intensified till the state government rolls back its decision.

Title: Goa: GST set to be part of Class XI syllabus this year
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Three years after GST was implemented across the country, a detailed chapter on the subject will be introduced as part of the Class XI accountancy syllabus for commerce stream students across Goa.

The Goa Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education (GBSHSE) has asked all affiliated institutes offering the commerce stream to introduce the new module from the academic year 2020-21, chairman Ramkrishna Samant said.

The move aims to help commerce students comprehend the newly-introduced tax reform, he said.

“GST is a landmark reform which has made affected the taxation system of India. It is an indirect tax levied on the supply of Goods and Services. GST replaced multiple taxes levied by state governments and the central government. It has brought us to ‘one nation one tax regime’,” states the module framed for higher secondary schools to implement.

Higher secondary schools have been informed of the decision through a circular issued on January 3.

The board has told institutes that due to the new module on GST, students will understand the meaning of GST, they will know the various indirect taxes merged under GST, students will understand the objectives and advantages of GST, besides learning the various slabs under GST structure. Students will also learn the accounting procedure for GST, the board has said.

The module to be implemented in schools states that the benefit of GST is that under it all taxes (excise, VAT, CST and service tax, etc) are subsumed into one. There will only be three accounts, SGST, CGST, and IGST. The tax administration between the state and Centre is easy to manage and ensures smooth functioning of business, the GST chapter reads

“GST taxes will be paid only at the point of consumption so there is transparency,” the module says. “Tax system becomes regular and certain. It removes the cascading effect, ie, no tax on tax even if goods move across state borders. Under GST, the tax is calculated on the value added at each stage of transfer of ownership. This helps in reducing the cost of goods to the consumers.”

Title: Lucknow CAA violence: 76-year-old former IPS officer gets bail after 15 days
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

S R Darapuri’s son Ved, 51, with his wife at their Indiranagar residence.

LUCKNOW: The phone of Ved Darapuri , 51, did not stop ringing ever since the news broke on Saturday that his father SR Darapuri, has been granted bail after 15 days.

The 76-year-old ex-IPS officer was arrested from his residence on charges of rioting and criminal conspiracy on December 20, a day after the city witnessed violent protests against new citizenship law. SR Darapuri was recently diagnosed with cancer. At his Indiranagar residence, Ved and his family could not hide their joy and relief when they received written bail order on Saturday evening.

Ved said his family could not wait for Monday when his father would be back home after staying in jail for 16 days. “Kids thought he will be back today itself but written bail orders came in the evening. We have waited for him for over two weeks, so Monday is not that far,” he said. Sharing the news on social media, S R Darapuri’s grandson Siddharth, wrote: “Keep decorating your castle of straw, gale of truth, sincerity and justice will blow it away.”

“I went to meet him in jail a week back. Rather than complaining about the behaviour of police or government, he asked how the city was doing and if children were fine,” Ved said.

Title: Made 2.35 lakh Atal Ayushman golden cards in 40 days: Health department
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Golden cards entitle people to receive treatment worth Rs 5 lakh

DEHRADUN: Health department claimed to have made 2.35 lakh Atal Ayushman golden cards through special camps in the past 40 days. These camps were set up exactly a month before December 25, 2019, the first anniversary of Atal Ayushman Yojana in state and also the birth anniversary of former Indian Prime Minister Late Atal Bihari Vajpayee .

In the review meeting of Atal Ayushman Yojana, Dilip Kotia , chairman of the scheme, informed that the health department has made 35.85 lakh golden cards under the scheme till January 4, 2020.

“We had set up various camps, which started functioning from November 25, to make golden cards for the scheme. The camps were opened across all districts of the state. Initially, these camps were to function till December 25, 2019, but now they will run till January 25, 2020,” Kotia told TOI. He said that the deadline for camps was extended to help people who couldn’t come to the camps. The official added that many people, who got stuck in villages of hilly region due to snowfall and harsh weather conditions, couldn’t come to the camp.

Earlier on December 25, 2019, chief minister Trivendra Singh Rawat had announced that the state has set an ambitious target of providing golden cards (which entitle people to receive treatment worth Rs 5 lakh) to 1.10 crore state residents under the scheme.

Title: Youth recaim, revamp, rewrite climate dialogue
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Name: Abhinaya Polaka

Age: 17 years

Supported by her photographer father, this class 11 student of Indus International Hyderabad took her first green steps in 2017. Armed with 63 saplings, she went around her community in Poddatur (Kadapa), and planted them hoping to see more trees in her colony, few years later. Today, Abhinaya has an NGO -- Guarding the Rights of Environment, Animals and People -- and is also in talks with government officials in Telangana to become a part of their afforestation programme. Last month, she, along with 10 other friends from school, cleaned out two tractors full of garbage from the famous Mypadu beach in Nellore. Her motto: Thing Big. Do Big. “We are at a very critical stage where taking small measures isn’t enough. Also, working in isolation will not help. The government and civil society have to come together to jointly fight climate change ,” said Abhinaya who believes that more youngsters must come forward to take charge of their future. “Unless we do something today to preserve what is left, we have to face the consequences tomorrow,” she added.

Abhinaya’s top 3 recommendations

- Take small steps towards zero waste management; make compost from kitchen waste

- Make it a habit to carry a cloth or paper bag while going to a supermarket/mall

- Don’t be afraid; we are never too young to do a good deed

Name: Asawari Bhagwat

Age: 16 years

Just around the time the world started taking note of Swedish climate activist and now youth icon, Greta Thunberg, city girl Asawari too got hooked onto the subject. Startled by news articles doing the rounds on social media, about the deteriorating standards of environment the world over, she vowed to do whatever she could to contribute to its preservation. “I decided to begin at school by recycling and reusing waste,” the class 11 student of Aga Khan Academy said. “As a first step we cleaned out our cupboards and segregated the paper that can be reused, from what was waste…The latter was handed over to government schools,” she added. Another important initiative she spearheaded was at the school canteen: reducing wastage of food. Together with other classmates, she ensured students took small portions at one time and didn’t have leftovers on their plate. An active member of the Fridays For Future (FFF) network – global climate strike by youth – she has also started segregation of waste at home and composting for her kitchen garden.

Asawari’s top 3 recommendations

- Keep tabs on the paper being used; if there is an alternative, don’t use

- Groundwater levels are very low; stop taking showers and use buckets

- Use public transport as and when possible; it’ll help curb air pollution

Name: Fariha Syed

Age: 15 years

Until two years ago, Fariha was just another teenager little aware of what was going on in the world outside. It was only when she joined Phoenix – a social group comprising young green activists – that she realised the seriousness of the conversations around climate change and how it could ruin the future of those like her. “I learned a lot and understood that it directly impacts us and unless we do something about it, we’ll have to suffer in the long run,” said the student of Villa Marie citing the Delhi smog as the perfect example of how the lives of people in big cities are at risk, thanks to environmental degradation. “Now, I have taken it upon myself to spread as much awareness as I can on this issue so that people can make more informed decisions,” Fariha said. Apart from touring educational institutions in the city to involve more youth in this fight against climate change, the teenager has also started making small yet effective changes within her college. One of them is – encouraging students to carry their own paper straws to the canteen. Recently, she also joined the fight against tree felling in Nallagandla, together with locals and other school students. “It is important that despite our academic schedules we youngsters make time for this…this is the purpose of our education, to make us responsible citizens,” she said.

Fariha’s top 3 three recommendations

- Keep a paper/jute bag handy; use it to carry groceries, vegetables

- Stop littering public spaces, use designated garbage bins to dispose waste

- Replace plastic straws with steel or paper straws; it’s a small step in the right direction

Name: Usama Hazari

Age: 21

Hugely inspired by Bhagat Singh and Che Guevara – both revolutionaries and eminent crusaders of social causes – Usama is among the frontrunners of Hyderabad’s youth movement against climate change. From organising awareness camps and discussions around the subject, to hitting the streets every time the authorities decide to put development before environment, he has been actively involved with it all. His strongest weapon: arts. “Instead of lecturing people, particularly the youth, I have realised that it is more effective if something is explained through a medium of performing arts. So, along with my team that comprises theatre artists, dancers, musicians etc, we do workshops in colleges where the issue is put forth through a narrative that students understand,” said Usama while admitting that the movement needs more young people to come out and get their hands dirty. “I had heard this speech by Hugh Jackman where he said that it takes only one generation to be great to change the world…we can be that generation, as we have that potential,” the student of St Marys College, another active member of FFF, said.

Usama’s three recommendations

- Spread more awareness among people around you

- Plant more trees; reject plastic

- Vote maturely; choose people who consider environmental issues

Name: Priyanka Kota

Age: 26 years

From the Nallamala forest closer home, to the hills of Uttarakhand, Priyanka has left her ‘green’ footprint everywhere. Born into a family of farming enthusiasts and brought up by grandparents in a village home surrounded by greenery, she has always been drawn to issues related to the environment. Hence, she didn’t think twice before joining a team of volunteers who went ‘plogging’ along the Tank Bund to remove plastic waste from the area or travel to Zaheerabad to participate in a biodiversity meet to learn about organic farming or even spearhead a campaign on seed ball plantation. Having spent a few years as an active campaigner of this cause, she feels that youth activists need to be more persistent. “Not everybody paid attention to Greta Thunberg on the first day. But she continued her mission, she was consistent. That’s what we need. People coming out to protest only when there is deforestation happening is not the solution,” said the MBA graduate urging people to be more conscious of the “climate emergency” facing them.

Priyanka’s top 3 recommendations

- Stop using showers; use buckets to conserve water

- Use local food rather than packaged food

- Organic waste can be very useful; segregate at source so that it doesn’t become toxic

Title: Togadia takes a swipe at Modi govt
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Roorkee: Pravin Togadia , international president of Antarrashtriya Hindu Parishad (AHP), who is on a tour of Roorkee and Dehradun, took a swipe at the BJP-led government in the Centre for its “lack of good governance”.

Togadia said on Saturday, “It is good that Ram temple is being constructed in the country [at Ayodhya in UP], but Ram Rajya is not yet visible in the country. Farmers are not debt free, youths do not have jobs, housewives are scared due to uncontrollable inflation, no security for women. When there are so many problems, then where is our Ram Rajya?”

The leader was addressing a group of his party workers at the residence of Umesh Pradhan, district general secretary of AHP, in Roorkee. On the issues of CAA and NRC, he said, “What is the harm in this move by Centre? But, I want to tell the government that displaced Hindus should also be settled down in Kashmir on priority.”

Togadia also announced a statewide agitation against the state government for setting up a Char Dham shrine board which he said was an attempt to “take over Char Dham and other temples in Uttarakhand”. “Can the state government dare to take over administration of mosques and churches?” he said.

Title: Moradabad: Buyer pours petrol on pump salesman after latter refuses to sell fuel in bottle, arrested
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

BAREILLY: An alert salesman saved his colleague’s life at Shri Sai Filling Station petrol pump on Kanth road in Moradabad on Saturday, after a local resident Danish poured petrol, which he had brought with him in a bottle, on another salesman, Ramratan.

Police said Ramratan had earlier turned Danish away when he had approached the petrol pump, seeking to buy petrol in a bottle. Enraged by the refusal, Danish managed to get the bottle filled at the next fuel station, and returned to teach Ramratan “a lesson”. The accused has been arrested and sent to jail.

The petrol pump manager D P Singh said Ramratan and Shamshad were on duty when Danish arrived with an empty bottle and asked Ramratan to fill it. “When Ramratan refused to sell petrol in a bottle, he threatened to set the petrol pump on fire and left in a huff, only to return within 15 minutes, this time, carrying a bottle full of petrol, which he poured on Ramratan.”

Seeing this, Shamshad, who was standing nearby, confronted Danish. In order to save Ramratan, he also poured petrol on Danish’s clothes, just as the latter had allegedly taken out a cigarette lighter from his pocket. On hearing Shamshad’s screams, other employees rushed to rescue both salesmen and catch the accused.

Inspector Naval Marvah, SHO of Civil Lines police station, said they have arrested Danish and sent him to jail, after lodging an FIR under Section 307 (attempt to murder) of IPC against him.

Title: AN EPIC, HUMANISED
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Being dragged into the royal court of Hastinapura by Dushasana was not the only instance when Draupadi was let down by her gallant husbands, who remained mute spectators even as the vile Kaurava tried to disrobe her in the full assembly. In Kannada writer SL Bhyrappa ’s novel ‘ Parva ’, which is a modern retelling of Mahabharata , after the Upa Pandavas – Draupadi’s five sons – were beheaded by Ashwatthama at the end of the battle, their fathers, the five Pandavas, sit around the bodies, albeit at a distance. They silently watch their grief-stricken wife roll over the torsos but don’t go near her to comfort her.

If it was ‘helplessness’ that prevented Yudhisthira, Bhima, Arjuna, Nakula and Sahadeva from rushing to the rescue of a humiliated Draupadi at the royal assembly, what is it that keeps them from hugging and consoling her at the war camp when her sleeping sons have been so mercilessly killed? After all, aren’t they their sons too? Earlier, when his son Abhimanyu was killed, had not Arjuna wept inconsolably, taking his wife Subhadra in his arms? When Ghatotkacha was done to death, had not Bhima brought his mighty son’s body from the battlefield on his shoulders, washing the blood with copious tears? But now? Why this indifference? Well, the fact is that the Pandava brothers are not sure who of them have sired which of those Upa Pandavas. Who knows whose father is who? Does even Draupadi know? So whom should they grieve for?

“Let go of that wretched Ashwatthama,” a disgusted Draupadi tells Krishna as she notices the apathy and mean-mindedness of her husbands. “Release him from captivity. Let him go. Today, not only has he brought me immense sorrow by beheading my sons but also shown me the darkest truth of my life.”

The stunning acuity and brutal practicality with which Bhyrappa unravels the minds and souls of the characters of Mahabharata make Parva stand out among the other versions of the ancient Sanskrit epic. Written in 1979, Parva is a watershed in reconstructing Mahabharata. It continues to be widely read and debated even after forty years of its publication. The 619-page book in Kannada is a literary gem, an epic in itself, as the author retains the characters and original framework of Vyasa’s Mahabharata but narrates the story in the most believable way.

Non-mythological approach

The author’s extensive study of the historicity of Mahabharata and social and anthropological aspects of the time have given incredible authenticity to the narrative in Parva. The novel is unique in a number of respects. It offers logical explanations to glorified exaggerations in Mahabharata, completely divesting the epic of its mythical, divine, superhuman and magical powers. Krishna here is no incarnation of god but a friendly, wonderful human being, a statesman with foresight, who intelligently counsels the Pandavas through difficult times. In Duryodhana’s court, Draupadi saves her modesty with her own courage. Devas, rakshasas and gandharvas are different tribal communities. Gandhari has only 14 children, not 100; the rest of them are born to Dhritarashtra through maidservants. The great teacher Drona is basically an insecure man, more concerned about securing a position for his son in the Kuru kingdom. ‘Dharmaraja’ Yudhistira often uses dharma as a shield for his inaction. Karna is bestowed upon a 15-year-old Kunti not by the solar deity Surya, but by the handsome sage Durvasa, whom she happens to ask out of curiosity ‘How are children born?’ Later, after her marriage, when Kunti to her dismay learns that her husband Pandu is impotent, she wistfully remembers Durvasa. Her co-wife Madri is fascinated by the Deva tribe in the Himalayas, who share husbands and wives. “Look at those women,” she tells Kunti in awe. “All of them roam around with babies on their backs! Not childless like you and me.”

“Sex and death are the most recurring themes in Bhyrappa’s novels. They reach their zenith in Parva. While the first is the basic instinctive drive that can turn humans into beasts, the second is the ultimate truth of life,” notes writer Uma Rao in her recent book ‘Parva – Aayama Mattu Ananyate (Dimensions and Uniqueness).’On this spectrum unfolds an intricately woven human drama of love and hatred, virtues and vices, noble thoughts and bloodshed. Kunti and Draupadi are the towering female personalities in Parva, with all their strengths, weaknesses, frustrations and ambitions. They are also the victims of circumstances, worst-hit by the evasive nature of dharma and changing definition of morality. With no holds barred, the author lays bare the sensuality of these female characters, thereby questioning the hypocrisy of the patriarchal society.

When all medications fail, Pandu, worried over the possibility of losing the throne to his brother Dhritarashtra’s heirs, invites five leaders from the Deva tribe to impregnate his wives, through ‘niyoga,’ a practice considered to be permissible to perpetuate the lineage. After Pandu and Madri’s death in the Himalayas, Kunti returns to the kingdom with the five kids in tow. When they all grow up, Duryodhana throws a basic question on which the war is to be fought: How can Pandavas, born to outsiders, be considered part of the Kuru lineage? This sows the seeds of doubt even in the mind of grandsire Bhishma about the legitimacy of niyoga.

War and devastation

How is it that the clash between two families for the throne of Hastinapura assumes the proportion of such a major war, encompassing kingdoms of the entire Aryavartha? The reason, as Draupadi puts it, is the weakness of the Aryan men for ‘gambling, alcohol, women and war.’ Besides being a great psychological epic and a social commentary of the bygone age, Parva is also an excellent treatise on politics and war. The novel opens with preparations for the war and progresses through a series of personal reflections of the principal personalities. In terms of storytelling, Bhyrappa broke a new ground in Kannada literature by effectively using the ‘stream-ofconsciousness’ technique of writing where the thought processes of the characters are often addressed to oneself rather than to readers, in fragments of sentences. One of the small drawbacks of the novel is repetitiveness at places. But this very style of saying things again and again also serves to help readers vividly picturize the sights and sounds of the settings, especially the battlefield of Kurukshetra .

After the bloodshed haunts the dark emptiness. The soon-to-be king Yudhisthira gets into a state when hundreds of women raped by soldiers come to him, asking him who will take care of their illegitimate children. A metalsmith goes about collecting broken metal arrows lying all over the battlefield to prepare ploughs and artefacts. The Pandavas have won the kingdom but lost their heirs. Abhimanyu’s pregnant wife Uttara, the last hope of the dynasty, delivers, but it is a stillbirth. At the same time, the wife of the metalsmith gives birth to a child, live and kicking, symbolizing the propensity of life to spring amid gloom, and foretelling the imminent fall of dynasties and rise of commoners in the time to come.

Title: Police file bind over cases against cockfight organisers
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vijayawada: As a precautionary measure to contain cockfights, Krishna district police have slapped bind over cases against 200 habitual cockfight organisers in the last few days. Apart from that, officials have set up inter-departmental teams with local revenue officers to crackdown on the organisers.

Speaking to STOI, Krishna district SP M Ravindranath Babu said they have not issued any permission for any cockfights so far. “We have been keeping an eye on cockfight organisers and bladesmiths who sell knives used in cockfight. We held a meet with the district collector and other stakeholders on December 27 and have began to take precautionary measures in a coordinated manner,” the district SP told STOI.

Last year, Krishna district police witnessed a 43% spike in the number of cases booked against illegal cockfight organisers. Elaborating on that, police personnel explained that they registered 914 cases in which 1,561 persons were arrested and Rs 8.32 lakh in cash recovered. Prior to that in 2018 in both Vijayawada and Krishna districts the number of cases against organisers rose up to 250% with 1,045 cases being registered.

Sources said that police are like to give permission for certain cockfights, which do not involve gambling or knives, keeping the cultural significance of Sankranti in mind.

Meanwhile, regardless of the precautionary measures, organisers continue to raise their fighter roosters, which are supposedly worth several lakhs. The common areas where cockfights take place in the district include Nuzvid, Gudivada, Kankipadu, Avanigadda and Machilipatnam.

Sources in the police admitted that several events will be organised, albeit low-key, on the border areas with Telangana like Nandigama and Jaggaiahpet with local political support.

Title: Two youths killed in accident in Shahjahanpur
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bareilly: Two youths died on the spot and another sustained serious injuries after their motorbike was hit by an unidentified vehicle on Bareilly road under Jalalabad police station in Shahjahanpur district on Friday night.

Police said three youths were riding on the bike when they met with an accident. Two persons died while the third youth sustained severe injuries. The deceased were identified as Rahul Kumar and Vishesh Kumar, both friends.

Rahul’s brother Ankur Tiwari said, “The trio was on way to Farrukhabad district when they were hit by a vehicle. Both Rahul and Vishesh died on the spot.”

Station house officer of Jalalabad police station Ravi Kumar said, “Locals claimed that the bike was hit by a tractor-trolley. We are yet to verify the vehicle. The bodies have been sent for postmortem. Their families have not given any complaint for lodging an FIR, so far.”

Title: Goa: To mark start of campus work, NIT to plant 1,000 mancurad trees
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Construction of the compound wall by the Goa public works department (PWD) is nearing completion at the land allotted at Cuncolim to set up a permanent campus of the National Institute of Technology (NIT), Goa. Work on the construction of buildings in the campus, allotted to the Central Public Works Department (CPWD) of government of India, will begin towards the end of January 2020. To mark the beginning of this work, NIT Goa will plant 1,000 trees of the indigenous mancurad mango variety this month, NIT Goa director Gopal Mugeraya told TOI.“There was a slight delay in starting work on the new campus due to a technical problem in the tender documentation. The work has now been allotted to CPWD and Rs 30 crore towards this work has already been transferred. Work will begin by January-end and phase one of the new campus will be ready by July 2021. We are planting 1,000 mancurad mango trees when the construction work begins, so that by the time we move to the first phase of the campus, the trees take good shape,” Mugeraya said.He said that the campus has also been designed to be a solar-powered one and will make use of water harvesting so that there is minimal burden on local natural resources.“The design of the new buildings is ready. Besides planting 1,000 trees of the indigenous variety, I am also seeing to it that not a single existing tree on the land is cut. We want to create a green campus,” Mugeraya told TOI.He said that there was an illegal structure in the campus land, which has also been demolished recently, clearing way for construction of the new buildings.NIT Goa became operational in 2010 and has sence been functioning from its temporary campus at Goa Engineering College at Farmagudi.After much delay, over 120 acres of prime land was finally handed over to NIT Goa in Cuncolim for construction of its permanent campus in mid-2017. The NIT was originally expected to shift to its permanent campus from the academic year 2020-21, but this target stands delayed by a year.The first phase of the project is estimated to cost around Rs 500 crore and is being funded by the central government.Mugeraya has maintained from the early stages of designing the new campus that he wants the permanent campus of NIT Goa to be an eco-friendly one. Stress is being laid on optimising resources as much as possible by using virtual laboratories, smart classrooms, the director said.

Title: Lucknow University’s crowdfunding legacy continues from birth to centenary celebrations
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Lucknow University

LUCKNOW: Lucknow University , which came into existence through crowdfunding , will again resort to it to not let its financial constraints hamper its centenary celebrations.

LU will soon be making a call to its former students and the general public to raise funds so that this historical institution can celebrate its legacy.

“We will be soon doing a centenary collection from our former students. We will also appeal general public to pay tribute to the institution which has contributed in disseminating knowledge for 10 decades,” said LU spokesperson Sanjay Medhavi. He said even a small contribution from the former students, who have excelled in various fields, be it sports, bureaucracy, music, medical and other to come ahead and help their alma mater.

LU began its journey as a small school in Canning high school in 1864. It was after 57 years that this school, located in palace Amin-ud-Daulah, Aminabad transformed into a university.

This was possible with the help of donations like land, personal bonds and money pooling by the general public and taluqdars.

Not only this, war bonds, which are debt securities issued by a government to finance military operations and other expenditure in times of war, were also given for the establishment.

The university administration is hoping for similar support from common people and its former students to help student fight its financial constraints.

Title: Protesters paint streets with anti-CAA messages in Kolkata
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kolam or alpana being drawn on the roads during Saturday’s rally

KOLKATA: As the mass agitation against the new citizenship act spread across the country, kolam and Faiz Ahmed Faiz’s, ‘Hum Dekhenge’, held a group of protesters together in Kolkata on Saturday. The participants in an anti-CAA rally from Gariahat to Garia drew kolam or alpana on roads as others recited Faiz’s poem, which recently raked up a controversy after students at IIT-Kanpur recited it during a protest following which, the institute set up a panel to consider whether the writing by the famous Urdu poet was anti-Hindu or not.

“Sab taaj uchhale jayenge/sab takht giraye jayenge/bas nam rahega Allah ka/hum dekhenge”: the lines rented the air as the rally started off from Gariahat in the afternoon. “The poem got dragged into a controversy recently after students at IIT Kanpur recited it during a protest on the campus a few weeks ago. We decided to chant the lines to show our solidarity with the students who protested against CAA,” said Tanmoy Ghosh of Bangla Sanskriti Manch. “The youth does not want a division on communal lines. They uphold secular values that the country has cherished for long. The need to raise a voice against divisive politics has been drawing youths to these rallies in large numbers across the country,” said Azhar Salim, a participant.

As the rallyists started walking, a group stopped and drew large kolam motifs with a strong anti-CAA message on the road near the Jadavpur University campus. Kolam, a form of art similar to alpana in Bengal, turned into a popular tool in anti-CAA protests in Chennai and protesters here seem to have taken a leaf out of their book. “Alpana is part of Bengal’s culture and every Bengali relates with it instantly. We decided to use it as a mark of protest this time,” said Pradip Goswami, a participant. As the procession proceeded towards Garia, several such kolams were drawn on the 10-km stretch.

Ichche Banerjee, a member of Mangal Shobhyatra—a cultural platform that was one of the outfits to organise the rally—pointed out a brush was the most powerful tool for painters and they wanted to use it when they registered their protest against the new citizenship law. “We do not want violent protests. But we need a powerful tool to express our emotions. It is unfortunate that we have to prove our citizenship after so many decades,” she said.

As the participants, some draped in tricolour and some carrying anti-CAA/NRC posters, marched on, people kept joining the rally from different points. “The new citizenship law affects each one of us. I have never participated in such rallies, but I decided to take to the street this time,” said Farhin Shayan, a member.

Title: Moradabad: Eunuch found murdered in home
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

BAREILLY: A 32-year-old eunuch, Sapana, was found murdered in her home in Chakkar ki Milak locality under Civil Lines police station limits in Moradabad on Saturday. Police suspect that she was killed two days ago. The body was sent for autopsy.

Upon getting information, superintendent of police Amit Kumar Anand also visited the crime scene and examined the spot. A forensic team also rushed to the spot and collected evidence.

The SP told TOI, “We have detained her companion Yameen (40) and interrogating him. He is the last person who was seen with Sapana.”

The police officer said Yameen had been living with Sapana for the past few years. Yameen, however, said he had a tiff with Sapana two days ago following which he left the home, said police. “We learnt that both consumed alcohol on Thursday night,” the SP said.

Police said Sapana was hacked to death. “On Saturday morning, when her friends visited her home, they found it locked from inside. They rang the doorbell but did not get a response. Then, they entered the home through terrace only to find Sapana lying in a pool of blood,” station house officer inspector Naval Marvah said.

An FIR under section 302 (murder) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) was lodged against the unidentified assailant.

Title: Techie from Chennai bells the CAT with 100 percentile score
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Rahul Gupta

CHENNAI: Rahul Gupta, a software engineer from the city, has scored 100 percentile in Common Admission Test (CAT), the results of which were declared on Saturday. Indian Institute of Management-Kozhikode (IIM-K) published the CAT results based on which admissions to IIMs will be conducted. Of two lakh candidates who wrote the exam, 10 scored 100 percentile with 238 out of 300 marks.

“I prepared for the exam in the last three to four months and am happy with my score,” Rahul Gupta said. He works in an infotech company as a software developer. Avinash Venkatachalam, another student who scored 99.32 percentile in the exam, said he aspires for admission into one of the top six IIMs. “I expected 99.6 percentile. The English paper was tough this year. I hope to get admission in one of the top IIMs,” he said.

Arvind Mantry, centre director of TIME Chennai, said the results were better compared to last year. “This year, candidates who scored 238 marks out of 300 marks got 100 percentile. We have many students with scores between 100 and 99 percentile from Chennai this year,” he said. The CAT exam was held on November 24. Though maths, data interpretation and logical reasoning were easier, students found English tough. The CAT paper had 100 questions — 34 in verbal ability and reading comprehension (English), 34 in quantitative ability (mathematics), and 32 questions in data interpretation and logical reasoning.

Title: Some 99 percentilers, who did Pune proud.
Content:
Siddharth Waghchavar (left) and Surabh Rathi

PUNE: Three city students scored above 99 percentile in the Common Admission Test 2019, results of which was declared on Saturday.Among the three, Siddharth Waghchavar termed the result “an early birthday gift”. An IIT Delhi alumnus from mechanical engineering, Waghchavar scored 99.97 percentile. “I turn 26 on January 5 so there are two reasons to celebrate now. I used to work, but took a break as I was preparing for CAT . This was my second attempt. In the first attempt, I had scored 99.84 percentile, but was unable to get admission to my choice of IIMs. Hopefully this time, I will be able to get into the top three institutes,” Waghchavar, who originally hails from Aurangabad, but stays with his parents in Pune, said.Surabh Rathi (24), a College of Engineering Pune alumnus, scored 99.88 percentile in CAT. “I did my bachelor’s in mechanical engineering and was working with an automobile company for the last two-and-a-half years. This was my second attempt. In the first attempt, I had scored about 97 percentile, which fetched me admission to IIM Indore. However, I wanted a place in the top IIMs. So I tried again and hope the score will be able to get me into the top three IIMs,” Rathi, who originally hails from Sangli , said.Harleen Virk (22) scored 99.83 percentile. With the better-than-expected score, she now aims to get admission in one of her dream colleges. Originally from Punjab, Virk recently passed out of the College of Engineering Pune in Computer Science Engineering. “I was expecting around 99.7 percentile. So, when I scored 99.83 percentile, it was a pleasant surprise. I have a list of colleges that includes IIMs, which I hope to get into with the present score. I just hope I don’t have to appear for the examination again,” Virk, who works with a financial consulting firm, said.Sandeep Kaushik, director of coaching institure Genesis Mentors, said, “Difficulty wise, CAT 2019 was moderate. An overall score of 158+ should fetch one a call from any of the old IIMs. For the new IIMs, a score of 130+ should be safe. Not to mention that calls are also subjective to the students’ past academic records and clearing of sectional cut-offs. We can expect calls from IIMs to start coming from next week.”Sidharth Unnikrishnan scored 99.84 in CAT to follow up on his 774 in GMAT. Unnikrishnan, who pursued his engineering from USA wanted to come back to India and pursue higher education and a career in India.

Title: Scientist, who helped in using first IVF technique, dies
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kolkata: Cryobiologist Sunit Mukherjee , who assisted Subhas Mukhopadhyay in using in-vitro-fertilization ( IVF ) technique to create India’s first and the world’s second test tube baby, Durga, on October 3, 1978, died on Saturday. He was 89.

“He was born on March 1, 1931. He died around 3.30am on Saturday,” a relative, Animesh Chakraborty, told TOI. Instrumental in having Mukhopadhyay’s name included in the Dictionary of Medical Biography, Sunit ran Subhas Mukherjee Memorial Reproductive Biology Research Centre inside Behala Industrial Estate almost single-handedly. He had a degree in applied nutrition from Grad School of Nutrition, Cornell University, USA and headed JU’s food technology department. He and Mukhopadhyay did extensive research on the role of food intake in prevention of infertility.

All his life, Sunit fought for his mentor’s recognition, from the time he had approached IVF specialist T C Anand Kumar, who, till then, was known as the “creator of India’s first test-tube baby”. Sunit made Kumar go through Mukhopadhyay’s handwritten notes and made him and the world accept that the title belonged to Mukhopadhyay.

On June 19, 1981, Mukhopadhyay committed suicide. It was thanks to Sunit’s pursuit that in 1997, Bengal recognized Mukhopadhyay’s feat posthumously. Sunit told the world that by the time Kumar’s “Harsha” was born in Mumbai on 6 August 1986, Subhas’s “Durga” or “Kanupriya Agarwal” was already eight years old, born 67 days after Robert G Edwards had the world’s first test-tube baby delivered in England. “Subhas’ method of assisted reproduction is the most preferred, worldwide. His use of human menopausal gonadotrophin (HMG) in multiple ovulation has the most success rate. He transferred the embryo after cryo-freezing and preservation to the next menstrual cycle,” Sunit had told TOI in an interview in 2018.

Title: Naidu dismisses Boston report, calls it ‘waste paper with a bunch of lies’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vijayawda: TDP supremo and former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu has ridiculed the Boston Consulting Group (BCG) recommendations on the capital and called it’s report a “waste paper with a bunch of lies”.

Speaking to media persons at the NTR Bhavan on Saturday, Naidu said the BCG has lost credibility by submitting a fake report, which was written by the ruling YSRC. He alleged that YSRC MP Vijayasai Reddy’s son-in-law, Rohit Reddy, is closely associated with BCG.

The BCG has failed to take into account the developments by the TDP and the space available to house the secretariat, assembly and the high court, said. He criticised the BCG for ignoring the fact that Visakhapatnam was rebuilt by the TDP government after it was devastated by the Hudhud cyclone. “They have failed to mention the available space in Amaravati for government and the development of Visakhapatnam. Thus, the report is a bunch of lies and was drafted by the Jaganmohan Reddy government,” Naidu said.

“A consultancy does what it is asked and it is paid for that work. The BCG, too, has done what the YSRC wanted and it was paid a fee,” Naidu alleged. He dismissed the BCG and the G N Rao committee recommendations and termed them as attempts by the Jaganmohan Reddy government to shift the capital from Amaravati. He said the government was dishonoring the commitment made to the farmers for their lands in Amaravati and a government has the responsibility to fulfill the promises of the previous government.

Coming out strongly in support of continuing with the earlier plan of making Amaravati the capital of AP, the former chief minister said that Amaravati was decided as the capital based on the recommendations of the Sivaramakrishnan Committee. He recalled that Jaganmohan Reddy and the YSRC had accepted Amaravati as the capital, when it was proposed. Moreover, he dismissed the government’s claim that Rs 1.1 lakh crore will be required to build the capital in Amaravati. He said that Amaravati is a self-finance city and the available land are assets for the government to build the capital and develop the state and accused the YSRC leaders of spreading lies about the capital.

Title: Pune: Crackdown on sand mafia, 23 boats set on fire
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Daund revenue officials on Friday set ablaze 23 fibre boats used by the sand mafia for illegal dredging along the Bhima river.

“We have destroyed 15 big-sized boats and eight small ones, collectively worth over Rs1 crore. Besides, we have seized 10 suction pumps meant to dredge sand from the riverbeds,” Daund tehsildar Sanjay Patil said on Saturday.

He said they were in the process of identifying the operators of these boats. “I have asked circle officers of the areas in question to identity the boats’ operators and submit a report. Based on their findings, we will plan our course of action,” Patil said.

The river passes through the Daund tehsil before flowing into the Ujani reservoir in Solapur’s Madha taluka. The villages of Vaklunj and Malthan lie along the riverbank.

The action followed several complaints lodged by the residents of these villages with the revenue department over the past few weeks. The villagers had complained that sustained illegal sand-mining caused a sharp deterioration in the quality of their roads.

“Hundreds of trucks illegally carrying sand ply on these roads. The roads are not designed to sustain heavy vehicular traffic. The subsequent deterioration of the roads and the riverbeds prompted the villagers to submit complaints to the revenue department,” a revenue official said.

Meanwhile, the villagers said the authorities need to take stricter action to curb illegal sand-mining in their areas. “Over the past decade, Daund has emerged as the hub of the sand mafia, with the demand for said rising consistently in the real estate market. Besides, the quartz of the Bhima basin is considered to be of a superior quality, boosting its demand in Pune’s construction industry,” another revenue official said.

Social activist Balasaheb Chaudhary, who has been pursuing the matter of illegal sand-mining with the authorities concerned, said the district administration needs to carry out this kind of drive on a regular basis. “These operators are financially influential. They purchase new boats within a week and resume their activity. The authorities must take sustained action,” he said.

BOX

HL: MODUS OPERANDI

Members of sand mafia buy boats from Gujarat

They locally fit suction pumps meant to illegally extract sand from the riverbeds

They use the boats to ferry the extracted sand till the river banks and later load in trucks

Extraction of one truckload of sand cost sand mafias Rs5000

Meanwhile, a truckload worth of sand might fetch anywhere between Rs15,000 and Rs20,000

Title: All eyes on SC judgment on rights of minority institutes
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Monday will pass an important verdict on whether the right of minority institutions including madrasas to appoint teachers could be taken away by the government by adopting a legislative procedure that aims to uplift the status of the community.

A bench of Justices Arun Mishra and U U Lalit will deliver its verdict on the issue while deciding constitutional validity of West Bengal Madrasah Service Commission Act, 2008, under which the appointment of teachers in madrasas was to be decided by a commission.

As per the Act, a Commission was constituted and section 8 of it says that notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force or in any contract, custom or usage to the contrary, it shall be the duty of the Commission to select and recommend persons to be appointed to the vacant posts of teachers. The case and the ruling can help settle an ambiguity in the law as while governments that fund or aid minority institutions can recommend guidelines for appointments, but till now, they have not been able to make the placements themselves.

The managing committee of various madrasas moved the Calcutta high court which declared the Act unconstitutional saying it is violative of Article 30 which says all minorities shall have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.

The HC verdict was thereafter challenged in SC by teachers who were appointed under the new law. Agreeing to hear their plea, the apex court granted them interim relief and directed the state government not to remove them from their jobs till final order and release them salary. As no appointment was done during the legal dispute resulting in more than 2,600 vacancies, the apex court in May 2018 allowed filling up of the posts.

Title: Two winners: HC grants injunction on swearing in panchayat president
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Madurai: Observing that it was prima facie convinced about a breach of rules regarding counting of votes, Madras high court on Saturday granted interim injunction on swearing in a woman candidate as panchayat president of Sankarapuram village in Sivaganga district after two women were declared winners to the post.

In her petition, M Devi stated that only two candidates including herself and A Priyadharshini had contested for the post. She said Priyadharshini is closely associated with the ruling AIADMK. According to her, of the 22,599 eligible voters in the village only 11,906 had voted in the second phase of polling on December 30. Devi said that the election officer/ block development officer of Sakkottai panchayat union had declared her winner after the counting of votes on January 2 around 8 pm. Devi said she had secured 5,871 votes and won with a margin of 62 votes while Priyadharshini had secured 5,809 votes. Officials handed over the certificate declaring her election to the post of panchayat president of Sankarapuram village. Since Priyadharshini created a commotion, the result was reaffirmed by the officials.

However, she was later shocked to know that the election officer had also issued a certificate to Priyadharshni declaring her as winner around 5 am on January 3. She alleged that it was under pressure from highly influential ruling party leaders and higher officials that the election officer illegally issued the certificate declaring Priyadharshini as winner. The petitioner thus moved the HC Madurai bench seeking to declare the second certificate null and void and unconstitutional under Tamil Nadu Panchayats Act and Tamil Nadu Panchayats (Election) Rules. She also sought interim injunction to forbear the authorities concerned from swearing in Priyadharshini as the panchayat president.

When the petition was taken up for hearing at a special sitting on Saturday, a division bench of Justice R Subramanian and B Pugalendhi observed certificate (Form 25) was issued to the petitioner on January 2 at 8 pm and now it has been stated that the certificate was issued wrongly. They said that it is now claimed that counting of certain votes were omitted before issuing Form 25 declaring the petitioner as the elected representative. “Even assuming that there was a mistake by the returning officer or the people involved in counting the counting process and the declaration was issued without proper counting of votes in Form 25, once the Form 25 is issued, the returning officer becomes funtus officio and he or she has no power to entertain the application for recounting as per the Rule 66 of Tamil Nadu Panchayats Act, 1994, which deals with the recounting of votes,” observed the judges while restraining the authorities from swearing in Priyadharshini as the panchayat president till January 10. The judges also issued notice to the state government and directed the registry to post the matter before the appropriate bench for hearing on January 8.

Title: Lucknow University to set up new panel to probe role of law teachers
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Lucknow University

LUCKNOW: After cancelling the third semester examinations of LLB on the recommendation of inquiry committee that found that some of the question papers were leaked, Lucknow University on Saturday decided to form another committee to probe the role of law faculty teachers and students in the leak.

LU authorities on December 11 had announced the suspension of two law teachers after several audio clips of telephonic conversations went viral in which they were allegedly heard dictating questions expected in examination to a woman student.

However, later LU deferred the suspension of teachers saying action will be taken after completion of the inquiry ordered on the leak, but on Saturday officials said the mandate of committee formed earlier was only to find out if the papers were leaked or not.

“As it is now confirmed that papers were leaked, a new committee will be set up to probe role of the teachers,” said LU spokesperson Sanjay Medhavi.

He said the police probing criminal angle and the committee to be formed will probe the academic front that whether the rules and laws of the university were compromised.

Strict action will be taken against students and teachers if found guilty, Medhavi further added.

Title: YSRC defends report, says North Andhra and Rayalaseema want development
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vijayawada: While opposition parties and farmers continued to protest against the GN Rao and BCG recommendations that Amaravati, Visakhapatnam and Kurnool be developed as cities representing three distinct capital functions, animal husbandry, fisheries and marketing minister Mopidevi Venkata Ramana tried to justify the decentralisation of administration and development on Saturday.

Addressing the media, he said the people of north coastal Andhra and Rayalaseema have on several occasions conducted agitations for their uplift but to no avail. “Keeping all these issues in view, all the committees have recommended decentralisation of administration and development,” said the minister.” Apart from Mopidevi, other YSRC MLAs — Gudivada Amarnath and Sidiri Appalaraju — too have come out in support of the report. The MLAs said the government has Rs 2.50 lakh crore debt and Rs 1 lakh crore would be required for the development of Amaravati. The BCG report has suggested that such a step would result in other regions not developing. tnn

Title: Kolkata: Vendor forages lottery tickets out of bin to see he won Rs 1 crore
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Sadek Molla

KOLKATA: Dum Dum market’s vegetable vendor Sadek Molla has hit the jackpot. Lady Luck almost slipped out of Mollah’s hands, literally, as he had thrown away his five lottery tickets in the dustbin. But as luck would have it, he scavenged through the waste and fished out the tickets to see he had won Rs 1 crore from one and Rs 4 lakh from four others.

The 36-year-old resident of Bhangor’s Kasipur and his wife, Amena Begum, are overwhelmed. “I can now send our son to a good school in Kolkata,” Amena said. Molla has booked an SUV for Rs 12 lakh.

On New Year’s Day, Molla bought the five Nagaland lottery tickets of the Dear series for Rs 6 each. On January 2, fellow vendors at the Dum Dum market told him he had not won any prize. To cross-check, he visited the lottery counter near his home and there, too, he heard he hadn’t won anything. Disappointed, he threw away the tickets in a dustbin. But the next day, while he was headed for market, the lottery seller stopped him and asked for his tickets. “I threw them away,” Molla said. But when the seller told him he had actually won the first prize, Molla dropped everything and ran to the dustbin. Bystanders looked on as he foraged through the waste. He finally found the tickets and jumped in joy. “I have won Rs 1 crore in lottery,” he said. The four other tickets, too, bagged Rs 1 lakh each. He will reportedly get the money three months later.

As the word spread, the manager of the local branch of a bank asked Molla to deposit the money in the bank. “I don’t have a PAN card,” Sadek told the manager. “Don’t worry, I will help you get it done,” the manager said.

Title: Botcha accuses Naidu of misleading ryots, spreading lies
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

State minister for municipal administration Botcha Satyanarayana slammed N Chandrababu Naidu on Saturday for spreading lies about Amaravati.

Satyanarayana, who launched several development projects in the temple city of Tirupati on the day, spoke to reporters on a range of issues, including the TDP’s ‘‘Save Amaravati” campaign.

“Naidu is desperately trying to instigate state government employees to stage protests against the government over the relocation of the capital. Naidu who was never bothered about farmers’ plight is now shedding crocodile tears for them that is nothing but a way to garner support,” he said. Satyanarayana recalled that several committees in the past, including the Justice Srikrishna committee and the Sivaramakrishna committee, had clearly underlined the need to ensure decentralised development of the state.

“The committees also suggested not to make Amaravati the capital as thousands of acres of arable land would perish. But Naidu went against the recommendations and tried to establish the capital in Amaravati and centralise development”, alleged the municipal administration minister.

“Naidu claims that his government spent Rs 10,000 crore for constructing the state capital and that the present government has to spend only Rs 3,000 crore to complete the remaining work. This is totally false. Naidu’s government had called tenders to execute various development work worth Rs 52,000 crore towards establishing the capital in Amaravati as part of the first phase alone. Why did you call for tenders then if capital construction can be completed with just Rs 3,000 crore more”, Botsa questioned.

Alleging that the TDP government had wasted Rs 842 crore public money on consultants alone, he questioned Naidu if the figures are not true. Reiterating that the government under the leadership of YS Jaganmohan Reddy was committed to ensure the development of all the 13 districts, Satyanarayana warned Naidu and his party to refrain from misleading the people.

Title: Anjaneyulu to take over as ACB DG
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vijayawada: In a major move, transport commissioner P Sitharama Anjaneyulu has been transferred and posted as director general of anti-corruption Bureau ( ACB ) in place of Kumar Vishwajeet on Saturday.

Viswajeet was then transferred to report to the director general of police at Andhra Pradesh police headquarters in Mangalagiri.

Anjaneyulu would also hold full additional charges as transport commissioner and Andhra Pradesh Public Service Commission (APPSC) until further orders. The chief secretary Nilam Sawhney issued the government order with this regard.

The decision does not come as a surprise as just two days ago chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy had conducted a review meeting with the ACB officials and expressed dissatisfaction over its performance.

The chief minister had even asked the officials not to be lethargic and that they need to be more involved and dedicated. He had directed them not to take leaves and ensure effective results within three months when the next review meeting would be held.

Title: Man held for selling banned tobacco products to minors
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Madurai: The Vilakkuthoon police on Friday arrested a 34-year-old man for selling tobacco products to school students in the city. Banned tobacco items weighing 500 kg stashed in a godown near Meenakshi Amman Temple was also seized by the police.

The accused was identified as Pravin Kumar Jain, 34, from Mudali Street.

He used to transport banned tobacco products purchased in Bengaluru through train and distribute it to shops around Meenakshi Amman temple. He targeted school children while selling a range of tobacco products in various sizes and prices.

According to the city police, the accused carried a couple of bags full of tobacco products in Odhuvar Lane.

On seeing a police team, he tried to run away. The team managed to catch him and took him the police station for an inquiry. Based on his confession, the team reached the godown belonging to him, where he had stashed all the tobacco products.

Apart from Cigarettes and Other Tobacco Products Act, he was also booked under a section under Juvenile Justice act for selling banned tobacco products to minors.

The police also seized five silver coins, which he had received from tobacco companies as an incentive for selling their products.

The worth of the seized products is estimated to be around Rs 5 lakh.

Pravin Kumar Jain was produced before a judicial magistrate and lodged in prison.

Title: Hosp employee found dead
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kolkata: A 26-year-old staffer , attached with a reputable private hospital located off EM Bypass, was found dead under mysterious circumstances at his rented home in Ajay Nagar. Police identified the victim as Shajimon Joseph Raj, an OT assistant . Though cops have ruled out the possibility of a homicide, they are not yet certain if it’s a natural death.

“There is a strong possibility of self-injection here. We were alerted by locals after which we broke into his ground floor residence to find him lying unconscious. We are speaking to his family. We cannot arrive at any conclusion unless we get the entire autopsy report,” said an officer. The Purba Jadavpur police are probing the case. Raj had good knowledge about administering anaesthesia and muscle relaxation before and after an operation.

Title: UPSSSC exam: 2 ‘Munnabhais’ from Bihar held
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: Responding to specific tip-off from an informer, sleuths of UP STF on Saturday arrested five persons and claimed to have unearthed a gang of solvers writing for examinees in the UPSSSC exam held for the posts of junior assistants on Saturday.

The arrested persons have been identified as Chandra Mani, Shakeel Ahmad, Jamal Ahmad, Nitish Kumar and alleged ring leader Qamar Alam.

STF first nabbed one Chandra Mani, who was going to take exam in place of Shakeel Ahmad in Lucknow. On his identification, Jamal Ahmad was nabbed while going to take exam in place of Nitish Kumar in Kanpur.

The four then disclosed about the gang leader Qamar Alam, who along with others was arrested from Vivekananad Inter College, Aashiana. Cops also recovered air tickets, two SUVs, 12 mobile handsets and Rs 51,000 from their possession.

ASP, STF, Satyasen said, “Alam has confessed he invited solvers Chandra Mani and Nitish Kumar from Bihar by providing them air tickets. They were also served with food and lodging at a five-star hotel in the city. He also said that a luxurious vehicle in their service round the clock was also attached.”

Each examinee was charged Rs 5 lakh, depending upon the post and the nature of exam. The money collected from different beneficiary examinees was credited to the account of one Ajit, a friend of Nitish, said the officer.

“The gang had changed the photo of examinee Shakeel and Jamal by pasting photos of Chandramani and Nitish Kumar for taking exam in their place,” added the ASP. Investigation is underway as to how many solvers did Alam arrange in how many exams till now, said the officer.

Title: Nagpur youths raise their voice against CAA, NRC without any political support
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Youth under the banner of Nagpur Youth Organization (NYO), took out a peaceful march under tight police watch ... Read More

NAGPUR: The city youths after two unsuccessful attempts on December 21 and January 2 finally gathered to register their first protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act at Samvidhan Square here on Saturday.

The 80 something youth, under the banner of Nagpur Youth Organization (NYO), took out a peaceful march under tight police watch without the support of any organization or political outfit. “We were expecting a bigger crowd. But we are happy that we could convey our message to the Centre,” said an activist of NYO.

The youths planned their first march outside VNIT gate on December 21, 2019 against CAA but the permission was withdrawn at the last minute for unexplained reasons. A handful of those gathered were forcibly evicted from the spot by policemen. On January 2 also, the protest was withdrawn as Union home minister Amit Shah, the brain behind the law, was in the city.

Expressing their anger against the suppression of dissent, youths read out poet Faiz Ahmed Faiz’s lines, ‘Hum dekhenge, laazmi hai ki hum bhi dekhenge’, and lyricist Varun Grover’s satire, ‘Hum kagaz nahi dikhayenge’, beside strong calls for ‘Azaadi’ from terrorism, poverty, unemployment, attacks on women, pollution, hunger, infant deaths, bigotry, social injustice, etc.

The youths slammed the National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) and National Population Register (NPR) on which the Modi government did a complete U-turn since December 29.

A protester said the fear of alleged police excesses were writ large on the minds of several youths who wanted to come but were apprehensive especially after what happened at VNIT gate and in several parts of Uttar Pradesh and Karnataka .

NYO representatives said, “This is just a beginning. We expected the opposition parties to do this but sadly we had to do their roles. Someone had to do it and hence we came forward. We aim to initiate a dialogue in society,” they said.

Alike the ‘azaadi’ sloganeering elsewhere in the country, these youths shouted, “Azaadi Azaadi Azaadi. tum goli chalao…tum police bula lo….garib mange, mahila mange, azaadi … atankwaad se, bhukhmari se, berozgari se azaadi.”

A group of middle-aged working Muslim women too joined the youths. “Are all other issues prevalent in the country resolved that the government is worried about this mission only? We are followers of the Constitution and we are here for all our brothers and sisters,” they said.

A woman teacher said, “Modi and Shah have been dragging the country 70 years behind.”

Title: State gives thumbs up for family politics in rural civic elections
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Madurai: Family politics is a hotly debated topic in every election, but take the just concluded rural local body elections in the state and people seem to have given a thumbs up to the trend. Be it Sivakasi or Kanyakumari, couples, siblings or parents and their children have won various posts in the unions together.

V Vivegan Raj, 38, an MBA graduate and Sivakasi south union DMK secretary, and his wife V Muthulakshmi have won the seats they contested comfortably. Raj contested the post of ward 7 member and his wife ward 6 in the Sivakasi panchayat union. ``I came into politics because my father was a DMK member and I liked the party, but now my responsibility has increased and I will do the best for my people,’’ says Vivekan who faced the union secretaries of AIADMK, DMDK and AMMK in a tough fight. He won on a margin of 180 votes while his wife had a more comfortable victory with over 575 votes. ``People only ask for better roads, water and street lights, which can be provided if elected representatives wish to,’’ says he.

In Kanyakumari, Sudalai Andi of AIADMK was elected president of Kulasekarapuram panchayat and his wife the panchayat union ward member. Sudalai Andi won with a margin of 423 votes while his wife Shanmugavadivu who contested the post of north Thamaraikulam panchayat union councillor won comfortably. In Kadaladi in Ramanathapuram, a man and his two daughters have won the local body posts. K Muniasamy Pandian, 57, former chairman of the Kadaladi union, contested the post of ward 16 member of the union for AIADMK. He also fielded his daughters, the elder one Muthulakshmi, 24, in ward 15 and the younger daughter Ramalakshmi, 22, in ward 4 in the union. All of them won hands down and the AIADMK also managed to bag 11 of the 25 seats in the union.

In Dindigul, a man and his daughter, both of DMK, emerged victorious. S Ulaganathan contested the panchayat president’s post in Pillayarnatham panchayat while his daughter Maheswari contested for the 6th ward of the Athoor panchayat union. Both of them got 1,200 votes more than their opponents. They credit the developmental activities in the union carried out by former DMK minister I Periyasamy for their facile victory.

However, it was a different story in Theni where a man lost and his wife won. Rajkumar contested the post of panchayat president in Ramasamy Nayakkanpatti panchayat in Uthamapalayam union and lost. His wife, Selvi of AIADMK, won the councillor post of ward 4 member in Uthamapalayam panchayat union.

Title: Pune: Crooks use email-spoofing trick to cheat College of Engineering of Rs 51 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The cybercrime police on Friday registered a case against unidentified fraudsters for using the email-spoofing technique to cheat College of Engineering , Pune (CoEP), of Rs51 lakh.

The incident occurred in October 2018, while a college official submitted a complaint application in January 2019. After investigating the case for several months, the police registered a case.

According to the complaint application, police said, officials of the college received an email on October 8, 2018, from an address that was strikingly similar to that of the college’s director.

The email contained details like the director’s name, designation and other pertinent information, and directed the officials to change the director’s bank accounts’ numbers in the college records.

The college authorities, under the impression that the email was from the institute’s director, made changes in the register and reverted to the sender.

The suspect(s), pretending to be the director, then instructed the college officials to transfer varying sums of money for different purposes, police said. “The officials transferred the money to the account numbers provided by the suspects,” inspector Rajkumar Wakchaure said.

Police said the college officials made payments till October 22, 2018, when a staffer contacted the director’s office to confirm that the payment was received. “However, the director’s office replied in the negative, bringing the fraud to light,” he said.

“We have furnished the details of the emails to the police. We will comply with the investigation,” a senior CoEP official said, declining to go into specifics.

The CoEP director did not respond to calls of SMSs.

Title: Chef, who fell into pit dug for lift, dies after 36 days in Chennai
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

A Selvaraj

CHENNAI: A 60-year-old man, who was a chef at some leading hotels in the city, died on January 1 at Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital , almost 36 days after he was injured at a construction site in Chromepet.

Police said the deceased A Selvaraj had in November last slipped into an open pit dug up to install a lift at an under-construction hotel site in Chromepet.

The man’s relatives alleged that police didn’t file a negligence case and instead registered a case of ‘accidental fall’ based on the complaint by Selvaraj’s son S Bhuvanesh, 25, of Kelambakkam .

A Raju, Selvaraj’s brother-in-law, said, “We have doubts over Selvaraj’s death. He earned a lot of good faith in the food industry.”

Officials at the hotel site in Chromepet claimed his entry into their premises was unauthorised.

Raju said, “It’s wrong. My uncle went to the place to attend an interview. Now, the officials claim there was no interview for chefs on the day he visited the place.”

Though Selvaraj was injured and admitted in a hospital at Chromepet, the local police didn’t register a case.

Raju said, “We met senior officers and demanded that police register a case. The senior police officers directed the Chromepet police to register a case, but they registered a community service register only on January 2 after my uncle died at the hospital and a first information report (FIR) on Friday.”

Speaking to TOI, hotel official Sekar said Selvaraj had approached him and inquired about a job opportunity as a chef at the hotel. He spoke to me the day he came to the place and later I came to know that he was rescued from the pit dug up for the lift, Sekar said. He added, “I met Selvaraj in the hospital and he responded to me when I called him ‘chef’.”

Title: Metro pillar’s frame falls on Sangam bridge, none hurt
Content:
A seven-foot-long portion of the retaining wall of Sangam bridge was damaged after an iron cage structure, wei... Read More

PUNE: A seven-foot-long portion of the retaining wall of Sangam bridge was damaged after an iron cage structure, weighing around 1 tonne, of an under-construction Metro pillar tilted and fell on it around 10am on Saturday. Nobody on the bridge or the work site was injured.Made of iron bars, the cage is the frame of the pillar.The mishap took place at the College of Engineering Pune (CoEP) end of the bridge. Soon after, the Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation (MahaMetro) pressed into service a crane, besides other machinery, to pull back the tilted portion of the iron cage structure. “The damaged portion of the retaining wall will be repaired by Sunday,” a MahaMetro official said.The MahaMetro said the cage structure was tied up with ropes to hold it together. These ropes were to be removed after the shuttering work of the pillar was complete. “In the case of this particular pillar, however, the ropes were removed before the shuttering work was completed. This caused the iron cage structure to tilt towards the bridge and eventually fall on about seven-foot-long portion of the retaining wall, leaving it completely damaged,” the MahaMetro said.The bridge has a walkway just next to the retaining wall. Thankfully, nobody was using the walkway at the time of the mishap, MahaMetro officials said, adding that the traffic movement was not disrupted due to the mishap as the iron structure fell on the retaining wall only and left the carriageway untouched.The site where the mishap occurred is a part of the Metro’s reach-3 segment between Civil Court and Ramwadi . The pillars are being constructed on the riverbed along the Sangam bridge for Metro viaduct, which will cross the river and travel towards the Regional Transport Office (RTO).A MahaMetro official said an internal inquiry had been ordered into the mishap. Besides, repair work has been started on the damaged portion of the bridge’s retaining wall. “MahaMetro has issued notice to the contractor for negligence and a fine has been imposed on him as per the terms and conditions of the contract and rules. We have also told the contractor to take utmost precaution at the work sites to ensure the safety of people, including workers,” he said.The MahaMetro also inspected the pillar following the mishap. It said the foundation of the pillar was intact and only the upper portion of the cage was damaged. “There was no need to demolish the pillar,” it added.

Title: Grads, PGs apply for peon, clerk posts in HC
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Nagpur: In a clear indication of alarming scenario of unemployment in the country, a whopping 96,845 candidates applied for the post of just 36 peons at the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court, and among them many are graduates, postgraduates (PGs) doctors and engineers. This was revealed by HC registrar Atul Shah, who interviewed some of the candidates, to RTI activist Abhay Kolarkar.

Though the administration refused to give classification of how many graduates, PGs, engineers and doctors had actually applied for it, Shah confirmed that there were many graduates and PGs, who were part of the interview process.

He said the administration do not have any specific data of applicants’ educational qualifications because scrutiny of all applications are conducted by MahaOnline, a portal of the state government. “We had published an advertisement on August 2 last year where applications were invited from the candidates having minimum qualifications of seventh standard cleared. Those with 10th and 12th standard passed with computer knowledge were given preference,” the registrar told TOI.

Sources in the HC, however, revealed to TOI that even many engineering diploma holders and other higher qualifications had applied for the peons’ and the clerks’ posts advertised by the HC administration. “We never anticipated such a massive response for a lower post. But, we conducted entire process very transparently and appointed all 36 of them. So far, we have inducted about 10 of them while others will be asked join eventually, as and when old employees retired,” the sources said.

The HC’s reply to Kolarkar queries informed that it has charged Rs50 from every applicant and collected Rs48.62 lakh from over 96,000 candidates.

Another RTI query by Sanjay Thool revealed that the HC administration received 42,725 applications for the 64 posts of clerks. It collected 48.42 lakh from the applicants towards application fees.

In reply to his query, the HC registry informed that the selection was done through stringent scoring pattern where academic performance was taken into account. After scrutiny, 380 peons and 640 clerks were shortlisted.

Further screening reduced their numbers to 122 peons and 151 clerks. Their interviews were conducted on November 6, the registry said.

Title: Protests after cops detain ex-TDP MP
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

High drama prevailed at the Anantapur rural police station on Saturday after former TDP MP J C Diwakar Reddy , who surrendered at the police station after obtaining anticipatory bail in connection with a case slapped against him for passing derogatory remarks against cops recently, was detained by for several hours.

It may be recalled that on Dec 18, Diwakar Reddy had passed derogatory remarks against the police department in the presence of TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu . “The police are dancing to the tunes of ruling party leaders even at the village level.
