But mark my words, this time when TDP comes back to power, we will make those cops lick our boots. We will also slap cases against all of them,” he had said.

The comments drew flak from various quarters and a complaint was lodged against him by Anantapur district police officers’ association president Triloknath, following which Anantapur rural police registered a case against Diwakar Reddy under sections 153 and 506 of IPC.

On Saturday, the former MP, who managed to obtain anticipatory bail from a local court in Anantapur, walked into the rural police station along with his lawyer and surrendered himself. As the court had granted bail on his personal surety along with five other sureties, Diwakar Reddy submitted his bail papers along with the sureties to the cops.

But as hours passed by and he did not come out of the police station, his followers led by TDP’s Anantapur president BK Parthasaradhi staged protests in front of the police station and raised slogans against the government and the police department.

Anantapur SP B Satya Yesubabu rubbished the claims. “The department was following due procedures,” said Yesubabu. Diwakar Reddy was finally released in the evening.

Title: Dalit who raised anti-Modi slogans now heads Samajwadi Party wing
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

LUCKNOW: A little less than four years ago, he shouted anti-Modi slogans. Today, he holds a responsible post of a state president of Lohia Vahini, Samajwadi Party ’s auxiliary organisation. Meet 35-year-old Ram Karan Nirmal, a master of laws (LLM) gold medalist who raised anti-Modi slogans in the presence of the prime minister at Babsaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar University’s convocation in January 2016 to protest against the death of Dalit scholar Rohith Vemula.

Happy with his new job, Nirmal, a native of Charwa village in UP’s Kaushambi district says, “I was preparing for judicial services in New Delhi when the news of Rohith’s suicide hit the nation. I was aghast with the incident. A student was forced to end his life due to injustice and indignity. This was unacceptable and I decided to be part of the protest.”

During the protest, Nirmal was among the many who were detained by the police. “It was very cold but the police charged the protesters with water cannons,” he recalls. Amid the protest, he got information of the PM’s visit to BBAU for its convocation. “I was also told that he (PM) will be handing gold medals to toppers,” Nirmal says.

And without giving a thought, this Dalit youth who was a topper in his LLM courses came to Lucknow. This, he says was the right place to stage a protest against discrimination shown to Dalits. Seconds after the PM started with his convocation address, Nirmal along with his Dalit friend Amrendra Arya shouted, ‘Modi Go Back’, and ‘Rohith Vemula hum sharminda hai, tere qatil abhi zinda hai’ (Rohith Vemula we are ashamed, your murderers are still alive) slogans.

“We were successful. How could a PM keep mum on a suicide of a student due to discrimination? This was my concern for the society,” asserts Nirmal, who was taken into preventive custody by the police, and his degree was held back by the university for a few days.

Title: Krishna district cops adopt areas to prevent child labour
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vijayawada: Krishna district police as part of their Operation Muskaan rescued 331 children , including 90 girls, on Saturday. Meanwhile, in a bid to achieve the goals of the operation, which seeks to rescue and rehabilitate children, Krishna district police adopted three areas, where child-labour is rampant, to ensure their.

Speaking to STOI, ASP M Sathi Babu explained that they have decided to adopt three specific areas where kids either beg or are engaged in child labour. These include — railway station, Drivers’ Colony and Narayanapuram. “While the district SP (M Ravindranath Babu) is looking into Narayanapuram area, I will take care of Drivers Colony and the Machilipatnam DSP Mehboob Baasha will be looking after railway station area,” Babu told STOI.

As part of the project, police officials said they would boost every-day surveillance in these areas where they have arranged for means of education for street kids, acquainted with the last few Operation Muskaan drives. Local NGOs, women and child welfare department and local Shakti Teams will help the police in it. Officials said that they would ensure that all the children get education as they have noticed a large number of children, whom they had rescued in the past, still engaged in child labour.

On the other hand, Vijayawada commissionerate police too conducted the same operation within the city limits and rescued 128 children. Interestingly, they also rescued around 12 migrant kids from Rajasthan. As per data collected under Operation Muskaan, usually, most of the children from other states, who were rescued, who used to either work or beg in Vijayawada would either be from Bihar or Uttar Pradesh.

City police commissioner CH Dwaraka Tirumala Rao addressed the media and said that the parents and the children would be counselled. He said that each police station has implemented Balala Mitra, a friendly police initiative for kids and that they can approach the police any time for any problem.

Title: Maharashtra: Second rake on track, trials begin with shunting engine
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The second rake on the Metro viaduct near Pimpri

PUNE: The Maharashtra Metro Rail Corporation Limited (MahaMetro) has loaded the second rake on the Metro viaduct near Pimpri to start the preliminary trials and inspections, days after the first rake was placed on the tracks on December 30.

As the MahaMetro is yet to provide power supply on the track, a battery-operated shunting engine , which can pull one rake easily, has been introduced for moving the rakes on the track. “During the preliminary trials, MahaMetro will check various parameters like alignment of tracks, vibrations generated by the movement of rakes as well as their impact and rake positioning on the track,” a MahaMetro official said.

Of the two rakes, one plied on about 1km stretch in the last two days. A senior MahaMetro official said, “There is no fixed schedule for running of the rakes. These trials are meant to ensure accuracy and will go on for the next few days.”

The rakes were lifted to the Sant Tukaramnagar Metro station. The MahaMetro plans to introduce Metro operations between Sant Tukaramnagar and Phugewadi stations on priority. However, testing and trials of the rakes are planned on the entire stretch, which begins from Pimpri.

MahaMetro officials said cable manufacturing for power supply had already started in the yard. “The installation of the cables is expected to begin next week,” an official said.

He said different agencies were working simultaneously on the viaduct and at the Metro stations to expedite the work. “The work on dedicated power sub-station at Vallabhnagar has been completed. Another sub-station is coming up at Vanaz,” the official added.

Title: Reprieve for Fadnavis, CJM adjourns hearing till Jan 24
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Nagpur: Leader of opposition in state assembly Devendra Fadnavis on Saturday received a reprieve from the chief judicial magistrate’s (CJM) court after his application for adjournment of hearing in a case filed by lawyer Satish Uke was accepted.

The CJM has now directed Fadnavis’s counsel Uday Dable to make him appear in the court on January 24 for replying to the summons issued to him. This is second reprieve for the South West Nagpur MLA, who was earlier allowed to skip the court proceedings on December 4, when he was asked to appear by JMFC court.

Uke had accused Fadnavis of suppressing information about two pending criminal cases while filing affidavit for nomination form during 2014 assembly polls.

After this case was remanded back by the Supreme Court to trial court, JMFC judge SB Mehta issued summons to the five-time MLA on November 4, asking him to remain present on December 4 to defend charges against him.

After Dable sought the ex-chief minister’s exemption from appearance citing “unavoidable circumstances” due to winter session of state legislature, the hearing was adjourned to January 4.

On Saturday, Dable submitted an application stating that being a leader of opposition Fadnavis was touring to meet hailstorm affected farmers in the state. Moreover, he was also touring various places for forthcoming zilla parishad polls and therefore, he couldn’t attend the hearing.

His contentions were strongly opposed by applicant Uke stating that Fadnavis was misleading the court and wasting its time. He even moved an application for producing the former CM in the court with police’s help. But the CJM allowed Dable’s application.

In his complaint, Uke had mentioned about two criminal cases in 1996 and 1998 pertaining to Fadnavis, where he was accused of cheating and forgery. The latter had furnished PR bond of Rs3,000 in one of them at that time.

Uke’s complaint was dismissed on September 7, 2015, however, the sessions court remanded back the case to same court for reconsideration.

Fadnavis later filed an appeal in Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court which granted him “clean chit” on May 3, 2018, by upholding the JMFC’s order of September 2015 and quashing session court’s verdict.

After Uke challenged HC’s orders in the apex court, it remanded back the case to JMFC on October 1 to ascertain whether a case for prosecution is made out or not.

Title: Terai pea growers claim losses due to Dec rainfall
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Rudrapur: Last month’s heavy rainfall in Terai region is believed to have damaged some perishable crops such as peas. Farmers in the region said that 1,214 metric tonnes of peas is estimated to have been damaged in Udham Singh Nagar district although the main Rabi crop of wheat may survive the inclement weather.

“Mustard was affected by heavy rain and strong gust of winds in the district. Pea crop has incurred a loss of more than Rs 1.2 crore for farmers of Kashipur, Sitarganj and Dineshpur. We have met the district magistrate for analysing the crop damage and compensation distribution,” Arun Sharma, president of Kisan Sangh, said.

HC Tiwari, the district’s chief horticulture officer, told TOI, “Pea growers have suffered losses as their crops are affected by rain. The district grows pea crops in 3,599 hectare of land. This season, heavy rain has damaged pea crops everywhere in the district.” The effect of fewer yields is already reflecting in the market where peas are selling at Rs 30 per kg as compared to Rs 10-Rs 15 per kg during the same period last year. “Preliminary reports of damage to crops, mainly perishable, indicate a loss of Rs 12 lakh, but it will take a few more days to assess the exact amount of loss,” Tiwari said.

He pointed out that “wheat is expected to gain from precipitation, though there could be a marginal yield loss in places affected by hailstorm.” “Since wheat crop did not attain height yet, it remains unaffected from the wind and rain,” Tiwari said.

Title: Man, 30, murders history-sheeter over money dispute
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Madurai: A history-sheeter from Tuticorin was stabbed to death by a 30-year-old man who was staying with him temporarily in Kodaikanal in Dindigul district on Friday night. Inquiries revealed that the murder took place due to a dispute related to money transaction between the two.

The Kodaikanal police have registered a case and arrested the accused. The deceased was identified as Johnson Arockiaraj, 58, from Thiraviyapuram in Tuticorin. There were a few cases pending against the deceased including a murder case in Tuticorin. He was looking after a toilet that belongs to the Kodaikanal municipality.

According to police sources, Johnson’s friend, Albert had taken the contract of the toilet. However, Albert was not able to manage it and hence had leased it to Johnson. Meanwhile, Johnson had taken a few lakh rupees from Saravanan, from State Bank Colony in Tuticorin to pay Albert.

As Johnson failed to return the money, Saravanan came to Kodaikanal to collect money from Johnson and stayed with him. Meanwhile, the duo consumed liquor on Friday night. Soon after, a dispute broke out between them in connection with the money and Saravanan in a fit of rage took a knife and stabbed Johnson. As he died on the spot, Saravanan, 30, went to the Kodaikanal police station and surrendered.tnn

Title: Migratory birds face starvation as water turns toxic at Uppalapadu sanctuary
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Guntur: At the Uppalapadu Bird Sanctuary on the outskirts of Guntur city, starvation deaths among migratory birds have become a common ocurrence. With the onset of winter every year, flocks of birds from other continents and interior Asia make their way to the sanctuary, build nests and forage for food for their chicks. This year, the lack of food and fish in the tank in the sanctuary has precipitated a crisis, forcing the birds to travel longer distances in search of food for their young. Visits by officials of the forest department to take stock of the situation are few and far between. “The situation in the sanctuary is grim. Chicks are dying due to shortage of food in the tank. Officials should take immediate measures to conserve the population of the birds,” said NV Sarathchandra, a bird conservationist.

Chairman of the Uppalapadu sanctuary development committee Perumalla Anil confirmed that the forest department had not spared funds for feeding the birds in the sanctuary. “Birds have to travel far to fetch fish. They do not feed here,” he told TOI. Anil added that he had initiated measures to clean the tank.

Locals, meanwhile, said that birds have been arriving in groups numbering between 1,000 to 2,000 and around 20,000 to 25,000 have already taken shelter in and around the sanctuary. Migratory birds from Russia, Mongolia and Siberia have been sheltering together in large groups in the absence of adequate maintenance of the sanctuary, leading to congestion and spread of disease.

“The birds are faced with acute space shortage. Every inch of the space available near the tank is occupied,” said M Mohanrao, a resident of Uppalapadu. The issue has been brought to the notice of officials of the forest department, he added.

Recalling a similar incident at Sambhar lake in Rajasthan, Sarathchandra said officials should act before large numbers of birds face starvation. “More than 17,000 migratory birds died at Sambhar lake, a Ramsar wetland site, due to negligence,” he said.

The Uppalapadu Bird Sanctuary, which lies between agricultural fields, faces contamination from chemical runoff from the fields. Water from the fields contains high levels of pesticides and residues of chemical fertilizers, which eventually makes its way to the tank. Diverting this waste is crucial, said Sarathchandra, adding that the forest department should conduct awareness programmes in the nearby villages to discourage the use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides.

“Uppalapadu Bird Sanctuary has been in a state of neglect and lacks proper maintenance. One significant issue which needs to be addressed is the serious depletion of fish stock in the sanctuary. As the migratory birds come here to breed, lack of abundant fish stock to feed their young will discourage birds in the future,” said Ravikiran, an engineering student and bird watcher. He added that fish stock must be improved by continuously replenishing the water with native fish.

A staffer at the sanctuary on the condition of anonymity admitted that birds were dying due to shortage of food and space but stocking fish in the tank would ease the situation. Guntur divisional forest officer Ramachandra Rao, however, said claims of bird deaths due to starvation were false.

Title: Nitin Raut says not upset over change in ministry, media speculations wrong
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Nagpur: A day after reports of change in his ministry emerged, cabinet minister Nitin Raut on Saturday said he was happy that a Dalit was given an important portfolio of Public Works Department (PWD) for first time in the state. He also said that he will “abide by whichever responsibility entrusted by the party”.

His reaction came after PWD ministry was handed over to former chief minister and ex-MPCC president, Ashok Chavan, after latter took an oath in second cabinet expansion. Now, Raut has been handed over the power ministry which was earlier looked by former Kamptee MLA Chandrashekhar Bawankule.

“I am not upset as speculated in the media. I was only pointing out that never before a Dalit was given a charge of PWD and I was fortunate. I will work with full dedication and integrity in any portfolio as I am a dedicated soldier of Congress party,” he told TOI.

Raut’s supporters, however, were upset over the development, terming it as “yet another injustice” to Vidarbha by the grand old party. According to them, the western Maharashtra netas always try to dominate their counterparts from the backward region. In Raut’s case, they have snatched the plum ministry offered to him and given him the portfolio where Vidarbha was rich in all aspects, being a power surplus region, they claimed.

The supporters added that Raut would be obviously upset over the way an important portfolio was taken away from him to accommodate the senior. He had even started his work in full swing and directed PWD officials in the state to repair and maintain all roads.

“It’s a clear case of injustice towards Vidarbha. On one hand, you handed over an important ministry to a backward candidate and took credit. A month later, you snatched his portfolio just because a senior wants it. He shouldn’t have given the PWD ministry at the first instance,” Congress spokesperson Sandesh Singalkar said.

He said Vidarbha would always take back seat in any government and only statehood could ensure justice to the backward region.

Endorsing him, national coordinator of All India Unorganized Workers Congress, Trisharan Sahare, said such instances on Vidarbha netas was not new and irrespective of any party’s government, the region would always remain neglected. “It was a proud moment for Vidarbha as a Dalit was entrusted with such an important portfolio and removing it from him is very unfortunate. Instead, the Thackeray government should have given more representation to the backward districts like Gadchiroli, Washim, Bhandara and Gondia in the ministership. But they removed a highly efficient person who would have made the difference to this backward region,” he said.

The North Nagpur MLA had taken oath of a cabinet minister along with chief minister Uddhav Thackeray on November 28. He was only one from Vidarbha in the first list of ministers and was awarded PWD portfolio along with other ministries. He was only backward face in the first list of ministers.

Title: Strong objection to playground user change plan
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) proposal to change user of city’s biggest playground — Patwardhan ground, Yashwant Stadium and adjoining land — continues to witness strong objection. All 30 individuals and associations who appeared before the civic body for hearing registered their objection against the proposal.

The state government owes 17.53 acres land between Panchsheel Square and Mehadiya Chowk at Dhantoli. There are some shops on Wardha Road followed by Tilak Patrakar Bhavan, government library, Patwardhan ground which is being used for parking city buses, slum on its rear side and Yashwant stadium.

The entire area is 140% more than Kasturchand Park and reserved for recreational open space/playground in city’s development plan.

City MP and Union minister Nitin Gadkari had proposed to develop entire area into Central Business District (CBD). Accordingly, the NMC started process to change user of entire area to Yashwant stadium and commercial. The existing stadium will be demolished and a new one will be part of CBD.

The NMC invited suggestions and objections in September to which 49 individuals and organizations responded. Municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar held hearing for 30 on Friday and Saturday. Others are likely to be given chance on Tuesday.

NMC sources told TOI that even Dhantoli Nagrik Mandal has opposed the proposal. The residents fear congestion will increase manifold if CBD is developed. Some also opposed demolition of stadium which is not too old. Owners of shops situated below stadium and those located on Wardha road, Patrakar Bhavan also registered their objection.

Nine years ago, the HC had directed the government to take back entire area from the NMC and use it for playground but it was never done. The civic body’s ongoing process is also violation of HC’s orders.

Title: IGI Airport: Directorate General of Civil Aviation wants action against unruly Air India passengers
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Videos have emerged showing some passengers banging on the cockpit door and asking the pilots to come out

NEW DELHI: The Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) has asked Air India (AI) to act against unruly passengers who banged on the cockpit door and misbehaved with the crew of a delayed Delhi-Mumbai flight on Thursday (January 2). While threatening to break open the door, some passengers had asked the Boeing 747’s pilots to come out of the cockpit and explain the situation a few hours after the jumbo jet had returned to the terminal at Indira Gandhi International Airport from the runway due to a technical snag.

The airline said it will decide on the issue of beginning proceedings under the strict No-Fly List against the unruly passengers of this flight after a thorough probe. India also now has a No-Fly List under which disruptive passengers can be barred from flying for upto a lifetime depending on the gravity of their unruly behaviour.

DGCA chief Arun Kumar said: “We have asked AI to act against the unruly behaviour.” AI spokesman Dhananjay Kumar said: “AI 865 of January 2 was considerably delayed due to technical reasons. The management has asked the operating crew for a detailed report on the reported misbehaviour by some passengers. Further action will be considered after getting the report.”

The 24-year-old B747 (VT-EVA) named “Agra” was to operate as AI 865 at 10.10am on Thursday. “Passengers had boarded the flight by 9.15am. The aircraft taxied out at 10am and returned from the taxiway in about 10 minutes. Attempts were made to rectify the snag. Finally passengers were asked to alight from the plane at about 2.20pm and flown to Mumbai by another aircraft at 6pm,” said an AI official. So there was a delay of eight hours in the passengers taking off for their destination.

While airlines should do their best to minimise passenger woes during flight delays, unruly behaviour by flyers targeting crew is unacceptable globally. “Passengers being made to wait inside an aircraft for hours is regrettable and should not happen. But the fact is this happens in almost every airline and will passengers have the courage to act as unruly as they did on a foreign airline or even a private Indian one?” asked a senior pilot.

Problems on board Agra began when passengers got restive after waiting for more than a couple of hours for the snag to be rectified. Videos have emerged showing some young passengers banging on the cockpit door, asking the pilots to come out. “Captain please one out… Loser come out… Come out or we will break the door…” they were yelling at the cockpit crew. Cockpit is on the upper deck of B747s, where AI and many other airlines have their business class.

One of the passengers in the videos even knows that doing so is against the law and can be heard saying “I do not have a criminal record and don’t want one.” When AI finally asks passengers to alight from the aircraft, another video shows a passenger trying to open the door even as the crew are in the process of doing so. Her co-passengers ask her to step aside and let the cabin crew open the door. “Don’t do this they will open it,” co-passengers are seen telling this person.

A senior pilot said if an aircraft is suspected to have a snag, the crew will not let it operate a flight till the same is rectified. “Passengers need to understand that. No one knows how long a snag rectification will take to rectify and that’s why airlines don’t immediately ask passengers to alight to avoid further delay by repeating the boarding process once the plane is good to go,” said the pilot.

India recently enacted rules to punish unruly or disruptive passengers who can face a ban on flying for up to a lifetime. The first level of disruptive behaviour includes “physical gestures, verbal harassment and unruly inebriation”. The next level has “physically abusive behaviour” like pushing, kicking and includes “inappropriate touching or sexual harassment”. The highest level is for “life-threatening behaviour, damage to aircraft operating system, physical violence such as choking, eye gouging, murderous assault, attempted or actual breach of” cockpit.

A passenger charged under the first level can be grounded for up to three months; up to six months under the second level and for third level, grounding can be upwards of two years with no maximum limit (meaning up to a lifetime). For repeat offenders in the same level, the period of grounding is doubled.

Last May, a Mumbai jeweller had become the first person to be put on the NFL following his disruptive behaviour on a flight of now-grounded Jet Airways.

Title: FTII, SRFTI entrance test fees relief for aspirants after stir
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: Aspirants taking the joint entrance test for admission to the Film and Television Institute in the city and the Satyajit Ray Film and Television Institute in Kolkata are all set to get fees relief.A committee tasked with revising the fees recommended aaround 50% cut in charges for aspirants under all categories. According to the new fee structure decided by the committee headed by the Film and Television Institute ( FTII ) chairman, BP Singh, those applying in the general category for three courses — one each in TV and film wings and a standalone course — will have to pay a maximum of Rs 4,000. Written test is conducted for admission to these courses.Those applying under the SC, ST and people with disability categories for all the three courses would have to pay a maximum of Rs 1,200 as the entrance test fee, a release of the FTII stated.A source said the fees would be less for candidates in all the categories if they apply for fewer courses. The candidates, who paid according to the older fee structure, would be refunded the extra money they paid, said an official of the FTII.Under the previous fee structure, aspirants had to pay a maximum of Rs 10,000 for the entrance test.Six students of the FTII as well as a few from the Satyajit Ray Film and Television Institute ( SRFTI ) and the Indian Institute of Mass Communication (IIMC) went on a weeklong hunger strike over the entrance test and course fees of the institutes.Student representatives at the FTII stated that the FTII Students’ Association (FSA) might hold a meeting over the revised fee structure on Saturday night to decide the future course of action.Some members of the governing council (GC) of the FTII had also expressed reservations over the fees structure. A GC member told TOI that the fee “should only be used to cover the costs for holding the test, and nothing else”.A GC meeting on December 27 had taken an “in-principle” decision to reduce the entrance test fees, after which the committee was formed.

Title: Placards play out anti-CAA messages
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Hyderabad: Several protesters came to the Million March holding placards , denouncing CAA and NRC.

“This is an expression to show our anguish against CAA and NRC. We want the government to revoke CAA and scrap NRC. I came all the way from Rajendranagar,’’ Mohammed Afroze, a degree student, told STOI.

A 28-year-old accountant Mohammed Rafeeq of Shalibanda said he set out from his home at 1.30 pm after the noon prayers to the rally venue. He said it took them nearly one-and-a-half hour to reach Dharna Chowk from his place.

Along with Rafeeq, 50 colony residents also reached Dharna Chowk. He along with others held aloft the placards. “We don’t want uneducated people in governance who do not know what to do and what not to do,” he said.

Some protesters came up innovative slogans on their placards. “Hum paper se Hindustani nahi hai, hum khoon se Hindustani hai (We are not Hindustanis on paper, our blood is of Hindustani)” read one such placard.

The organisers distributed pamphlets to protesters, explaining the finer details on CAA, NRC and National Population Register (NPR) for their benefit.

Title: Salt Lake roads to get facelift ahead of book fair
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kolkata: The Bidhannagar Municipal Corporation will take up the repairs of certain stretches in Salt Lake to ensure a smooth ride to the International Kolkata Book Fair 2020, scheduled to be organised at the Central Park ground from January 29 to February 9.

The civic authorities have floated tenders to engage contractors to take up the project urgently. Work is supposed to start from the end of next week and the agencies are expected to complete the repairs before the book fair starts.

The authorities have set aside a budget of over Rs 1.3 crore for this. Civic officials said the focus of the repairs was the roads leading to the fair ground as thousands of vehicles are expected to head there for those two weeks.

Among the important stretches that have sprung large potholes are the two flanks from Anindita Island to Tank 13, the road from Tank 13 to the Bharatiya Vidya Bhawan island, from Tank 9 to the lane going inside DL Block, Tank 9 island to the canal side road, several lanes inside DL and EE blocks in front of Karunamoyee and the areas adjacent to the Central Park fair ground, where most of the vehicles will head for. Besides, plans are on to repair the pavement spots, where paver blocks had come off, surrounding the fair ground.

Title: Inheritors of grand legacies do maestros proud
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Romance and beauty are the hallmarks of the rasa

AHMEDABAD: In her recitals, Dr Viraj Amar enforces attention with the authority of a calm truth. She presents even the trickiest passages with unhurried rapture, her Banaras Gharana affiliation intensifying her radiance on the stage. “I chose Chayanat, which is informed by the Shringar Rasa,” Dr Amar told TOI. Romance and beauty are the hallmarks of the rasa. “It is a beautiful but difficult raga because it is structured,” she said.

Those who missed her Chayanat exposition on Day 3 of Saptak, on Friday, can refer to a 2014 YouTube video which presents her earlier essay of the raga. The video shows her capacity to find the infinity of substance even within the well-defined structure of a style.

The finale of Day 3 was Ayaan Ali Bangash’s sarod performance. He played Tilak Kamod and Kirwani. Like his father, Ustad Amjad Ali Khan, Ayaan Ali Bangash elucidates musical intricacies with generosity and clarity. TOI asked him to explain the nine and a quarter beats around which his Kirwani was organized.

“This taal is inspired by the South Indian system as it’s not a traditional taal,” he told TOI. “However, the oceanic world of Indian rhythmic time cycles allows these out-of-the-box taals to be played.” Taal has a Sanskrit root that means “handclapping, musical time”.

Ustad Amjad Ali Khan was pleased with the warm reception his son’s recital had received. “I am proud of Amaan and Ayaan,” Khan-sahab told TOI. “Thank God we all don’t sound alike! The credit goes to their mother and first guru, Subhalakshmi Borooah.”

Title: Snag sparks rotational power cuts in Swargate
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Various parts of Swargate are experiencing load shedding on a rotational basis since Wednesday after the extra high voltage power line of the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited developed a major fault.

A statement issued by the distribution company on Saturday said the repair work was undertaken on a war footing and the power supply would be restored by Sunday.

According to the statement, a supply line coming from the 220/132KV Parvati sub-station to the GSI Rasta Peth sub-station developed a fault at 8am on Wednesday. As a result, the power supply to the sub-station at Rasta Peth was cut off, disrupting supply to various areas, including Mundnagar, Maharshinagar, Subhashnagar, Gultekdi Industrial Estate, Sujay Garden, PMC Colony, Parvati Gaon, Vega Centre and Swargate ST stand.

“The utility company was forced to implement load shedding on a rotational basis in these areas as a temporary measure to manage the load,” the statement added.

Title: Govt releases Rs 6,108 crore for Amma Vodi
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vijayawada: The state government is set to launch ‘Jagananna Amma Vodi ’, which seeks to encourage mothers to send their children to schools, on January 9. The state government issued four orders releasing Rs 6,108 crore for the scheme on Saturday. All mothers who belong to below poverty line will be given Rs 15,000 every year to help them send their children to school .

Amma Vodi was one of the election promises made by chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy. It is also one of the flagship programmes of YSRC’s Navaratnalu. The scheme aims at increasing the number of schoolgoing students in the state and enhance the quality of education.

The financial assistance would be provided to all mothers or guardians irrespective of the number of children at their home. The mother or the guardian should be a white ration card holder and ensure that the student must have 75% attendance. In case of dropout from school or college, the scheme would not be applicable to the beneficiary. Government employees and income taxpayers are not eligible for the scheme.

The scheme is applicable from 2019-20, in all the government, private-aided, private-unaided schools and junior colleges, which include residential schools and college as well. The government has also included orphans and street children in this scheme who are studying in schools through voluntary organisations. The financial assistance will be provided to these organisations after coordination with the departments concerned.

The lists of beneficiaries, which the district collector will prepare, will be displayed at all village and ward secretariats.

Title: Noida tapes expose rift between UP IPS officers
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Lucknow: The leaked tapes of Noida SSP have triggered a rift between Indian Police Service (IPS) officers in the state, even as a report by him against five IPS officers to the government and DGP has opened a new front. IPS officers named in the letter have termed the allegations baseless, and also threatened to lodge a defamation suit. In case they file a cross-complaint, then a ‘cold war’ will be out in the open, sources in the police department claim.

The simmering war between a section of IPS officers came out in the open after three sex tapes and several chats on WhatsApp, allegedly between a woman and the SSP Noida, got leaked on social media. In fire-fighting mood, the SSP Noida hurriedly conducted a press conference and allegedly leaked to media details of five IPS officers against whom the former had sent a report to the home department and the DGP.

Interestingly, one of the five accused IPS officers, who is currently on training, told TOI that he learnt of the allegations of posting a constable with criminal antecedents. He stated that he had got all the documents checked and made no such appointments. The officer also said that he was waiting for the government report and then will seek legal action. Similarly, another accused officer said, “He should have lodged an FIR instead.”Other officers also conveyed similar sentiments, clearly hinting at signs of a looming internal war. When DGP OP Singh was asked about war between IPS officers during his press conference on Friday, he had categorically stated that it was untrue and that all the officers work like a team in the state. “The police has worked well and handled all the challenging situations by working together as a force in the past many months,” he added.

The matter is under probe by additional director general of police (Meerut zone), who has sought 15 days’ time.

Title: ‘Unfit for use’ Gunhill ropeway may continue for another year
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Earlier in an inspection, technical flaws were were found in the ropeway

Mussoorie: The iconic Mussoorie ropeway service, which connects Jhulaghar on the Mall Road with Gunhill, might continue for another year even though in an inspection by BRIDCUL (Bridge, Ropeway, Tunnel and Other Infrastructure Development Corporation of Uttarakhand Limited) last month, technical flaws were found in the machinery of the four-decade-old ropeway service and accordingly, it was decided to suspend the service from January. At a Mussoorie Municipal Council (MMC) meeting on Friday, the officials agreed upon exploring possibilities of keeping the ropeway operational for one more year.

Speaking to TOI, MMC chairman Anuj Gupta said that the municipal council will try to address the technical flaws in the machinery of the ropeway and subsequently approach BRIDCUL and IIT-Roorkee for conducting a technical inspection of the ropeway and giving a clearance certificate.

“Considering the popularity of the ropeway with tourists and the fact that livelihoods of a number of shopkeepers are dependent on it, we want to continue the service for another year. We hope that technical flaws are addressed soon,” Gupta said.

Meanwhile, the renewal of contract of the agency, which operates the eco-tax barrier at Kohlu Khet, was also done at the board meeting along with a 2% hike in royalty fees.

“The agency is currently paying Rs 2.30 crore to MMC. The board has decided to hike this amount by 2% and renew the contract, which will remain valid till August 2020,” Gupta said.

During the meeting, a proposal for a new parking lot near Civil Hospital was also mooted. The civic body has decided to seek approval for the parking space from the state government.

Title: 1 dead, many hurt as bus with kids, teachers falls into gorge
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Students of a government boys’ high school in Kadiri did not fathom that their excursion would end in a nightmare. In the late hours of Friday, a bus carrying 45 students and 10 teachers from the school skidded off the road near Dharwad district in Karnataka and fell into a 500-feet gorge. All but one miraculously escaped death as the trees on the sides of the gorge broke the bus’s fall.

Anantapur SP B Satya Yesu Babu told reporters on Saturday that the group had set out on an excursion to Karnataka on January 2. The group of students and teachers were on their way from Jog Falls to Murudeshwar at around 10.30 pm on Friday night, when the accident took place.

He said, the high school’s headmaster Rajendran first managed to break the rear windshield of the bus and helped a few students reach safety. He later informed his relatives and Anantapur police about the mishap and sought help. Anantapur police in turn passed on the information to their counterparts in Karnataka, who rushed to the spot and rescued the passengers.

While two students sustained grievous injuries, a class 10 student, identified as Baba Fakruddin, succumbed to his injuries. A few other students and teachers sustained minor injuries. The injured were taken to Manipal Hospital in Udupi, where they are undergoing treatment.

Meanwhile, chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy, who condoled the death of the class 10 student, directed Anantapur district collector Gandham Chandrudu to extend all necessary medical and logistical support to the group of students and teachers, who have been stranded following the accident and bring them back safely to their home.

Title: Moving of army from Buldi fort attempt to grab land: Activist
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Nagpur: An organization working on agrarian issues has accused a local political heavyweight of being complicit in shifting the 118 Territorial Army (TA) from Sitabuldi Fort so that the “prime property could be commercially exploited”.

Addressing the media on Saturday afternoon, Avinash Kakde, president of Kisan Seva Sangh (KSS), alleged that the Sitabuldi Fort is slowly being emptied so that ultimately its purpose will be brought into question.

“It is nothing but a land grab attempt by a very powerful politician from Nagpur. Once the Sitabuldi Fort’s existence comes into question, it will be exploited commercially in the name of maintenance. There is also a possibility of the original owner of the land, a well-known family local family with historical roots, will stake their claim on the property saying it is no longer serving its intended purpose,” Radke said.

“And then, our local politician will come into picture and resolve the issue which will be the final nail in the coffin for Sitabuldi Fort,” said Kakde. Retired personnel from the TA also shared the stage with Kakde while addressing the media.

KSS is now preparing to file a public interest litigation (PIL) over the issue. Retired personnel had already approached the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court when the initial decision to move 118 Territorial Army was taken. However, the final decision did not go in their favour.

Kakde said, “My legal team is working on the documents and we will be filing the PIL with other points related to land origin, its purpose etc.”

Kakde said, “I have written to the PMO and defence ministry about this issue. How can one even think of shifting a territorial army for this region to Bhusawal? That defeats the entire purpose of it being called the Territorial Army.”

“The silence of powerful politicians on this issue means just one thing that there is something fishy. My direct charge is that the decision to remove 118 Battalion from here has been taken with all probability to grab this army land. This smells of collective corruption,” he added.

Title: Pune: Bogus army man dupes designer with dud cheque
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A man was booked on Friday on the charges of posing as an army man and duping an interior designer of Rs 15,300 by issuing him a dud cheque after buying his smartphone at the National War Memorial Chowk between November 22 and 29 last year.

The complainant, Hrishikesh Samose (22), of Rajyognagar in Warje Malwadi had bought a smartphone but soon realized that the device did not meet his requirements.

The Wanowrie police said Samose then posted an advertisement on an e-commerce website to sell the smartphone. “A man posing as an army man then contacted him to buy the smartphone. After considerable negotiations, Samose agreed to sell the phone for Rs 15,300,” a police officer said.

Assistant inspector Asaram Shete from the Wanowrie police said, “The buyer on the pretext of buying the smartphone called Samose to the War Memorial Chowk where he took the device from him against a cheque of Rs 15,300. Samose initially refused to accept the cheque, but the buyer won his confidence after he told Samose that he was an army man.”

Shete said, “Samose accepted the cheque and deposited it in his bank branch at Warje Malwadi. To his utter shock, the cheque bounced. Samose then called up the suspect on numerous occasions, but to no avail.”

“One fine day, he somehow managed to get through to the suspect, following which he agreed to meet him at the War Memorial Chowk for settling the dispute. He, however, did not turn up,” Shete added.

After Samose’s efforts to recover the smart phone or the cash proved futile, he visited the Wanowrie police station and lodged an FIR. “The person has been booked under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code,” Shete added.

Title: Caught in traffic, TISS aspirants denied entry into test centre for reaching late
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Hyderabad: Delayed due to traffic caused because of the Million March , several students from the city missed their Tata Institute of Social Sciences National Entrance Test (TISS-NET) on Saturday. Students said they were denied entry into test centres as they arrived about three-four minutes late. While they made frantic calls to the institute’s helpline number, it failed to yield any result.

“I was only two minutes late. I tried to reason with them and tell them that I was caught in the traffic jam, but they did not allow me for the exam. Now, I have to wait for a whole year to write the entrance examination,” said a student, whose centre was at Old Alwal. He was taking the test for admission into Human Resource Management & Labour Relations.

The candidate said that at least 25 students at the centre were not allowed to appear for the TISSNET for reaching only minutes after the exam started.

While members of student council of TISS said that almost all undergraduate students, who applied for the entrance test, appeared for the examination, they said that the examination staff should have allowed candidates for the exam even if they were late by a few minutes. “There is no way someone could predict traffic today. All roads were congested and everyone was aware of it. So, they could have considered it as extraordinary circumstance,” said a member of the student council.

TISS-NET is a computer-based test with 100 objective type multiple choice questions for admissions to Masters (Master of Arts / Master of Science / BEd-MEd Integrated) programmes.

Title: Gujarat: Clerk jumps off ninth floor at civil court
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 40-year-old resident of Vrajdham in Ghatlodia, Palak Patel, allegedly committed suicide by jumping off the ninth floor of the city civil court in Bhadra on Saturday afternoon.

Police sources said Patel was an assistant clerk at court number 34, and had been employed in the court for the last five years.

Karanj police sources said they have registered a case of accidental death. “The reason for the suicide is not yet known. We have spoken to his colleagues, but they don’t know what caused Patel to commit suicide,” a senior Karanj police station official said.

According to police sources, at about 2pm during the recess hour, Palak climbed up to the 9th floor and jumped to his death from there.

“We have not found a suicide note. We are yet to question Palak’s family,” a police official said.

Police sources said, “The family is in shock and it is not the right time to question them. We will speak to them after they finish the last rites. The body has been sent for a postmortem,” a police official said.

Title: Pune: Autorickshaw driver in cop net for robbery, culpable homicide
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: An advertisement sticker pasted on the hood of an autorickshaw helped the Koregaon Park police detect the case of missing realtor Rajesh Leeladhar Mhatre (46) from Navi Mumbai. Mhatre’s body was recovered from the Mula-Mutha river bed on November 28.The police on Friday night arrested the autorickshaw driver, Shabaf Jahangir Bangi (28), from Gadital at Yerawada and booked his two friends for culpable homicide and robbing Mhatre of Rs4 lakh. A magisterial court on Saturday remanded Bangi in police custody till December 8.Mhatre had withdrawn cash from his bank account on November 26. He boarded a state transport bus and alighted at the Swargate bus terminus around 7.15pm. He then hired Bangi’s autorickshaw to reach Mandai on account of a business meeting.According to the police, Bangi got the whiff that Mhatre was allegedly under the influence of alcohol and he was in possession of a large amount of cash. Instead of dropping Mhatre at his destination, the rickshaw driver drove him to Kumbhar Ves chowk. At the junction, Bangi called his friends and asked them to meet him on Burning Ghat Road.The trio then allegedly offered Mhatre liquor, and after he passed out, they robbed the cash and dumped him behind the bushes on the river bed, the police said.Senior inspector Pramod Patki of the Koregaon Park police said, “We recovered the body of an unidentified man after receiving a telephone call from the city police control room. We established Mhatre’s identity on the basis of the Aadhaar card found on him. The Sassoon hospital has preserved the victim’s viscera for seeking expert opinion and reserved the cause of his death after post-mortem.”Patki said, “While checking footage of CCTV cameras, a police team received the vehicle registration number of the autorickshaw but the number plate was only partially visible. We then received a clue that the vehicle hood had a private firm’s advertisement sticker. We checked CCTV footage from other locations and established the route taken by the rickshaw driver. Bangi had changed the hood but he was taken into custody after investigations established that he had abandoned Mhatre at a secluded spot on the river bed.”Bangi’s questioning revealed the involvement of his friends. A manhunt has been launched to arrest them.A police officer said, “Mhatre’s family registered a missing person’s complaint with the NRI police station at Navi Mumbai on November 27. We are recording statements of his family members and others.”An offence under sections 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder), 392 ( robbery ) and 34 (common intention) of the Indian Penal Code was registered against Bangi and others.

Title: Now, pay Rs 10-Rs 200 more for rail trips
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: After the newly introduced fares, rail passengers will have to pay from Rs 10 to Rs 200 more in various classes of trains for different destinations. For Delhi, train passengers will have to pay at least Rs 50 extra, while for other destinations including Howrah, Mumbai and others, passengers will have to pay Rs 100 or more extra.

Railways started charging increased fares of 1 paisa to 4 paisa per km, though there has not been any hike in the reservation and superfast charges of various trains from January 1 onwards. The fares of the trains were increased last in 2014-15.

TOI on Friday spoke to the officials of the NWR to find out the exact increase in the fares, which is going to affect rail passengers travelling from Jaipur to Delhi, Jaipur to Mumbai, Jaipur to Howrah, Jaipur to Bengaluru, Jaipur to Jodhpur and Jaipur to Udaipur .

Delhi passengers travelling in I-AC were earlier paying Rs 1,380 and with the increased fares, the passengers will have to pay Rs 1,395. “Delhi II-AC passengers were paying Rs 830, who are now required to pay Rs 840, for III-AC passengers will have to pay Rs 610 instead of the earlier fare of Rs 595,” said a senior officer of NWR on Friday.

The passengers travelling to Mumbai from Jaipur in I-AC have to pay at least Rs 100 extra for the travel. “Earlier they were required to pay Rs 3,495 but now they will have to pay Rs 3,595. Likewise for the same destination in II-AC, earlier they were paying Rs 2,050 but are now required to pay Rs 2,100,” said an officer.

Even the employees’ unions of the north western railways welcomed the step saying it was “much needed” and “long pending”. “I think to increase the earnings, railways require to increase fares and even platform ticket. We are already running in losses. Also, I would suggest the rail ministry to increase the freight as growth of railways is dependent on freight and fare,” said an office bearer of a railways employees union.

Title: Passion for wine gives her a high, and an award as well
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

One might indulge in the aroma and flavours of wine out of delight and enjoyment but for Sovna Puri, it’s her passion. Her in-depth knowledge about wine, spirits and beverages has made her the only Indian to feature among the Future 50 award winners announced on November 28 by the Wines & Spirit Education Trust (WSET) and International Wine and Spirit Competition (IWSC).

Born and brought up in Nagpur, Puri chose a very creative and different profession which deals with educating people about wine and other beverages.

Puri was selected from a global list of 600 professionals working in winemaking, distilling, product development, design and distribution, marketing, journalism and hospitality.“I have been working in the field for over 13 years. I have studied hotel management where I was introduced to ‘wine’ as a distinctive subject. Gradually, I started loving its different flavours, aromas and other technical elements which makes one wine different form another,” said Puri.

People from different countries participated in the competition but only a few made it to the list of winners after an in-depth analysis of their technical knowledge, passion and qualification. The purpose of the awards was to recognize and felicitate 50 future influencers of the global beverage industry, who are under the age of 40.

The Future 50 is an initiative by WSET and IWSC to celebrate 50 years of their establishment. Talking about her selection process, Puri said, “The awardees are selected from the wine and spirit industry. They are the ones who are not only talented, but have also made a significant contribution in areas of academia, social responsibility and innovation.”

There were more than 600 nominations in the first round, 200 in the second and 82 in the final list from which 50 were chosen.

Sovna is a level four diploma holder in Wines & Spirits from WSET, London. She is also a WSET certified educator certified to teach WSET courses up to Level 3 in wines, making her one among only two people in India to hold the distinction.

“I have been deeply involved in the Indian wine story for over 13 years. I’m currently working as an independent wine and spirit consultant, educator and trainer. It feels amazing to be the only Indian making it to the list of winners. It was a very thrilling experience overall. Having wine is not a common practice in Indian culture but times are changing and I want people to become more educated about it,” added Puri.

She was also one of fifteen women who were awarded the ‘Phoenix Leading Lady Awards 2019’ under the category ‘Personal Brilliance — Breaking Unconventional Barriers’. A regular contributor to ‘Sommelier India’, India’s first premium wine magazine, Nagpurian Puri now lives in Mumbai.

Title: Import from Maha, Guj drops onion prices in Raj
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Jaipur: With arrival of onions from Jhalawar, Nasik (Maharashtra) and Bhavnagar (Gujarat), prices have dropped across the state.

With wholesale prices raging between Rs 20 and Rs 40 per kg, the tuber sold between Rs 40 and Rs 60 per kg in the retail market. Traders at Mohana Mandi said prices would be around Rs 35 to Rs 45 per kg within a week. Since October 2019, onion prices were bringing tears into the eyes of homemakers and were literally away from the reach of common man. In November, onions were imported from Afganistan and Turkey but that too failed to bring down the prices. “We are now getting fresh onions mainly from Nasik, Bhavnagar, Tonk, Mathania and Nagaur which is the reason prices have come down. On Saturday, the small-sized onions were sold for Rs 20 per kg in the wholesale market while the big-sized were priced around Rs 40 per kg. In the retail market, it was sold for Rs 40 to Rs 60 per kg,” said Mukesh Totlani, a wholesale trader of onions at Mohana Mandi of Jaipur.

Traders said the onions from Bhavnagar and Nasik are dominating the market because of its quality. “If the supply continues, retail price would be Rs 35 to Rs 45 per kg from January 15 onwards,” said another trader at Mohana Mandi.

Title: Pune: Warmer days to return after cold’s cool cameo
Content:
Walkers brave a chilly and foggy Saturday morning near Mahatma society in Kothrud

PUNE: The prevailing “chill” is expected to make way for warmer days in the city from next week.The India Meteorological Department (IMD) on Saturday said the winds from the south were expected to bring moisture and a warmer weather to Pune in the next few days.The recorded maximum temperature at IMD’s Shivajinagar station was 25.7°C, which was 3.3° below normal. The day was even cooler in the eastern suburbs of the city, with Lohegaon reporting 24.6°C, over 5° below normal. Haze and shallow fog was also seen in parts of the city, followed by generally clear skies.“Yes, there was a drop in the maximum temperature in some parts of the state. However, these were not cold wave conditions. The temperatures are expected to marginally increase. It was colder in the city on Saturday because there was a little effect from the northerly winds,” Anupam Kashyapi, the head of weather at IMD, Pune, said.He said in the next few days, the moisture content in the atmosphere would increase over the region, due to moisture from the Arabian Sea brought in by the southerly and south-westerly winds. Due to this, both the minimum and maximum temperatures are expected to increase.“From January 7 to 9, we expect generally cloudy skies in the region,” he said, adding that foggy conditions with haze were also expected on Sunday in isolated parts of the city.Parts of the state, including central Maharashtra, areas in Marathwada and the northern parts of the Konkan coast, also recorded lower than normal daytime temperatures, with Mumbai’s Colaba station reading 26°C, over 4° below normal.However, minimum temperatures remained close to seasonal normal and even above it, with Malegaon’s minimum of 16.2°C being 5.8° above normal.

Title: Pune: Autorickshaw driver in cop net for robbery, culpable homicide
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: An advertisement sticker pasted on the hood of an autorickshaw helped the Koregaon Park police detect the case of missing realtor Rajesh Leeladhar Mhatre (46) from Navi Mumbai. Mhatre’s body was recovered from the Mula-Mutha river bed on November 28.The police on Friday night arrested the autorickshaw driver, Shabaf Jahangir Bangi (28), from Gadital at Yerawada and booked his two friends for culpable homicide and robbing Mhatre of Rs4 lakh. A magisterial court on Saturday remanded Bangi in police custody till December 8.Mhatre had withdrawn cash from his bank account on November 26. He boarded a state transport bus and alighted at the Swargate bus terminus around 7.15pm. He then hired Bangi’s autorickshaw to reach Mandai on account of a business meeting.According to the police, Bangi got the whiff that Mhatre was allegedly under the influence of alcohol and he was in possession of a large amount of cash. Instead of dropping Mhatre at his destination, the rickshaw driver drove him to Kumbhar Ves chowk. At the junction, Bangi called his friends and asked them to meet him on Burning Ghat Road.The trio then allegedly offered Mhatre liquor, and after he passed out, they robbed the cash and dumped him behind the bushes on the river bed, the police said.Senior inspector Pramod Patki of the Koregaon Park police said, “We recovered the body of an unidentified man after receiving a telephone call from the city police control room. We established Mhatre’s identity on the basis of the Aadhaar card found on him. The Sassoon hospital has preserved the victim’s viscera for seeking expert opinion and reserved the cause of his death after post-mortem.”Patki said, “While checking footage of CCTV cameras, a police team received the vehicle registration number of the autorickshaw but the number plate was only partially visible. We then received a clue that the vehicle hood had a private firm’s advertisement sticker. We checked CCTV footage from other locations and established the route taken by the rickshaw driver. Bangi had changed the hood but he was taken into custody after investigations established that he had abandoned Mhatre at a secluded spot on the river bed.”Bangi’s questioning revealed the involvement of his friends. A manhunt has been launched to arrest them.A police officer said, “Mhatre’s family registered a missing person’s complaint with the NRI police station at Navi Mumbai on November 27. We are recording statements of his family members and others.”An offence under sections 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder), 392 ( robbery ) and 34 (common intention) of the Indian Penal Code was registered against Bangi and others.

Title: Now, pay Rs 10-Rs 200 more for rail trips
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: After the newly introduced fares, rail passengers will have to pay from Rs 10 to Rs 200 more in various classes of trains for different destinations. For Delhi, train passengers will have to pay at least Rs 50 extra, while for other destinations including Howrah, Mumbai and others, passengers will have to pay Rs 100 or more extra.

Railways started charging increased fares of 1 paisa to 4 paisa per km, though there has not been any hike in the reservation and superfast charges of various trains from January 1 onwards. The fares of the trains were increased last in 2014-15.

TOI on Friday spoke to the officials of the NWR to find out the exact increase in the fares, which is going to affect rail passengers travelling from Jaipur to Delhi, Jaipur to Mumbai, Jaipur to Howrah, Jaipur to Bengaluru, Jaipur to Jodhpur and Jaipur to Udaipur .

Delhi passengers travelling in I-AC were earlier paying Rs 1,380 and with the increased fares, the passengers will have to pay Rs 1,395. “Delhi II-AC passengers were paying Rs 830, who are now required to pay Rs 840, for III-AC passengers will have to pay Rs 610 instead of the earlier fare of Rs 595,” said a senior officer of NWR on Friday.

The passengers travelling to Mumbai from Jaipur in I-AC have to pay at least Rs 100 extra for the travel. “Earlier they were required to pay Rs 3,495 but now they will have to pay Rs 3,595. Likewise for the same destination in II-AC, earlier they were paying Rs 2,050 but are now required to pay Rs 2,100,” said an officer.

Even the employees’ unions of the north western railways welcomed the step saying it was “much needed” and “long pending”. “I think to increase the earnings, railways require to increase fares and even platform ticket. We are already running in losses. Also, I would suggest the rail ministry to increase the freight as growth of railways is dependent on freight and fare,” said an office bearer of a railways employees union.

Title: TTD contribution to Andhra Pradesh government hiked to Rs 50 crore
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

YV Subba Reddy, Chairman, Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD). (Photo credit: FB)

TIRUPATI: The annual contribution of Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) to the AP government has been raised to Rs 50 crore from the earlier from Rs 2.5 crore, following the decision of the state government to bring in amendments to the AP Endowments Act .

TTD, the richest temple administration in the country, will now have to cough up the amount towards Common Good Fund (CGF), Endowments Administrative Fund (EAF) and Archaka Welfare Fund (AWF). The government sought the TTD to enhance its contribution under the three different heads through a memo, following which the trust board, under the chairmanship of YV Subba Reddy, accorded its approval to the proposal during the revision of the TTD’s budget estimates held on the sidelines of the trust board meeting on December 28.

According to sources, in 2012, the then endowments commissioner had asked the then TTD trust board to enhance the CGF and the EAF to Rs 15 crore and Rs 10 crore. The board had then passed a resolution to hike the contributions accordingly and forwarded the same to the government to modify the Act. But with the then united AP government failing to modify the Act, TTD continued to pay Rs 2.5 crore as the provision did not change.

However, the YSRC government has now decided to not only amend the Act but has also proposed to amend the earlier proposal which did not include a hike in the AWF from Rs 50 lakh to Rs 25 crore. The TTD’s contribution to the CGF has now been enhanced from Rs 1.25 crore to Rs 15 crore, EAF from Rs 50 lakh to Rs 10 crore and AWF from Rs 50 lakh to Rs 25 crore. The government has also proposed to seek Rs 16 crore towards salaries for archakas working with the endowments department.

Besides spiking up the TTD’s annual contributions, the government has also proposed to further hike the contributions by 10 per cent every five years.

Earlier, apart from the annual contribution of Rs 1.25 crore to CGF, TTD used to contribute Rs 16 crore annually towards ‘Dhoopa-Deepa Naivedyam’ scheme, for a total contribution of Rs 17.25 crore till now.

In addition to this, the government puts forward several requests to the TTD to provide financial assistance for upliftment of endowments temples and other temples across the state, which amount to an additional financial burden of approximately Rs 30 crore to Rs 50 crore annually.

It has been learnt that several members voiced concerns during the trust board meeting which approved the government’s proposal to hike TTD contributions. They also wanted the temple body to henceforth turn down undue requests for financial assistance to renovate/uplift other temples across the state.
