Title: IAF flew 625 tonnes of new notes post-demonetisation: Former air chief Dhanoa
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Former Air Chief Marshal BS Dhanoa (file photo)

MUMBAI: Post-demonetisation in 2016, the Indian Air Force flew 625 tonnes of new currency in 33 air sorties across the country to various destinations. This little-known aspect of demonetisation was revealed by former IAF chief B S Dhanoa while speaking at the IIT-B’s annual Techfest on Saturday.

Dhanoa mentioned this while highlighting some of the unknown roles of the IAF. He said the air force has risen to the occasion during natural disasters like floods and earthquakes. Dhanoa regretted that indigenisation has not fructified as much as one wished for. He said IAF has to depend upon 32 diverse platforms from nine different countries. At the same time, he said if the defence procurement procedure was politicised, “the whole system will become backward”. “Slowing down defence procurement will affect India,” Dhanoa said.

According to him, when the Balakot strike was approved, the government sent a political message to Pakistan that henceforth acts of terrorism will come with a heavy price.

“The Pulwama attack made the government change its strategy with regards to the response to terrorist attacks,” he told the huge gathering.

According to him, the IAF needs to modernise in order to provide a credible deterrence.

The IAF has identified 18 projects in the current financial year under the technology development fund.

Title: Swachh drive after the anti-CAA rally in Hyderabad
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

HYDERABAD: Soon after the rally, several volunteers at the Million March were seen cleaning the stretches where a large number of protesters had gathered. With many of them leaving plastic bottles, placards, food packets, papers and other waste, volunteers hand- picked and dumped them in big sacks.

Later, the waste bags were transported to designated garbage dumps. The volunteers consisted mostly youngsters, including girls. Some used broomsticks to clean the road near Indira Park crossroads. Cleaning of the roads and NTR ground started immediately after the conclusion of the public rally.

The event organisers had roped in several volunteers, who were seen wearing radium vests and moving around.

Title: Delhi: 60-year-old dead, eight injured in house collapse
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Several persons feared trapped under debris after a roof of a building collapsed in Uttam Nagar on Saturday (A... Read More

NEW DELHI: A 60-year-old woman was killed while eight others, including six children, were injured as the first floor roof of their house collapsed on the ground floor in west Delhi’s Uttam Nagar on Saturday afternoon. Cops have detained the houseowner, Giridharilal, who is a retired security officer, and registered a criminal case against him.

Police said that the floor was made out of Kota stone and did not have a support under it. Giridharilal had erected a false ceiling at the ground floor, which increased the weight on the roof due to which it collapsed.

The fire department received a call at 3pm about a house collapse in Batasehay Wali Gali in Mohan Garden. “Three fire tenders were sent to the spot. The two-storey house was built in an area of 50 square yards. As the roof of the first floor collapsed, people got trapped under the debris. Nine persons were rescued and rushed to a hospital with the help of local residents,” said Atul Garg, director, Delhi Fire Service.

The deceased was identified as Dulhari Devi (60). The injured included her brother Dharminder and his family who were visiting her for the weekend. Dulhari’s husband Vijay had taken the first floor, while his brother, Musafir, and his family were residing on the ground floor. Their paternal house was being reconstructed. Vijay, Musafir and his family members were out for work.

Title: Corpn staff to get certificates on R-Day
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Chennai: As a mark of appreciation for efforts by staff who did a commendable job in water body restoration and rainwater harvesting implementation projects of Greater Chennai Corporation, the civic body will on Republic Day award certificates to those who did exemplary work. The certificates will also be given to individuals and resident welfare associations.

The corporation said they brought to life 330 community wells along with Chennai Metropolitan Water Supply & Sewerage Board, desilting unused wells in all 15 zones. These wells are linked to rainwater harvesting structures in commercial buildings and apartment complexes nearby to ensure increase in groundwater levels, officials said.

According to a release from the corporation, 3.15 lakh buildings have been surveyed by officials. Of these, 2.47 lakh had rainwater harvesting structures. The release added that rainwater harvesting structures have been set up in all buildings belonging to the civic body and Metrowater.

Title: How many illegal hoardings in city? NMC’s market dept has no answer
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

turning blind eye

Nagpur: Former mayor Pravin Datke on Saturday expressed anguish over lackadaisical attitude of the market department to provide information on the number of legal and illegal hoardings across the city. Already, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation is facing contempt petition in view of its failure to curb illegal hoardings across the city.

The civic administration had convened a meeting of hoarding committee where Datke is an invitee while additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi is a chairman.

The market department was supposed to present details of both legal and illegal hoardings across the city. The department was unable to submit action initiated against illegal hoardings defacing the city. Even it has failed to furnish details of legal hoardings across the city and Datke had been insisting the details for one year. Despite warnings, the department had no requisite details to present at the meeting.

Datke also convened two other meetings — preparing a policy to shift private travels out of the city limit and projects undertaken under built operate and transfer or private public partnership.

Regarding shifting of private travel operators out of the city limits, regional transport officer (Nagpur city) Dinkar Manwar, senior inspectors from traffic police zones — Jayesh Bhandarkar, Shailesh Sankhe among others attended the meeting along with Datke.

It was discussed that shifting of bus stops outside city may cause inconvenience to passengers. Hence the NMC will ensure that private travel bus stops which will shift outside the city limits should locate within 5km of the city.

Datke also pointed out that many private bus operators have approached him with suggestions of developing their own bus stops. After a healthy discussion for over an hour, Datke directed the civic administration to invite suggestions from the citizens over the issue. The NMC will start the process to invite suggestions from citizens and travel bus operators from January 6.

Meanwhile, mayor Sandip Joshi has formed another committee headed by senior BJP corporator Sanjay Bangale to ease rents of NMC owned market places.

Title: Elocution: VC to meet both groups
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Nagpur University vice-chancellor SP Kane and pro-vice chancellor Vinayak Deshpande gave a hearing to a delegation of Save Merit Save Nation (SMSN) which met the duo after the Sanvaad elocution competition organized by SMSN, in association with TOI, was postponed.

The topic of the elocution competition is ‘Reservations in New India’. The decision to defer the competition was taken on Friday after opposition from a group of students under the aegis of an organization ‘The Platform’.

According to SMSN, the VC has decided to call a meeting of five office-bearers from both groups soon to “protect the constitutional right of all interested students irrespective of their opinion”.

The competition was to be first held at the Ambedkar College and then shifted to University Law College.

SMSN told the NU top brass that they are only against divisive vote bank politics leading to caste hatred. They are against excessive reservation and not Constitutional reservation, the delegation stated.

The SMSN delegation comprised president Sanjay Deshpande, secretary Anup Marar, vice-president Shreekrishna Buty, principal coordinator Brijesh Segan, Sanvaad convener Rashmi Shukla and Ganesh Iyer.

Title: West Bengal government pushes back Tallah Bridge razing, sets sights on April date
Content:
The demolition of Tallah Bridge, which was scheduled to start on January 5, is not likely to commence before ... Read More

KOLKATA: The demolition of Tallah Bridge , which was scheduled to start on January 5, is not likely to commence before April. The state government will pull down the structure and the railways will play a supervisory role.Earlier, it was decided that railways would raze the road overbridge (ROB) portion — like it did for Majerhat bridge — and the state public works department (PWD) will take care of the approaches. Accordingly, PWD was looking at a January date. Railways would have started pulling down the ROB part a month later, after having invited bids for the demolition job. But after a meeting convened on Thursday by state chief secretary Rajiva Sinha, where engineers from Eastern Railway (ER) and those from PWD discussed issues threadbare, a holistic outlook has been adopted.Post Thursday’s meeting, it has been decided that PWD will demolish the 57-year-old Tallah Bridge that has lost much of its load-bearing capacity and needs to be replaced immediately. The state agency is also implementing the ROB’s reconstruction. Therefore, a composite tender — for dismantling the existing ROB and rebuilding a new one — will be invited. “The procedure of calling an engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) tender should be over by March. Therefore, work for pulling down the bridge can start by April,” a senior state official said. PWD is likely to start floating tenders by January 31.“If the same construction agency is asked to pull down the bridge and build the new one, we could do away with unnecessary red-tape. This way, the implementation will be speedier. Had the railways been given the job of dismantling the ROB and the PWD pulled down the approaches, a lot of permission and formalities would have had to be addressed. In case of Majerhat bridge (that fell on September 4, 2017), PWD had to approach ER for various issues during the demolition. When the same construction company builds the bridge, they would know how to go about with the demolition. Of course, the ROB will be razed under ER’s supervision,” said a state official.ER, in fact, has been shooting letters to PWD over the last one month for payment of the demolition cost. Railways had estimated the cost of pulling down the ROB portion at Rs 30.4 crore. ER was unable to award tender for demolition because the money wasn’t tranferred. “The railways had said it can start razing the ROB portion by January-end provided the cost is handed over immediately,” an official said.Now that there is a three-month breather, the temporary level crossing near the Lock Gate flyover can be set up to enable movement of heavy vehicles through the alternate road. ER has sent the proposal for Railway Board’s approval. PWD will also need demolition’s permission from the Commissioner of Railway Safety (CRS). Meanwhile, the state and central agencies have time to sort out other issues.The most crucial of them is the new ROB’s design. Railways has rejected PWD’s proposed bowstring design for the new Tallah Bridge, saying construction of multiple piers would jeopardize train movement. It has suggested a cable-stayed bridge instead. A cable-stayed bridge, railways has said, would require two spans supported by a single pier that could be built on the railway premises and train movement wouldn’t collapse completely.The chief secretary has formed a task force to thrash out the design issue.

Title: This ‘Pad Man’ bats for reusable pads
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Omkar Sathe

PUNE: Omkar Sathe appreciates Akshay Kumar-starrer “Pad Man” for propagating the use of sanitary pads and trying to remove the stigma around menstruation , but his organization, Allforasmile, takes a slightly different route to derive the same result.

The organization Sathe heads is staffed mainly by women. It manufactures low-cost and reusable cloth sanitary pads. Allforasmile started off as a skill-inculcating venture, aiming to train women in stitching as a means of earning a livelihood. Initially, manufacturing sanitary pads was a secondary project.

“We started in 2010 with stitching as the core skill area. Later, some people approached us because they wanted cotton pads. So, we started manufacturing cloth sanitary pads. The pads were circulated in select areas of the city, like Janwadi slums, during the trial run,” said Sathe, who would deliver a lecture about his venture as a part of the Kirloskar Vasundhara International Film Festival (KVIFF).

Women unable to afford commercially-made sanitary pads often use discarded cloth and thus, suffer from a variety of infections. However, Sathe said the manner in which cloth is used is often the line between hygiene and the lack of it.

“The pads that we sell and distribute are made entirely of cloth. They are reusable and can be used for years unlike synthetic pads that are very polluting to the soil and water. There are also many misconceptions about cloth pads, like the difficulty in washing them or the use of cloth being unhygienic. If the cloth pad is washed and dried properly, there is no risk,” he said, addressing a news conference about the venture.

Sathe also warned against the “trend” of schools and colleges setting up incinerators for used sanitary pads, claiming that many do not follow the World Health Organisation (WHO) guidelines.

“The WHO actually has a wide set of rules and guidelines, which must be followed while setting up such incinerators. It is clearly mentioned there that if the pads are incinerated at low temperatures, there is a huge risk of carcinogenic emissions. Most products in the market do not follow those regulations,” he said.

Title: Kolkata: Parking plaza in Sector V by July
Content:
Representative image

KOLKATA: The IT hub of Sector V is going to get its first multi-tier car parking plaza by the middle of this year. The Nabadiganta Industrial Township Authority (NDITA) is setting up the 1 acre G+7 parking plaza behind Technopolis that will accommodate 648 cars. It will also have a pre-booking facility.“We have set a target to inaugurate the parking plaza by July this year,” an NDITA official said. The authorities are spending Rs 34 crore for constructing the structure.As per plans, cars will be parked from the first to seventh floor and the ground floor will have a food court. Each of the floors (from first to seventh) will be able to accommodate about 92 cars each. There will be washroom and tea stalls on each of the floors for the drivers and parking plaza attendants.“Hawkers who are presently doing business on the roadside will be rehabilitated at the food court,” the official said. “As an added advantage, motorists will be able to book a parking slot in advance through a mobile app. The authorities will decide on what will be parking rates before the plaza gets inaugurated,” he added.“For those who have their offices a few kilometres from the parking lot, the plan is to run bus services on short routes,” said the official.IT employees said that they are eagerly waiting for the parking plaza to come up. “It will be much beneficial as parking cars is a huge problem in Sector V. There is congestion 24X7 and often it is very difficult to find a space close to where we want to reach,” said Kaustav Dey, an IT employee.

Title: DMC arranges bonfires at 33 spots in Dehradun
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

yyyyyyyyyyyyyy

DEHRADUN: In the wake of the ongoing cold wave, Dehradun Municipal Corporation ( DMC ) has arranged for 33 bonfire spots across the city to provide relief to city residents.

Till last month, the civic body was running 10 bonfire spots but the count has now been increased in view of dipping mercury levels.

According to DMC officials, around 40 quintals of wood is being used daily for bonfires in the city. “Each identified spot is given around 1-2 quintals of wood so that the bonfire can be operational for a few hours,” said Kailash Joshi, chief health officer of DMC.

He added that two trucks are being used to drop logs at various bonfire spots in the city. “One truck travels from the IT Park to Raipur while the other travels on the ISBT-Rajpur route.”

Some of the prominent spots where bonfires have been arranged are Clock Tower, Prince Chowk, Gandhi Road, Parade Ground, Railway Station, Jakhan, Dilaram Chowk, Race Course and Doon Hospital, among others.

Title: Ahmedabad: Flowery mosquito draws large crowds
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visitors were seen taking selfies with displays of Hanuman, a heart, and even with the mosquito

AHMEDABAD: The exhibit on the Aedes aegypti mosquito and its life cycle and that of Lord Hanuman carrying the Dronagiri mountain were the centres of attraction for the visitors on Day 1 of the flower show here on Saturday.

Despite being a Saturday, footfalls were lower than expected, likely as this was the first day of the show.Visitors were seen taking selfies with displays of Hanuman, a heart, and even with the mosquito. Groups were seen dancing for videos on social media.

The flower show, now an annual event in Ahmedabad, has been held by the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation every year since 2013. This eighth edition had the special attraction of an exhibit on the life cycle of the Aedes aegypti mosquito.

The show, which will continue for 15 days, is spread over 88,500 square metres. One special attraction this year will be the display on the life of Mahatma Gandhi, on his 150th birth anniversary. There are five flower sculptures on Mahatma Gandhi on display. The Salt March exhibit was one of the most popular with visitors.

Sculptures on sports themes (badminton, football, hockey and cricket) was new this year. There are also displays on saving water, anti-smoking and other themes. A children’s cartoons theme drew large numbers of younger visitors.

Title: Special drive to enrol folk artists on welfare board
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Sivaganga: Over 100 folk artists from Sivaganga got enrolled in the welfare board constituted for performers of folk arts in a special drive conducted in the district on Saturday. The Tamil Nadu Folk Artistes Welfare Board was constituted to promote folk arts and also provide financial assistance to the folk artists. Artistes performing various folk arts including Thappattam, Bharathanatyam, Thavil, Naiyandi melam, Devarattam, Oyilattum, Silambattam, Karakattam, Marakkal attam, Kumi among others participated in the drive .

Project director of Madurai zone, Buhari, said that 4000 artistes had registered themselves with the welfare board in Madurai. A pension of Rs 6000 is given to the members when they reach 60 years of age. All members should submit income certificates to prove that their annual income is less than Rs 72,000 to get the welfare measures. Members of the board also get assistance for their children’s education and the families would get Rs 25000 after the death of a member. tnn

Title: A walk down history when India banked on Calcutta
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Diplomats and heritage enthusiasts at Samriddhi Bhavan on Saturday

By: Swarnali Dutta

KOLKATA: The original minutes of a meeting held on June 2, 1806, recording the establishment of the Bank of Calcutta, is preserved on the fifth floor of Samriddhi Bhavan, the regional headquarter of State Bank of India, on Strand Road. So are documents like registers and passbooks of scholar and politician Dadabhai Naoroji, scientist Jagadish Chandra Bose, India’s first President Rajendra Prasad and Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore — all of them customers of the bank.

These and many more artefacts displayed at the State Bank archives and museum were showcased on Saturday morning to a group of heritage enthusiasts, including US consul general Patti Hoffman, Japanese consul Masayuki Taga and Thai consular official Nutt Svasthi and American Centre director Monica Shie. The group also visited the RBI Museum, a heritage and knowledge centre created by the Reserve Bank of India at the old RBI office on Council House Street in Dalhousie. The heritage museum walk was organised by Bespoke Art & Unique Legacies (BAUL) that promotes heritage.

The Bank of Calcutta, which was renamed Bank of Bengal on Janaury 2, 1809, was the first joint stock bank in the country and remained so till April 15, 1840, when Bank of Bombay was established. Bank of Madras opened for business still later, on July 1, 1843. The three banks were later merged to form the Imperial Bank of India in 1921, which was then nationalised and rechristened State Bank of India in 1955.

“The Bank of Calcutta issued the first legal tender or currency notes in India of denominations ranging between 10 and 10,000. However, only eight types of currency notes could be issued and be in circulation at a time. That remains even today with notes of Rs 5, Rs 10, Rs 20, Rs 50, Rs 100, Rs 200, Rs 500 and Rs 2,000 denomination,” informed SBI chief manager (archivist) Ramakanta Hoom.

Among the bank’s illustrious borrowers were Prince Dwarkanath Tagore and Pandit Iswar Chandra Vidyasagar. While Tagore had first taken a loan of Rs 60,000 on July 21, 1817, and went on to take more loans at an interest of 9%, Vidyasagar had taken a loan of Rs 6,200 in 1873.

The bank had also maintained a complaint register from the very beginning. One of the complaints lodged by one Potit Pabun Mitra in 1889 against the rude behaviour by bank employee TWL Bruce finds mention. During the inquiry, Bruce denied recollection of the event and refused to apologise. But the inquiry concluded that the customer’s feelings had indeed been hurt and that Bruce must apologize.

The archive also has records of frauds. The biggest early fraud took place between 1826 and 1828 when Rajkissore Dutt, a petty businessman, took a loan of Rs 3.5 lakhs from the bank against forged company papers. These were later written off in the profit and loss account. But the first fraud was two years prior to it, when Rs 40,000 that had been advanced by the bank was repledged to it in 1824.

The RBI Museum situated next to the HSBC building offers fun and innovation beside history and knowledge. There is a replica of a gold vault where a gold bar weighing 12.5kg is displayed. There is an entire floor dedicated to games like Strike-N-Know, life-size Snake & Ladder, Spin the Wheel and Banking Ally to learn about prudent financial decisions, important financial terms, how to take financial decisions and basics of opening a bank account. The motive behind the games is to create awarenss about the banking system, explained museum curator Mahesh A Kalra. Other attractions include bioscope on how notes are printed and destroyed, kaleidoscope by using coins not in circulation any more.

Title: Make fitness a lifestyle, advises cancer survivor
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: City-based functional strength trainer and cancer survivor Farzana Begum is on a mission to change perceptions about fitness. Farzana organises free strength training sessions in the city to motivate women to make fitness a part of their daily routine.

A certified functional trainer from TotalFit, USA and a nutritionist from GMSA Fitness, New Delhi, Farzana’s love for strength training started in 2017 after witnessing several women suffer from low bone density, low muscle mass and other health issues. Wanting to educate women about the importance of strength led her to become a certified trainer.

In late 2017, however, Farzana was diagnosed with a spinal tumour. After surgery, doctors informed her that another surgery was required after recovery as the tumour had moved to the chest. Another surgery later, Farzana started training women but in March 2019, underwent surgery again as the tumour had grown in size and eroded part of her ribcage. After her second surgery, Farzana was diagnosed with high-grade lymphoma.

But the 38-year-old found the strength to persevere against the disease. Speaking to STOI, Farzana said, “Like any other cancer patient, I lost my hair, eyebrows, looked pale, was extremely weak and had no strength at all. The treatment was stressful, but I had the support of my family and friends and was able to stay positive through most of it. What kept me going through the painful journey was my training sessions with my clients which gave me the courage to fight it and to have hope that I would get through it.”

It was during this time that Farzana made the decision to take fitness to women who could not afford training session. “I believe fitness is every woman’s right, no matter what her circumstances and also every woman’s duty to herself. The only way to create awareness is to make fitness available to every woman, hence I started free training sessions,” said the mother of two girls.

“My future plan is to have an all women’s gym that will cater to holistic health development,” added Farzana.

Title: Tiger makes year’s first human kill in Chanda
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

CHANDRAPUR: A tiger killed a 50-year-old shepherd in Chimur forest range of Rajura tehsil on Saturday. It is the first human kill by predator a in Chandrapur this year.

Sources said that Santosh Khamankar from Dhanora village had taken his cattle for grazing in compartment no. 137 under Kavilpeth beat of Virur range on Friday. A tiger lurking in the dense forest pounced at Khamankar and killed him on the spot.

One other fellow shepherd was eyewitness to the attack and he fled to the village leaving the cattle behind. He later returned with villagers and found Khamankar’s body in the jungle .

Sensing further trouble, principal chief conservator of forest ( wildlife ) on Saturday issued orders to capture the problem tiger following a request made by CCF the office.

As many as 23 people were killed in the district last year, including 20 killed by tigers, two by leopards and one other by an elephant .

SV Ramarao, CCF (Chandrapur), said that it is likely to be the same tiger from Rajura range that has already killed two persons and injured one other in the last 40 days. Forest officials have confirmed the identity of the male tiger responsible for two human kills with the help of camera trap and DNA samples sent to Center of Cellular Biology, Hyderabad.

“The proposal to capture the problem tiger has been already moved and PCCF have granted permission to do so. Instructions have been relayed to veterinary doctor and local staffers to constitute a team for capturing the problem tiger,” Ramarao told TOI.

Title: Madurai: Gang loots family posing as cops
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Five people, who masqueraded as police officials, looted gold jewellery weighing 170 sovereigns and Rs 2.8 lakh in cash from the house of a civil contractor.

The incident that took place on December 27 last year came to light only on Saturday after the Koodal Pudur police registered a case based on the complaint from the contractor identified as Solai Gunasekaran.

Assistant commissioner of police, Tallakulam range, A Godwin Jagadeesh Kumar confirmed that they have registered a FIR and said that they have not got any clues so far to confirm the perpetrators involved.

Police sources said a five-member gang reached Gunasekaran’s house located in Appadurai Nagar near Koodal Pudur on December 27 and introduced themselves as a special police team.

Apart from Solai Gunasekaran, his wife and son were also present in the house.

Gunasekaran let them inside after the gang wanted to conduct a search in his house.

They conducted a thorough search throughout the house and as they did not find any suspicious things, they directed the family members to open bureaus.

When they resisted, one of the gang members took out a fire arm and threatened them with dire consequences.

They took all the gold jewels and cash found in the bureau and also took away a few documents found in the bureau.

While leaving, the gang took Gunasekaran with them in the car and left him at Othakadai. They then asked him to appear before local police station to get his valuables back and fled the spot.

After returning, he consulted with his relatives before lodging a formal complaint with the police. Higher police officers too conducted an inquiry.

The city police analyzed video footages from CCTV cameras available in the area seeking clues.

Title: Ahmedabad: Trader files FIR against loan shark
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Dharmesh Prajapati

AHMEDABAD: Dishank Shah, 34, a resident of Ghatlodia, on Friday lodged a complaint at Sola police station against one Dharmesh Prajapati , for allegedly harassing over borrowed money even though Shah has paid him Rs 5 crore overall for a Rs 1 crore loan.

Sola police officials said that they lodged an offence against Prajapati and are hunting for him, adding that they had invoked charges of extortion and under the Gujarat Money-Lenders Act against him.

Shah, who used to run a two-wheeler showroom in Thaltej, stated that between March 2013 and March 2019 he had borrowed a total of Rs 1 crore from Prajapati in instalments, on interest, for his business.

The FIR states that, Prajapati, by using the blank papers with his signature, has become his partner in his company, Diya Auto. According to the FIR, Prajapati used the blank signed papers to cancel Shah’s part in the partnership and does not allow him to sit in the office.

Title: Specialised varsities on the cards in higher edu revamp
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: An expert committee headed by Prof Balakrishnan on reforms in the education sector has recommended that the government convert Gurazada Apparao University in Vizianagaram and Andhra Kesari Tanguturi Prakasam University in Ongole in Prakasam district into specialised universities.

The expert committee has also suggested that one of the universities be converted into an open university and the other into an education administration university. The recommendations have been made keeping in mind the low gross enrolment ratio (GER) among students between the ages of 18 and 23 in Andhra Pradesh.

AP ranks 10th among all states in the recent all-India survey on higher education (AISHE), with a GER of 32 per cent. The recommendation of the committee to launch an open university and an education administration university was made keeping in mind the low GER and the absence of an open university in the state after bifurcation.

Further, the state lacks a university that exclusively offers courses that promote excellence in teachers’ education. The need for an institution offering courses to enhance administration and operational capacities of teachers to run academic institutions has grown with the increasing number of new schools and colleges in the state.

Speaking to STOI, an official from the Andhra Pradesh State Council of Higher Education (APSCHE) said that the state government will take a final call on converting one of the universities into a specialised university.

With the government considering the conversion of Gurazada Apparao University into a specialised varsity following the recommendation, “we expect a decision on the same in the next few weeks to make the universities operational from the next academic year,” said the official.

The state government had constituted Gurazada Apparao University by merging the Andhra University (AU) campus and the Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University (JNTU) campus in Vizianagaram. Academic activity is yet to start on the campus.

Meanwhile, employees of the AU Vizianagaram campus continue to operate from the Visakhapatnam campus.

Title: Engineering students sparkle in CAT exam
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Jaipur: A fourth-year engineering student Aryan Pankaj Sawhney has scored 99.95 percentile in Common Admission Test ( CAT ), the results of which announced on Saturday. A student of computer science branch of engineering from BITS Pilani has missed the top slot by 0.5 percentile.

He was not always interested in pursuing MBA until he was introduced to finance in BITS Pilani. “I am pursing a course in finance which drew my interest towards business management and I decided to prepare for management degree,” said Aryan who hailed from Nasik.

Even before he could have utilised his engineering degree, he has cracked CAT. “I am pursuing my B. Tech degree in computer science and would like to pursue MBA in artificial science and data science. Both are connected and will make me more employable,” said Sawhney.

Aryan like others is worried about the economic slowdown in the country. He would like to create some economic models for better forecast of such a situation. “I believe with the advancement in the academics, the projections and data crunching will become much easier leading to the ways to pre-empt the slowdown situation,” said Swahney, who later would like to work towards bringing some policy decisions. He is eyeing a call from IIM-Ahmedabad.

Next to Sawhney is Nishant Agrawal who scored 99.91 percentile. He is pursuing final year civil engineering from MNIT. “Civil engineering has an element of human resource management. The technical skills of engineering added with financial and marketing skills will help me handling big construction projects like airports, townships and railways on my own,” said Agrawal.

Title: Spa running flesh trade was on police radar for long
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

NAGPUR: Owners of the spa , which cops raided on Friday to bust a flesh trade den, were avoiding the police action by deploying several ‘tricks’.

Police officials had been keeping an eye on Zeedos Spa and Beauty Unisex Salon at Trimurti Nagar for more than a year. On Friday, social service branch (SSB) of crime branch rescued three women after raiding the place where flesh trade was allegedly going on under the garb of salon.

A couple, identified as Puja Nagdeve and Mithun Sarode, was arrested. They have been booked under sections of Immoral Trafficking Prevention Act.

It is learnt that the previous SSB team, which was dissolved following an ACB action, too had kept a watch on the salon. Senior PI of SSB Kishor Parvate said, “We had kept a close vigil on the spa after receiving a tipoff about the flesh trade. Raids couldn’t be conducted earlier as the spa owners were not allowing other people inside the salon. They were providing extra services to only specific customers.”

Police then sent a decoy as customer to the spa. But he was denied the extra service. So, cops kept sending him again and again until he gained trust of the accused who then agreed to provide the extra service.

On Friday, cops planned the raid by sending the fake customer. “The accused used to collect mobile phones of customers so we were not able to connect with our man inside. So, we decided to wait for some time and then raided the spot as it was necessary that we catch the accused red-handed,” said Parvate.

Title: ‘Quacks under check in Madurai, only 2 held in 2019’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Madurai: Health department officials in Madurai on Saturday said that the health officials were constantly monitoring the clinics and hospitals to weed out any quacks in the region. The officials said that only two quacks were arrested in Madurai last year and that the situation was under control in Madurai district.

“Only three major raids were conducted last year, namely at Alanganallur, Thirumangalam and Peraiyur. Out of the three raids, only two quacks were arrested. There were complaints from Alanganallur that a person was administering injections at a pharmacy after which drug inspectors investigated,” said a source from the health department. The most recent case was the arrest of a 52-year-old quack in Peraiyur who was running a clinic in Saptur.

Local drug inspectors are also carrying out periodical checks on pharmacies in the district for possession of poor quality medicines, unlawful administration of abortion pills etc., based on complaints and tips, said an official from the office of the Assistant Director of Drugs Control, Madurai.

It has been widely reported that quacks are a major concern in Tamil Nadu and that the punishments in law are not severe enough to deter their growth. It was reported earlier this year that at least 1500 quacks have been booked in the state over the last 11 years.

Title: Cops raid 60 places, arrest 21 peddlers
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Jaipur: Rajasthan’s crime branch raided 60 locations in Jaipur and arrested 21 persons accused of supplying as well as dealing in narcotics along with illegal liquor in the city, under the ongoing Operation Clean Sweep. Based on prior information, cops raided various locations in Vishwakarma, Jhotwara, Bhankrota, Bagru, Bhrampuri, Amber, Nahargarh, Transport Nagar, Muhana,Vidhayak Puri and Kho Nagoriyan police station areas.

“We received information that banned substances were being peddled in these areas and 60 teams planned simultaneous raids at these locations. Few suppliers who had previously been caught and were out on bail were also found to be dealing in drugs again, so they were also under surveillance. We arrested the accused from different parts of the city,” said a police official.

Out of the 21 arrested, one is a second-year college student. The official added, “The student hails from Kota and was studying in Jaipur. He first became an addict himself and then started supplying the drugs to other students as well. He studies in a reputed college in the city and was arrested from Vidhayak Puri police station area. We also recovered drugs from him.”

Police have recovered five kg of marijuana, 27 gram of hashish, 594 quarters of illegal liquor and five cartons of illegal beer. Since the initiation of Operation Clean Sweep in October 2019, 167 cases have been registered and 191 persons arrested.

Title: Delhi corporation school students sit on mats, issue rocks SDMC House
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Even as Delhi was witnessing severe cold days , students of many corporation schools were forced to brave the chill sitting on mats as there were no benches in their classrooms.

Despite making plans to procure benches from government’s e-portal or other sources last year, the three municipal corporations could not supply them to all schools for various reasons.

The issue rocked the house meeting of South Delhi Municipal Corporation on Saturday. Expressing resentment over no supply of benches in schools in his wards, Congress councillor from Ranhola Suresh Kumar questioned the mayor and commissioner about the reason for the delay and whether councillors’ fund could be used for the purpose.

“For three years we had been hearing about the supply of benches in primary schools. The civic officials should be ashamed of themselves for not being able to arrange for the benches,” said Kumar as he was joined by councillors from other political parties.

Officials said, supply of 7,000 benches was awaited in south corporation for Classes IV and V and 6,200 benches for Classes I and II. There was shortage of benches in nursery sections too. “We placed the work order four days ago and the shortage would be fulfilled in a couple of days,” said the official.

Situation is nowhere different in east corporation schools, which needed over 10,000 dual benches. “We had placed a demand for 10,260 dual benches on e-portal sometime back and recently got to know that Kendriya Bhandar had agreed to supply them as per our requirement. As soon as we get the samples verified, the process for delivering them to primary schools would start,” said a senior EDMC official. The civic agency pointed out that shortage of funds was one of the main reasons for the delay in the procurement process.

The north corporation, meanwhile, claimed to have fulfilled half of the requirement. “We required 12,000 benches and of them, 6,000 had been procured or supplied to the schools. At rest of the places, we either arranged for old benches donated by private schools and NGOs or ensured that the mats used for children were of good quality,” said north body’s standing committee chairman Jai Prakash.

Title: Karnataka under financial crisis but CM, MPs buy new luxury cars

This story is from January 5, 2020

Title: Depict Prithviraj as Gurjar king: Outfit to filmmakers
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Jaipur: The Akhil Bhartiya Veer Gujjar Mahasabha, a body of Gurjars, has issued a diktat to the makers of upcoming Bollywood film ‘Prithviraj’, based on 12th Century ruler Prithviraj Chauhan (1166-1192 CE) to project him as a Gurjar emperor instead of a Rajput king.

In a press conference held in Jaipur on Saturday, the body has claimed that Chauhan traced his origin to the Gurjar community while he was established as a Rajput king much later. Chauhan is known as a Rajput king from Chahmana dynasty.

In the film, Akshay Kumar is playing the role of Prithviraj, while Sanjay Dutt will be seen as Mohammed Ghori. The film is slated to release later in the year.

Acharya Virendra Vickram of ABVGM says that it is the right time in the history of last 900 years to claim the rightful origin of Prithviraj Chauhan.

“Piles of historical evidence in the different languages, including Persian, Jainism, Prakrit and Sanskrit suggest that Chauhan comes from a Gurjar clan,” said Vickram. The body said that oldest claim comes from Prithviraja Vijaya known to have authored by Jayanaka around 1191-92 CE.

“The book is a collection of poems in Sanskrit has keywords like Gurjar Mandala and Gurjar Durg which refers to the cultural identity of king which is none other than Prithviraj. It also has an account of the first battle of Tarain between Chauhan and Mohammed of Ghor. Also mentions about the Nandol fort which is known as Gurjaro fort,” said Jitesh Singh, member of the ABVGM.

The body also presented historical evidence from the epic Prithviraj Raso authored by Chand Bardai, Al Baruni’s (973-1050 CE) Tarikh Al Hind book, Mohammed Qasim Ferishta (1560-1620 CE) book Tarikh-e-Ferishta and 10th century poet Dhanpal.

“Our claim is based on history and those who have objection for the same can have a debate with us anywhere they want. I believe that history should be written in the light of the evidences which are still emerging,” said Vickram.

Why issuing diktat to film makers? The body responded that films are biggest source to create impression on the minds of people and they want them project the true characteristics of the warrior.

Title: Prize money missing, NU cultural winners get empty envelopes
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur University (NU) has handed over empty envelopes to over 40 students who brought laurels to it at state, zonal, national and international levels by bagging top positions in cultural events like singing, dancing, elocution, and other sporting events in the last two academic years.

The teams were felicitated in August last year and given envelopes having bank forms instead of cheques towards prize money, ranging between Rs2,000 and Rs20,000 each. Besides, they have also been told that they will get only Rs3,000 irrespective of the event.

Authorities had told them to return the filled form for direct transfer of the amount as they have shifted to cashless and paperless system.

Till date, none of the athlete or the cultural team has received the prize money. The NU had honoured two batches in the same event in August 2019 and hence, the amount is said to be in lakhs.

Denying the charge, officials blamed the students for filling incorrect details.

Students Development director Abhay Mudgal said several students didn’t provide IFSC code or gave incorrect bank details. “We are fed up following up with students to provide complete information. When IFSC code comes, they will get the prize money in 8 days,” he said.

Mudgal said same is the case with earn and learn scheme and hostel students who face problems in receiving university grants and funds.

“In some cases, even the account number was not proper. We had even attempted NEFT transfer but it was returned,” Mudgal said.

He said only 8 to 10 students are facing problems while around 35 were felicitated from 2017-18 and 2018-19. “This money is given by the university and not from the organizers of the event where these students excelled,” he said.

“As per event, all are getting uniform prize money of Rs15,000. A notification has been issued in this regard,” he said.

The finance and accounts section will verify and process the forms of students who are stuck but there is no clarity when they will get money. Mudgal also ruled out cash payout when “students are unable to get it right”.

A student said if there are any students who don’t have banking knowledge, then teachers can assist them. “But we filled all details accurately. We are 100% sure. They are only giving excuses to delay payment. The forms were filled under the university’s supervision only,” students said.

Title: Kodanda to CM: Make turmericboard happen
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Hyderabad: All-India Kisan Congress vice-president M Kodanda Reddy on Saturday said that chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao should take the initiative and convince the Centre to set up a turmeric board , a long-pending demand of farmers of Nizamabad district.

The AIKC vice-president charged the NDA government at the Centre and the TRS government in Telangana with dragging their feet on the issue. Urging the chief minister to write to the Narendra Modi government to announce a minimum support price (MSP) for turmeric, Reddy slammed the TRS government for neglecting the agriculture sector which needed to be encouraged to achieve better GDP.

KCR had also not fulfilled promises he had made to sugarcane farmers, Kodanda alleged. “The Nizam sugar factory has not been re-opened. The crop loan waiver scheme has not been implemented so far though KCR government has completed one year in office during its second term,” he said. “Even Rythu Bandhu scheme is not being implemented as 50 per cent of the over 50 lakh farmers in the state did not get money under the scheme,” Kodanda added.

Title: 4 held for robbing tea stall owner
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Hyderabad: Four persons, including two juveniles, were caught by Shamshabad Central Crime Station along with Rajendranagar police on Saturday for robbing a tea stall owner in Rajendranagar and beating him up.

The accused were identified as Chattla Nikhil, Tarun Varmora and two juveniles, all residents of Rambagh, Rajendranagar. All four are friends, said police. Police said the four culprits approached Methri Maruthi, who runs a tea stall at Hyderguda, when he was on his way back home after closing his stall at around 10 pm.It was one of the minors who approached the victim under the pretext of buying a cigarette. When Maruthi refused to offer the cigarette for free, the minor called his three friends who were on a bike. The gang attacked the victim and robbed Rs 1,200, a cellphone and fled from the spot. TNN

The victim sustained injuries on his left hand and head. The accused were nabbed from Rajendranagar and booked under section 394 (voluntarily causing hurt in committing robbery) of the IPC. Cops recovered the mobile phone from the accused.

Title: Municipal polls: Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao puts ministers, MLAs on notice
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

In his address to party workers , CM K Chandrasekhar Rao said that he would not tolerate groupism and indiscip... Read More

HYDERABAD: Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao has put his ministers’ and party legislators’ necks on the line in the event of Telangana Rashtra Samithi (TRS) not faring well in the January 22 municipal elections. Dropping enough hints that he would not hesitate to drop ministers if they fail to deliver the goods, the chief minister also told MLAs that they would not be considered for nominated posts.

The chief minister, who has decided not to campaign, however, wanted the ministers and legislators to go the whole hog to ensure the party’s victory in the polls. The TRS president also talked tough against groupism and indiscipline in the party. Making enquiries about the reported fight between minister Ch Malla Reddy and LB Nagar MLA D Sudheer Reddy at a public rally in Medchal the other day, the chief minister said: “I will not tolerate groupism and indiscipline that can impact the party’s performance in the elections.”

The chief minister also said that once the party declares the candidature in a ward, all the leaders and workers should strive for his or her victory. The party MLAs would be given the responsibility of selecting the candidates for ward member posts. Urging the ministers and MLAs to hold ‘aatmiya sammelanams’, KCR said that they will have to interact with important leaders and workers in their respective municipalities and municipal corporations.

“They should also meet the beneficiaries of government schemes and impress upon them to vote for TRS,” KCR said during the party’s extended executive meeting held at Telangana Bhavan on Saturday.

Title: CAT 2019: One from Telangana among 10 to secure 100 percentile
Content:
Clockwise - Satwik Rao Kolluru, Sameer Ahmed, Sujith Ramagiri and Parth Gowswami

HYDERABAD: After failing to find a spot in 100th percentile list last year, a student from Telangana secured top marks in the Common Admission Test (CAT) 2019 examination, results of which were released on Saturday. He is among 10 candidates, all from engineering or technology background, who was in the 100th percentile from across India. The topper from the state is believed to be a resident of Rangareddy district and is from the Indian Institute of Technology, Mumbai.While the number of aspirants from two states securing top score has remained low in last three years, academicians say many have still managed to secure a seat in the top IIMs (Indian Institute of Management ). “Hardly two candidates managed to secure highest percentile, but that doesn’t mean candidates did not get into top IIMs,” said Ramnath K, all-India CAT course director, TIME Institute.Among those in the 99.99 percentile bracket is Satwik Rao Kolluru from Hyderabad who is currently pursuing his final year in civil engineering at IIT-Mumbai. Speaking to STOI, Satwik said that his aim is to pursue MBA from IIM Ahmedabad or Bangalore. “If I fail to get a seat in one of these IIMs, I would consider the offer I received during placements and would try again next year,” he said.As per IIM-Kozhikode, that organised the exam, 21 candidates from across the country scored an overall 99.99 percentile in CAT 2019 . Out of them, 19 candidates are from the engineering/technology background. Attributing the performance of students from the two states to many giving the exam a miss, N Ramana Rao, director, National Institute of Technology, Warangal said: “IIMs have never been the preferred choice for students here, until very recently. Since top candidates give CAT examination a miss, there are not many toppers from Telangana and AP.”

Title: Karnataka: Across districts, authorities go all out to better SSLC outcome
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representational Image

BENGALURU: Missed calls from teachers to parents at 5am to wake up children for studies, students drawing rangolis to learn parts of a heart, special classes, reading rooms and monthly meetings for mothers — government schools across Karnataka are gearing up for the upcoming SSLC exams and using innovation to push up the pass percentage.

With district-wise rankings getting more competitive, various districts are taking special care not to leave any student behind. Last year, Hassan topped the list and then deputy commissioner Rohini Sindhuri was hailed for the turnaround in the district’s performance.

“Our preparations started as early as August. We’ve formed a special task force. A special assessment exam was conducted in August and 30% students were found to be weak. They have been categorised as ‘slow achievers’ to ensure they aren’t demotivated, and are clubbed in smaller classes. A special syllabus has been drafted for them and they’ve been given books,” said Fouzia Tarannum, CEO of Chikkaballapura zilla panchayat. The authorities also intend to take students to exam centres in March to give them a feel of the hall. The exams will begin on March 27.

In Bengaluru Rural district, students who scored less than 40% in mid-term exams are attending activity-based sessions influenced by the philosophy of renowned educationist John Dewey. Special worksheets have been prepared with corporate social responsibility (CSR) funds received from Bengaluru International Airport Limited.

In some districts, parents too are being involved in the process. “Teachers give missed calls to parents to wake up their children at 5am. In case guardians don’t turn up for parent-teacher meetings, teachers visit houses. We educate parents not to engage Class 10 children in other work. It’s important to take parents along,” Fouzia said.

In Hassan, special meetings are organised for mothers of SSLC students, where they are updated about their wards’ performance. In Mysuru district, students drop details of questions and problem areas in a box, and teachers hold classes on those topics for the entire batch.

In Mandya, there’s a special focus on boys as their pass percentage last year was 12% less than that of girls. “Boys get easily distracted with games, social media and TV. Girls are more motivated,” said K Yallakki Gowda, CEO, Mandya ZP. Thirty-two schools with a pass percentage of 40-60% have been allotted nodal officers who visit the institutions frequently to assess kids’ progress.

Raichur district, which was among the poorest performers last year, is conducting 48 tests in 12 weeks — one chapter per day. “This will not only make students familiar with questions but also help them overcome exam fear,” said Lakshmikanth Reddy G, CEO, Raichur ZP. In Hassan, 21,010 students are given take-home exams and open-book exams.

Teachers from Government High School, Pillangere village (on the outskirts of Shivamogga), are footing the electricity bills of SSLC students from poor families and buying them brighter bulbs.

-With Inputs from M Shrinivasa and Mahendra Kumar in Ballari

Boxes: Take a break from TV, parents told

Following feedback from students that the television-watching pattern of their parents is disturbing their preparations at home, education department authorities in Mysuru district have asked parents to take a break from TV when their children are at home and studying. The message has been communicated through parents meetings’ conducted at the school level.

Reading rooms in 225 Ballari schools

Reading rooms (odina mane) were set up in 225 Ballari schools on January 1 and are open from 6pm to 9pm every day. Bharathi Thimmareddy, president of Ballari ZP, said, “Most government school students are from lower-income groups and face problems like unaffordable power supply and disturbance caused by family members and neighbours. After talks with educationists, we set up these odina manes.”

No district-wise ranking?

Suresh Kumar S, minister for primary and secondary education minister, said the government is considering scraping the district-wise ranking announcement. “We want qualitative and not quantitative results. How students cleared the SSLC examination is equally important, not just the number of students who cleared it. So, we don’t want to declare district-wise ranking based on pass percentage. A final decision will be taken in a day or two,” he said.

Title: Reservations finalised for municipalities
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The government completed reservations for 385 corporators in 10 municipal corporations and 2,727 ward councillors in 120 municipalities along with the voters’ list on Saturday. Reservations for chairperson posts in urban local bodies will be completed by Sunday. Government has sent list of voters and number of wards reserved for each category to district collectors and municipal commissioners. Officials said reservations were finalised taking the Census 2011 population figures into consideration.

While 50% of wards had been reserved for women, some wards for SCs and BCs. At least one seat has been earmarked for STs where the ST population is less than 1 per cent. For instance, in Karimnagar Municipal Corporation, of total 60 wards, one seat was reserved for an ST, six for SCs, 23 wards for BCs and 16 for women. Fourteen wards are unreserved which means any category candidate can contest. Since the reservation process is over, the State Election Commission (SEC) will announce the list of wards that were reserved for each category on Sunday and issue the poll notification on January 7. TNN

Title: CBI courts seeks status of case against ex-AP minister Dharmana Prasad Rao
Content:
Dharmana Prasad Rao. Photo credit: @YSRCParty

HYDERABAD: Principal special judge BV Madhusudan Rao of Hyderabad Central Bureau of Investigation(CBI) court has directed the agency to inform the court by January 7 the status of the case filed against Andhra Pradesh’s former revenue minister Dharmana Prasad Rao wuth the Supreme Court . Dharmana was made an accused in the Vanpic charge sheet of quid pro quo case filed by CBI against AP’s current chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy.As the provisions of the Prevention of Corruption Act make it mandatory for the CBI to obtain sanction from the state government to prosecute a public servant like a cabinet minister, CBI had applied to Andhra Pradesh in 2013 seeking permission to prosecute the minister. The state government did not accord sanction.As a result, the CBI court refused to take into cognisance the role of Dharmana in the case. However, when Dharmana stepped down, the CBI filed another memo before the trial court urging it to take cognisance as he was no more a public servant.The trial court then took into cognisance the role played by the then revenue minister in the huge land allotments made in Vanpic episode. Aggrieved by this, Dharmana had approached the high court challenging the trial court’s decision.Finding force in the argument of Dharmana, the high court earlier set aside the cognisance order.Aggrieved, the CBI challenged the HC order in the Supreme Court. It was the status of this case, the CBI court now wants to know.

Title: Telangana: One more held in IMS scam
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Days after arresting Omni Medi owner K Srihari Babu and a pharma company representative, the Anti-Corruption Bureau on Saturday arrested one more person in the multi-crore Insurance Medical Services ( IMS ) scam . So far, 24 persons have been arrested in the scam.

Cherukuri Nagaraju, 47, marketing manager with Omni Medi, was taken into custody and booked for criminal conspiracy and relevant sections of Prevention of Corruption Act, 1988. According to ACB , Nagaraju colluded with government officials and others and lured public servants to get the bills cleared in a dubious manner.

Nagaraju allegedly obtained purchase orders and got the bills cleared for Omni Medi and Legend Enterprises. Sources said Nagaraju worked for both Omni Medi and Legend Enterprises. It may be recalled Srihari, former IMS director Ch Devika Rani and former joint director K Padma played a key role in obtaining purchase orders for Legend Enterprises.

ACB arrested Srihari and Sweden-based pharma company HemoCue’s regional manager T Venkatesh on January 1. Venkatesh allegedly issued a fake authorisation letter indicating that Legend was the authorised distributor of HemoCue’s products in Telangana.

ACB sleuths arrested retired civil surgeon Dr P Gurumurthy, husband of Devika, unearthed Rs 100 crore worth disproportionate assets belonging to the couple.

Title: Karnataka: Across districts, authorities go all out to better SSLC outcome
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representational Image

BENGALURU: Missed calls from teachers to parents at 5am to wake up children for studies, students drawing rangolis to learn parts of a heart, special classes, reading rooms and monthly meetings for mothers — government schools across Karnataka are gearing up for the upcoming SSLC exams and using innovation to push up the pass percentage.

With district-wise rankings getting more competitive, various districts are taking special care not to leave any student behind. Last year, Hassan topped the list and then deputy commissioner Rohini Sindhuri was hailed for the turnaround in the district’s performance.

“Our preparations started as early as August. We’ve formed a special task force. A special assessment exam was conducted in August and 30% students were found to be weak. They have been categorised as ‘slow achievers’ to ensure they aren’t demotivated, and are clubbed in smaller classes. A special syllabus has been drafted for them and they’ve been given books,” said Fouzia Tarannum, CEO of Chikkaballapura zilla panchayat. The authorities also intend to take students to exam centres in March to give them a feel of the hall. The exams will begin on March 27.

In Bengaluru Rural district, students who scored less than 40% in mid-term exams are attending activity-based sessions influenced by the philosophy of renowned educationist John Dewey. Special worksheets have been prepared with corporate social responsibility (CSR) funds received from Bengaluru International Airport Limited.

In some districts, parents too are being involved in the process. “Teachers give missed calls to parents to wake up their children at 5am. In case guardians don’t turn up for parent-teacher meetings, teachers visit houses. We educate parents not to engage Class 10 children in other work. It’s important to take parents along,” Fouzia said.

In Hassan, special meetings are organised for mothers of SSLC students, where they are updated about their wards’ performance. In Mysuru district, students drop details of questions and problem areas in a box, and teachers hold classes on those topics for the entire batch.

In Mandya, there’s a special focus on boys as their pass percentage last year was 12% less than that of girls. “Boys get easily distracted with games, social media and TV. Girls are more motivated,” said K Yallakki Gowda, CEO, Mandya ZP. Thirty-two schools with a pass percentage of 40-60% have been allotted nodal officers who visit the institutions frequently to assess kids’ progress.

Raichur district, which was among the poorest performers last year, is conducting 48 tests in 12 weeks — one chapter per day. “This will not only make students familiar with questions but also help them overcome exam fear,” said Lakshmikanth Reddy G, CEO, Raichur ZP. In Hassan, 21,010 students are given take-home exams and open-book exams.

Teachers from Government High School, Pillangere village (on the outskirts of Shivamogga), are footing the electricity bills of SSLC students from poor families and buying them brighter bulbs.

-With Inputs from M Shrinivasa and Mahendra Kumar in Ballari

Boxes: Take a break from TV, parents told

Following feedback from students that the television-watching pattern of their parents is disturbing their preparations at home, education department authorities in Mysuru district have asked parents to take a break from TV when their children are at home and studying. The message has been communicated through parents meetings’ conducted at the school level.

Reading rooms in 225 Ballari schools

Reading rooms (odina mane) were set up in 225 Ballari schools on January 1 and are open from 6pm to 9pm every day. Bharathi Thimmareddy, president of Ballari ZP, said, “Most government school students are from lower-income groups and face problems like unaffordable power supply and disturbance caused by family members and neighbours. After talks with educationists, we set up these odina manes.”

No district-wise ranking?

Suresh Kumar S, minister for primary and secondary education minister, said the government is considering scraping the district-wise ranking announcement. “We want qualitative and not quantitative results. How students cleared the SSLC examination is equally important, not just the number of students who cleared it. So, we don’t want to declare district-wise ranking based on pass percentage. A final decision will be taken in a day or two,” he said.
