Title: Advocate files plea in Telangana high court to trace over 2,000 missing kids
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: An advocate, whose letter played a key role in ridding Yadadri of its infamous child trafficking and prostitution tag, has now set his eyes on tracing the missing children in Telangana. He stated that had police not closed missing cases and carried out proper investigation, Hajipur killings could have been averted.

Advocate Rapolu Bhaskar, whose letter on the woes of children caught in the clutches of trafficking mafia moved the high court, has now filed a public interest litigation (PIL) on the missing children. The high court had converted his letter into a PIL and ordered crackdown and freed Yadadri from the menace.

In his latest PIL, the advocate mentioned about the cases of missing children in Telangana. “Between 2015 and 2018, 2,000 children—1,350 girls and 650 boys — went missing. What is alarming is the fact that police are closing these cases without tracing the children,” he stated in his petition.

“Children are being kidnapped by mafia elements and are trafficked. Girls are being forced into prostitution,” he said. “The menace is more prevalent in Adilabad district, where the kidnapped children are being trafficked out to other states. Telangana has the dubious distinction of being at eighth place in the country in trafficking girls,” he said.

Most missing children belong to socially and economically weak sections. Police were not filing charge sheets in all the cases of missing children, he alleged.

Bhaskar urged the court to direct the director-general of police (DGP) and home secretary to reopen all the closed cases pertaining to missing children. “This would unearth the real criminals playing with the lives of children in particular and people in general,” he said.

He cited the Hazipur killings as an example where the rape and murder of three minor girls came to the fore long after the police closed these cases. “Had police investigated the cases properly, then the crimes would have been averted,” he said.

Title: CPI, CPM members detained for protesting against CAA
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Coimbatore: As many as 90 members and representatives of Communist Party of India (CPI) and Communist Party of India (Marxist), including CPM’s member of Parliament from Coimbatore P R Natarajan, were detained on Saturday evening for holding a protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and other policies of the Centre. Nine of the detained people were women.

The Left parties had called for the protest a week ago and had sought police permission. But the permission was denied on Friday.

The members, however, held the protest at 5pm on Saturday near the powerhouse on Sivananda Colony in the city. Police detained them and kept them at a private marriage hall nearby.

The protesters also voiced their support to the nation-wide strike on January 8, which, they said, has been called to condemn the Centre’s economic policies and the moves that would lead to the privatisation of public sector units. They called for the Centre to repeal CAA and also condemned police attacks on public, who have been protesting against it. TNN

Title: Environmentalists congregate at Haridwar to support woman seer fasting for clean Ganga since 21 days
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Brahmacharini Padmavati has been on a fast unto death since past 21 days against what she terms as the governm... Read More

Dehradun: Environmentalists from across the country have started gathering in Haridwar to support a woman seer from Bihar, Brahmacharini Padmavati who has been on a fast unto death since past 21 days against what she terms as the government’s apathy towards river Ganga. The seer has been among those who took up fasting for a clean and free-flowing Ganga after the death of IIT professor-turned seer GD Agrawal who had been fasting for the issue before he passed away in October 2018.

Agrawal’s major demands were stopping all four major dam projects on Ganga and its tributaries, stopping mining and stone crusher works on Ganga and its tributaries, ensuring standard e-flow in the river after scientific consultation from experts and implementing a Ganga Act to save the 2,525km-long river. Environmentalists say that none of these demands have been acted upon by the government despite Agrawal laying down his life for the cause.

“India has a tradition of respecting neer, naari, jal (water, women and river) but nobody seems to be bothered that a woman for the first time in history has been sitting on a protest fast to save a river. It is shameful for all of us. We urge the government to take cognisance and help Padmavati break her fast and show the world that this government really cares for the water system of the country and respects women,” said veteran water conservationist Rajendra Singh who reached Haridwar on Saturday to support Padmavati’s cause.

He added that in Padmavati’s support, a two-day national conclave on ‘Ganga Ecology Conservation’ is being organised at Matri Sadan, the ashram where the seer has been sitting on a peaceful protest. “The conclave will focus on bringing change in the policy to safeguard our country’s largest water system – Ganga. It is a sad reflection of the way the system has become that seers have to sit on protest in order to safeguard a river,” Singh said.

Meanwhile, Swami Shivanand Saraswati, head of Matri Sadan, blamed the state government for paying no attention to the Ganga, “Chief minister of Uttarakhand recently said Ganga is pure. If it is so, then why do they drink bottled water even at functions held at Haridwar? They should save money of exchequer and consume Ganga water when visiting Haridwar. This government is simply focussed on minting money through Ganga, and least bothered about the river.”

Title: Cops, NMC staff accused of having free city bus ride
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Nagpur: Police personnel and Nagpur Municipal Corporation employees allegedly travel in Aapli bus without paying the fare. This was informed by checkers with Aapli Bus programme manager Delhi Integrated Multi-Modal Transit System (DIMTS) to transport committee chairman Balya Borkar on Friday.

“Whenever conductors raise objection the cops and NMC employees threaten them with disciplinary action,” the checkers or flying squad members of DIMTS said.

Borkar said he will write to police commissioner BK Upadhyay and municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar regarding the issue. The NMC’s transport department has also approached the civic administration to provide 15 employees to form a special squad to curb cases of conductors pocketing bus fares, he said.

Title: KGH-AMC gets surgical skills lab
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A surgical skills lab or endo trainer lab (Nymisha) was inaugurated on Saturday at the department of surgery of Andhra Medical College ( AMC )-King George Hospital ( KGH ) by Dr K Venkatesh, director of medical education (DME), Andhra Pradesh and vice-chancellor in-charge, NTRUHS.

At a meeting following the inauguration, the DME spoke of the importance of an endo trainer laboratory for the development of surgical skills. He also stressed on the need for surgeons of all specialties to develop basic skills in minimal access (laparoscopy) surgery and to acquire the latest skills to operate state-of-the-art equipment.

The cost of the unit (consisting of 12 components) is around Rs 10 lakhs.

Dr PV Sudhakar, principal of AMC, stressed the need for continuous postgraduate learning as part of the curriculum for endo trainers. Dr G Arjuna, superintendent of KGH requested the DME to grant sufficient funds to KGH for its modernisation. Dr C Jayaraj, professor and head of the department of general surgery presided over the function. Other faculty members and postgraduate students of all departments attended the programme.

Title: Health min was enjoying in Dubai: BJP MP
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Ajmer: BJP MP from Ajmer Bhagirath Choudhary attacked health minister Raghu Sharma and alleged that when children were dying in the Kota hospital, Sharma was enjoying in Dubai.

Choudhary said that the issue was a sensitive one and that the BJP will come on roads to raise voice against it.

Ajmer is the home district of Raghu Sharma and the BJP seems to be creating an atmosphere against Sharma, to regain its vote bank here. While addressing a press conference, Choudhary attacked the Congress and said that minister Mamta Bhupesh a day ago accused the BJP of politicising the issue of death of children in Kota.

“It is the duty of opposition to highlight the failures of the government and on such sensitive issues, the BJP never does politics,” added Choudhary.

Title: Coimbatore: Man arrested for sharing child porn
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: Police on Saturday arrested a 23-year-old man from Assam for sharing child porn on Facebook.

The accused was identified as Renda Pakamathari, a native of Assam working in a tiles company on Palakkad Road in Pollachi .

The social media cell of the police department had recently identified the user, who had been uploading child porn on Facebook from Pollachi. “The All Women Police Station (AWPS) in Pollachi interrogated Pakamathari, who confessed that he had sent child porn to his friends through Facebook Messenger,” a police officer said.

Police arrested him under Section 13, 14 (1) and 15 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 read with the Information Technology Act, 2000. Pakamathari has been remanded in judicial custody.

Title: Deputy CM Sachin Pilot slams own government over Kota infant deaths
Content:
Sachin Pilot

JAIPUR: In an embarrassing development for the Ashok Gehlot-led Rajasthan government, state Congress chief and deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot on Saturday slammed its handling of the infant deaths in Kota’s JK Lon Hospital and demanded accountability. As many as 107 infants have died in the hospital in the past 35 days.After paying a visit to the Kota hospital, Pilot said the state government could not escape responsibility by pointing fingers at the previous government as “this is not a small incident, but a heart-wrenching one”.“I think our response to the entire episode could have been more sensitive and more compassionate. After 13 months in government, it may not serve any purpose (for us) to keep pointing towards the previous government’s wrongdoings or misdeeds,” Pilot said.He said, “As many as 107 children have died. It is not stopping. I have met some of the bereaved family members. I have no words to express their grief and hurt. The poor strata of society depends on government hospitals. Rolling out statistics will not do any good. We must infuse confidence in people that this kind of incident will not occur again. That is the demand of the people as well.”The deputy chief minister said the people voted out the previous government for its failures and blaming it will not absolve the present government of its responsibility. “We have been voted in. We have to take responsibility and face consequences. People expected us to deliver.”Asking for fixing accountability at all levels, Pilot said: “While expecting others to be accountable, we have to be accountable to ourselves first. The whole state, and the country, was shaken following the deaths. I think a much more positive and sensitive response coming from whole of us will be appreciated.” The incident has reignited the Gehlot-Pilot factional fight in the state. Only a few days ago, Pilot had publicly protested against the chief minister hogging all the limelight after the government completed one year in office. This, he had claimed, despite the good work done by him.According to sources, Pilot was even ignored in the deliberations for the anniversary celebration. Despite Pilot being the deputy CM, it was power minister BD Kalla who was made the chairperson of the cabinet committee to decide on the celebration.

Title: A Class(es) Apart
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Within four decades, Nagpur has metamorphosed from being a town dotted with small tuition classrooms into an established education hub with an estimated annual turnover of Rs100 crore. It was somewhere in the late 1970s, that the ‘tuition class’ trend started taking shape in Nagpur though still carrying a taboo of sorts as it was perceived to be only for academically weak school/junior college students. 40 years later, Nagpur now boasts of numerous coaching institutes which witness a staggering 20,000 enrolment each year in tailor-made course modules that prepare the kids for medical and engineering competitive exams.

Ejaz Inamdar started his math and science tuition class in the second half of 1980 with batches starting from right from 5am to accommodate the high student demand. “In those days, I never got a student who would score 80% or more in school because tuitions were considered to be something that only weak students enrolled for,” recalls Inamdar, who also broke the stereotype image of tuition teachers.

Always dressed in classy attire, designer glasses and riding an uber-cool bike, in the 1980s Inamdar was known as much for his unique teaching style as he was for his chocolate hero looks. This unintentional brand building helped, in some ways, to create an aura around tuition classes.

From individual stars like Inamdar, Nagpur saw a rise in integrated tuitions where more than one teacher taught. Panini Telang, founder of Pioneer Study Centre, said, “I believe the first organized tuition institute in Nagpur was Jayant Tutorials somewhere around 1982. It probably was the first known experiment where a group of teachers got together and started an institute.”

While this may have been the first attempt to make such multi-teacher classes commercially viable, earlier too multi-teacher set up existed as social projects. Around 1975, veteran academician Vijay Swami was involved in one such attempt to tutor underprivileged kids. “Tribal students or those coming from marginalized sections were taught by almost three to four of us. It was a completely charitable exercise,” said Swami.

The 80s and 90s firmly established the tuition class culture in Nagpur with students hopping to more than one class for math, biology etc. By the time the 90s ended, tuitions had become a need. Ranjnikanth Bondre, founder of Sneha Classes, said, “By 1997 or ’98 it was clear that every parent wanted their child to be enrolled in a tuition class. Competition had increased and it was natural for parents to want the best for their kids. Tuitions gave their kids an edge, and edge that made all the difference in the crucial board exams.”

As the 90s staggered to an end, Nagpur had an extremely well established tuition class culture with both single and multi-teacher set ups thriving. And this established culture meant that Nagpur was ready for the watershed moment that was coming in 2003. This was the year, when competitive exams came into play for admissions to medical and engineering colleges.

Sarang Upganlawar, founder of ICAD Institute, said, “That year was a turning point not only for the coaching industry but also for society. Before this only rote study was in vogue as board exam marks were the benchmark and then students would struggle when they enrolled for professional courses. But with competitive exams, the students started learning analytical skills and worked their brains to full capacity. Competitive exams have provided a stimulus to the brain.”

He added that now students from Nagpur are working in top first like Microsoft, IBM, Facebook, PWC etc with their first package itself starting from Rs25 lakh.

Though high quality and results producing local institutes had already taken roots in the city, this did not prevent national level players to step in. Allen Institute has been aggressively expanding its presence in Nagpur, even though it has been a relatively late entrant into the local market. Ashutosh Hisaria, the Nagpur centre head of Allen Institute, said, “The feasibility study of any city and its potential is done by our expert team, and based on that we take a decision on moving in or not. But if there are so many existing coaching institutes in a city, then it means there is a strong demand as well.”

Every coaching institute’s success lies in its faculty which produce results.

Tanjit Chhabra, business development head of, Resonance said, “It is a pure numbers game with demand-supply equation coming to the fore. In this industry, the faculty which has a higher strike rate (of students qualifying) is obviously more in demand. Every year faculty upskilling initiatives are also held in Kota to make sure everyone is up to date with the paper pattern.”

In Nagpur, monthly salary for teachers range between Rs25,000 to Rs5 lakh. It all depends on the seniority, performance of teachers. It is common for institutes to have a group of core and supplementary teachers. Core teachers are the subject experts while supplementary team clarifies smaller doubts in any subject or even the paper pattern.

In the over 15 years of its existence, coaching institutes in Nagpur have evolved to provide additional facilities. Narendra Wankhede, director of Wankhede Madam’s Academy, said, “Now a coaching institute has a well stocked library, a reading room and even a dining hall. Many institutes provide tiffin facilities for students as well. All this is done to save time for students that would otherwise be wasted in commuting.”

The coaching industry in Nagpur has also boosted its ancillary economy. Real estate rentals are thriving wherever coaching institutes are set up because they are considered ‘non-nuisance’ tenants. School vans and mini buses, that were idle post school hours have tapped into a booming business of transporting kids from home-to-institute, whereas road side food vendors are thriving in their vicinity. No wonder it is said, that Nagpur’s economy is run because of education.

Title: Assn calls for state-wide stir against ban on toddy
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Madurai: Demanding the ban on toddy to be lifted, the Federation of Tamil Nadu Agriculturists Association will hold a state-wide protest on January 21.Speaking at a press meet, C Nallasami, coordinator of the association, said that the state government has unfairly banned toddy for over 30 years now. Toddy is a white-coloured alcoholic beverage prepared by fermenting sugar sap extracted from palm trees and contains around 4-5% alcohol. It was banned in 1987 in Tamil Nadu.

“We have been challenging the government, public and activists to convince us that toddy is only harmful for health and have offered Rs 10 crore as prize money. However, till now, no one has come forward. Clearly, there is only unfair discrimination because other liquor with higher alcoholic content is not banned,” said Nallasami.“The state-wide protest will be held under the banner ‘Tamil Nadu Toddy Movement’ . We want to spread the message that toddy is like food and medicine, not the same as intoxicating, addictive drugs and liquor. Even Periyar supported the sale of toddy,” they said. tnn

Title: NCPCR report mentions glaring discrepancies at Kota hospital
Content:
Infrastructure of JK Lon Hospital was found to be pathetic.

JAIPUR: The National Commission for Protection of Child Rights (NCPCR) in its preliminary report has found glaring discrepancies in Kota ’s JK Lon Hospital where 107 children died in the last 35 days. A fact-finding team headed by NCPCR chief Priyank Kanoongo assisted by senior consultant Raman Kumar Gaur had visited the hospital on December 29 after the incident came to light.The commission said only nine ventilators out of 15 were working at the time of the incident. Also, the status about the operation and function of life saving equipment were not available with the authorities.It emerged during discussions with hospital staff that 10 infants who died within 48 hours were suffering from severe infection, hypoxia and septicemia. It said of the 10 children, two were brought at the hospital directly while three were referred from other hospitals.A newborn, whose parents wre from Madhya Pradesh, was brought to the hospital in a serious condition and died during treatment. However, the hospital did not have any information or knowledge where this newborn was delivered.The commission said the hospital did not have faculty as per the norms of the Medical Council of India.It was informed to the commission that one of the reasons for the deaths of infants was underweight kids born to anaemic mothers.Kota chief medical officer was found negligent towards his duties and was not present at the meeting despite calling him several times.

Title: Will push for metro rail, bus port in Madurai: Revenue min
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Madurai: Revenue minister R B Udhayakumar has said a boost will be given for infrastructure development in Madurai as it is one of the top developing districts in the state.

The minister, while speaking at the valedictory function for a trade fair organized by the Tamil Nadu Chamber of Commerce on Saturday, stressed that he will push for projects including metro rail and bus port in the city.

“Madurai will surely become one of the top smart cities in the state and country. I will personally push for a metro rail project in Madurai and put forth the request to CM Edappadi K Palaniswamy. Various other projects as proposed by the chamber like bus port, overbridges, elevated highways in the district will also be given full support by the government,” said Udhayakumar.

The minister further said that the government will continue to always offer support to the Tamil Nadu Chamber of Commerce. “The bus port proposed first by the chamber has seen administrative delays but I will ensure that efforts will be speeded up. We will also try to speed up road and flyover projects in the district which are seeing legal, administrative and technical delays,” he said. The members of the chamber also requested for a trade centre to be built in the district.

Other dignitaries present at the event include Madurai South MLA S S Saravanan, district collector T G Vinay, TNCC president N Jegadeesan and other prominent members of the chamber. The sixteenth TNCC trade fair was held began on December 20 and concluded on Saturday at the Tamukkam ground in Madurai.

The fair hosted around 250 stalls from across various sectors, a play area and food court.

Title: Chennai: Basin Bridge turns one-way for now
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The closure of the Elephant Gate flyover had caused traffic snarls on Basin Bridge

CHENNAI: The traffic police have made Basin Bridge one-way on a temporary basis to ease flow of vehicles which used to line up for at least a kilometre on all sides, choking movement.

They have prevented vehicles from making a right turn at Basin Bridge flyover and proceed towards Choolai and Pulianthope.

Instead, the vehicles coming from Vyasarpadi flyover have been directed to travel further on Basin Bridge and proceed upto Mint flyover where they will have to make an U-turn to travel back on a parallel road through Padmanabha theatre and then climb Basin Bridge flyover to proceed towards Choolai or Pulianthope.

Motorists also cannot proceed on Wall Tax Road to reach Choolai, Pulianthope or Vepery, since the Elephant Gate flyover is under construction, though it will soon be thrown open. A senior police officer said, “We have made the arrangements on a trial basis to check viability.”

Police said the motorists have to travel an additional 2.5 km to proceed towards Choolai or Pulianthope. As the stretch – Basin Bridge – connects Grand North Trunk (GNT) Road with one of the city’s premier medical institutions — Government Stanley Hospital — ‘108’ ambulance drivers had often complained of vehicular pile-up at the bridge, forcing them to lose the ‘golden hour’ for those injured in accidents.

The traffic police also plan to add another one-way route to ease the flow on Basin Bridge flyover. The vehicles from Choolai and Pulianthope will be allowed to proceed towards Vyasarpadi and make an ‘U’ turn under Vyasarpadi flyover and proceed towards Basin Bridge flyover and further on to Mint.

They are also working on detailed plans to end the traffic snarls choking Basin Bridge. “Many people who reside in RK Nagar, Tondiarpet, Korukkupet, Washermenpet and Manali prefer to use the Vyasarpadi stretch to take Basin Bridge to reach MGR Central in less than 30 minutes. It earlier took more than two hours to reach these places,” said a police officer.

According to police data, at least 50–60 vehicles pass through Basin Bridge flyover every minute during the peak hours. Police said they were re-routing ambulances on the one-way stretch to reach Basin Bridge flyover, especially during peak hours, to avoid snarls.

Title: Delhi: Kalindi Kunj road shut, ripple effect on Barapullah
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The cops will conduct a study of the traffic volume on the stretch and might ban the entry of small commercial... Read More

NEW DELHI: Ashram Chowk has reached breaking point after traffic was diverted with the closure of the Kalindi Kunj road due to anti-Citizenship Amendment Act protesters occupying it. But the Barapullah elevated road has also suffered collateral damage, with an increasing number of affected vehicles using it. This is compounded by a bottleneck formed at the DND Flyway entry near Sarai Kale Khan. The situation is so bad at peak hours that cops are forced to stop vehicles at the DND loops leading to the elevated segment.

With the Kalindi Kunj road blocked by police, vehicles going to Noida from south Delhi use Mathura Road to access the DND flyway, but many try to avoid the exasperating jams at Ashram caused by the construction of the underpass and the increased volume of traffic by taking the Barapullah-DND route.

According to a police estimate, around 30,000 vehicles are plying on the Barapullah stretch these days, nearly double the number that the elevated road can accommodate. The snarl at the DND intersection adds to the overall chaos.

Some of the harassed commuters claimed that even normal drive time on the Barapullah length, usually 45 minutes at most, has now increased by up to an hour and a half due to the congestion. Apart from cars, over a thousand commercial vehicles going from south Delhi to east Delhi or Noida have also been using the route to avoid Ashram. Though the traffic police has been directing them to alternative passages, including the Noida Link Road, they somehow contrive to use the shorter elevated road.

Police officers warned that the snarls are expected to linger on until the Kalindi Kunj road is opened to traffic again. However, they also added that the jams are not likely to fully end so long as the extension of the elevated road to Mayur Vihar is not completed. There is construction work going on, resulting in the three-lane road getting constricted near Sarai Kale Khan. The road takes a loop towards the DND connector here and vehicles tend to slow down, creating a tailback that can stretch back to even Kidwai Nagar during the rush hours.

A similar situation is reported during the morning hours when a huge volume of traffic from Noida travels towards south Delhi using the same facility. “We have to deploy personnel on the elevated road, which was designed to provide a seamless flow of traffic, to manage the situation caused by traffic from the DND loop merging there,” said a traffic police officer.

The cops will conduct a study of the traffic volume on the stretch and might ban the entry of small commercial vehicles to alleviate the pain of commuters. Police may also halt traffic on Ring Road periodically to allow vehicles from the Barapullah road to access the DND loop and thus undo the traffic knot clear on the elevated road

Title: Exhibition on achievements of yesteryear biz captain
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Coimbatore: A gallery displaying inventions and innovations of Gopalaswamy Doraiswamy Naidu referred to as the Edison of India in the fields of radio technology, machine tools, bus transport, agriculture and siddha was opened at the GD Naidu Museum here on Saturday.

The gallery, managed by GD Naidu Charities, shows how Naidu, with no formal education, was able to acquire such a vast knowledge and actively involve himself in the field of education and contribute to the industrial growth of the district.

It also chronicles the legendary innovator’s early life, his travels to Europe, his tryst with the income tax department and his contributions to job-oriented vocational education.

Some black and white photographs on display show his residence Gopal Bagh, where he hosted eminent personalities to discuss the progress of India.

It was opened by chairman of Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan B K Krishnaraj Vanavarayar. Group editorial director, India Today Group, Raj Chengappa, was the guest of honour.

Title: Mining scam: four declared absconders
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Jaipur: After failure of execution of arrest warrants, a special court dealing with money laundering cases on Saturday declared four accused in the infamous mining bribery case were declared as absconders.

Those who were declared absconders are Pankaj Gehlot, the then additional mines director, Sanjay Sethi who was a middleman between the mines owners and mining department, Shyam Sundar a chartered accountant and Dhirendra Singh. The court has also issued standing warrants against all four accused. However, the court of Justice Arun Kumar Agarwal refused to issue standing warrants against the accused including retired IAS Ashok Singhvi, Pushkar Raj Ameta and Rasheed Khan.

Agarwal has summoned the re-arrest warrant these three accused. An arrest warrant is continuing in the money laundering case against all accused.

Title: Universities should bring about social revolution: Ex-CJI
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Coimbatore: Education is a process of refinement and the best investment a country can bestow on its youth, Justice P Sathasivam , former Chief Justice of India and former governor of Kerala, said here on Saturday .

“Universities should help bring a social revolution by contributing batches of scientists, technicians, engineers, agriculturists and others, who would change the economic character of the society,” he said while speaking at an event held at the Tamil Nadu Agricultural University (TNAU) to present the lifetime achievement award to former vice-chancellor of Anna University E Balagurusamy.

Sathasivam also spoke on the initiatives he took as the chancellor of 14 universities in Kerala during his tenure from 2014 to 2019. He said he instituted the chancellor’s award for the best university. “I appointed a committee consisting professors from IIT, IIM and the VC of Law University and asked them to formulate guidelines and eligibility for the award. The Kerala chief minister agreed to give Rs 5crore as the prize money,” he said. “I also instituted an award for the best emerging young university.”

The former CJI said he had conveyed this to all governors at a governor’s conference attended by the President of India, the vice-president and the Prime Minister. “This is one method of improving the quality of education. I sought quarterly progress reports from university vice-chancellors on specific parameters. These reports were reviewed, and feedback was given on the same day. I had also sought monthly reports on sexual harassment, ragging and drug abuse and action taken report on incidents. These instilled a better sense of quality in higher education.”

TNAU vice-chancellor N Kumar, vice-chancellor of Bharathiar University P Kaliraj and vice-chancellor of Mother Teresa Women's University Vaidehi Vijayakumar attended the event.

Title: Badaga festival: Local holiday on January 8
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Udhagamandalam: On account of ‘Hethai Habba’, an annual festival of the Badaga community – the largest social group in the hills, the Nilgiris district administration has declared a local holiday on January 8.

The Badaga community’s eight day long main festival season ‘Hethai Habba’, (a festival of ancestress Goddess of the Badagas), is going to be held in Beragani village near Kotagiri from January 6.

Declaring local holiday on the main festival day of ‘Hethai Habba’ season was one of the election promises made by the then AIADMK chief late J Jayalalithaa during her election campaign here in 2011.

Since 2012, the Nilgiris has been enjoying a local holiday on the main festival day.

According to a press released by the Nilgiris district administration, the declared holiday applies to all the schools, colleges, government offices and private concerns. The release added that essential services would function as usual including the treasuries in the district. To compensate for the holiday, February 1 will be a working day.

Title: Coimbatore News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Coimbatore: A huge crowd of men , women and children watched in awe as the waves of a turquoise Kurichi lake gently rocked six sailboats, a kayak and a rowing boat.

The two-day Royal Boat Show, which began on Saturday as part of the 12th edition of the annual Coimbatore Vizha (Coimbatore Festival), will create awareness on rainwater harvesting and preservation of water bodies, said B Praveen Kumar, chairman of Young Indians (YI), which is organizing the event in association with the Indian Navy and the Royal Madras Yacht Club (RMYC).

Commanding officer of INS Agrani Ashok Rai along with social activist SP Anbarasu inaugurated the show.

The boats were brought from the Southern Naval Command in Kochi, Kumar said. “A team comprising of 14 Navy personnel and RMYC members are rowing the boats. The boats neither pollute the lake nor make noise,” TOI. “We have also deployed a motorized rescue boat to handle any untoward incident.”

“Coimbatore Vizha is not just about celebrations but also about creating a platform for new ventures. As of now, no boating activity is carried out in the city. By laying a foundation as part of the vizha, we are planning to create an ecosystem where sailing can be taken up as a sport for the younger generation,” Kumar said.

YI is planning to conduct a regatta, which will have a series of boat or yacht races, as a part of the vizha next year, the official said. “We are also conducting talks with the city corporation, Indian Navy and various government departments on starting a boat club as a part of the lake beautification project.”

The only thing that connects the city with boating is the non-functioning boat house at Singanallur lake, said Dharmalingam, a resident of Veerakeralam. “It is the first time a boat show is being organized in the city. As there are not many recreational spaces, the event attracted several people, especially children. But, as the details of the event were not publicized properly, we could not reach here on time,” he said.

The boat show is on from 10:30am to 12:30pm and again from 3pm to 5pm.

Title: Judicial magistrates trained in handling forest cases
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Udhagamandalam: A two-day training programme to enlighten the 2019-batch judicial magistrates in the state on Wildlife Protection Act and Tamil Nadu Forest Act, 1972, got under way at Mudumalai Tiger Reserve (MTR) in the Nilgiris on Saturday.

Field training on forest-related cases for the judges was the main part of the programme. In 2017, a similar kind of training was conducted for the first time in MTR for civil judges.

Organized by the Tamil Nadu State Judicial Academy in association with the forest department, the training was attended by 55 judicial magistrates on Saturday.

According to K K Kaushal, field director, MTR, the main objective of the programme was to sensitize the judges on forest cases, which, he said, were different from police cases.

Pointing out that the training programme would facilitate the young civil judges to gain first-hand information on forests and its importance, Kaushal said, “It would help them adopt special mechanism to deal with forest and wildlife related cases.”

Another forest official said the training programme helped bridge the gap between the forest department and the judiciary.

Meanwhile, the 2018-batch IFS officers on probation also visited the MTR as part of field training.

Title: Madras high court restrains use of Ambur star biriyani logo
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: The Madras high court has restrained B Firdous Ahmed of Ambur from using the trademark and symbols of Ambur Star Biriyani, saying there was enough material to show the trademark had been infringed.

Justice G Jayachandran before whom a civil suit by M Anees Ahmed, proprietor of M/s Ambur Star Briyani, came up for hearing on Friday, said: “There is prima facie material to indicate that the trademark is being infringed by the defendants (Firdous Ahmed) who deceive the common public and pass the products as those of the plaintiff (Anees Ahmed). Hence, interim injunction restraining the defendants from using the registered trademark ‘Ambur Star Briyani’ is ordered till January 30, 2020.”

Stating that the photographs of the defendants, wherein the name ‘Star’ is identical and the colour and design are predominant beneath the word ‘Ambur Briyani’ is shown, the judge recorded that though notices had been delivered to the defendant, there was no representation. Postal covers were returned with an endorsement as either ‘door closed’ or ‘left’.

Title: TNSTC to ply special buses to handle Pongal rush
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Coimbatore: The Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) is all set to operate special buses to Salem and Trichy from the city to manage Pongal rush.

According to a press release, TNSTC is planning to operate 230 additional buses to Salem and another 200 buses to Trichy from the city from January 11 to 14.

Presently, there are 127 buses making 184 trips to Salem from Gandhipuram bus stand and 55 buses making 60 trips to Trichy from Singanallur bus stand on a daily basis, the release said.

To avoid traffic congestion, a temporary bus stand would be set up on CODISSIA ground, from where the buses to both the destinations (Salem and Trichy) would operate. TNSTC said in the release that adequate town buses would also be operated from CODISSIA to Gandhipuram bus stand and Singanallur bus stand.

Basic amenities like toilet and drinking water facilities will be provided at the temporary bus on CODISSIA ground, it said.

Title: ‘Stress makes anger worse, use techniques to quell before it aggravates’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Rachna Bhola, a postgraduate in psychology counselling as well as English literature, conducts dermatoglyphics multiple intelligence tests (DMIT) and workshops on stress and anger management. While pursuing her post-graduation, the teacher-turned-counsellor completed a project on ‘Depression and stress among urban victimized adolescence’. Rachna had to shift to Chandrapur from Delhi after her husband, a senior government official, was transferred.

In a chat with TOI, she spoke about her plans to starts workshops on stress and anger management in Vidarbha.

Excerpts from the interview...

Q. How would describe anger as an emotional outburst?

A. Anger is one of the most powerful and vital emotions. It’s a reaction to frustration and maltreatment. It’s an ‘umbrella emotion’, covering numerous feelings like rejection, hurt, embarrassment, fear and insecurity. Anger styles are predominantly learnt from early childhood but can also be caused by mood disorders such as depression or other genetic inheritances. It is a negative, internal feeling associated with specific cognitive and perceptual distortions. In angry people there are several deficiencies like mis-appraisals, errors, attributions of blame, injustice, preventability, intentionality, subjective labelling and physiological changes.

Q. What are the ills and evils of anger?

A. People who explode with anger are at a great risk of getting a stroke. Anger ruins relationships. When anger turns to aggression or violence, the evil effects are more severe. Study shows that one-third of couples experience at least one incident of domestic violence due to anger. The effect on children witnessing conflict at home can be devastating. Anger also affects productivity at the workplace.

Q. Are anger and stress linked?

A. There is more anger in the world today than 20 years ago. It is evident in workplace violence, road rage, school shoot-outs, etc. Stress can increase certain problems and if you experience anger often, chances are, stress will make it worse. Healthy stress is good when it is controlled and does not lead to irritability. One must learn to identify unhelpful or negative thought patterns and change inaccurate beliefs.

Q. In what way is violence related to anger?

A. Crime is a result of emotional strain in one’s life. Strain is a result of losing something valuable such as a career or marriage or failing to achieve financial or academic goals. Strained relationships also lead to anger. According to a research, negative emotions take the form of anger. They lead to crime, including violence, within the four walls of the house or outside it. Domestic violence and road rage are the two most common fallouts of anger.

Q. Is anger playing a role in the rising number of suicide cases?

A. The suicide rate of adolescents has increased. Some adolescents have difficulty regulating their behaviour in the face of anger and emotion associated with suicidal behaviour. Suicide is the third leading cause of deaths in 15 to 19-year-olds. Physical, emotional and social changes, including poverty, abuse, violence, can make adolescents vulnerable to mental health problems. Anger and the expression of anger is associated with suicidal behaviour.

Q. Has anger increased violence against women?

A. Driven by anger, men tend to become violent. Lack of education, a history of child maltreatment, exposure to domestic violence against their mothers, alcohol, unequal gender norms and a sense of entitlement over women are the main reasons. Women are more likely to experience intimate partner violence. They need to be educated and more socially aware about their rights in order to handle a man’s aggression and anger.

Q. Has anger become one of the most damaging aspects of today’s society in the context of personal relationships or social behaviour?

A. When anger is not handled properly in a relationship, it can cause irreparable damage. If people learn to understand and share the underlying drivers of their anger, it will go a long way in saving relationships. Some partners do respond positively by listening and caring.

Q. Do you feel the rise in the number of divorce cases, marital disputes and family problems have risen due to anger?

A. Angry exchanges are bound to happen between intimate partners. Anger is identified as the most powerful emotion expressed in relational conflict and may escalate quickly. If not corrected, the fallout could be separations or irreparable rifts. Anger has certainly increased divorce cases and disputes. Timely intervention and counselling can save marriages and families.

Q. Do you feel anger has damaged many interpersonal relationships?

A. Correlation analysis revealed that there is a negative relationship between anger and interpersonal relations. Anger elicits stronger paralinguistic changes in a person’s voice. People communicate anger through facial or postural gestures. We need to listen before we speak. In this manner, we can assess the situation logically. Don’t assume that you ‘know’ how others feel or why they made certain choices. Focus solely on the issue as it makes you more objective. Respond assertively and not aggressively. Avoid over-generalization. Keep words like ‘“always,” “never” or “everyone” out of discussions. For example, instead of saying “everyone takes advantage of me” and getting worked up, you can instead say “I can’t do this for you over the weekend. I already have plans”.

Q. Do you feel there is anger behind every ‘danger’?

A. Anger is initially elicited by a perception of a threat to one’s physical well-being, property, present or future resources, self-image, social status or projected image to one’s group, maintenance of social rules that regulate daily life or comfort. It may persist even after the threat has passed. Anger motivates a response of antagonism to thwart, drive off, retaliate against or attack the source of the perceived threat. By controlling your physical responses, you can diffuse a tense situation because you are better able to calm down and reframe the situation mentally.

Q. How can one control anger?

A. Through anger management techniques, anger can be reduced. Reconstruction of focus and thinking style can help. Provocation and impulsive reactions can be controlled through breathing techniques, in-depth muscular relaxation and imagination. Learning behavioural coping to manage provocative situations in a constructive manner can help to solve problems.

Q. What must one do to quell one’s anger?

A. One must use stress management techniques before it turns into anger or aggression or aggravation. Lack of empathy leads to poor communication skills and failure to understand others. It’s all about learning to recognize and modify self-talk or inner conversation. Learning to effectively communicate without getting hostile, adjusting expectations and learning the process of forgiveness are steps towards anger control.

Title: Rogue elephant tramples elderly woman to death
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Krishnagiri: An elderly woman was trampled to death near Hosur here in the early hours of Saturday when she, along with her granddaughter, ventured out of her house to attend nature’s call. Forest officials identified the deceased as Vengita Lakshmiyammal, 75, of Kudisaganapalli village.

A forest official said Vengita was on her way to nearby forest to attend nature’s call when the elephant attacked her. She was accompanied by her granddaughter Divya, 22 .

“A herd of 9 elephants suddenly started moving towards the duo. One rogue elephant trampled Vekgita Lakshmiyammal. She succumbed to her injuries on the spot,” the official attached to the Hosur forest division said.

Divya alerted the villagers and the forest officials, who sent the body to government hospital in Hosur for postmortem.

In a separate incident, a section of villagers near Sanamavu forest region damaged a forest department jeep on Friday night after forest officials failed to chase the elephant herd away into the forest. “They also attacked forest guard Rakul, 27, who was on duty,” informed a police officer attached to Uthanapalli police station.

Based on Rakul’s complaint, the Uthanapalli police have registered a case and initiated inquiry. They also took the forest guard the government hospital in Hosur.

Title: ‘146 kids died in two Jodhpur hospitals in December'
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

File photo

JODHPUR: Amid the chaos over the deaths of infants at Kota’s J K Lon Hospital, disturbing figures of similar deaths have emerged from Jodhpur .

A joint report on infant deaths at Umaid Hospital and MDM Hospital in Jodhpur, prepared by the hospitals’ governing organisation, states that a total of 146 deaths (of children) were recorded at the Neo Natal Care and Paediatric ICUs in December.

As per figures obtained from S N Medical College, the governing organisation, a total of 4,689 children were admitted to the two hospitals in December. Of these, 3,002 were infants. During treatment, 146 children, including 102 infants, died.

SN Medical College principal S S Rathore said the child mortality rate came to 3%, which was in keeping with international infant mortality rates.

As per the figures, 47,815 children had been admitted to the hospital in 2019, of which 754 children died, which is 1.57%. But, of these, 5,634 children were admitted to the Neo NICU and ICU in serious condition and all 754 deaths were reported in the NICU and ICU.

Rathore said the paediatric care units for critical patients had been winning first prize for the past 2 years in succession and this was because “we are doing the best”.

He added that the hospital here has to bear the load of patients from entire western Rajasthan and children are also referred to this hospital from hospitals like AIIMS.

While calculating the mortality rate, the hospital administration calculated it factoring in patients admitted to the paediatric wards while the deaths occurred in the NICU and ICU.

Though Rathore denied any shortage of resources to deal with the “pressure”, many senior doctors from the hospital’s paediatric department have been running their own private hospitals and skipping hospital duties. Recently notices had been served on these doctors, including those who had medical shops at their residences, but the situation has not shown any improvement and the absence of senior doctors from the OPD remains a matter of concern.

Title: Corp to resume hygiene inspections of all eateries
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kozhikode: City Corporation authorities have decided to resume the inspection covering all types of food handling outlets ranging from make shift eatery outlets to hotels and restaurants in its limits.

The decision was taken after a recent inspection carried out by corporation health standing committee chairman K V Baburaj detected anomalies at the hotels in the city limits.

The surprise inspection held on January 1, 2020 detected unhygienic conditions at the hotel kitchens and inside the freezers used to store food items. They have also come across the repeated reuse of cooking oil for the food preparation and absence of waste disposal facilities at some of the hotels.

The health section had detected anomalies at the major hotels of Top Form; Ruchi Bhavan; Hotel Yash International; Dakshin The Veg; Adyar Sree Bhavan; Royal Restaurant and Sopanam vegetarian during the inspection.

The inspection will cover hotels restaurants, juice parlours, make shift eatery outlets and other food handling business to ensure the use of safe water for the preparation of food and juice items and hygienic quality of prepared food items. The move will also ensure that the consumers get the good quality food items. The health officials will also check the display of price chart at the hotels and waste disposal facilities set up at the food handling business outlets for the disposal of generated waste water and solid waste. The inspections will be conducted by the squads headed by respective health inspectors in-charge of 18 health circles and three zonal offices of Elathur, Beypore and Cheruvannur-Nallalam. Corporation health standing committee chairman K V Baburaj said that civic body will commence regular inspections to check the hygienic quality of food and water using for the preparation of various types food items. “We have also decided to take stern actions in the coming days and to resume the inspections headed by health inspectors in the respective health circles,” he said adding that he along with health officers will conduct surprise inspections soon.

Title: Seeranaickenpalayam bridge is now open for motorists
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Coimbatore: Much to the relief of motorists, Seeranaickenpalayam bridge that was closed for renovation seven months ago was opened for traffic on Saturday. Thousands of motorists use it as a shortcut to reach southern parts of the district and Thondamuthur from areas in and around Vadavalli and Thadagam Road.

R Siraj, a varkey baker, said, “I was forced to drive all the way up to Thadagam Road, take a right and then turn to Sundapalayam Road to go to Perur for work. It was not only tiring but also used to take me at least 10 minutes longer.” He was happy to ride through Seeranaickenpalayam Road on Saturday.

Seeranaickenpalayam Road connects PN Pudur with Sundapalayam Road. When it was closed for repair works, hundreds of agriculture students had a hard time reaching paddy breeding stations and grounds. Other commuters too had to take roundabout routes.

“Many people from Vadavalli and PN Pudur travel regularly to areas such as Selvapuram, Perur, Ukkadam and RS Puram. This shortcut is critical part of their route,” said N Chandran, an activist from the area.

Roads on both sides of the bridge too have got a makeover. “The bridge and roads on its both sides were in a terrible condition with deep potholes,” recalled courier delivery boy G Manikandan. “It was a nightmare to ride through the stretch. I was afraid of slipping and falling down. But now that the roads have been relaid, they are flat and smooth to ride on,” he said.

Many residents of Seernaickenpalayam also heaved a sigh of relief, saying they no longer have to travel all the way to Veerakeralam to reach either Marudhamalai Road or Sundapalayam Road as the main road was now open. They are also satisfied with the newly relaid interior roads. Kaveri G, a resident, said, “We had been riding on bad roads for so many years. With new roads around, our area looks different now.”

The new bridge is wider and higher, allowing two-way movement of vehicles and preventing sewage from flowing over the bridge during rain. The bridge was widened to 11m from 7m, while its height has been increased to 10ft from the earlier 5ft.

Title: Woman dupes senior citizen of gold chain
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Coimbatore: The city police are on the lookout for an unidentified woman, who stole gold ornaments from an elderly woman near Gandhipuram bus stand.

According to a police source, the accused befriended M Maruthayi, 65, a resident of Karur, while she was waiting at the central bus stand on November 19. “She approached Maruthayi and initiated a conversion. She told her that she has been receiving old age pension and offered to help Maruthayi to avail the same if she was interested,” the source said.

When Maruthayi showed interest, the woman asked her to remove her gold ornaments, saying she would look wealthier with them and that officials were likely to reject her application. Maruthayi subsequently removed her gold chain that weighed two sovereigns.

“The woman then offered to help her wrap the ornament. After handing over a package to her, the woman left the place asking Maruthayi to wait for her. As she didn’t return, Maruthayi opened the package and found it contained only stones and not her chain,” the source said.

On Friday, Maruthayi filed a complaint with the Kattoor police, who registered a case under Section 379 (theft) of the Indian Penal Code.

A similar incident had taken place at the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital a few days ago when two people stole gold ornaments weighing 7.5 sovereign from a woman by promising her financial assistance to meet her medical expenses. Police had arrested the duo - Krishnakumar and Vijayalakshmi - in that case.

Title: 11 tonnes of red sanders seized in Perungalathur
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Police on Saturday seized about 11 tonnes of red sanders from a warehouse in Perungalathur near Maraimalai Nagar. They later handed over the seized logs to forest officials in Chengalpet. Based on a tip, personnel from the Maraimalai Nagar police station raided a warehouse on Kamarajar Salai in Maraimalai Nagar in the morning and found red sanders logs hidden under areca palm trees at the facility. Later, they informed district forest ranger Pandurangan, who subsequently arrived at the spot with his team. Investigation revealed that the warehouse belonged to Palani of Ambattur. He had rented it out to Sheik Ali of Manali for Rs 1.8 lakh a month. After preliminary inquiries, forest officials said that Sheik Ali hired the premises on December 16 claiming that areca stems for export would be stored there.

After the red sanders logs were removed, the warehouse was sealed. A hunt has been launched for both Palani and Sheik Ali, as they have absconded. In the past one year, red sanders have been seized from multiple warehouses in Maraimalai Nagar and forest officials are investigating if the culprits use the area to hide the logs to be later smuggled to different places.

Title: Farmers want govt banks to employ staff who know Tamil
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Coimbatore: The Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam has appealed to the Union finance ministry to ensure that at least government banks in rural areas have staff who are proficient in local language. They cited the example of Indian Overseas Bank (IOB) branch in Thirumalaiyampalayam, saying the customers were suffering as its manager and staff didn’t know Tamil.

Pointing out that the IOB branch in Thirumalaiyampalayam was serving a large rural population of farmers and self-help groups, the association said of the seven staff members only one was proficient in reading and writing Tamil. “The new bank manager, who took charge three months ago, is refusing to sanction gold and agriculture loans. He is also reluctant to sanction loans to a self-help group, which had taken a loan in 2011 and has been promptly paying it back,” said P Kandasamy, district secretary, Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam.

The farmers said they had taken up the issue with the Chennai headquarters following which the bank manager agreed to sanction loans. “But he still asks for multiple approvals and documents. All we demand is that they place managers, who understand the local language. So, villagers can show them necessary guarantee documents and convince them for a loan,” Kandasamy said.

The farmers also said they were opposed to the central government’s decision to withdraw the interest subsidy given on agri gold loans. “The government usually gives a 3% interest subsidy on agri gold loans, which are availed at an interest of 7%. So, farmers need to pay only 4% interest. Now, there are talks of removing the subsidy and also increasing interest to 11%. This will only push farmers to approach usuries and lead to their financial ruin” said Karthik Krishnakumar, treasurer, Tamil Nadu Vivasaigal Sangam.

Title: Appoint administrative PAs for chief edu officers: Union
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Coimbatore: Administrative workers of the school education department want the State government to create administrative personal assistant (PA) posts for chief educational officers (CEOs).

At present, there are two PAs for CEOs, one in the cadre of high school headmaster and another in the cadre of higher secondary school headmaster. Administrative workers said these PAs would be able to assist CEOs only in academic functions and school services and not in administrative functions.

There is a need for a PA with administrative knowledge to supervise and deal with files related to finance, postings or those related to litigations, state president of Palli Kalvi Thurai Nirvaga Aluvalar Sangam (School Education Department Administrative Staff Association) T L Srinivasan said. “In the offices of district education officers (DEOs), files from the superintendent would be passed to DEOs only after being run through the PA. But in CEO offices, they are sent from the superintendent directly to the CEOs. As a result, there would be no administrative guidance for CEOs. The PAs, who are from HM cadre, would not have the experience of handling files related to laws and rules when they were working in schools. So, it is necessary to have a PA for CEOs from administrative side to ensure work on such files are done properly,” he said.

Files relating to financial bills and post approvals could be properly checked only by personnel with administrative experience, Srinivasan said. “Of the 52 DEO offices across the state that were created two years ago, 26 need a PA each and 120 superintendents. The government should fill these posts also.”

The members of the association had recently represented the demands to the commissioner of school education.

Title: Coimbatore: British-era postal cash bags found in dump yard
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The 12 British-era postal cash bags found among garbage at the waste management park at Ottupattarai in Coonoo... Read More

UDHAGAMANDALAM: The 12 British-era postal cash bags found among garbage at the waste management park at Ottupattarai in Coonoor will soon find a place in the Government Museum in Ooty.

A team of volunteers of the Clean Coonoor initiative had found the bags while segregating garbage a few days ago.

The bags were found in a fresh batch of trash, said Vasanthan, a member of Clean Coonoor. “Volunteer Navin Joseph had noticed the bags, which looked quite old but in good shape, thanks to the tough leather and excellent workmanship,” he said.

Vasanthan approached the curator of the Coimbatore Government Museum, Sivakumar, to find out more about the bags.

Sivakumar’s research revealed that they were Indian postal department’s money order bags. Names of post offices with pin codes are printed on the bags, Sivakumar said.

“Enquiries with retired postal department staff revealed that those are postal money bags which were in use till the late 70s. There is a provision to lock the bags using two keys. While one key was kept at the post office from where the money was sent, the other was kept at the post office at the receiving end,” he said.

Names of post offices at Coonoor Railway Station, Kolacombai and Kundha Bridge, among others, are imprinted on the bags. “The money orders carried in those bags were the sole means of financial transaction across the length and breadth of rural India,” Vasanthan said. “It is a shame that such priceless objects were found in garbage.”

Title: 5, including 4 of a family, killed in road accident
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Five persons, including two women and two children of a family were killed and one person was injured in a road accident on Kottapalli culvert in Mandasa mandal in Srikakulam district in the early hours of Saturday.

The accident took place when the driver lost control of the vehicle, hit the bridge, turned turtle and fell into the canal.

The deceased were identified as Vanita Jenna, Adarsh Kumar Jenna, Pratap and Reetu. The details of the driver are yet to be identified. The injured person and only survivor in the accident was identified as Trilochan Jenna, whose condition is stable.

As per information, all six persons had visited Simhachalam temple in Vizag from Bhubaneswar on Friday and were returning to Berhampur late at night. The vehicle was retrieved using cranes and the bodies sent for postmortem.

Title: Lakshmi is easy to please, Saraswati needs all you’ve got: Professor CNR Rao
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Prof C N R Rao and Isreli Nobel Laureate Ada Yonath inaugurating the Rashtriya Kishore Vaigyanik Sammelan, a C... Read More

BENGALURU: Reiterating that if India wants to be a great financial and political power, it must first become a great power in science, Prof CNR Rao said it won’t happen unless young scientists work honestly towards doing good science.

“You must have heard some speeches yesterday too...But in India, science doesn’t get importance like some other fields, and unless you give importance to science, India will be a secondary country,” Rao said at the inaugural of the Children’s Science Congress at ISC-2020.

While pointing out that India lacks hard-working and dedicated scientists, he said most people just want money and do all kinds of things and do science only on the side.

“But science is a lifetime occupation and not something easy. Lakshmi (goddess of wealth) is easy to please, you can all make some money quickly, but what about Saraswati (goddess of knowledge)? She will require everything you have before she gives something to you,” he said.

Citing the example of how China deals with science, he said India cannot match the neighbour in quantity or quality. “The question we need to ask is why is India not on top? And then we need to address it. But such discussions aren’t happening in the country,” he said.

Arguing that science unlike other fields is not just a profession but an occupation for life, Rao said it does not discriminate as long as scientists are willing to put in hard work and pursue challenges. “Science does not know religion, caste or colour. It only wants a good mind. Not a brain, which even small animals have, but a good mind is what enables science. Also, background doesn’t matter. There are so many examples of people from poor backgrounds doing great science,” Rao said.

Pointing out how several great findings and discoveries in science have come from people with engineering degrees, he said: “You don’t even need a degree in science or lots of money. If you put your mind to solving problems, science will never let you down.”

Rao said Dmitri Mendeleev, the Russian scientist who developed the periodic table in 1869, was a great example of how dedication results in good science. “He didn’t have a great background, but he had a commitment to science. In 1869, when we didn’t have a clear understanding of atoms and didn’t even know electrons, he worked out the periodic table. He had moved all the way to Moscow from Siberia just for science,” Rao said, adding that he hoped

“People ask me what they need to do science, and I tell them it is doggedness and tenacity. How did Gandhi fight such a powerful British force? It is with such qualities,” Rao said, adding that he hoped at least some children at the event would become scientists.

Title: 33km green corridor to connect south Delhi’s residential areas in four years
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: In a few years, footpaths and cycle tracks would meander through Delhi forests, making the national capital friendly for pedestrians and cyclists. In a bid to shift towards greener mobility, the foundation of a 33-kilometre-long corridor called the ‘Delhi Cycle Walk’ will be laid on Monday at Tughlaqabad .Union home minister Amit Shah will lay the foundation stone of the Rs 550 crore project that Delhi Development Authority has claimed to complete by 2024. The corridor will connect the residential areas in South Delhi such as Tughlaqabad, Greater Kailash, Saket and Nehru Place, and will pass through the city’s green lungs, including Jahanpanah forest.Officials concerned said that the main objectives of the project include making the city walkable and environment-friendly; helping people save money by encouraging them to walk down or cycle to their places of work, shopping and studies; reducing pollution; connecting all the forests of the city; and revival of the dried-up lakes.To ensure connectivity access, origin and destination points have been mapped which are proposed to be interlinked to each other by the tracks for cycling and walking. It will be a loop around the city like a ring and connect metro stations, bus stands, high density residential areas, business districts, industrial areas, recreational centres and green areas.The width of both the cycle track and the walkway will be 2.4 metres each with a green strip of a metre width separating the two. The cycle walk will be a controlled track with defined and secure entrance points near residential areas and exit points near places of workplaces, malls and schools. These points of entry shall be called Origin Destination plazas and shall have all facilities for washrooms, cafés, cycle repairs and parking slots.An official said that the Cycle Walk tracks shall move seamlessly from one forest to another with small water lakes also being created to solve the waterlogging problem in sunken areas along the roads in these forests.As a part of the same project, solar lights will be installed across the stretch; CCTV cameras will be installed every 100 metres and a centralized monitoring station shall also be made; more public toilets will be constructed; and rainwater harvesting chambers and vehicle parking area shall also be made.Over 11 lakh active cyclists use the roads of Delhi, officials claim. Most of these are regular commuters who pedal from home to work and back. “Typically distances travelled by them are under 10 km. Most cyclists prefer to use cycle lanes wherever they are clean and contiguous. Apart from low wage-earning working population, cycling enthusiasts and students also use cycling as a way to commute. While the percentage is small, it can increase in case a safe, convenient and practical option is available,” said an official.

Title: Two cyber crime units start operating in Kozhikode
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

KOZHIKODE: Giving a boost to the cybercrime investigation in north Kerala, two cybercrime investigation units started functioning in Kozhikode on Saturday. A cyber police station and a regional unit of the Cyberdome of the state police were opened by chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan, on Saturday.

With the opening of the first Cyber Police station in north Kerala, the officials are expecting to bring down the number cybercrime offences reported in the city. The cyber police station in Kozhikode is one of the three such stations in Kerala. The new station was set up spending Rs 30 lakh. According to a senior official, apart from cybercrime offences being reported in Kozhikode, the station will handle cybercrime cases being reported in Kozhikode, Kannur , Wayanad and Kasaragod districts also. The cyber police station will be headed by a station house officer . Besides, 18 other personnel are also part of the cyber station. The special cybercrime investigation team is expected to assist the police in North Kerala to recover scientific evidences using cyber technology. The team members were selected after offering them training. The training was conducted by Centre for Development of advanced Computing (C-DAC). The CM also opened a regional unit of the Cyberdome of the Kerala police on Saturday. The Cyberdome, started functioning at the Government Cyber Park. Though the plan was to start the Cyberdome much earlier, the work was delayed owing to technical reasons, said a police official. It is planned in a way to operate with the support of nearly 100 IT experts. The Cyberdome is functioning at Sahya building of the government IT Park. Three police officials under the guidance of a charge officer will lead the operations.

It was arranged at the IT Park by spending Rs 80 lakh. A team of technical experts, ethical hackers and cyber professionals have been arranged at the spot.

The opening of a Cyberdome in Kozhikode is expected to benefit cybercrime investigation and the investigation of other complaints in an effective and speedy manner.

It will focus on cyber Security, cyber forensic, cyber intelligence, incident response, research and development and training and awareness creation. The expert volunteer groups are expected to play significant role in understanding the identity of the cyber-criminal. The team will also work to tackle emerging cyber security threats. The CM also opened the modern police control room in the city through video conference. The CM during the inaugural address assured that the shadow police system would be strengthened to ensure security to women.

Title: Tusker damages thatched roof houses in Erode
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Erode: A lone tusker damaged four thatched roof houses and a compound wall of a government school near Thalaimalai in Sathyamangalam Tiger Reserve (STR) forest range here in the early hours of Saturday. It also raided standing crops in the area.

The tusker had been camping at Gandhi Nagar hamlet in STR for the past couple of days. P Mathesh, a villager, said, “The elephant damaged banana plants, sugarcane and maize crops around 2am on Saturday.”

When the villagers attempted to chase the tusker away into the forest, it entered the village and damaged four thatched roof houses and the compound wall of the government elementary school, he said.

When alerted, forest officials rushed to the spot and chased the animal away into the forest by bursting firecrackers and using tom-toms.

“We have chased the tusker away into the deep forest and it is unlikely to come back again. We will, however, monitor the elephant’s movements for a few days,” a forest official said.

The villagers, meanwhile, said they had suffered huge losses in the elephant raid. They also urged the forest officials to find a permanent solution to prevent wild elephants from entering the village to raid standing crops.

Title: In a first in AP and T, brain AVM treated without surgery
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A brain AVM (arteriovenous malformation) was treated for the first time using stereotactic radio surgery (SRS) and surface guided radiation therapy (SGRT) in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, at Omega Hospitals in the city.

SRS is a non-surgical radiation therapy used to treat functional abnormalities and small tumors of the brain. It can deliver precisely-targeted radiation in fewer high-dose treatments than traditional therapy, which can help preserve healthy tissue. SGRT is a rapidly growing technique which uses stereo vision technology to track patients’ surface in 3D, for setup and motion management during radiotherapy.

Title: Anti-adulteration group felicitated for completing 10 years
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Nagpur: The Anti-Adulteration Consumer Society (AACS) was felicitated by Food and Civil Supplies officials on the occasion of National Consumer Day on December 24 for completing a decade in the field of food safety. AACS founder Mohd Shahid Sharif says the task of protecting consumers is now more important with online platforms catering to multiple products.

“For a consumer, sometimes it’s not worth the time or effort to raise objection over quality of products. And that's why many companies take advantage of gullible consumers. We want to raise awareness about consumer rights, process of filing complaints etc so that nobody can take them for a ride,” said Sharif.

Leeladhar Wadekar, food and civil supply officer felicitated the organization with a letter of appreciation. Sharif said, “We have successfully fought cases of adulterated oil, expired food products, cheating in weight or quantity of fuel etc. Our mission is to arm every citizen with enough information so that they can identify malpractices easily,” said Sharif.

In February, AACS will be organizing a free workshop for citizens about consumer rights. Experts from different sectors will speak about products in their industry and what basic quality they need to adhere to.

Title: Kota deaths: Rajasthan deputy CM Sachin Pilot slams own govt
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Rajasthan deputy CM Sachin Pilot (file photo)

JAIPUR: In an embarrassing development for the Ashok Gehlot-led Rajasthan government, state Congress chief and deputy CM Sachin Pilot on Saturday slammed its handling of the infant deaths in Kota’s JK Lon Hospital and demanded accountability. As many as 107 infants have died in the hospital in the past 35 days.

After paying a visit to the Kota hospital, Pilot said the state government could not escape responsibility by pointing fingers at the previous government as “this is not a small incident, but a heart-wrenching one”. “I think our response to the entire episode could have been more sensitive and more compassionate. After 13 months in government, it may not serve any purpose (for us) to keep pointing towards the previous government’s wrongdoings or misdeeds,” he said.

He said, “As many as 107 children have died. It is not stopping. I have met some of the bereaved family members. I have no words to express their grief and hurt.

The poor strata of society depends on government hospitals. Rolling out statistics will not do any good. We must infuse confidence in people that this kind of incident will not occur again. That is the demand of the people as well.”

Pilot said people voted out the previous government for its failures and blaming it will not absolve the present government of its responsibility.

Title: Mercury may drop again after next week’s rain in Delhi
Content:
The met department forecast a spell of rain on January 7 and 8, following which the temperatures are likely to... Read More

NEW DELHI: In a stark contrast to last month, Saturday was yet another warm day in the capital with both maximum and minimum temperatures above ‘normal’ for the season. While the maximum was 21.6 degrees Celsius – two notches above normal — the minimum was 8 degrees. The rising temperature has led to an improvement in the air quality , which fell from 352 (very poor) on Friday to 334 (very poor) on Saturday, CPCB data showed.Track the pollution level in your cityThe met department forecast a spell of rain on January 7 and 8, following which the temperatures are likely to drop again. Kuldeep Srivastava, scientist, IMD, said no significant change in temperatures was expected in the next 48 hours. “When a western disturbance influences the region, temperatures start to rise and we will continue to see warm temperature in the next few days. We can expect rains in the northern plains from January 6, while Delhi will receive some rain on January 7 and 8. Temperatures will only drop after that,” said Srivastava.System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting and Research (SAFAR) said with a change in wind direction, the surface wind speed had picked up, which could help the air quality. “The minimum temperature is forecast to increase by 2-3 degrees in the next two days. AQI is forecast to improve by Sunday,” said SAFAR.The Central Pollution Control Board central control room data showed NCR’s average PM 2.5 and PM 10 levels to be around three times the standard. While the average PM 10 level was 303 micrograms per cubic metre at 10pm on Saturday, the average PM 2.5 level was 195 micrograms at the same time.

Title: Palmyra promotion drive sees distribution of 3.5 lakh seeds
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Coimbatore: The agriculture department is inching closer to achieving its target of distributing five lakh palmyra seeds to farmers across the district. According to officials, they have already distributed 3.5 lakh palmyra seeds in the past three months and the remaining 1.5 lakh seeds would be distributed by the end of this month. The seeds, they said, were sourced from the district and other districts, and federations that promote palmyra.

The objective of the initiative is to increase the coverage of palmyra trees - Tamil Nadu’s state tree - in the state.

An agriculture officer said they were also collaborating with the District Rural Development Agency (DRDA) to implement the project. “Wherever there are farm ponds, we work with DRDA to maintain them and plant palmyra seeds around them. The tree, which draws water from deep, would help preserve groundwater levels and strengthen tank bunds.”
