The official said they were planting the seeds not only on farms, but also in common areas and around waterbodies. “We also see to it that seeds are planted on the bunds of common ponds and tanks.”

Pointing out that palmyra has a very low rate of germination and requires a long time to germinate, the official said around 20% of planted seeds was likely to germinate.

Apart from the agriculture department, environment forums have also been planting palmyra seeds near water bodies, on forest boundaries and other areas in the district. R Manikandan, organizer of Kovai Kulangal Padhukappu Amaippu said their volunteers had planted around 1.25 lakh palmyra seeds in the district last year. “Of them, around 5% has survived.”

Title: SILK to cut parts of grounded ships
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kannur: Following the failure to tow away the two ships that ran aground when they were being brought to the ship-breaking unit of Steel Industries Ltd Kerala (SILK) at Azhikkal here in the monsoon season, the meeting of the officials and the local body representatives, called under the initiative of Azhikode panchayat on Saturday, decided to cut the rudder and propeller of the ships and tow them away after dredging the area where the ships have been stuck at Dharmadom and Azhikkal.

“We have decided to safely cut the rudders and propellers so that it can be towed away after dredging, and we will ensure there is no pollution,” said Jayesh Anand, the in-charge of the Silk unit. The dredging would be done in an 80m stretch, with 20m width and 3m depth, without causing problems to residents.

The two Maldivian ships that broke from the tug ran aground due to rough sea in August 2019. Though a Kochi-based agency was given the contract to tow away the ships, it could not do anything major.

The company would be able to tow them away if the propellers and rudders are cut and the surrounding area is dredged further, according to SILK.

But this is a drama to break the ship in a step-by-step manner, violating all rules and they would strengthen the agitation, said the action committee.

“There were many efforts in the past few months to break the ships at sea but it was due to our opposition that the authorities withdrew from the move,” said M K Manoharan, chairman of the action committee. When there are state-of-the-art technologies to tow away the ships or even lift them from the bottom of the sea, why does it take so long to lift the ships, he asked.

He said they were not formally invited for the meeting and the information was passed to them at the midnight and hence they did not attend it.

Even if the ships are towed away, SILK will not be permitted to break it violating the rules, he said, adding that the unit has no license to break the ships.

However, the Silk authorities said they would break the ships after getting all clearance from the local body and the pollution control board.

Title: Delhi: Engineer held for trying to extort politicians’ kin for MLA tickets
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police has arrested an engineer while he was trying to extort money from politicians by threatening to get their names delisted from the candidate list of their respective parties.

Police suspect that the man is a part of a racket that has even been duping students on the pretext of providing fake marksheets. The cops have seized a mobile phone from him, in which he was found to be in contact with a few people who were found to be involved in duping other politicians in a similar way.

Police said that they received a complaint from Sumit Goel, son of Delhi legislative assembly speaker Ram Niwas Goel, on Wednesday, in which he mentioned that a man named Vishal Sagar had approached him saying that he needed to pay Rs 2.5 crore to secure Ram Niwas’ seat, out of which Rs 50 lakh needed to paid in advance.

Speaking to TOI, Sumit said that the man posed as a complainant and entered his office in Shahdara on Wednesday afternoon. He approached him saying that he was known to a senior functionary from the party and needed to meet Goel personally. “When I asked his purpose of meeting my father, he said that the time had come for my father to meet him instead,” said Sumit.

Sagar claimed that the senior party leaders had decided to strike off Ram Niwas’ name as a candidate from the Gandhi Nagar constituency, but he could arrange for a method to get it back on the list. He even called his “senior” based in Bangalore so that Sumit could have a word with him.

“I realised that he was trying to extort money since my father’s name was never proposed for the Gandhi Nagar constituency. I informed my father and the cops about it,” said Sumit. Sagar was handed over to the police and interrogated, during which he claimed to be a mechanical engineer who was part of a group that had been duping people by threatening them in a similar way.

During interrogation, Sagar said that he is a resident of Vasant Nagar in Vasant Vihar and had joined the gang to earn quick money. The cops will issue an advisory for political parties to warn them about the racket.

Title: Farmer jumps in front of tusker to save kin, is killed
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

RAIPUR: A 61-year-old farmer sacrificed his life to save his daughter and toddler grandson from a rampaging tusker in Chhattisgarh ’s Jashpur on Saturday.

Seeing the elephant charging at the mother and child, the man threw himself in its path and was trampled to death.

On Saturday night, the tusker entered Sirikima village. It headed for farmer Sonsai’s house and smashed the door. The noise woke up the farmer, who was terrified to see the elephant looming over him. The tusker turned and headed towards another part of the house where his daughter and her two-year-old son were sleeping.

Without hesitating a moment, Sonsai picked up a burning torch and jumped between the tusker and his family. He waved the torch and screamed to try to distract the elephant, but it stomped on him, crushing him to death.

The forest department has given Sonsai’s family an initial assistance of Rs 25,000.

Title: Kerala: Sand scarcity stalls geotube works
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Around eight geotubes have been filled and laid along the coast to the north side of Velankanni Church at Chel... Read More

KOCHI: The geotube project at Chellanam coastal hamlet that had resumed in November after many legal hassles, is once again stalled. Though around eight tubes have been filled by the contractor and laid near the Velankanni Church in December, the entire work was stopped citing lack of sand to fill the tubes.

Officials at the irrigation department, which is monitoring the project, said that though they have asked the contractor to stop the work and conduct a dredge survey to meet the sand requirements, no initiative has been made in this direction yet. But people associated with the contractor said that the survey will begin on Monday and dredge works will start soon.

“The court has given six months to the contractor to finish the project and the contractor said that it will be completed by March. The filling of tubes needs to be speedier and we have told the contractor to do the needful. But the sand scarcity is the immediate challenge and it is yet to be seen how the contractor will solve it. The pace of the project needs to be increased to complete the project within stipulated time,” said an irrigation department official.

It was on November 11, PWD contractor Mohammed Niyas, who had received the renewed contract following a high court order that settled a legal dispute between the irrigation department and the contractor, started filling the geotubes at the northern side of Velankanni Church. Then the contractor had said that the project will be completed before the deadline by the end of March 2020. They have given subcontract of the work to a Noida-based company and the work was progressing until the scarcity of sand became an issue.

“Earlier the lack of enough sand was a challenge but the then district collector had issued a notice to irrigation and panchayat officials to give permission to take sand from anywhere in Chellanam. But the sand which had been procured from the canals here were sufficient to fill only eight tubes, which are laid at the northern side of Velankanni Church. Around 10 more tubes have to be filled to complete the works at this site. Though we tested the sand from the canal, we found it muddy and cleaning the sand will be time-consuming. We plan to dredge sand up to 500m off the coast and the survey will begin on Monday,” said a source associated with the sub-contractor.

Through the project, the contractor will lay geotubes at a total length of 1km and at a height of 5m at five places in Chellanam coast, including Velankanni, Bazar, Companypady and Maruvakkad.

Meanwhile, the residents have once again started the protest alleging that the contractor does not have any previous expertise in constructing geotube walls.

Title: CAA & NRC may force Hindus to leave too: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Asking people to understand the chronology, Kejriwal said under NRC, everyone will have to prove their citi... Read More NEW DELHI: Speaking out against Citizenship Amendment Act and National Register of Citizens , chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said on Saturday that these would force not only Muslims, but Hindus also to leave the country . At a town hall in Janakpuri, where he presented a report card on the performance of his government in five years, Kejriwal called CAA a strange law, expressing the fear that some spies may masquerade as Hindus and come to India under this act. Asking people to understand the chronology, the chief minister said under NRC everyone will have to prove their citizenship. “Aadhaar and PAN cards will not be considered for proving citizenship. The government says only birth certificates will be considered. If you produce your and parents’ birth certificates, you will be considered citizens, irrespective of religion. If you are a Muslim and if you are unable to produce the birth documents, you will be asked to leave the country,” said the CM. “If you are Hindu and have come from Pakistan, you will get citizenship,” he said. “There is a misunderstanding among people that only Muslims will be asked to leave the country. All those Hindus who have not come from Pakistan and are unable to produce their birth certificates and that of their parents will also be asked to leave the country.” About home minister Amit Shah’s statements that a nationwide NRC was not currently under consideration, Kejriwal said a few days ago Shah had stated on TV that he had never ruled out NRC but did not clarify when it would be implemented. “It is playing with words. CAA has been brought to clear the way for NRC. Together, CAA and NRC will create a dangerous situation. I believe the country does not need such laws. The country is facing unemployment, economy is down and inflation is high. Had the PM said the government will never bring NRC, things would have normalised, but he just said that currently the government is not considering NRC,” pointed out Kejriwal. Asked whether the persecuted minorities in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bagaladesh who want to come to India should not be accommodated, Kejriwal said that first crores of Hindus of the country need jobs and social security. “Around 4 crore people qualify to come to India, and even if half of them arrive, who will give them jobs?” Kejriwal asked. In the report card, Kejriwal emphasised 10 major achievements of the AAP government in the past five years in education, health, power, water, budget performance, women safety, unauthorised colonies, transport and pro-people governance besides others. He said parking and and pollution will be the key focus areas of his government in its next tenure. The CM also promised to clean up Yamuna in the next five years. In an interaction with the audience, Kejriwal said a system will be devised in collaboration with the corporations to resolve the issue of non-availability of parking spaces in commercial and residential areas. On traffic congestion, he said the government was “redesigning roads on the lines of London, Tokyo, and France...we have already given a contract for 40 km”. Replying to a question, Kejriwal said full statehood is important for the people of Delhi and it will be a part of AAP’s election manifesto. He announced that the proposed hike in the circle rate of agricultural land in Delhi has been approved by the LG and a notification was likely to be issued next week. About Congress’s promise of 600 units of free electricity if elected in Delhi, Kejriwal said they should first start it in Madhya Pradesh, Rajasthan and Punjab.

Title: Chennai: After BJP objection, JNU retired professor’s lecture put off
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vijaya Ramaswamy (Photo credit: http://www.jnu.ac.in/Faculty)

CHENNAI: In the wake of strong objections raised by right wing activists and leaders of the BJP state unit, the lecture on ‘Reluctant brides, deviant wives, cunning witches: Women in Tamil Mahabharatas’ by Vijaya Ramaswamy, retired professor of Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU), that was to be held here on Saturday, has been postponed.

It was organised by CP Ramaswami Aiyar Institute of Indological Research (CPRIIR) at Alwarpet and was scheduled to be held at 10.30 am. The institute cited recent “heavy rain” and “construction activities” for postponing the programme without announcing a future date.

The message from the institute came hours after H Raja, BJP national secretary, tweeted criticising the choice of topic for the lecture. “Can such a lecture be organised over any other religion’s scriptures or holy book?” he asked in the tweet and tagged chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami and K Pandiarajan, minister for Tamil Culture, demanding that the programme be cancelled. Many BJP sympathisers and right wing activists also joined the chorus.

“I was here to speak about the greatness of Tamil literature from Sangam era and how it gives importance to women. The focal point of the lecture was Draupadi and her greatness,” Vijaya Ramaswamy, retired professor of centre for historical studies at Jawaharlal Nehru University, Delhi , told TOI. She, however, said she was informed about the cancellation of the programme citing construction activity on the premises. “I am leaving Chennai with a heavy heart,” said Vijaya Ramaswamy, a native of Kanyakumari. She came for the programme from Delhi.

A senior professor of the institute said the lecture was on the “greatness of Draupadi”, worshipped as Draupadi Amman in the state, unlike any other part of the country. “The topic was misinterpreted and misinformed to outsiders and it attracted a lot of criticism,” the professor said, but declined to comment on whether political pressure resulted in cancellation of the programme.

Educationists said the state succumbed to pressure mounted by vested interests and failed to protect the rights of educational institutions. “I never expected such a reaction to academic programmes from our state,” Vijaya Ramaswamy added.

Earlier too, there have been instances of last-minute cancellation of programmes that were opposed by the BJP.

Title: Ex-members of local bodies to stage dharna on January 7
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Thiruvananathapuram: Demanding pension and health insurance coverage, former elected members to local bodies will stage a dharna in front of secretariat here on Tuesday.

Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala will inaugurate the dharna being organized by association of former panchayath members and councillors at 10am. “Several times we had taken up the demand with successive governments, but we are yet to get a positive response. Former MLAs and MPs receive pension and other benefits. But those who are elected to the local bodies are denied the same. Ward members work in the ground level and are forced to work almost round the clock. But once their term is over, they are ignored. This is unethical. There are several former members who suffer from various diseases. Many even suffering from terminal illness,” said N A Azeez, state president of the association.

MLAs P Aisha Potty, R Ramachandran, N A Nellikkunnu, former speaker M Vijayakumar, former MLAs V Sivankutty and Varkala Kahar, and BJP’s state secretary J R Padmakumar will attend the dharna. The association was formed seven years ago and has nearly 70,000 members. TNN

Title: Anganwadi workers stage massive protest demanding pay hike
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

yyyyyyyyyyyy

Dehradun: Thousands of anganwadi workers on Saturday staged a massive protest at Hathibarkala Chowk, demanding pay rise, job regularisation and other facilities at work. The protest threw traffic out of gear at several busy stretches in the city.

The agitators started their march from Dharna Sthal around 2 pm, stayed put through two downpours in a span of five hours and continued their protest till late evening. They also tried to reach the CM’s residence, but were stopped by police.

The protest caused jams on stretches like Rajpur road, Subhash Road, EC Road and Gandhi Road, to name a few.

The women who had come from several places across the state raised anti-government slogans, saying the government had turned a blind eye to their problems. Even though the demonstrations were interrupted by rain, many of the workers continued with their protest alleging that they are now “fed up of empty promises.”

State president of Anganwadi Union, Rekha Negi said that they were disappointed at not having met the CM. “The government claims that it is accessible to everyone but then why were we stopped by police when we wanted to reach the CM, who is also the health minister of the state?” On their demands, she said, “We want free gas connections, Provident Fund (PF), health insurance and travel allowance facilities in case we need to travel for assignments. Also, if the state government wants to give us mobile phones, they must increase the allowance so that we can pay for the recharge.”

Vimla Kohli, state vice-president of the union, added, “We are the most hardworking and yet the most deprived section of government servants. We work in schools and hospitals, in cities as well as villages. Still, the government has turned a blind eye to our issues. We work day and night to ensure implementation of various government schemes. Can’t the government bring a scheme for our benefits?”

The workers are also demanding increase of their salary to Rs 21,000 per month and their helpers’ pay to Rs 11,000 per month. Among their other demands are Diwali bonus, perks based on their skills and seniority and promotions in due time. The union members said that if the state government failed to meet their demands, they would resort to protests across the state and sit on strikes. The state has around 15,000 anganwadi workers and 14,000 helpers.

Title: Brace for power shock as discoms seek to recover old losses from you
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bhopal: Does another shock await power consumers? After urging MP electricity regulatory commission to allow them to recover Rs 25,000 crore losses — incurred during the previous BJP government — from consumers, and then additionally seeking 5% tariff hike for the next fiscal, discoms now want to recover Rs 5,000 crore losses incurred in 2018-19 fiscal, again from consumers.

If MPERC allows all three requests, your power tariff will shoot up by more than 300%.

Sample this: If MPERC allows only 50% of the Rs 25,000 crore losses incurred between 2015-16 and 2017-18, and 50% of the Rs 5,000 losses incurred in 2018-19, and the Rs 2,000 crore estimated revenue loss for the next financial year, then a consumer who uses two ACs (5-star), a couple of fans, an LED TV, and five LED bulbs — together about 425 units of electricity a month — will have to shell out a whopping Rs 1,500 extra every month. So, if you are paying around Rs 3,600 for using 425 units, your bill will be a whopping Rs 5100 (approx).

Discoms submitted true-up petitions for 2014 to 2017 and 2018-19 in the second week of November last year. In December, they submitted the annual revenue requirement (ARR) report for 2020-21 fiscal and claimed Rs 2,000 estimated losses. Now, in early January, discoms have submitted true-up petition for 2018-19, claiming that they incurred Rs 5,000 crore loss that year and MPERC should allow them to recover it from consumers.

MPERC sources said it has scheduled a hearing on January 21 for the 2018-19 true-up petition and will seek objections from the public before taking its decision.

Power tariff for a fiscal is determined on the basis of the projected consumption and sale of energy and estimated expenditures related to purchase, other expenses and income from sale of energy. Discoms seek hikes through ARR petition so that they can bridge the gap between their estimated income and loss. True-up losses are calculated at the end of the fiscal.

Title: Centre for deafblind to come up at Nish
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: A first-ever national conference for the deafblind has been organized by National Institute of Speech and Hearing in association with Society for the Empowerment of the Deafblind. A decision to set up a centre under Nish to address concerns and formulate projects for the deafblind was announced at the two-day conference that began here on Saturday.

A social justice department survey had found that there are approximately 850 deafblind people in the state. “Chennai-based Chetana Trust will associate with the centre, providing training and trainers. Besides, two suitable posts will be reserved for Public Service Commission jobs, and health, social justice and women and child development minister KK Shailaja will initiate steps regarding this,” secretary (social justice and women and child development) Biju Prabhakar said, adding that the upcoming centre at Nish will function as the nodal centre for the deaf and blind.

More than 60 delegates from various parts of the country are participating in the conference, interacting with each other with the help of personal interpreters. The conference, themed ‘inclusion through technology and advocacy’, provided at platform for participants to share their experiences on overcoming challenges in life and on how technology has helped make their lives easier.

Deafblindness or dual sensory impairment (DSI) is a distinctive disability, which encompasses varying degrees of hearing impairment and low vision. According to studies, its impact is not merely an addition of the impact of the two disabilities, but it is manifold. Deafblind children have cognitive, speech, motor and social delay. They also can have multiple medical needs, which should be identified and met. It is estimated that there are more than 500,000 deafblind adults and children in the country.

Title: TRS too under fire at Million March for ‘unclear’ stance on CAA & NPR
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Hyderabad: Telangana and AP Joint Action Committee against Citizenship Amendment Act on Saturday held a protest at Dharna Chowk, Indira Park.

In the line of fire of those who addressed that huge gathering were the BJP, TRS and AIMIM. The demonstrators rejected Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) calling it unconstitutional. They vowed not to fill any form to prove their citizenship and played the National Anthem at the end of the protest meet.

“We will not fill National Population Register (NPR) form. The questionnaire has changed. We have no issues with the old form and questions mentioned in it,” said Mohammed Mushtaq Malik, convenor of the JAC.

Majlis Bachao Tehreek (MBT) spokesperson Amjadullah Khan lashed out at the TRS and AIMIM for collusion. “Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao should be vocal against Citizenship Amendment Act like West Bengal and Kerala were. As on today, he is appeasing Muslims with the help of Asaduddin Owaisi. We are afraid he will change his attitude towards Muslims after municipal elections,” Khan said. Unlike regular public meetings, a lot of burqa-clad women were present and raised slogans against CAA. With the Tricolour in their hands, women raised Azadi slogans along with other protesters. “This government (BJP) unlike previous governments is taking major decisions in haste. This time they questioned our nationality based on our religion,” said a woman protester.

“If the same Act was passed by any other government, the impact would be less. Many Muslims who I know don’t have a good opinion about the Centre. We have come here to vent our anger against discriminatory proposals,” said Syed Abdul Kashaf, a protester.

Title: Govt names Kuruvilla John as ATS head
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

T’puram: In the latest reshuffle initiated in the police top brass, the state government has appointed DIG Anup Kuruvilla John as the head of the anti-terrorism squad ( ATS ) in the state. Anup, an officer from the 2004 batch, has been holding the charge of DIG (training) at the Kerala Police Academy ( KEPA ) at Thrissur for the past three years. He has earlier served as SP, Kannur, city police commissioner, Kozhikode, and as SP in National Investigation Agency (NIA).

Neeraj Kumar Gupta from 2005 batch who joined the cadre after his central deputation as the DIG (training) has been appointed in KEPA. Yatish Chandra will be the new district police chief in Kannur in place of Pratheesh Kumar. Pratheesh Kumar, who is leaving on central deputation soon, has been appointed as SP (headquarters).

R Adithya, who is currently DCP (law and order) in the capital, replaces Yatish Chandra as city police commissioner, Thrissur. Wayanad SP R Karuppasamy has been appointed as DCP (law and order) in the capital. The government also mutually transferred Idukki SP T Narayanan and Kollam city police commissioner P K Madhu. SP crimes, Idukki, Zakaria George has been appointed as SP, women’s cell. Consumerfed MD R Sukeshan has been posted back in the police department as SP (special branch CID). TNN

Title: Just 91 trees to be shifted for Azimganj Sarai work: Aga Khan Trust for Culture
Content:
National Zoological Park

NEW DELHI: Refuting claims that over 2,000 trees could be cut down to connect Azimganj Sarai with the National Zoological Park , the Aga Khan Trust for Culture (AKTC), which is undertaking the conservation of the 16th century fort-like structure, clarified on Saturday that only 91 trees would be required to be moved from the area and transplanted elsewhere. Permission for this has already been sought.Reacting to TOI’s story on Friday on an environmental activist requesting the Union ministry of environment, forests and climate change to stop the felling of 2,000 trees, AKTC said a detailed survey had revealed 706 trees in and around the structure, of which only 97 were identified for felling since they were growing atop the archaeological remains. This number was later pruned to 91.“The claims of over 2,000 trees being chopped is absolutely false. The area itself has just around 700 trees,” Ratish Nanda, project director, AKTC, told TOI. “We found 91 trees growing on the medieval inn complex and conservation work requires their transplantation.”Delhi government’s department of archaeology had requested the transplantation of the trees. “We have no intention to transplant or chop any tree growing in the courtyard. Also, contrary to the report printed, there are no sandalwood trees and most of the standing trees are the invasive subabul species,” asserted Nanda.Conservation work at the site has actually been going on for the past five years. Phase 1 of the project is finished and the second phase will involve repairing the 9-metre wall and gateway of the medieval sarai. There are 108 individual rooms and a large courtyard in the middle. Nanda said most of the walls were in a dilapidated state, and some, including those adjoining the zoo, had also collapsed.“In Phase 1, we stabilised the two wings of the sarai comprising 54 vaulted cells and their arched openings,” disclosed Nanda. “Phase 2 can only begin after the saplings growing on the ruins are moved. Without restoration, there is every likelihood that the walls will collapse, possibly injuring the jackals and elephants inhabiting the area.”AKTC said there were no current plans to provide visitor access to the Azimganj Sarai from the Delhi zoo side. It said the Union housing and urban affairs ministry had suggested to the environment ministry that visitors should be permitted only from the Sundar Nursery side. Nanda said the conservation could lead to the sarai being added to the World Heritage Site of Humayun’s Tomb, which has six such recognised monuments.The plans propose entry to Azimgarh Sarai through its western gateway on the Sundar Nursery side. “Even though the site is located within Delhi zoo’s residential area and not its operational area, a 2.4-metre wall has been built to enhance security and prevent animals moving to the park area,” AKTC noted in its letter to the Delhi zoo director in October 2019. Access to the sarai will be through a double-door fitted with automatic door closers to allow a single visitor to enter at a time.“We don’t have plans at the moment for commercial events or an orchestra or paid events at Azimganj Sarai,” added Nanda. “Also, no land transfer has been sought and it is strange for AKTC to be charged with trying to acquire land. We only want to conserve the old sarai and get visitor access to this protected monument.”

Title: Protesters ask KCR for clarity
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Hyderabad: With TRS yet to clarify its stand on National Register of Citizens (NRC), some of the protesters at Million March asked chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to give them clarity.

There were also placards from protesters who were asking KCR not to implement both Citizenship (Amendment) Act and NRC. “CM please stop National Population Register (NPA), NCR, CAA in Telangana,’’ a placard held by a protester at Indira Park crossroads said.

Earlier, Jamath-e-Islami Hyderabad unit president Hameed Mohammed while addressing the crowd asked KCR to give clarity on whether TRS would support NRC or not. Similarly, a few protesters TOI spoke to insisted that KCR make his stand clear and reject the implementation of the controversial Act.

Title: Will move court against Union HRD minister & Ayush minister, says BJP member
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

CM Rawat had assured to return the hiked fees to students of Ayurvedic colleges

DEHRADUN: Activist and BJP member Ravindra Jugran on Saturday asked the state government to ensure that the hiked fees paid by students of private Ayurvedic colleges across Uttarakhand is returned to them. He also threatened to move court against Union HRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank and state Ayush minister Harak Singh Rawat if the students aren’t paid back their fees within three weeks.

“On November 21 last year, CM Trivendra Singh Rawat had ordered all colleges to immediately comply with the Uttarakhand high court (HC) order and return the hiked fees. But still, nothing has been done,” said Jugran. He further claimed that both Harak Singh Rawat and Nishank have direct or indirect stake in Ayurvedic colleges in state.

To recall, CM Rawat had assured that the state government will ensure compliance of the HC order which had asked Ayurvedic colleges to return the hiked fees to all students. The CM had also announced to form a fee fixation committee which would be headed by a HC judge to ensure compliance of the order.

The decision of ensuring the compliance of the HC order was taken in an emergency meeting called by the chief minister on November 21, 2019 which was attended by Ayush minister Harak Singh Rawat, Ayush secretary Dilip Jawalkar and officials of Uttarakhand Ayurvedic University.

The meeting was called in the wake of Ayurvedic students protesting against “an arbitrary fee hike of around 200%-300%”. They alleged that Ayurvedic colleges had hiked their fees to Rs 2.5-Rs 3 lakh from Rs 80,000.

While hearing the matter last year, Uttarakhand HC had said that the fee hike was “unreasonably high” while ordering the colleges to return the fees.

As many private Ayurvedic colleges had failed to comply with the HC order, the court had also issued a contempt order on October 22, 2019 against the owners of some private colleges seeking a response within three weeks.

Title: Cabinet clears Rs 5 lakh medical insurance cover for state staff
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bhopal: In a major decision, Kamal Nath government on Saturday decided to bring 12.55 lakh state employees, pensioners and their families under medical insurance cover. The decision was taken at a cabinet meeting headed by chief minister Nath at the state secretariat.

Till now, the state government employees and pensioners were not covered under medical insurance and regular employees had medical reimbursement facility. The medical insurance scheme announced is a contributory scheme that would be optional for employees of the state undertakings (corporations and boards).

The scheme has been drafted on the lines of those for All India services that has been adopted by some states.

Briefing newsmen minister for health Tulsi Silawat said, “Mukhya Mantri Samuhik Swasth Bima Yojana (Chief Minister’s Group Health Insurance Scheme) effective from April 1 will make every government employee and his or her family eligible for free medical treatment up to Rs 5 lakh per annum. For some critical diseases, the eligibility maybe increased to Rs 10 lakh per annum. OPD (Out Patient Department) treatment in hospitals will be free up to Rs 10,000 per annum.”

Claiming it a historic decision taken by the state government, Silawat said that retired state government employees under previous regimes received free medication worth Rs 288 per annum. While all employees will be eligible for Rs 5 lakh medical treatment, a permission will be necessary from a state-level medical board for approval to increase the insurance cover to Rs 10 lakh for specific critical diseases.

Those who will be covered under the insurance scheme include 5,73,752 state government employees of various departments, another 1,79,470 government school teachers and 4,91,666 retired state personnel. Implementation of the scheme will incur a financial burden of Rs 756.54 crore on the exchequer. Portion of the premium will be deducted from employees’ salaries and the amount will be determined the salary grades.

Minister for higher education Jeetu Patwari explained, “While approving the scheme, the chief minister and cabinet has kept the number of beneficiaries open. If there are some departments or employees who have been missed out, then they will also be included in the scheme later.

Other decisions: Second phase of farm loan waiver starts

After the cabinet meeting on Saturday afternoon, state government claimed that the second phase of Jai Kisan Fasal Rin Maafi Yojana has been launched throughout the state. “In the first phase, 21 lakh farmers have been benefitted under the farm loan waiver scheme up to Rs 50,000. In the second phase 10 lakh more farmers have been listed for loan waiver up to Rs 2 lakh,” minister for PWD Sajjan Singh Verma said. “The third list of farmers will also be ready soon. These will be of those agriculturists who have taken more than two farm loans on a single agricultural field,” he added.

Council of ministers also increased cabinet ministers’ discretionary fund from Rs 50 lakh to Rs One crore. Silawat argued, “When ministers visit the districts and villages, many poor people ask for help. That is why the discretionary fund been increased.” Previously, discretionary fund for cabinet ministers was Rs 50 lakh and ministers of state Rs 35 lakh. Now cabinet ministers will get Rs One crore and ministers of state Rs 60 lakh. However, all 28 ministers in the Kamal Nath government have cabinet rank, there are no ministers of state.

In another decision, cabinet decided to review BPL ration card holders. Minister for food and civil supplies Pradyumn Singh Tomar said, “There are 1.17 crore ration cards for a total 5.40 crore beneficiaries. We know 3% to 4% of these are either in the names of deceased persons, women who have been married and settled elsewhere or frauds. We have decided to start a campaign to reject these fraudulent or deceased persons’ names and issue ration cards to new holders. There are 46 lakh persons waiting for ration cards,” he said.

Cabinet also decided to recruit 1,359 guest teachers to fill vacancies of teachers in schools. Minister for higher education Jeetu Patwari said, “Approval has been given for recruitment of guest teachers. The government wants to regularize all guest teachers so not a single person is left out.” Cabinet also gave its nod for 560 new posts in the women and child development department.

How the scheme works

Covers employees— (regular, daily wagers & contractual), pensioners and their dependents

Will be contributory, optional for state PSU staff

Rs 5 lakh cover for treatment (Can be hiked to Rs 10 lakh in case of critical ailments)

OPD treatment upto Rs 10,000 per annum

Title: Hold spl Assembly session on CAA, Uttam tells KCR
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Hyderabad: Telangana Congress president and Nalgonda MP N Uttam Kumar Reddy on Saturday demanded that chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao convene a special session of the legislative assembly to pass a resolution rejecting CAA and NRC.

Addressing a municipal elections’ preparatory meeting in Miryalguda, Uttam said several chief ministers had already announced that they would not implement CAA and NRC. “KCR has been silent on the issue. He has been supporting the (Narendra) Modi government at the Centre since 2014. He backed them on demonetisation, GST and elections of President and Vice President of India,” he said.

He alleged that KCR has not fulfilled the promises, including providing 12% reservation in jobs and education to Muslims, he had made in April 2014.

Uttam urged the unemployed youngster to give KCR a big shock in the coming elections. “The youth should ensure the defeat of TRS,” he said.

He added that Congress would win a majority of seats in the polls.

Title: Safety additions on Biodiversity Flyover mostly just distractions?
Content: HYDERABAD: A month after an accident on Biodiversity Flyover left one dead and injured many, it was reopened on Saturday.When TOI drove over the flyover, several features stood out: An excessive number of signages, rumble strips and speed-breakers just ahead of the sharp curve where the accident had happened.The abrupt ride caused several vehicles to stop, and restart engines at the scene of the widely reported accident. Infrastructural expert Dr SP Anchuri who is the vice president of Structural Engineers World Congress — India, who joined TOI’s commute said the new additions were likely to have a ripple effect on traffic jams along Gachbowli-Miyapur main road and other connecting roads during peak hours.“Putting speed breakers on flyovers, especially in the ascend is avoided as a rule. Since the structural defect cannot be rectified now, the changes can only serve as a precautionary measure.The general tendency of motorists is to speed up after crossing speed breakers. Hence, the placement of the speed bumps is not accurate. Another problem is that two-wheelers need a minimum speed to balance but coming down to a near stop at the bumps would itself cause many accidents, making pillion riders vulnerable to falls,” said Anchuri.As per the expert, no physical changes have been made and the changes made are more of a distraction (like signage and announcement of speed limit etc) and will serve only as precautionary measure.While a few motorists did halt on the flyover, within minutes an announcement was made the vehicles should not halt and any such vehicle will be fined. Also speed limit was being constantly announced and motorists were cautioned against over-speeding. “However, this didn’t seem to act as a deterrent to many. Ideally the motorists over-speeding should be apprehended just after to flyover’s descent so that an immediate check can be put in place,” added Anchuri. This flaw was also pointed out by motorists themselves. Umaid Khan, a motorist said that the spot where the accident happened is 15- 20 feet away where the speed-breakers should have been put.Meanwhile, the second turning of the S shaped flyover remains hidden by buildings. This is a threat to speeding vehicles.While a majority of motorists kept away from the left side of the flyover and tried driving in the middle, there were a few driving rashly too.“Even though care has been taken by the committee to suggest points when we had one drive, found that it’s not at all made any impact on the rash drivers. It will be very difficult to avoid accidents.There is need to go for a few more rectifications to ensure accident free commuting. Detailed studies should be conducted from time to time over during peak hours. Also there is a need for bringing about a change in the mindset of commuters,” added the expert.

Title: Increase width of service road along Beed Bypass: MLA
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Aurangabad: Aurangabad West MLA Sanjay Shirsat has sought an increase in the width of the service road along the crucial Beed bypass.

The MLA had met the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) commissioner on Thursday to seek the civic body’s action regarding the matter. According to Shirsat, in view of the increasing traffic, the width of the service road should be increased by another 2.5metre thereby bringing the total width of the road to 7.5metre.

The MLA said that the municipal commissioner has agreed to his request to increase the width of the service road.“Of the funds approved for the project, about Rs 25 crore can be used for the acquisition of land required for the road widening. Acquisition of land will be carried out through the municipal corporation as the areas on both sides of the service road fall under municipal limits,” Shirsat said.

The work of widening the 9-10km stretch of the Beed bypass from Mahanubhav Ashram to Jhalta is under way. For that purpose, the municipal corporation is conducting an anti-encroachment drive. The project to construct and widen the road, at an estimated cost of Rs 306 crore, is being funded by the state government. The World Bank project division of the Public Works Department Aurangabad is implementing the project.

The tender process has been completed and the work order is likely to be issued on January 9 or 10. As part of the project, three flyovers and three vehicle underpasses will be built on the Beed bypass which passes through Aurangabad city. Incidentally, the road is used by residents of Satara and Deolai to travel to the city as well as by cargo trucks. The narrow width of the road has led to several accidents and even deaths in the past. Subsequently, the project of widening of the road was taken up.

Title: Chennai: Line work to make trains late, some local services cut
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Passengers of suburban trains and long distance trains are expected to face inconvenience in the coming days. Railways has cancelled a few late night suburban trains and delayed a few express trains on MGR Central-Arakonam route due to work undertaken at the Ambattur yard and on the Chennai-Gudur route from January 5 to 7.

Two suburban trains will be cancelled while a train will skip six stops on the Moore Market Complex- Arakonam route. Moore Market Complex – Avadi EMU local scheduled to leave Moore Market Complex at 12.15am will be cancelled on Sunday and instead, a passenger special will leave from Moore Market Complex to Avadi at 11.45pm Saturday.

Train no. 43801 Chennai Beach – Arrakkonam EMU local scheduled to leave Beach at 1:20am on Sunday will skip stoppages at Korattur, Pattaravakkam, Thirumullaivoyal, Annanur, Hindu College and Pattabiram.

Due to line block on Chennai – Arakkonam section at Pattabiram station, Pattabiram Military Siding E-Depot-Moore Market Complex EMU local leaving Pattabiram at 3:20am will start from Avadi and Moore Market Complex-Pattabiram Military Siding E-Depot EMU local leaving Moore Market Complex at 10.35pm will run only up to Avadi on January 6.

Train no. 43799 Velachery-Pattabiram Military Siding E-Depot EMU local leaving Velachery on January 6 at 10.30pm will be operated till Pattabiram and the same train will run as a passenger special between Avadi and Thiruninravur.

Five express trains will be hit because engineering work will be taken up between MGR Central and Gudur sections at Odur yard on January 7. The trains are: Train no. 12510 Guwahati – Bengaluru Cant Express will be delayed by 170 minutes at Gudur, train no. 17644 Kakinada Port – MGR Central, Circar Express, will be delayed for about 130 minutes at Gudur, train no. 12604 Hyderabad Deccan – MGR Chennai Central, Chennai Express, will be delayed at Gudur for about 125 minutes, train no. 12616 – New Delhi – MGR Chennai Central, Grand Trunk Express, will be delayed for about 95 minutes at Gudur, train no. 12622 New Delhi – MGR Central, Tamil Nadu Express, will be delayed for about 65 minutes.

Title: Karnataka govt mulls renaming Ramanagara district for investment
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Chief minister BS Yeddiyurappa (File Photo)

BENGALURU: The state government is learnt to have set in motion an exercise to examine if Ramanagara district, south of Bengaluru, can be renamed Nava (New) Bengaluru. According to sources, officials from industries department in consultation with Ramanagara district administration have raised the demand.

The government is yet to take a call. When asked about the speculation on Saturday, chief minister BS Yediyurappa did not respond.

Industries department sources said Bengaluru as a brand holds great value in terms of attracting investments but unfortunately the city has reached its saturation point because of non-availability of land.

The city is investors’ favourite destination in Karnataka . In 2018-19, for instance, Bengaluru got 70% of the total investment in Karnataka. It is also among the largest technology clusters in the world.

What makes the city more conducive to IT sector growth is its strong regulatory environment for business and globally competitive talent pool. “Renaming of Ramanagara as Nava Bengaluru will naturally attract more investments,” said a senior officer privy to the information.

In 2007, Ramanagara district was carved out of the erstwhile Bengaluru Rural district comprising Ramanagara, Channapatna, Kanakapura and Magadi taluks when HD Kumarswamy, who represented Ramanagara assembly constituency, was the chief minister. Then people had demanded the new district be named Bengaluru South but it wasn’t considered for historical reasons.

Title: Suleimani killing reasserts Trump’s ‘maximum pressure policy’ to get Tehran to mend its ways
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Mourners attend funeral procession of Iranian Major-General Qassem Soleimani and Iraqi militia commander Abu M... Read More

NEW DELHI: The assassination of Iranian military strongman Qassim Suleimani marks a strong reassertion of US President Donald Trump ’s “maximum pressure” policy which was seemingly stalled by Tehran countering America with its own “maximum resistance” that hinges on its asymmetric warfare capability.

Faced with intense US pressure through economic sanctions that inflicted serious damage on its economy, Iran chose to escalate tensions from mid-2019, targeting shipping in the Gulf of Oman, shooting down a US drone and organising calibrated strikes on Saudi oil fields. All these actions aimed to use its leverage with militias to attack interests of America and its allies in the middle east.

In counter-attacking, Iran sought to up the stakes and Suleimani was its key man who could turn on the heat through a range of proxies and allies that included Hamas , Palestine Islamic Jihad and the Hezbollah . Though US has had extended back channel contacts with Iran, it saw the general as a high value target who might have been useful in combating ISIS but was also a threat to its interests.

The electoral calculations in the drone attack have been speculated on, but do not obscure an essential shift in US objectives under Trump — a sharper focus on getting Iran to rollback its ambitions in the middle east and significantly reduce use of various state-supported militias it has funded and armed.

This approach to Iran was driven, as experts have pointed out, by the calculation that nuclear issues were not the sole, or even the most important, point of discussion with Iran’s theocratic dispensation. Also, having chosen Saudi Arabia as its preferred partner, the Trump administration cast Iran as the greater threat in the volatile region.

Both sides have spurned dialogue, but doing so can cost Iran more. A window that opened through a third party after Iran used mines against oil tankers was understood to have been spurned by the regime. It then upped the ante again not long after Trump held back from retaliating to a drone being downed, apparently due to the high collateral cost of such military action.

Opening a dialogue could have increased Iran’s options as despite uneasiness in Europe, and stronger words from China and Russia, it is unclear how much useful support it will garner. After US nixed the nuclear deal, Iran failed to find the succour it needed to soften sanctions, despite sympathetic noises in some western capitals. Its reputation as a sponsor of militias hurt Iran despite support for the deal.

Opinion is divided whether the nuclear deal arrived at by Barack Obama had indeed encouraged Iran to mend its ways. Its actions in Yemen and Iraq suggest otherwise. It can now calculate that the threat of escalation may help its cause, but a miscalculation can also prove very costly to the Iranian leadership.

Title: Now, corpn draws ‘kolams’ to check garbage dumping
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Chennai: The ‘ kolam ’, traditionally drawn to ensure prosperity of households, over the past few days became a symbol of opposition to or support for the Citizenship Amendment Act. Now the Greater Chennai Corporation has restarted its initiative of drawing them in a bid to shame litterbugs.

On Saturday morning, shopkeepers and residents of New Farrance Road in Otteri woke up to civic staff drawing ‘kolams’ with eco-friendly themes along the road. The corporation staff said they were fed up with picking up after people who dumped garbage and household stuff they didn’t want where ever there was open space, especially in ward 73.

Corporation officials of Thiru Vi Ka nagar zone (Zone 6) went door to door campaigning for segregating garbage and assuring residents that conservancy workers will collect it at their doorstep. The civic officials also promised residents that they would be given manure generated from organic waste.

Officials said the response from residents was positive, but the dumping of garbage on open spaces has not stopped entirely. That’s when corporation officials thought of drawing ‘kolam’, a practice it has followed off and on in various parts of the city.

“We identified vulnerable points along the stretch where garbage as well as unused household items and other waste material was dumped. We were cleaning up after them for the past ten days. So, to put an end to this, we decided to opt for creative ways and draw ‘kolams’,” said Kumaravel, assistant engineer, ward 73 in Thiru Vi Ka Nagar.

Kumaravel said they hoped that since ‘kolams’ are mandatory during Margazhi season, they could appeal to people’s sentiments and curb littering in open spaces. “Based on the response to this, we will employ similar measures in other vulnerable points in all divisions in the zone,” the assistant engineer added.

Residents welcomed the move by the corporation, but also expressed scepticism whether they will keep at it. “The corporation staff do clean the stretch every day, but dumping continues nevertheless,” said Abdur Rahaman, a resident.

Title: Kerala: Strict action against drug shops near educational institutions
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

T P Ramakrishnan (Photo credit: Facebook)

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The government will intensify action against drug-selling shops in the vicinity of educational institutions, including refusal of permission to reopen if found guilty of the offence, labour and excise minister T P Ramakrishnan said.

“Currently, such shops reopen even though they were identified as the real perpetrators in many cases. To change the scenario, the state excise department and the local self-government institutions will together take severe action against such shops and prevent them from reopening,” he said while chairing a meeting of the executive committee of the state’s drug and addiction-free mission Vimukthi on Friday.

The minister said the excise department registered 67,713 cases under cigarettes and other tobacco products act (COTPA), 12,425 excise cases and 6,573 cases under narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances act (NDPS) in 2019.

He said a Rs 100-crore model de-addiction centre would be opened at Kinalur in Kozhikode jointly by the excise and health departments in collaboration with the Aardram mission.

The minister said that units of Vimukthi Sena would be formed in all the wards in the state by January 30 to keep track of drug-related activities. Out of the 19,499 wards in the state, Vimukthi Sena units were formed in 11,550 of them. Each unit will have five to 10 members, including two women, Anganwadi workers, Asha workers and Kudumbashree workers.

He said anti-drug clubs will be set up in all schools, professional colleges and medical colleges. Currently, such clubs are functioning in 3,739 schools and 576 colleges. “Apart from this, around 7,500 anti-drug clubs will be established in all libraries in the state. Various anti-drug campaigns such as evening gatherings, home visits and lighting the lamp against drugs will also be organized,” he said.

Vimukthi stepped up its campaign by tapping on Kudumbashree network down to the grass root level and displaying the ‘drug free Kerala ’ message on 500 KSRTC buses.

Vimukthi also prominently displayed its “say no to drug” message at food stalls of Kudumbashree at the ongoing flower show at Kanakakunnu. Apart from floating banners, display cards carrying the drug-free message have been placed on the tables set up to serve food and on the t-shirts of the suppliers.

Title: DGCA team arrives to probe Sagar plane crash
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Bhopal: A team from Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) arrived in Sagar on Saturday to investigate the crash of a trainer airplane that killed an instructor and trainee pilot on Friday evening.

Aircrash investigators inspected the accident site, where the debris of the crashed plane still lie. The single-engine Cessna of Chimes Aviation Academy (CAA) crashed into a field in dense fog just short of Dhana airport of Sagar. Instructor Ashok Makwana, 55, and trainee Piyush Chandel were killed. Both of them were from Mumbai. Their families arrived in Sagar at night. According to sources, Piyush was working as an aeronautical engineer in Doha and wanted to be a pilot.

CAA administrator Rahul Sharma said, “The accident happened because of unexpected weather conditions. There was lot of difference between the weather at 9pm and just 5 minutes later.” Asked if the fliers had taken note of IMD weather forecast and the thick fog, he said, “All aspects were taken into consideration before they took off.”

“The fog was unexpectedly thick. You ask anyone about the difference in visibility between 9pm and 9.05pm. The fog was very dense and rolled in suddenly,” he said, adding that DGCA will investigate the crash. He was not able to say how long the plane was in the air before it crashed. Asked about fuel, he said: “There was enough fuel and that it did not catch fire was the only silver lining in the tragedy.”

Sagar SP Amit Sanghi said, “We can’t investigate the crash, as it is not in our purview. It will be investigated by DGCA.” Police have registered a ‘dead person’s report’ and are investigating related aspects.

Title: 10 schoolchildren, man injured as van overturns
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A private van carrying school children overturned after hitting a pedestrian near Ponneri on Saturday morning. While the pedestrian, Kuruvappa, suffered a fracture in his leg, students inside the van escaped with minor injuries.

The incident happened on Ponneri-Panchetti Road at Peruncheri early on Saturday. Police said the van driver picked up 10 children from nearby villages and was heading to drop them off at a school in the neighbourhood.

Witnesses told police that the van driver lost control of the vehicle while negotiating a curve on the route right around a bus stop, knocking down Kuruvappa who was waiting there. The van then overturned into an open drain nearby. Passersby rescued the children and Kuruvappa and sent them to the government hospital at Ponneri.

Kuruvappa was later shifted to a private hospital in Chennai for further treatment. On information, the Ponneri police detained the van driver for rash and negligent driving and are conducting inquiries.

Title: Aspirated molar tooth stuck in lung for 3 years removed
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kochi: An aspirated tooth that was stuck in the lung of a woman for three years was removed by a team of doctors at a city hospital. The tooth resembled a tumour in the lung during endoscopy.

The 63-year-old woman from Kasaragod , who complained of cough, fever, loss of appetite and weight, was treated for pneumonia initially for almost two years on the basis of sputum and biopsy reports.

Later on, she underwent endoscopy, which showed a polypoidal growth in the right lung resembling a tumour. The treating doctors also suspected the tumour to be malignant. In three years, the patient spent around Rs 5 lakh but her condition only worsened.

For further evaluation, the patient then came to Amrita Institute of Medical Sciences and Research Centre ( AIMS ).

At AIMS, the patient underwent a rigid bronchoscopic procedure, and the growth involving her lung was removed and the doctors noticed the impacted tooth below the growth.

“The patient was not aware of the aspirated tooth. It was molar tooth and she didn’t even know that it was missing. Though her dental hygiene was poor, she said that she had never gone to a dental surgeon in the past three years. We suspect that this could have happened in sleep,” said interventional pulmonologist (AIMS) Dr Tinku Joseph, who performed the procedure.

The tooth was then successfully removed. “This was the source for her recurrent pneumonia in the initial years and later on multiple growths resembling tumour started forming around the impacted tooth,” said Dr Joseph.

Pulmonologist Dr Sobha Subramaniam who evaluated the patient initially at AIMS said that aspiration of foreign bodies is more commonly seen in children and in adults such instances happen during sleep. Such incident is also suspected in an individual who suffers from recurrent non-resolving pneumonia.

Title: AAP lied on ownership rights: Manoj Tiwari
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Manoj Tiwari

NEW DELHI: Slamming Aam Aadmi Party for its remarks on unauthorised colonies, Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari said that chief minister Arvind Kejriwal should apologise to the people of unauthorised colonies for making misleading remarks on the ownership rights.

“The AAP MP had left Lok Sabha proceedings when voting was taking place on the Bill introduced for conferring ownership rights to 40 lakh people living in unauthorised colonies. Kejriwal government could not fix the boundaries of unauthorised colonies within the time fixed for it and they sought extension again and again from the ministry of housing and urban affairs,” Tiwari said during a press conference and added that Kejriwal did not want to confer ownership rights to these people.

“The Narendra Modi government took over the work of regularising these colonies and completed it within 100 days,” Tiwari said, adding that AAP leaders resorted to lies to mislead these people but failed.

Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal had described the registry papers and conveyance deeds handed over to 20 residents of unauthorised colonies by union minister Hardeep Puri on Friday as fake. Kejriwal asked how registry could be done without regularising the colonies.

AAP functionaries said that the documents were worthless without a notification for change of land use.

Tiwari later said that after a mob of jihadis in Pakistan attacked Nankana Sahib Gurdwara, Sikhs are in terror there. “The CAA has been framed to save such minorities from prosecution but Kejriwal is opposing it because he does not want to protect them,” Tiwari said. Despite attempts to seek reaction from AAP, no comment was available.

Title: Bailiff in net for accepting Rs 2.5 lakh bribe
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The state anti-corruption bureau (ACB) on Saturday afternoon arrested a bailiff of a small causes’ court on the charge of accepting a bribe .

The ACB said the suspect had demanded and accepted a Rs2.5 lakh bribe in exchange for providing documents related to a case to a Shivajinagar resident.

A team comprising superintendent of police Rajesh Bansode and additional SP Sanjay Patil arrested Manohar Rudrappa Kamble (48), the bailiff. A case has been registered with the Shivajinagar police station.

The ACB said the complainant moved the court against another person over the possession of a piece of property in the Deccan Gymkhana area.

The court recently delivered a judgement and a decree in favour of the complainant, who sought a copy of the decree from the bailiff, ACB said.

The suspect sought a bribe, and was caught red-handed, ACB said.

Title: Pune: Illegal parking near makeshift MSRTC bus stand hits traffic
Content:
The scene outside the terminus was chaotic on Friday afternoon

PUNE: Commuters using the old Pune-Mumbai highway passing by the newly set up bus terminus of the Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporations at Wakdewadi are feeling “choked”, courtesy illegal halting of autorickshaws on the service road and parking of two-wheelers on footpaths right outside the facility.The scene outside the terminus was chaotic on Friday afternoon. Autorickshaws were parked outside the entry-exit gates of the terminus. The footpath was occupied by two-wheelers. The Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporations (MSRTC) buses taking turn from the main road to enter the terminus jostled for space, triggering traffic snarls.The MSRTC temporarily shifted its bus operations to the Wakdewadi depot from the Shivajinagar terminus from January 1 to facilitate the Metro project work. Over 1,000 buses are expected to be operated from the terminus every day. The MSRTC will also take up maintenance of buses arriving at the terminus.Commuters availing the old Pune-Mumbai highway claimed that the MSRTC did not take adequate measures to manage the traffic on the road as well as ensure seamless travel of bus commuters while shifting the bus operations.Yashavant Kamble, a resident of the area, said, “Hundreds of buses are expected to arrive and depart from here. The authorities need to provide adequate infrastructure to manage the movement of buses and commuters. Appointment of controllers and traffic police should be done on priority basis.”Ramesh Bhosale, who arrived at the bus terminus to board a bus, said the location of the terminus was difficult to access. “Moreover, it is not accessible by Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) buses. Commuters are being fleeced by the autorickshaw drivers,” he added.Akshay Kelkar, a regular traveller on the road, said the authorities have not spent a thought on entry and exit of buses to and from the terminus. “Buses enter or exit the terminus every three to four minutes. The movement of these buses hamper the vehicular traffic on the main road,” Kelkar said. He added that the administration would also face a challenge while controlling illegal vendors and presence of private bus operators outside the terminus.Officials in the MSRTC said they were reviewing the situation and initiating steps to introduce improvements to minimize the hardship of commuters. An official from the MSRTC said a letter had been submitted to the PMPML to increase the frequency of buses near the Wakdewadi terminus to ensure that commuters did not face hassles in reaching the terminus.

Title: Kanam fires back, credits Achutha Menon for land reforms
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Thrissur: The CPI-CPM row over the architect of the Kerala’s Land Reforms Act intensified on Saturday with CPI state secretary Kanam Rajendran making a scathing attack on those who were trying to undermine the role of late C Achutha Menon in that historic initiative.

Speaking at the 50th anniversary of the implementation of the Land Reforms Act here, Rajendran refrained from making any direct reference on the reported undermining of the role of Menon, who was the party leader and former chief minister. However, it was clear whom he was targeting.

“Even though there were initiatives for redistribution of land even earlier, it was Achutha Menon who made the Act into a reality. Those who are trying to negate his contribution in the land reforms of Kerala are only indulging in the futile task of trying to hide bright sun with an old ‘muram’ (traditional winnowing fan). History must be evaluated objectively and the deserving persons must be given their due credit for their historical contributions,” Rajendran said.

“It was the Achutha Menon government which decided to implement the Land Reforms Act on January 1, 1970. That government could effectively achieve the goals of land redistribution set by the first Communist government in the state in 1957,” Rajendran said.

He said the departed CPI leader E Chandrasekharan Nair had moved an amendment to the Land Reforms Bill when it was being considered by the assembly select committee during the tenure of the seven-party front in which both the CPM and CPI were partners.

The amendment suggested that the Bill must be implemented immediately. However, those who were heading that government pointed out the practical difficulties in implementing it immediately. Subsequently, it was decided to implement the Bill in phases. But those who were heading the government were not keen to implement the land reforms even after those changes, Rajendran said. He said there were several facts available in historical records to recognize the contribution of Menon and CPI in the land reforms in the state. Those who try to read them will understand the real history, he added.

Earlier, in his address, revenue minister E Chandrasekharan also slammed those trying to undermine the contributions of Menon in the implementation Land Reforms Act.

Opposition leader Ramesh Chennithala also criticized the efforts to sabotage the contribution of Menon. “The chief minister appears to be feeling some allergy when he had to mention Achutha Menon,” Chennithala told reporters.

Title: Aurangabad MP seeks kabaddi training centre for boys at SAI
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Aurangabad MP Imtiyaz Jaleel

AURANGABAD: Aurangabad MP Imtiyaz Jaleel has written to Union sports minister Kiren Rijiju asking him to start a kabaddi training centre for boys at Sports Authority of India ( SAI ) here and requested that the existing kabaddi training centre for girls be kept operational. According to Jaleel, the kabaddi training centre for girls is being shifted to Mumbai, which will make it difficult for the athletes in the region. Athletes from across Marathwada region and nearby districts can benefit from the training centre, said Jaleel. The MP took up the issue with Rijiju after the Aurangabad District Kabaddi Association wrote to him on December 28. The association, in the letter to Jaleel, wrote that the SAI had two kabaddi training centres in Maharashtra — one in Mumbai and another in Aurangabad. The one in Aurangabad was for boys but it was shut down. Aurangabad District Kabaddi Association Datta Pathrikar told TOI that after pursuing the matter with the authorities, the kabaddi training centre for girls was opened in Aurangabad. “Many women athletes have benefited from the training centre at SAI, Aurangabad, and have improved their game. The centre is a boon for athletes from rural areas across the Marathwada region and even south India. Now, the SAI has received a letter to shift the women’s hostel to Mumbai,” she said “This would be a setback for kabaddi players as travelling to Mumbai would be expensive for them,” Pathrikar said. He added that Aurangabad also needs a kabaddi training centre for boys. Virendra Bhandarkar, the SAI Aurangabad director, said that he has now been posted to Guwahati and cannot comment on the issue.

Title: Pune: Inebriated criminal attacks 2 cops, held
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A criminal in police records was arrested on Friday in an inebriated state for attacking two policemen over a petty dispute at Sainiknagar around 12.05pm.

The arrested man, Suresh Keshav Galfade (40) from Sainiknagar, was creating public nuisance under the influence of liquor.

When the city police control room received a telephone call from bystanders, beat marshal Rajiv Hile and one of his colleagues from the Yerawada police rushed to the spot and appealed to Galfade to maintain peace.

They warned him against creating nuisance, and disturbing the peace and tranquillity of the locality but he refused and picked up a dispute with them.

Senior inspector Yunus Shaikh from the Yerawada police station said, he picked up a dispute with the policemen because he wanted to know if they were real policemen.

“In a fit of anger, he hurled abuses at the policemen, attacked Hile and pushed him to the ground,” Shaikh said.

“Hile suffered minor injuries. Galfade was later taken into custody,” Shaikhadded.

“Investigations revealed that Galfade had a fight with a woman after she refused to give him money for buying liquor,” Shaikh said.

“The control room received a telephone call regarding the incident when he started beating up the woma,” he said.

The beat marshals tried to control the situation but Galfade abused and attacked them as well, the senior inspector said.

“Galfade is a criminal on record of the Pimpri Chinchwad police for his involvement in body offences,” he added.

Title: Rail projects: Minister requests fund allocation
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state government has listed out several projects in the state, including initiation of semi high-speed rail corridor, to the Union ministry ahead of the Union budget 2020-21. PWD minister G Sudhakaran has sent a communication to Union minister for railways Piyush Goyal requesting to consider need-based demands of the state for railway developments in the forthcoming budget.

The minister has requested fund allocation for semi high-speed rail corridor between Thiruvananthapuram and Kasaragod estimated at Rs 66,000 crore, Palakkad rail coach factory and Angamaly-Sabarimala project in the Union budget.

“There is an urgent need to improve the rail infrastructure within Kerala like doubling of the track, provision of terminal facilities, additional platform, introduction of new trains, MEMU services, etc. Also, the government of Kerala through the joint venture company, Kerala rail development corporation Ltd (KRDCL) has identified new rail projects and is processing detailed project report (DPR),” the letter stated.

“Railway board has given in-principle approval for the project and the DPR is being finalized and will be submitted to railway board during the first half of 2020-21. Request for final sanction and provision of fund towards the equity of Government of India,” reads the letter.

Fund has been requested for doubling work between Ernakulam and Ambalapuzha, Ernakulam and Kayamkulam via Kottayam and Thiruvananthapuram and Kanyakumari.

The letter also states about the feasibility study conducted by KRDCL for redevelopment of abandoned terminus station at Ernakulam in the 42 acres of railway land near the high court.

Sudhakaran has also requested for introduction of trains, including Palakkad-Thiruvananthapuram Jan Sathabdi Express, Kochuveli-Malda, Guwahati, Howrah, Kamakhya weekly service, Kochuveli Rameswaram and Kochuveli-Velankanni expresses. The letter has also requested to expedite development of Nemom and Kochuveli railway station. TNN

Title: People will be less dependent on smartphones in 10yrs: Baidu CEO
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Chennai: Baidu , China’s largest search engine, is looking forward to working with Indian institutions in future, says its co-founder and CEO Robin Li .

Baidu already has a presence in markets such as Japan, Thailand and Egypt. "The search will be very different from what is seen today. Once we transform search into a different product, we will be ready to launch it internationally," he said during a talk at IIT Madras tech festival Shaastra on Saturday.

"Artificial Intelligence is a big wave. Not every company has resources to develop full-fledged cutting edge technology. We have devoted a lot of resources to open platforms so that everyone can take advantage of that," Li said.

AI is also used for public welfare, Li said, adding that they have already found 9,000 missing persons using AI and face recognition technologies in China. It also can be used to help the visually challenged. "We use AI to help visually impaired people use voice to control air conditioning and other devices."

Li said video has become the most important content on the internet. "We used to see text; then more and more images on the Internet. Today, video is the most important form of content on the internet. People’s mindsets are also changing — changing toward video content," he said.

AI can make a person immortal as computers can learn the way humans thinks through voice, video and text.

On other trends, he said AI can speed up everything from drug discovery to banking, where virtual assistants can now help people create bank accounts, borrow money and so on.

"In the next ten years, people will be less dependent on mobile phones because wherever they go, there will be surrounding sensors, infrastructure that can answer your questions. You may not be required to pull out your mobile phone every time to find an answer," he added.

Search engines would also be very different in future. "In future, you will not be able to distinguish between search and recommendation. The search engine technology is evolving quickly," he said.

Title: Draw of lots gives Aurangabad ZP post to MVA
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Newly elected Aurangabad zilla parishad president Meena Shelke (foreground, centre) flashes the victory sign o... Read More

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad ZP elections took an interesting turn on Saturday with the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) and BJP candidates securing same number of votes each for the president’s post, forcing draw of lots that went in favour of the Congress nominee.

The election to the ZP president’s post was postponed on Friday, following confusion and clashes over the number of votes both candidates had received as one member had raised the hand twice in favour of each candidate.

Saturday’s election saw Congress’s Meena Shelke and Devyani Dongaonkar, who was supported by the BJP, receiving 30 votes each. Subsequently, a draw of lots was conducted and Shelke was the lucky winner.

The ZP election was a bitter-sweet experience for BJP. Although the party lost the president’s post, its candidate L G Gaikwad defeated MVA’s Shubangi Kaje to clinch the vice-president’s post, elections for which were held on Friday.

However, clinching the vice-president’s post has failed to assuage the BJP which has decided to challenge the Aurangabad ZP president’s election in court.

BJP state vice president Bhagwat Karade told TOI that there was no need for the returning officer to hold fresh elections for the president’s post as the elections had already been conducted on Friday.

“We had an upper hand in the zilla parishad which was proven in the vice president’s election, where our candidate received 32 votes while the MVA nominee got 28. BJP is the largest party in the ZP with 23 members. Disgruntled Sena and Congress members approached us. We formed a group with them and decided to throw our weight behind Devyani Dongaonkar.’’

Following chaos on Friday, returning officer Bhanudas Palwe decided to hold fresh elections for the president’s post on Saturday. He had told reporters that it was hard to count votes amid tremendous commotion in the meeting hall.

Palwe allowed the three members who could not make it to the election venue on Friday to cast their votes on Saturday.

The BJP is the largest party in the 61-member ZP with 23 members, followed by Shiv Sena (17), Congress (16), NCP (3) and a member each belonging to the Democratic Republican Party and Maharashtra Navnirman Sena.

Cross-voting happened from both the sides during the election process on Friday. Three candidates were in the fray for the president’s post, including outgoing president Dongaonkar. She earlier represented Sena as the ZP president but rebelled against the safrron party and re-contested the elections with BJP’s support, much to the discomfiture of the Sena leadership in the district. The BJP had fielded Anuradha Chavan for the president’s post. She too pledged her support to Dongaonkar.

Meanwhile, former city MP Chandrakant Khaire came down heavily on newly appointed minister of state Abdul Sattar, dubbing him a traitor saying that six members belonging to Sattar had voted in favour of Dongaonkar (now a Sena rebel).

Khaire said since Sattar was elected on a Sena ticket and made minister, it was his moral responsibility to support the MVA nominee.

Title: New look Hamidia hospital to be ready by May, expansion pegged at Rs 435 cr
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Construction work underway at Hamidia hospital 2nd gate

Bhopal: The renovated Hamidia hospital with state of the art facilities is expected to be completed by May this year, if senior officials are to be believed. The expansion of largest tertiary care hospital in the state capital would include completion of two new blocks for medical treatment, hostel and library.

Current phase of Hamidia expansion is pegged at Rs 435.97 crore. A 24x7 work is taking place at Gandhi Medical College (GMC) that would redefine the skyline of the area. Infrastructure development would entail an additional Rs 90 crore, budget for which is awaited.
