The expansion would create 1,538 beds in two building blocks towering 13 floors. They would be connected by a bridge – three floors high. Rs 89.21 crore has been allocated for upgrade of GMC which includes a new library and new administrative block. New allocation of funding for up gradation of infrastructure for 250 MBBS seats at GMC has also been approved – all this is expected to a reality by mid-2020. Expansion of Hamidia hospital began in December 2016.

“We expect the shifting of the hospital to new block to be ahead of time,” said Bhopal divisional commissioner, Kalpana Shrivastava. Divisional commissioner is also head of GMC autonomous body which administrates the medical college and its associated hospitals. If achieved it would one of the fastest transformation or expansion of a health care setup in Madhya Pradesh on this scale. Before the expansion, Hamidia hospital strength was 850-beds.

The move would also pave the way for new maternity care building within GMC campus. Currently, the hospital for obstetrics and gynaecology is Sultania hospital, about 5 km away from GMC campus.

Three entries to GMC: Two entries from Royal Market side and one pedestrian way from Fatehgarh would be opened for public at Hamidia hospital. Entry of the hospital has been an issue that has affected emergency vehicles too.

Off late, due to Ijetma market nearby, BMC and police have focussed removing encroachments from Royal market main gate entry to GMC. However, instances of ambulances being stuck in the traffic are a regular site.

A new entry has been proposed, ahead of development and restoration of current main gate. Other passage would be for pedestrian only. The entry is from Fategharh end of GMC.

Earlier this week, during a visit to Hamidia hospital Bhopal north MLA Arif Aqueel asked for opening of closed entry gate of Hamidia hospital. The gate towards Fatehgarh was closed when construction for new blocks began in mid-2017. The proposal has been met with apprehension from engineering consultants.

“Only the pedestrian walkway of the smaller entry would be opened. All safety measures would be in place before the pedestrian way is opened,” said Shrivastava. Off the record, consultants said that there is on-going plaster work on the 13-storey building. A peeling of even a small strand from this level could cause serious damage to a person below. Opening of the gate would also create an easy connect with private pharmacies on the side towards Fatehgarh side.

Title: Rajasthan hospital horror: Now, 102 infants perish in two Jodhpur facilities
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

A man with his child at a ward in Kota’s J K Lon Hospital on Saturday.

JODHPUR: Amid the chaos over the deaths of infants at Kota’s J K Lon Hospital , disturbing figures of similar deaths have emerged from Jodhpur .

A joint report on infant deaths at Umaid Hospital and MDM Hospital in Jodhpur, prepared by the hospitals’ governing organisation, states that a total of 146 deaths (of children) were recorded at the Neonatal Intensive Care and Paediatric ICUs in December.

As per figures obtained from S N Medical College, the governing organisation, a total of 4,689 children were admitted to the two hospitals in December. Of these, 3,002 were infants. During treatment, 146 children, including 102 infants, died.

SN Medical College principal S S Rathore said the child mortality rate came to 3%, which was in keeping with international infant mortality rates.

As per the figures, 47,815 children had been admitted to the hospital in 2019, of which 754 children died, which is 1.57%. But, of these, 5,634 children were admitted to the NICU and ICU in serious condition and all 754 deaths were reported in the NICU and ICU.

Rathore said the paediatric care units for critical patients had been winning first prize for the past two years in succession and this was because “we are doing the best”.

He added that the hospital here has to bear the load of patients from entire western Rajasthan and children are also referred to this hospital from hospitals like AIIMS.

While counting the mortality rate, the hospital administration calculated it factoring in patients admitted to the paediatric wards while the deaths occurred in the NICU and ICU.

Though Rathore denied any shortage of resources to deal with the “pressure”, many senior doctors from the hospital’s paediatric department have been running their own private hospitals and skipping hospital duties. Recently notices had been served on these doctors, including those who had medical shops at their residences, but the situation has not shown any improvement and the absence of senior doctors from the OPD remains a matter of concern.

Title: SHRC orders probe into custodial torture
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kochi: State human rights commission (SHRC) on Saturday ordered a detailed inquiry into a complaint of custodial torture by Chottanikkara police.

Joji Cherian of Muriamangalam at Chottanikkara alleged in his complaint to SHRC that the police officers who were influenced by real estate mafia registered a bogus case against him and thrashed him in custody. He was booked for obstructing the duty of police in connection with an argument over a property dispute.

The commission which sought a report from Ernakulam district police chief, later assigned SP VM Sandeep, who is an investigation officer with SHRC, for investigating the case.

An official communique from SHRC said that the SP found that the complainant underwent medical examination thrice but he could get the copy of only one report.

In the said report, he found that there were as many as six injuries on the petitioner’s body and that custodial torture cannot be ruled out. The SHRC hence ordered a detailed probe into the incident.

Title: 7 held in Peb fort moral policing, 2 outfits involved
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Shiv Pratishthan Hindustan has claimed responsibility for action

NAVI MUMBAI: Neral police have arrested seven persons, members of Shiv Pratishthan Hindustan and a local organisation named Sahyadri Prathishthan, in connection with the alleged assault and stripping of 11 youths at Peb fort on New Year’s Eve . Police are searching for the rest of the accused .

Meanwhile, Shiv Pratishthan Hindustan has claimed responsibility for its members’ action against “illegal activities” at the fort.

The arrested accused include Sanket Karale (20), Premnath Mali (31), Samir Shinde (35), Vaibhav Sawant (28), Ganesh Dharane (28), Yatin Bhosale (28) and Nagesh Bhoir (23).

All accused are Karjat taluka residents. They have been booked under IPC sections for wrongful restraint, unlawful assembly, rioting, causing hurt, mischief and defamation, among others, by Neral police.

Requesting anonymity, a Neral police constable said, “The seven persons arrested are locals. A few of the arrested belong to local organisation Sahyadri Pratisthan while others are from Shiv Pratishthan Hindustan. The accused belong to different villages."

Raigad superintendent of police Anil Paraskar said, “They were produced in a Karjat court and were released on bail. A few of them are members of Shiv Pratisthan Hindustan and while others belong to local organisation. Police are still looking for five to eight more accused.”

Paraskar added, “Despite our repeated requests, none of the 11 victims have come forward to cooperate with the police. This is surprising. However, the police are pursuing the case.”

Claiming responsibility for the assault, Shiv Pratishthan Hindustan state secretary Nitin Chougule said, “We have information that our workers have acted against those involved in the illegal activities at Peb fort. Our organisation strongly endorses and supports the activities of our workers.”

Chougule said, “The administration must find out how and from where liquor and ganja were sourced and brought to the fort. A thorough probe should be conducted into the ganja link and action should be taken against those involved in the supply.”

Neral police had formed teams after the video went viral on social media. Some of them are searching for the accused while others are reaching out to the victims.

Title: ‘Why compete with China, we have our goals’
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Chennai: “We should not fall into the trap of trying to compete with China and fritter away our meagre economic resources," says Lt Gen (retd) Sathish Dua, former chief of integrated defence staff and counter terrorism expert.

He was responding to a question from a student at IIT Madras on why India has been restrained while China is carrying out projects like the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) and building ports in Sri Lanka and other countries.

"China wants to replace the US as superpower and it is their stated aim to become a superpower. India’s

stated position is it doesn’t want to go beyond our borders. We are not competing with them in that space," he said while interacting with students as part of defence tech summit at IIT Madras on Saturday.

"We should be able to deter them from carrying out a military offensive like in 1962," he added.

On combat roles for women, he said, "The living conditions in bunkers or posts are very difficult especially in hilly areas and borders. In such conditions, sharing convenience with women is not a good idea considering our social context. You have to bear with us. It will be tough to manage. That’s the reason we are opening up very cautiously." He hailed the appointment of a chief of defence staff (CDS) as a very bold step and said it was long overdue.

He asked the young engineers to find solutions to help combat cyber crime.

Title: Bus crash: SETC told to pay Rs 17L to amputee
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Chennai: An accident claims tribunal in Kancheepuram has directed the Tamil Nadu State Express Transport Corporation to pay Rs 16.56 lakh to a woman whose limb had to be amputated after a rashly driven SETC bus hit a truck, leading to injuries to passengers.

S Nirmala of Villivakkam stated in her petition that she was traveling in a SETC bus from Trichy to Chennai in September 2014, when she met with the accident. According to her petition, the bus was driven rashly and tail-ended a truck. Nirmala’s leg got stuck amid vehicle parts in the collision and she sustained grievous injuries. Her leg was amputated subsequently. She sought a compensation of Rs 61 lakh from the transport corporation.

The transport corporation denied the allegations and stated that the bus driver had handled the vehicle with due care and it was the truck that halted all of a sudden, leading to the accident. The transport corporation that it was not liable to pay compensation.

After perusing the submissions and going through the contents of the FIR, the tribunal judge noted that the documents show that the accident happened only due to the rash and negligent driving by the SETC bus driver.

The tribunal took note that Nirmala was 42 years old at the time of the accident and was working as a nursing tutor, a profession she still pursues. However, her disability due to amputation needs to be compensated and after computing other factors, the tribunal said Rs 16.56 lakh was to be paid by SETC to the woman.

Title: Mumbai: Serial CAT taker gets his sixth perfect score
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Patrick D’Souza

Patrick D’Souza (41), a tutor from Mumbai, secured 100 percentile for the sixth time and the fourth time consecutively, in CAT 2019. D’Souza, who first appeared for CAT in 1996, failed to get an IIM call then.

Soon after, D’Souza pursued an MBA from Jamnalal Bajaj Institute of Management Studies and then joined a corporate firm. Four years later, the serial CAT taker quit his job to get into teaching. Since then, he has been training a small group of students for CAT.

“Some of my candidates managed over 99 percentile every year. It is very important to stay abreast of current trends in paper patterns and questions. It is a different experience for me every year,” says D’Souza, a Thane resident.

According to D'Souza, CAT is an exam that not only tests an aspirant’s aptitude but also one’s ability to manage pressure in three hours. “I have seen the best failing to manage the pressure and those who remained calm do well. The sections may be constant but the paper is largely unpredictable.”

D'Souza claims that he writes CAT every year to understand the exam. “It helps me to train my students better and review my teaching practices. Writing the paper helps me understand the changes in paper pattern if any, what methods work or don’t work and accordingly teach,” D’Souza adds.

“Many faculty also appear for CAT with the same intention. But training students for the exam and writing it are two different things. Only a few score 99.9 plus and I have managed to crack it four times in a row and six times overall,” added D'Souza, pointing out that CAT does not require you to be brilliant.

“I wasn’t the brightest in the school. Unfortunately, a lot of students prepare for CAT like the way they prepared for exams in school. But that is a wrong method,” said D'Souza.

This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

Title: Till December, GST collections in Maharashtra Rs 4,683 crore short of target
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: While Maharashtra generates the highest GST revenue in the country, collections in the state were Rs 4,683 crore short of the target for the nine-month span between April and December 2019. This means collections are 3.3% behind the target set for the state.While the collections are 9.3% higher than last year, they are still much lower than the 14% growth target set for the state.The shortfall is an indicator of the economic slowdown in the country since GST is a consumption-based tax. Officials say the slowdown in auto and real estate sectors has significantly impacted GST collections in Maharashtra .Consumption in the state, though, picked up during the festive season and helped revive GST collections. For the month of October 2019, GST collections were 22% higher than 2018, said officials. For November 2019, collections are expected to be at least 15% higher than in 2018.“There was a rise in the sale of white goods, except televisions during the festive months. This helped raise GST collections,” said a senior official. Earlier this year, GST on white goods was reduced from 28% to 18%, which may have boosted the volume of sales during the festive season.The Centre’s GST collection target for the state is 1.9 lakh crore for the year. In the nine-month span between April and December, the state should have generated collections totalling Rs 1.41 lakh crore. The collections, though, amounted to Rs 1.4 lakh crore, said officials. In 2018-19, the figure for collections during the same period was Rs 1.25 lakh crore.Officials say it may be difficult to achieve the GST target by March-end. “The monthly collection average till December is Rs 15,232 crore. In order to achieve the target, the monthly average till the end of March will have to be Rs 17,300 crore,” said a senior official.GST is the main revenue earner for the state government. A shortfall in GST collections combined with the delay in compensation cess from the Centre could impact the revenue stream of the cash-strapped state. The Centre is supposed to compensate states for the loss of revenue arising from implementation of GST up to 2022. The state is currently waiting for compensation worth Rs 4,206 crore for the October-November period.

Title: BJP leadership not to bail out strife-ridden BDJS
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: BJP is unlikely to take sides with any of the warring factions within BDJS. The allegations that the BDJS president Thushar Vellappally and its general secretary Subhash Vasu have unleashed against each other, feel BJP leaders, have more financial implications than political ones.

Senior leaders in state BJP have already decided not to make public comments on the developments in the BDJS. The central leadership, contrary to the claims made by Thushar and Vasu, too have refused to intervene. The safe distance that BJP tries to keep from BDJS can be interpreted as a sign of disgust the BJP leadership has developed towards BDJS. Though it tried to preen a political identity, the party has seldom been able to wean itself away from the shadow of SNDP Yogam to which Thushar is the vice-president. Once Yogam general secretary Vellappally Natesan changed side and started cosying up to the CPM, especially chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan, the political fortunes of BDJS had gone astray. But then, it was the cordial relationship Thushar had with the BJP central leaders that kept BDJS afloat.

However, the financial controversies that landed Thushar in jail in August 2019 had made irreparable damages in the ties between him and the BJP central leadership. “Thushar used to call on Amit Shah in New Delhi frequently. But since his arrest in the UAE last year, his repeated attempts to meet Shah were not paid back. Last time when he finally met Shah, he had to make himself satisfied with a casual meet up during a BJP function in New Delhi,” a senior BJP leader said.

The BJP leaders in the state were seldom in favour of the central leadership’s decision to take Thushar along with an eye on Ezhava votes. “Now, the central leadership too is convinced about the political impact the BDJS could make. Naturally that party has come to a naught and it’s only a matter of time before it crumbles down,” said another BJP leader.

Sources said that the row over sharing the good fortunes coming from SN Trust-run institutions and other business opportunities has led to the ongoing spar between Thushar and Vadu. The old-time foes of Natesan are also believed to have put their weight behind Vasu, who until recently was the most trusted lieutenant of Natesan. BJP central leadership’s refusal to remove Vasu as the chairman of Spices Board of India underlines BJP’s wait-and-watch attitude.

Title: Kerala: Flood-hit government high school gets new lab
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The science lab was opened at the school at Kuttamassery on Friday

KOCHI: Hardly 200 metre away from Periyar, the government high school at Kuttamassery lost most of their infrastructure during the August 2018 floods. The most devastating was the loss of computer and science labs and the library. The school also lost valuable office equipment.

On Friday, a new science lab was opened at the school, with help of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), which granted Rs 24 lakh. As a special initiative, IEEE is revamping the centre for visually challenged students of the school.

A special programme to train such students in computer and technology was organized by Chakshumathi trust as part of the event.

The proposal for revamping the flood-hit school was submitted by Cochin University of Science and Technology ( Cusat ) faculty Bijoy Jose, who is the secretary of Kochi subsection of IEEE.

The project was among 35 proposals received that year and six were selected for funding. Techno Unnati, the proposal by Jose, received the highest amount of Rs 24 lakh for building computer and science labs.

Bijoy said the project aims to build computer labs, smart classes and library that were damaged in 2018 Periyar flooding. Part of the fund is also being utilized to provide better facilities for visually challenged students of the school.

C K Aanandan and Ressel P P, who teach at the department of electronics, Cusat, had been providing volunteering support for over a year. “Cusat had been helping the school in student training and we are seeking a higher grant from IEEE headquarters,” said Jose.

The project is being implemented with help of principal Jessy M, headmistress Leelamma K P, teacher Usha Manatt and PTA president Abdul Gafoor. Around 700 students will directly benefit from the lab facilities.

Title: Amid opposition, railways extends Rajya Rani Express to Nanded
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Passenger associations and regular travellers from the Nashik region are up in arms over the extension of the ... Read More

AURANGABAD/NASHIK: The Indian Railways has announced that the Mumbai-Manmad-Mumbai Rajya Rani Express has been extended up to Nanded in via Aurangabad.

The railway ministry, in a letter to the general manager of the Central Railwayand the South Central Railway (SCR)has said that the train numbers 22101 and 22102 Manmad to Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus (CSMT) will be extended to up to Huzur Sahib Nanded railway station. The train will start from Nanded at 10pm every day and reach CSMT at 10.07am the next day. On its return journey, it will depart at 6.50pm from CSMT and reach Nanded at 7.20am.

“The Railway Board has issued directives to the Central Railway and the SCR to start running the train on the extended route. Its operations are expected to begin from January 10,” said a senior SCR official.

Passenger associations and regular travellers from the Nashik region are up in arms over the extension of the route. “Since the train timings will suit several passengers from Nanded, they will occupy most seats and won’t allow commuters from Manmad and Nashik to board the train,” alleged Rajesh Fokane, former member of the Divisional Railway Users Consultative Committee (DRUCC). “The train departs from Mumbai at an ideal time. While this helps Nashik residents get home in the evening, and now people heading for Marathwada will also flock to the train as it will help them get home after an overnight journey,” said Sangeeta Shahane, a frequent passenger.

Railway authorities are anticipating friction between passengers from Nashik and those travelling to and from Marathwada. “We will ensure that Railway Protection Force personnel are deployed to thwart attempts to delay the train in any direction,” said a railway official. “There has been a strong need for a new train to Mumbai from Marathwada considering the passenger rush. The traffic congestion faced by the Central Railway was always cited as a major hurdle for starting a new train. It is a welcome move by the top brass of the Indian Railway which has found a way around this issue and extended the route of the Rajya Rani Express,” said Sanjay Gaikwad, a private professional who commutes between Mumbai and Purna every week.

Title: Chennai: Fog over city delays flights, messes with schedules
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visibility was as low as 500 metres at the city airport during a foggy Saturday morning

CHENNAI: Flying to Chennai has turned risky for pilots and passengers as fog disrupted flights at the city airport for the second day on Saturday.

Fog in Bengaluru’s Kempagowda airport around the same time has complicated the issue as it is the alternative airport closest to Chennai but was also not available for diversions.

This means pilots may now have to carry more fuel than the usual to be prepared to handle diversions to Hyderabad. With the Met department saying there could be fog in the region for the next couple of days, pilots will have to carry at least five to six tonnes of additional fuel to last for a diversion to Hyderabad airport.

“Pilots often carry three tonnes of additional fuel to handle diversions to Bengaluru but now more fuel must be carried. As a rule, pilots should carry fuel enough to reach Hyderabad as weather conditions are not ideal early in the morning in January to use Bengaluru as an alternate landing city,” said an airline official.

“This looks like freakish weather. Visibility usually dips closer to Pongal week. But this year, it has started becoming foggy early in the month. This will be an added blow because pilots are anticipating delays in airports in Delhi too,” said a pilot.

As arrivals are delayed, departures too get affected. On Saturday, planes could not taxi at the usual speed to reach the end of the runway for take-off because visibility was at 500 metres to 550 metres before dawn. This slowed down other departures. Though Chennai airport has airport operations control centre and collaborative decision making to communicate about ground delays to airlines, these are not efficiently linked to the Air Traffic Flow Management System, which foresees air congestion at airports well in advance. Though the city airport was enveloped with fog, most of the diverted flights came close to the airport before being diverted on Saturday.

An AAI official said in most of the cases, airlines allow their flights to proceed to the airport despite alerts about poor weather in the hope that the visibility will clear by the time the aircraft approaches the city for landing.

Title: Drone monitoring tech by Bhopal boy wins global laurels
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Vibhu Tripathi and Ayush Jindal

BHOPAL: A demonstration for tracking low altitude aerial vehicles including drones by a Bhopal-based start-up has been adjudged fourth amongst 142 entries from 51 countries at an event in Toulouse, France, according to a press release from Bhopal smart city development corporation limited (BSCDCL).

The duo, RGPV student Vibhu Tripathi and his partner Ayush Jindal who go by call-sign ‘Vizzbee’ were ranked 4th in Global Earth Observation 2019. Last year, a top Asian investor in new tech Zeroth purchased a 6% stake in the start-up. They were part of 30 start-ups in Asia in which the Hong Kong-based accelerator would invest $1.2 lakh (about Rs 82 lakh).

Vizzbee is an improvement from their early stage Artificial Intelligence (AI) and machine learning for the project. The new line of improvement deals with safety for low altitude aerial vehicles. According to Airbus, there will be an addition of aerial vehicles, both manned and unmanned in the current airspace and since air traffic controllers are already running at their maximum capacity, said Tripathi.

“There is a need of unmanned traffic management and routing system that can handle the operations, which considers the safety of not just the vehicle, but the area on top of which it flies,” he added. Last year, Bhopal collector Tarun Pithode had announced for a special cash prize for start-ups that could integrate GPS-based technology to identify the number of drones operating in the state capital.

Currently, Tripathi and Jindal’s idea is being tested for multiple use cases such as medical delivery for hospitals and search and rescue operations. The uniqueness of the project has promoted an invite from Airbus headquarters.

The project is a shot in the arm for B-nest, which has found central government funding hard to flow, said sources.

Ayush Jindal, the co-founder and an IIT-Delhi graduate (2019) has been working on autonomous robots since last two years. He is an expert in motion planning and robot navigation algorithms. Tripathi, a graduate from RGPV Bhopal, is a drone enthusiast. He has developed various drone applications ranging from search and rescue emergency response and centralised drone swarming.

It is a welcome move by the top brass of the Indian Railway which has found a way around this issue and extended the route of the Rajya Rani Express,” said Sanjay Gaikwad, a private professional who commutes between Mumbai and Purna every week.

Title: City theatres, after the last picture is shown
Content: BENGALURU: One of the things that most old Bengalureans remember with fondness is the plethora of movie theatres the city once had. These graceful old buildings, built across decades – all the way back to the 1920s - showcased a wide variety of architectural styles and played some great movies. History enthusiast Babu Ajaz is known as the Calendar Man among Bengaluru’s online history buffs. Every year, this Whitefield resident brings out an online calendar with an old Bangalore theme. This year Ajaz turned his sights on these theatres.“Many of us miss our old Bangalore and to see black and white photos of the bygone places brings both happiness and melancholy,” says Ajaz.The photographs have been mainly sourced from the Facebook group Bangalore – Photos from a Bygone Age. They include an image from the 1960s of the bygone Liberty Theatre on MG Road playing Mughal-e-Azam. There’s also the Paramount theatre, which was built in the 1920s in the City Market area. It was where the first Kannada film Sati Sulochana was screened on its release in 1934. Paramount made way for new structures a few years ago.Other photographs include the Elgin in Shivajinagar, the Opera on Brigade Road, Plaza on MG Road, Alankar on KG Road, Bharat talkies on JC Road, Central in Seshadripuram, Swastik near Majestic and Ajanta in Ulsoor.Two of the showcased movie halls that are still functional: the landmark Everest theatre in Fraser Town near the Bengaluru East railway station that screens Hindi and English movies and Sharada cinema in Nagarathpet which has been refurbished and is operational.“The photographs of the cinema halls bring in a lot of memories of younger days connected to each hall and the film that I have watched there. Those were the days when life and entertainment revolved around cinema halls in our beautiful city,” says Ravishankar Neelam, a Bengaluru cinema history enthusiast, who holds a rare collection of ticket stubs from many bygone cinema halls of the city.As for Ajaz, every year demands pour in from netizens to convert the online calendar into a hardcopy, and make it available for sale, but he isn’t interested. “My answer is simple. It is just for the viewing pleasure of old Bangalore lovers – to help them remember. I don’t plan to make it commercial,” he says.B/W photographs courtesy: Facebook/Bangalore – Photos from a Bygone Age

Title: 107 children dead so far at J K Lon where pigsroam, gadgets don’t work
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Deputy CM Sachin Pilot addresses media in Kota on Saturday.

KOTA: It struck Shubham Hada almost immediately that the ICU to which he had brought his infant of two days with a respiratory disorder had no window panes. The temperature would plummet to about 3°C at night and bring with it gusts of wind that cut through a flimsy blanket to gnaw at the bone. His baby may just have shivered to death at Kota 's JK Lon Hospital, one among the 107 children to have perished till now since the start of December 2019. The new year brought no cheer. Seven kids died within the first four days of January.

“My child was exposed to biting chill,” Hada said as he mourned with family at his Vigyan Nagar house on Saturday. A state government report has now confirmed that many of the infants died from hypothermia, an emergency condition where the body temperature falls below 95°F. The normal is 98.6°F.

On the night of January 3, it was Mohammad Vakil’s heart that turned cold. Waiting on his baby, he watched another slip on the hospital bed nearby. “The attendant realised that the oxygen cylinder was empty. He immediately alerted the nursing staff, but it was too late. The infant couldn’t survive.” The country has now suddenly woken up to the horrors of the Rajasthan hospital, but thousands of parents have seen their children die because even basic amenities and gadgets weren’t provided to doctors and nursing staff.

Alarm bells rang in 2018, too, when a social audit of the hospital revealed that 22 out of 28 nebulisers were not working. Of 111 infusion pumps, used to administer medicines to infants, 81 were non-functional. Only 6 of 20 life-support machines could be used. In short, the bulk of equipment was worthless.

In 2019, 963 infants had died in the hospital out of 16,915 admissions. In 2018, it was 1,005 from 16,436. On average, the figure has been 1,100 each year since 2014.

Doctors and nurses -- angry, helpless and often at the receiving end of attendants’ ire and frustration -- take pains to explain their struggle to bring down the mortality rate. But not only are they severely understaffed, they have appalling gadgets, much of it in disuse, to go to in times of an emergency. The infrastructure is crippling. It’s routine to tie up three babies to a bed, windows are gaping holes without glass, ventilators are dead and pigs roam around merrily. Sometimes patients are in danger of being bitten by rodents. Hygiene is as bad as it can get.

“They have now closed the holes the rats made to enter the NICU,” said Manish Kumar of Sultanpur in UP, whose baby is admitted here. He said it with great relief and obligation.

Padma, 25, lost her six-month-old son Tejas on December 23. She said she is setting aside her grief to take on the hospital for its negligence so that “no other mother should have to face” what she did. She has gone to the government demanding that she be compensated for the money she had to borrow for her baby’s treatment.

Enraged at the staff, she told TOI that their behaviour with attendants was “merciless and rude”. She recounted how guards at the NICU ward would often remark that no child would come out alive. “I had already spent close to Rs 80,000 in private hospitals before I took Tejas to JK Lon on December 22. Suffering from pneumonia , he died the next day,” she said.

The building itself offers no succour – or even hope. Dilapidated, the open wiring is old and unconcealed. Pipes leak at many places and there are dirty stains on its walls. However, hospital authorities said they are in the process of improving the facilities. "The public works department has submitted a report in which it stated that there is a requirement of Rs 1.35 crore for repairs,” said Dr Suresh Dulara, medical superintendent at the hospital. “We have forwarded it to the district collector. If we get the funds, it will help us improve things around here.”

The hospital has a total of 63 ICU beds for its paediatric and neo-natal units. The mother and child facility has 471 beds in all and caters to not only patients from Rajasthan but also from MP and UP, often the poorest who have nowhere else to go but JK Lon.

Title: Zilla parishad election results Maharashtra: Maha Vikas Aghadi wrests Beed from BJP
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Pankaja Munde

AURANGABAD: Pankaja Munde , the beleaguered former rural development minister who had lost her Parli seat in the 2019 polls, received another setback on Saturday as she lost both the zilla parishad president and vice president’s post to the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA), which was led by her estranged cousin and Cabinet minister Dhanajay Munde.

The MVA had fielded NCP’s Shivkanya Shirsath for the president’s post while Bajrang Sonwane was its vice-president nominee. The BJP fielded Yogini Thorat and Bharat Kale respectively for the president and vice-president’s posts respectively.

Sources in the NCP said that the MVA nominees received 32 votes each while the BJP candidates got 21 each. “The results might be declared on January 13, subject to the outcome of high court verdict in case of five ZP members.”

Pankaja’s younger sister and Beed MP Preetam Munde, told reporters that the BJP already had 19 members and an independent and got its president and vice-president elected earlier with the help other members, so it can’t be said that the BJP lost the numbers. She as well as BJP MLC Suresh Dhas asserted that Shiv Sena members, who earlier supported the BJP to win the ZP, couldn’t do so due to the changed in the political equation at the state-level and had to toe the MVA line.

Meanwhile, Pankaja tweeted: “It’s an impact of Aghadi in the state. Last night, the Sena has expressed its inability to come along despite their wishes. Participating in the election as a part of democratic process. Otherwise, the outcome is clear.”

Sources in the administration who conducted the poll process said that as per the high court direction, they conducted the election and would submit the outcome before the HC on January 13 in a sealed envelope. “The petition by five disqualified ZP members is pending in the high court, which would come up for hearing on January 13,” an official said on condition of anonymity.

Title: Increase psychiatry seats in medical colleges, says PIL; HC orders notice
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

TNN

Chennai: Though India has abysmal number of qualified psychiatrists, resulting in a condition where the ratio is one mental health professional for 1 lakh people, government medical colleges do not have adequate psychiatry seats at post-graduate level, said a PIL in Madras high court. One in every 20 people in India suffer from depression nearly and 1% of population in India has high suicidal risk, it said.

Citing rapid increase in mental health cases like depression, anxiety disorder and suicidal tendency among people, the PIL filed by advocate E Ranganayaki of Chennai wanted the high court to order increase in the number of student intake in psychiatry and psychology courses, and to incorporate mental health and wellness programmes like yoga in school curriculum.

A division bench of Justice M Sathyanaryanan and Justice R Hemalatha, before which the issue came up for admission on Friday, issued notice to union and state governments. The case will come up again for hearing on February 26.

In her PIL, relying on media reports, including those appeared in TOI, and surveys by Nimhans and Assocham, Renganayaki said there was a crucial need to bridge the gap between patients and mental health care professionals. There is critical need for more number of practising professionals in the field of mental health, she said, adding that in most government medical colleges the student intake is 2 to 4 in psychiatry stream.

The survey said children and adolescents are vulnerable to mental disorders in the age group 13-17 years was 7.3% and nearly equal in both genders. Nearly 9.8 million of young Indians aged between 13-17 years are in need of active interventions the petitioner said prevalence of mental disorders was nearly twice as much in urban metros as compared to rural.

Citing union ministry of home affairs report, the PIL said Tamil Nadu reported the highest number of police personnel committing suicide in the country, and added that 166 police personnel ended their lives in Tamil Nadu between 2010 and 2014, followed by 161 in Maharashtra and 61 in Kerala.

The PIL wanted authorities to create awareness about mental health among children and said including it in school curriculum will help equip students to with knowledge and skills to be aware of the disease and the skills to manage it at young age itself.

Title: Citing poor teaching, parent wants law exams deferred
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Chennai: Imagine a government law college where the post of principal is lying vacant since 2004, and physical education teacher vacancy lying unfilled since 2000. Also, of the sanctioned faculty strength of 18, only nine are available to teach students. This is Dr Ambedkar Government Law College in Puducherry for you.

The issue came to light when a student’s father moved the Madras high court to postpone the first semester examination saying the five-year LLB course students had not been taught much during the year. The examination, scheduled to commence on Monday will, however, go on as the court has refused to stay the examination. It, however, directed the authorities concerned to furnish details of the vacancy in faculty positions by January 8.

Justice P D Audikesavalu passed an interim direction to this effect on a petition filed by a Puducherry-based advocate, S Subramanian, whose son is studying first year LLB in the college.

The petition said though the first year classes commenced with a lecture on August 23, 2019, regular classes began only at the end of September. Not having enough faculty members in the college deprives students of the right to equip themselves for the semester examinations, the petition said, adding that even temporary faculty members were not available due to a low salary offered of Rs 10,000 a month.

Stating that the college has to comply with the mandatory rules of the Bar Council of India under the Advocates Act, which clearly mentions the requirement of faculty and other infrastructure , the petitioner said the college had admitted students for the academic year 2019-20 without complying with the rules.

He prayed for a direction to restrain the college from conducting the semester examinations for first year LLB students and a direction to fill the vacancies of faculty members within a time frame.

Title: Thiruvananthapuram: APJ Abdul Kalam Technological University cancels third semester BTech exam
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: APJ Abdul Kalam Technological University has cancelled a third semester BTech computer science exam, held on December 31.

The examination on ‘switching theory and logic’ was cancelled after it came to the varsity’s notice that most of the questions included in the question paper were the same ones used for the internal examination held in College of Engineering, Trivandrum recently.

“The new date for the examination will be announced later. The syndicate sub-committee on examination has been asked to look into the incident and submit a report. Strict action would be taken against those responsible for the goof up,” said university vice chancellor K M Rajasree, on Saturday.

A member of the university academic council and a senior faculty in computer science engineering have been included in the enquiry committee. The committee has been asked to submit its report in seven days.

Title: Call of the city leaves behind empty villages
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

BENGALURU: Suddenly in a burst of renewed interest, the media recently trained the spotlight on the Japanese village of Nagoro. The New York Times, The Straits Times and some websites published news features about this “abandoned village” that has no shop, school or railway station and the oldest resident is aged 50-plus. It’s nearly two decades since the last child was born there.

Yet Nagoro isn’t uninhabited in a sense. Giving company to the 30-odd human residents are over 350 life-sized dolls stuffed with cotton and straw, all located at strategic spots. Road workers taking a smoke-break, school students in a classroom, a man slouching on a couch, villagers gathered on the porch of a store, farmers working in fields are all cloth effigies, many of them resembling elders who have passed away. It all started with Tsukimi Ayano (70), a crafts hobbyist who came back from Osaka in 2002 to take care of her father. Her first doll was a scarecrow that looked like him. Over the years, given the dwindling numbers, more dolls had to be made and there are haunting images of these in Fritz Schumann’s 2014 documentary film, “Valley of Dolls”.

Tourists and visiting writers have described the ambience varyingly as creepy and charming. The dolls seem to be in a performance, their zombie eyes keeping tabs on everyone. Ayano likes to give the dolls a hint of expression: if she tugs the strings at the mouth, they smile. But sadly, not too long; they “live” only for three or four years.

Nagoro is perhaps the most glaring example of demographic crisis in Japan, but some would like to pin the blame on the allure of big cities. Isn’t it reflective of the great exodus to cities? It’s happening everywhere – from China to India to Latin America. And surely around Bengaluru and in many districts of northern Karnataka where we hear of weekdays in villages inhabited only by the old, the infirm, children and a few women.

I asked Pico Iyer, writer, novelist and Japanophile, whether he’d buy this theory. He said: “To me the main question is not one of geography so much as orientation; in other words, I’m less concerned with where humans live than with what values they live by.

“In my adopted home, Japan, more and more people are moving to the cities, but in the cities they live with a strong sense of neighbourhood and connectedness, almost as if they were still in the countryside. Japan strikes me as an urban culture guided by traditional values, very much a place wearing 21st century clothes, but sustaining 8th century souls--like an old man in a Planet Hollywood T-shirt, as I write in my Beginner’s Guide to Japan, who is up-to-the-minute, urban and cool, but no less old or Japanese for that.

Pico feels sad and wistful at the image of villages emptying out and the fact that Japan last year saw fewer than 900,000 births for the first time in its recorded history. But for him the bigger problem “which I’m sure you witness in India, is a hundred different communities all living side-by-side in Mumbai or Delhi or Bangalore, and a growing inequality between those in the high-rises and those on the streets.” He believes we’re moving towards a massive global city – not a village -- which becomes a “literal truth in the circumstances we’re witnessing”.

But there’s no stopping the migrant. “It’s hard to legislate dreaming, and in our media-connected world, every last villager across the planet can see, every moment, images of what looks to be a better life in Mumbai or New York or London. The main challenge that brings to us is that we have different kinds of neighbours and we have to think freshly about them,” he says.

In a ritualised society like Japan, where the traditional and the modern aren’t binaries, change doesn’t surprise anyone. Pico lives in the bustling suburb of Nara, south of Kyoto, where the calendar seems “still largely determined by the agricultural festivals of a village: ceremonies to greet the last harvest of the year, ceremonies to thank the gods for a good harvest, ceremonies to propitiate the gods for a good harvest next year, the lighting of the 5000 stone lanterns that lead to the shrine, and so on.” All this, he says, makes them feel, “even while living in a 1970s suburb of a pretty big city, we’re still basically around the rice-fields of centuries ago.”

Not all cultures accept contradiction as a way of life. Not everywhere are people so stoical about the impermanence of things. The Japanese, it seems, could bask in the comfort of convenience stores and acknowledge the neon winks of entertainment hubs with as much the same spirit of belief in Omikuji – paper strips of fortune tied to trees at shrines. With such equanimity, the countryside needn’t necessarily become a museum of despair.

— Jayanth Kodkani

Title: Operation Breakthrough set to go down the drain?
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kochi: Operation Breakthrough — a project to prevent waterlogging in Kochi — could be reduced to a cosmetic exercise if it does not include the remit for a drainage master plan, which will take into account the topography and other features of the city.

According to revenue officials, no funds have been earmarked for a drainage master plan. “It is learnt that there are plans for a drainage master plan under the Smart City project. So, we have not earmarked funds for the same,” said an official associated with Operation Breakthrough. “We will be focusing on cleaning drains and a couple of canals , and eviction of encroachments where it is unavoidable. We have identified contractors for 25 of the 33 works to be carried out in the first phase,” the official said. The state government has allotted Rs 10 crore for the first phase of the project, the full implementation of which is expected to cost Rs 60 crore.

Going by the website of the Cochin Smart Mission Limited (CSML), the agency to implement Smart City projects, there is no proposal to prepare a drainage master plan. Even if a new proposal is included, it won’t be easy to get it approved. As per the existing schedule, all Smart City projects will have to be awarded by January 31. It takes at least three months to prepare a detailed project report.

According to experts, Operation Breakthrough sans a drainage master plan wouldn’t serve the purpose. “Authorities should have availed the service of competent agencies or persons for preparing a master plan. If we start work on the basis of a master plan, we will be able to find lasting solutions to the waterlogging in the city,” said architect S Gopakumar, president of Better Kochi Response Group. KJ Sohan, former mayor of Kochi, echoed the view. “Without a drainage master plan, Operation Breakthrough won’t be able to do much for avoiding waterlogging in the city,” Sohan said.

As part of Operation Breakthrough, engineers and supervisors with various departments, studied different parts of the city. On the basis of site inspections, they have suggested remedies for avoiding waterlogging in each area. Unfortunately, no official from the revenue and district survey departments was part of the team. As a result, identifying encroachments and evictions on such land may prove to be a hard nut for authorities to crack.

Title: Rotegao and Lasur find place on extended route
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Rotegaon and Lasur railway stations will fall on the extended route of Rajya Rani express, which will now run from Mumbai to Nanded . While the notification issued earlier had skipped these two stations, a revised communication from the Railway Board has incorporated these two key stations. TOI had advocated the inclusion of Rotegao and Lasur stations while highlighting the demand among passengers to extend the train’s route till Nanded. The revised communication mentions mentions eight stops, including Rotegao and Lasur, which are: Purna, Parbhani, Manvat Road, Selu, Partur, Jalna and Aurangabad.

Activist Gautam Nahata credited the success of sanctioning additional stops to the different MPs and MLAs of the region along with other railway activists. “It is a good move by the railway authorities to pay heed to the demand of passengers and incorporate additional stops,” he said.

The stop at Ankai has been dropped in the revised notification. “Ankai railway station comes under Bhusaval division of the Central Railway. Located in Yeola taluka of Nashik district, it is close to the temple town of Shirdi . The revised route map of the Rajya Rani express eliminated this station as few more stations were added,” a senior SCR official said, adding that a balance had to be maintained between the number of stops and the total journey time in keeping with the existing rail traffic.

Title: Satavahana era well found in Osmanabad’s Ter
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The well, which has unique brickwork, was discovered last month during excavation work being carried out for t... Read More

AURANGABAD: A brick-lined well , believed to have been constructed during the Satavahana period, has been discovered at Ter in Osmanabad district, around 250km from here. The well, which has unique brickwork, was discovered last month during excavation work being carried out for the construction of a building, where a museum in Ter is planned to be relocated, authorities said.

“The Ramalingappa Lamature Museum in Ter is set to be shifted to another location. The state government has started constructing a new building for that and the well belonging to the Satavahana period (230BC to 200AD) was discovered during the excavation on December 14,” said Amol Gote, assistant curator of the department of archaeology.

“The well has a unique brickwork. Also, the bricks are larger when compared to those found earlier in Ter from the Satavahana period,” he said. According to archaeology department authorities, the bricks found during the excavation in Ter in the past were 40cm long, 20cm wide and 7cm thick. “But the bricks used in the construction of this well have different measurements: 45cm in length, 24cm in width and 9cm in thickness,” officials said.

After the discovery of the well, the archaeology department has demarcated the area to carry out a scientific excavation. “The arrangement of bricks in the well gives us an idea that the work was executed during the Satavahana era. The vertical and horizontal arrangements of bricks is unique here. While one layer is vertical, three others are horizontal,” authorities said.

Umesh Bagade, head of the history department at Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University, said that the bricks are vital clue in deciding the period of history of any structure. “Along with Ter, present-day Paithan in Aurangabad district and Bhokardan in Jalna district were prominent cities during the rule of Satavahana dynasty. While Paithan, then known as Pratishthan was the capital of the dynasty, Ter was also a major centre as it was on the route of international trade. The wells and rivers were the only source of water during those days and therefore the well found at Ter appears to be intact as it was built well,” he said.

The archaeology department during the excavation work carried out so far, has reached the depth of around three meters. History scholar Revansiddha Lamture, elaborating on Ter’s significance as a trade centre during the Satavahana period, said, “Commodities from different regions were brought at Ter, from where they would be sent as far as Rome via Paithan (Aurangabad) and Bharuch (Gujarat),” he said. Located around 22km from Osmanabad, Ter, which was called ‘Tagar’ in ancient times, is believed to have hosted one of the oldest civilisations in the country and was populated during the pre-Satavahana, Satavahana, post-Satavahana and Vakataka periods. Ter place, however, was at peak of its glory during the Satavahana rule.

(With inputs from PTI)

Title: Maharashtra: Praniti Shinde supporters burn Kharge’s effigy
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Praniti Shinde

KOLHAPUR: Solapur Congress workers, miffed over non-inclusion of Praniti Shinde into the state cabinet, on Friday burned the effigy of AICC general secretary Mallikarjun Kharge .

Despite not getting permission from police to carry out the protest, the workers, mostly youths, gathered at Hutatma Chowk in the morning and demanded Kharge’s removal from the party.

Youth Congress president Ambadas Kalgute blamed Kharge, who is in-charge of Maharashtra, for neglecting Praniti — daughter of senior Congress functionary and former home minister Sushilkumar Shinde.

Several Congress workers have resigned from their posts to register protest against her non-inclusion in the cabinet. The party, however, is divided into two groups over the issue.

One group feels that workers should not resign and take up the issue to the high command, while another is of the view that the high command would not pay attention without resignation.

On Wednesday, the workers staged a day-long peaceful agitation out outside the party office. They alleged that Praniti was being deliberately neglected when new comers and first time MLAs are given opportunity.

Many Congress workers are of the view that Praniti’s name was dropped at the last moment. Many workers were on their way to Mumbai to attend the swearing-in ceremony when they came to know that Praniti would not be part of the cabinet.

A youth Congress worker had written a letter with his blood to interim Congress president Sonia Gandhi to press for the demand. He had also pointed out that it is Praniti who had kept the party alive in Solapur district.

Title: World War II POW’s son make emotional trip from Milan to Bengaluru
Content: BENGALURU: The North African Campaign, fought between the Allies and Axis powers in the World War II took place between June 1940 and May 1943. It raged across Libya and Egypt, Morocco and Algeria and Tunisia. The campaigns fought across the deserts of Libya and Egypt – generally called the Desert War or the WesternDesert campaign, rank among the most famous battles of the war – with a rich cast of characters: Field Marshal Erwin Rommel, aka the Desert Fox, General Archibal Wavell - who would later become Lord Wavell, the Viceroy of India who struggled with Winston Churchill, Ettore Baldassarre, the head of Italy ’s fabled Ariete Armoured division, Field Marshal Claude Auchineck - and many others, whose stories have been told many times in many formats.But there were others - hundreds of thousands of others - normal soldiers who fought and died for their countries and their governments, each of whom had a unique and interesting story as well. One of those others was Roberto Rovellini.Italy in the WarWorld War II officially began with the German invasion of Poland on September 1, 1939. But Italy officially declared war on England and France in June 1940 - and invaded France. The campaign was called the Battle of the Alps, and it was 21-year-old Rovellini’s first major engagement. He was part of a motorised division of the ground troops and served as an army messenger - riding a motorcycle across frontiers.After the Battle of the Alps, Italy’s focus shifted to Africa. Within the week of Italy entering the war, the British seized an Italian fort in Libya. In retaliation, Mussolini ordered the Italian forces to invade Egypt – which was in British hands at the time. The young Rovellini was part of the forces sent to North Africa. Mussolini had instructed his generals to carve a path through Egypt, but the Italian army was hampered by the lack of transport and weak supporting arms. In January, 1940, the British launched their first offensive and a joint force of British and Australian troops captured the port of Tobruk. They also took close to 200,000 Italian prisoners of war (POWs) as part of the Desert war. Roberto Rovellini was one of them.Imprisoned in BangaloreRovellini was first sent to POW camp in Ceylon (Sri Lanka). From there, he was moved to another camp – this time at Hebbal, here in Bengaluru. “Nearly, 60,000 Italian including soldiers and officers, captured in war, where brought to Bangalore in 1941 and were locked up in camps here,” says Stefano Rovellini, Roberto’s son.The 65-year-old Stefano had heard stories of his father’s days as a prisoner of war in Bangalore – and made up his mind to retrace his father’s footsteps. “My father used to tell me bedtime stories of this beautiful city – he was here for six years before he was sent home,” he says.Stefano, his wife Domenica Battaglia, his daughter Giulia and son Simone arrived in Bengaluru on Wednesday for what they call an “emotional and memorable trip of a lifetime”. “It took a long series of steps and requests through the strangest channels to get here,” said Stefano.Not many people remember that India was the location for several POW camps in World War II. Thousands of captured troops were held in camps across India – in Bangalore, Dehradun, Ramgarh and Bhopal. In Bangalore alone, there were eight camps spread across what were then the outskirts of the city, mainly Hebbal and Jakkur.The ReturnRoberto Rovellini was a prisoner here till the famous Armistice of Cassibile was signed between Kingdom of Italy and Allied forces on September 3, 1943 in Sicily and made public the following week.“The treaty was a boon to many of the prisoners as the British offered limited freedom for the POWs to move around in a restricted manner as long as they were willing to cooperate with their captors. My grandfather took up the offer – and was allowed the freedom to go out of the Bangalore prison camp,” says Giulia, recalling the stories her grandfather told her.Not all prisoners accepted the amnesty, and Roberto Rovellini’s acceptance of the British offer upset many of his fellow prisoners. But there were a few others who did take it up, and the British put them to work. “My papa and many others were assigned work and he was part of the team that was involved in setting up the 515 Army Base Workshop in 1943. POWs built the place and began working there post 1943,” said Stefano whose father began repairing heavy machinery and tank engines at the city workshop which still stands on Artillery Road serving the Indian Army .Roberto Rovellini worked at the Army Base Workshop till 1946. By this time, World War II had ended, and the prisoners began returning home. Roberto got his turn in July 1946, when he was sent to Bombay to board a ship for Naples.After being reunited with his mother and his siblings in Piacenza, Roberto started refurbishing automobiles and worked as a car mechanic. He got married and had three children. “He would often talk about his time here, and he would always talk of coming back to Bangalore one day,” says Stefano.Sadly, that return never took place. Roberto passed away in 2016 – at the ripe old age of 97.The Passage to IndiaBut Stefano decided that the family would have to visit the Army Base in the city that his father had talked so often about. Last year, the Rovellini clan wrote to the Indian Consulate in Milan seeking permission to visit the Bengaluru Army Base where Rovellini senior worked. Following a series of procedures and an official interview with the consulate in Milan, the family was granted permission and liaison officers of the Indian Army were assigned to guide them. Soon after, Stefano and his family arrived in Bengaluru on New Year’s Day and visited the 515 Army Base on Thursday morning.“This visit is what we have been waiting for many years. Sadly, Roberto is not with us. But we witnessed and experienced the very places he had lived and worked. It is so overwhelming,” said Domenica, her eyes brimming. An equally emotional Stefano also took his family members to the St. Mary’s Basilica in Shivajinagar where Rovellini senior was part of the church choir along with other Italians. “He learned English in Bangalore, sang at the church and often visited the cinemas. Even though we have come here for the first time, this city brings a special feeling in us and and will be part of us for many years to come,” Stefano said.More to ComeThe Rovellini’s visit appears to be closely watched by children of other World War II veterans – and could be a precursor to more families visiting the prisons of their parents or grand parents. On the Facebook group “POW. Italians, in India, prisoners of the British”, Stefano wrote “Today was a very emotional day for me and my family...We managed to cross this gate, greeted with great courtesy by Colonel Kapir Sharma, commander of the Base, in Bangalore. Harry’s Barracks 525 Workshop Army Base was where my father Roberto spent most of his imprisonment... He worked and lived in this place with another hundred compatriots. A place that, unique among the Bangalore camps, has remained practically intact. The Commander and his staff did not know the fact that Italians contributed to giving birth to what is now a vast arsenal. We have reopened a page of history.”

Title: Kochi: Maximum width of canals set at 20.5m, from 40m earlier
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The Rs 1,365 crore project will also facilitate smooth flow of water from canals and drains in the city into t... Read More

KOCHI: When Kerala Shipping and Inland Navigation Corporation (KSINC) drew up a plan to widen and beautify five major canals in the city, National Transportation Planning and Research Centre (Natpac) was entrusted with preparation of a detailed project report. As per its report, the canals were to be widened to 40 metres for facilitating smooth navigation on them. The project was then handed over to Kochi Metro Rail Ltd (KMRL).

They entrusted a Netherlands-based agency to implement the project. “Earlier, Natpac had conducted a land acquisition survey. As per their report, the canals were to be widened to 40 metres. As per the current decision, the maximum width required for the canals is 20.5 metres. Now, we have to just validate the survey conducted by Natpac. So, we are all set to entrust chief hydrographer, Government of Kerala, to conduct a validation survey,” an official associated with the project said. “Officials with chief hydrographer’s office conducted site inspection. They will be give us the quotation for the work carried out soon,” the official said.

It was after considering the difficulties in removing encroachments that authorities decided to cut the maximum width of the canals to 20.5 metres. As of now, maximum width of major canals like Thevara-Perandoor and Edappally is around 10 metres. The Thevara-Perandoor canal is 60 metres wide at many points. Rampant encroachments have shrunk the width of the canals over the years.

Though the plan was to prepare an outline of the work by December 31, authorities couldn’t complete it. “Because of the Christmas and New Year holidays, the pace of the work dropped. Now, we will be expediting the work. We will be completing the outline in the next ten days,” sources said.

Under the project, five major canals — Edappally, Chilavannoor, Thevara-Perandoor, Thevara and Market canals — will be rejuvenated and made navigable. The Rs 1,365 crore project will also facilitate smooth flow of water from canals and drains in the city into the major canals. KMRL authorities are learned to have taken measures to rehabilitate those residing on the banks of these canals.

Title: Cancer: Artificial intelligence can make up for lack of doctors, says expert
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

(L-R) Dr Sudha Seshayyan, vice-chancellor of the Tamil Nadu Dr MGR Medical University, World Health Organisati... Read More

CHENNAI: Using artificial intelligence for diagnosis and telemedicine services for treatment along with Ayushman Bharath programme will improve cancer diagnosis and treatment outcomes in India, which is reeling under a shortage of doctors, said World Health Organisation chief scientist Dr Soumya Swaminathan .

Over the past three days, experts have been discussing how artificial intelligence is proving to be more effective in spotting breast cancer from mammograms than expert radiologists. AI outperformed specialists by detecting cancers that radiologists missed in the images and also junked features they falsely flagged as possible tumours.

“If AI can make breast screening more effective and ease the burden on health services where radiologists are in short supply, it will help systems diagnose women in early stages of the disease and improve treatment,” she said, delivering the Dr S Krishnamurthi Centenary Memorial Oration on ‘Cancer in India: Challenges and Opportunities.’ The oration was organised by the Cancer Institute, Adyar.

Breast cancer is the second most common cancer among women after cervical cancer. The incidence of breast cancer is increasing, particularly among women in urban areas of Tamil Nadu. “In the rural areas, screening of cervical cancer has substantially improved with health workers screening women with simple tests using acetic acid. Besides radiology, state can use tele-pathology for confirmation as well,” she told a hall filled with doctors, medical students and social workers.

Further, if single dose of the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine proves to be as good as two or three injections at preventing cervical cancer in the ongoing research, it may make the World Health Organization’s goal of eliminating cervical cancer easier, she said. The vaccine is now given in at least two doses, but a single dose vaccine will make it easier for countries like India.

While an Indian pharamaceutical company is in the final stages of clinically testing a HPV vaccine, research programmes in India should focus on better collection of data through cancer registries across the country and interpretation of data for stronger policies, she said. For instance, effective policies to bring down tobacco use can bring down incidence of cancer substantially. Now, tobacco use is considered the leading risk factor for cancers in India, besides dietary factors, alcohol, air pollution and obesity. “Though we have a robust cancer registry, there is no data coming from states like Bihar and Uttar Pradesh,” said.

She further added that the Centre’s promise to invest more money in research should be directed to understand the genetic and environmental determinants of cancer.

Title: 4 VNIT students among 7 probable city CAT toppers
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kaustabh Chatterjee (L), Shuvendu Ranabijuli (R)

NAGPUR: Four VNIT students are among the seven probable city toppers in Common Admission Test ( CAT ) held primarily for entry to Indian Institute of Managements (IIMs) and other premier B-schools.

Sushant Thombre (VNIT) emerged first with a percentile of 99.99 followed by Sri Ram Mahalingam (VNIT) at 99.97, Yash Gupta (BITS, Pilani) at 99.57, Shuvendu Ranabijuli (VNIT) at 99.54, Kaustabh Chatterjee (VNIT) at 99.44, Pranay Gupta at 99.36 and Vedant Vyas (both RCOEM) at 99.26.

Mehul Zunzunwala, who runs a well-known CAT coaching institute in the city, cautioned students to be careful while selecting mentors at this stage. “The level of competition will increase significantly now as the best will be competing against better than the best ones,” he said.

He said students will now be assessed in various areas like essay-writing, group discussions, group exercise, case studies and personal interviews based on the B-school.

Zunzunwala has planned a month long training to ensure that all students who have got calls get a final selection in the IIMs and top B schools.

Title: Mumbai: Drunk cop ‘loses’ 30 bullets, sends officers on 5-hour hunt
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: After an assistant sub-inspector (ASI) attached to the Local Arms (LA) misplaced a loaded magazine with 30 bullets in Bandra on January 3, officers from the Khar and Bandra police station went on a five-hour hunt till they found them.

After misplacing the 30 live rounds at a bus depot near Taj Lands End in Bandra (west), ASI Rajan Dhule rushed to the Bandra police station around 9.45pm to report that his bag containing the weapons had been stolen. Dhule was on protection duty for Bhai Jagtap, or MLC Ashok Arjunrao, at his Carter Road residence, when the incident occurred.

Dhule told the Bandra police that he did not have a clear picture on how the bag was stolen and where it happened. Assistant commissioner of police Dattatray Bhargude and senior inspector Vijaylaxmi Hiremath, supervised by deputy commissioner of police (IX) Paramjit Singh Dahiya, led a team of officers who went on a search for the bag. Five hours later, around 2am on January 4, the bullets were found at the Bandra bus depot near Taj Lands End.

According to the Bandra police, Dhule was under the influence of alcohol while on duty. They have sent a default report to the commissionerate, for further action. “He was sent for protection duty on Friday. On finding that the MLC and his family were not at home, he left and went drinking. He has been sent on protection duty twice before as well,” said a police officer.

“On receiving his complaint about the stolen bag, teams searched locations around Shah Rukh Khan’s bungalow on Carter Road. There was no sign of the bag. So the team checked CCTV camera footage and found Dhule walking on the road towards Taj Lands End. He sat the bus depot with the bag for a while, but when he left, he did not take the bag with him,” said the police.

Before reporting to MLC Jagtap’s residence, ASI Dhule had collected the firearms and arrived at the Bandra police station around 4.55pm on Friday.

When contacted, Bhai Jagtap told TOI to get in touch with the Bandra police to get a clear picture of the incident, as he was in Vadodara at that time.

Deputy commissioner Dahiya confirmed the incident, but refused to divulge details. He said that a diary entry of the same was made at the police station, and that a report would be sent to the concerned department at the commissionerate, who will decide on the further course of action.

A departmental inquiry into Dhule’s actions has been initiated, and will be completed before an action to suspend him can be taken.

City police spokesperson deputy commissioner Pranay Ashok said that he wosuld have to check the details about the incident and whether any action was taken against Dhule.
