Title: Experts call for liberal policy to boost city’s fledgling IT sector
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: While speculation continues over Vizag becoming the executive capital of the state, experts feel a liberal information technology policy is the need of the hour to attract investments to the City of Destiny.

“Many states have IT policies which offer huge incentives to investors. We need a similar policy to ensure that the city’s IT sector, which is still in a fledgling stage, gets a timely boost and is ready to cope with the pressure of being the state’s executive capital,” says Naresh Kumar, vice-president of Rushikonda IT Park in the city.

A booming IT sector would encourage investors to come to Visakhapatnam, he said. “It would also improve international and domestic connectivity to the city. There would be more skilled labour and more training institutions will come up. Supporting facilities like hotels, residential complexes and intra-city communication too would develop to a great extent,” he added.

Though it’s been more than a decade since the setting up of the IT hub in Rushikonda, big companies are reluctant to set base there due to lack of supporting facilities. “The Rushikonda layout was developed 25 years ago while the dedicated IT hub was created about 12 years ago. There are a few restaurants and a medicine stall in this hub. If the city becomes the executive capital, these issues need to be sorted out first,” said K Murali, a senior IT professional from the city.

Another issue that needs to be taken into account is traffic congestion, which will increase manifold once the city becomes the capital. But experts feel those issues can be addressed at a later stage. “The government first needs to roll out a comprehensive IT policy that will help attract investments. Look at Delhi. It is the national capital. The country’s top offices are based there, including the Supreme Court. If just being the capital was the yardstick to attract investments, then all investments in the country would have gone there. But that’s not the case,” added Naresh Kumar, who is also the president of Vizag Development Corporation.

Meanwhile, though a final call on the capital issue is yet to be taken, speculations have already begun about the places where the temporary offices would be established. Ch Srinivas, vice-president of Credai’s Visakhapatnam chapter, is confident that it’s just a matter of time before Vizag is declared the executive capital. “We are sure it would be announced shortly. It will likely be built in Kapuluppada in the northern part of the city, where plenty of land is available. The area is close to the city and is also in close proximity to the proposed Bhogapuram airport,” he predicted.

There are also talks that the temporary secretariat will come up near Satyam junction. However, water shortage could pose a problem there.

“This is where the Polavaram project will play a key role. The city will require water not just for industrial purpose but to cater to the growing population once the capital call is taken,” said B V Radhakrishna, former minor irrigation advisor to the erstwhile government of united AP.

Title: GVMC takes steps to sort out traffic
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: In the wake of the executive capital proposal, the city’s civic body seems to have gone on an overdrive to take up proposals to widen roads and main junctions and translating them into action.

The Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) has identified four intersections to be developed in the city and is also planning four flyovers. The aim of these projects is to ease traffic congestions on major junctions.

According to sources, projects worth Rs 800 crore are being planned. The GVMC, in association with the city police has identified four main junctions in the city which suffer from traffic jams regularly.

Talking about the projects in the pipeline, GVMC commissioner G Srijana said, “We have long-term plans for the city with an estimated budget of Rs 15,000 crore. Of which, Rs 500 crore worth of works has been initiated. Detailed Project Reports (DPRs) are ready for some of the projects.”

As per the proposals, four flyovers are being planned at four intersections across NH-16, which passes through Hanumanthawaka Junction, Carshed Junction, Maddilapalem Junction and Gajuwaka Junction. Moreover, there are plans to widen major arterial roads in Dwarakanagar and the Srikanya Theatre area.

Title: Sports body scouting for office space
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The promise of Vizag becoming the executive capital having gained momentum, the Sports Authority of Andhra Pradesh (SAAP) is scouting locations for its administrative building. The state’s sports authority is reportedly looking for space in and around the GVMC’s Swarna Bharati Indoor Stadium near Maddilapalem.

The SAAP administration was shifted from Hyderabad to Vijayawada in October, 2016 following bifurcation. Since then, the SAAP administration was being carried out from the Indira Priyadarshini Municipal Stadium.

According to sources, the SAAP head office will be shifted to Vizag if the city indeed becomes the executive capital. “SAAP may take over the Swarna Bharati stadium,” said a senior SAAP employee. However, vice-chairman K Bhaskar maintained that no communication regarding executive capital has been received till date.

Title: SS update: City tops in citizens’ feedback
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) has come out first in the country in collecting citizens’ feedback for the on-going Swachh Survekshan 2020 as of Saturday.

Other cities from Andhra Pradesh which feature in the top 10 are Tenali, Tirupati and Palamaneru.

On the other hand, Vizag stands at the seventh place in overall rankings as per the Swachh Survekshan Josh Tracker as of Saturday.

Citizen feedback constitutes a key part of the survey as it has a 25% weightage (1500 marks) in the 6000-mark survey.

Citizens can still share their feedback through the Swachhata helpline number: 1969, the Swachhata App, the Swachh Survekshan 2020 portal, outbound calls and the Vote for Your City App from January 4.

Citizens can provide feedback on seven parameters such as conditions of public or community toilets, cleanliness of public or commercial areas, waste segregation and awareness of Swachh Survekshan.

Apart from public feedback on the seven questions, the number of active users on Swachhata App or Swachh Manch/local App (integrated with Swachhata App) will also be measured to award marks under the citizen feedback component.

The other aspects that will be considered include the percentage of complaints resolved within the service-level agreement time-frame and user feedback on resolved complaints.

Swachh Survekshan teams are likely to visit the city between January 4 and January 31 to take direct feedback from citizens as well as for direct observation of the city’s sanitation and cleanliness levels.

Title: Does city have enough water to host executive capital?
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: If Vizag were to really become the executive capital of Andhra Pradesh, one of the most significant problems will be that of water. Experts believe that Vizag does not have adequate water resources to cater to large-scale immigration.

Experts are of the opinion that even when the Polavaram project is completed and water released, there would still be a considerable deficit, considering the requirement in terms of industrial commitments made.

Former civil servant EAS Sarma said, “We simply do not have water to host the executive capital. We will not have enough even after the completion of Polavaram.”

“If the Polavaram project is completed by 2021, around 1,137 MLD of water will be available, while the requirement will be 1,751MLD. This means, there will be a deficit of 614MLD per day with Polavaram. Without Polavaram, there will be a deficit of 1,424MLD water per day,” Sarma, who is now the convenor of Forum for Greater Visakha said.

Meanwhile, BV Radhakrishna, an irrigation expert said that while the executive capital idea is welcome, the issues concerning water supply to Visakhapatnam and Vizianagaram need to be addressed.

Radhakrishna said, “The previous government has committed 60TMC Godavari water to the Krishna delta by constructing the Pattiseema lift irrigation project. This has resulted in the Polavaram project getting truncated, which was supposed to supply water to dry areas in Vizianagaram for irrigation. But the canal stops in Vizag.” He added that the state government must ensure adequate supply of water by implementing the Sujala Sravanthi in Vizianagaram and dry parts of Visakhapatnam.

The irrigation expert added that it is unfortunate that the two main rivers which feed the Godavari— Sabari and Sileru originate in the Andhra-Odisha Border area in north-coastal AP but the region is denied of its water.

Title: Sustained cold spell may hamper mango yield, farmers worried
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Farmers of north-coastal Andhra Pradesh are worried that the low temperatures across the region could affect the mango crop. With day and night temperatures hovering between 15°C and 21°C, farmers are keeping their fingers crossed.

The sharp dip in temperatures, say farmers, could hamper the flowering of mango in the plains of Visakhapatnam. Mango is the main horticulture crop and is grown across 20,000 hectares land in the district.

The yield was poor last year too, owing to drought-like conditions. This year, if the low temperatures sustain for much longer, it could hamper the flowering in mango trees which is supposed to happen around this time. R Srinivasa Rao, deputy director of horticulture, Vizianagaram said, “The problem is not so much with the cold weather, but with mango hoppers (a pest) which thrive in cold weather conditions and cause a drop in flowering.”

Assistant director of horticulture K Sailaja said, “The flowering happens during winter. But pests manage to damage flowers in case of a long and sustained cold spell.”

Farmers point out that mango plantations have come down in Visakhapatnam and Vizianagaram over the last few years owing to the dry spell between 2017 and 2019. Now the cold spell has become a major cause of concern, they say.

Title: Erra Matti Dibbalu in dire need of protection
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Year after year, the same saga of neglect of ‘nobody’s property’ continues. Declared as a scientifically significant geo-heritage site by the Geological Survey of India (GSI) in July 2014, Vizag’s Erra Matti Dibbalu (Red Sand hills) near Bheemili, is still lying amidst litter in sheer neglect.

Without even a signage, fencing or gate, the place is filled with garbage left behind by picnickers and revellers. Garbage is also strewn all along the Vizag-Bheemili road bordering the Red Sand hills. At times, hue and cry is raised by heritage activists to stall attempts of illegal construction at the rare geological formation site. However, there is still no proper committee or government body to safeguard the site that is in utter need of protection.

Heritage narrators and activist couple Jayshree Hatangadi and Sohan Hatangadi, who visited the site recently, plan to hold a clean-up drive with India Youth for Society (IYFS) volunteers this Sunday (January 5) from 6.30 am to 11 am.

“For the clean-up drive, volunteers from Indian Navy’s INS Kalinga and JCI organization will also collaborate. However, it’s not a permanent solution. The 2km by 4km site needs wire fencing, gate, signage and a protection committee to check littering and entry of drinking public. As of now, there is no clarity as to who is responsible for maintaining the site,” rued Sohan.

The rare marine geological formation near Bheemili, dating back to the Holocene period (approximately 12,000 years) is one of three such heritage geological sites existing in South-East Asia (besides the ones in Tamil Nadu and Sri Lanka). These geo-morphological formations, consisting of a mixture of sand (40-50%), silt and clay (another 50%) were formed when ancient sand moulds were blown from the beach to the land. They indicate sea level oscillations and the extent to which the sea level has receded from the land.

“For over a decade, local administration like GVMC and VMRDA and the state tourism department have not been able to get their act together to save and promote Erra Matti Dibbalu. Even though it was declared a significant geological site by the GSI, and seminars, meetings and rallies were held for its protection, it continues to be treated just as badly as ever with callous public littering and destroying the site,” said Jayshree.

Title: Now, GVMC area to be reorganised into 98 wards
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The area under GVMC (Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation) is going to be reorganised into 98 wards. The number of wards will increase to 98 from 81 earlier.

According to a government order issued on Friday, cities that have a population of over 15 lakh shall have 90 elected members in local bodies. For every 50,000 people over and above 15 lakh, the number of elected members will increase by one. “There shall be one additional elected member for a fraction of more than 25,000 people,” read the order.

After the five Bheemili villages with a population of 19,000 were merged into GVMC a few days ago, the city’s population increased to 19 lakh. Therefore, according to government guidelines, the city will have a total of 98 wards.

Nine new wards were carved out in Vizag in 2017, increasing the number of wards from 72 to 81. As per the 2011 census, the city has a population of 18.81 lakh.

The number of wards was fixed on the basis of prevailing norms of having 63 wards for the first 10 lakh population and 18 wards (one ward for about 50,000 people) for the remaining 8.81 lakh people, totalling 81 wards.

Later, the GVMC conducted a reorganisation process for the 81 wards and sent a report to the state government. Now, the GVMC has to initiate the delimitation process again. GVMC chief city planner AJ Vidyullatha said that the civic body will reorganise the wards on the basis of new guidelines from the state government. “We will also address issues related to geographical precincts of the wards in due process,” said Vidyullatha.

Title: Sanjay Raut to Muslims: We’ll push Amit Shah out
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Sanjay Raut

MUMBAI: Shiv Sena politician and Saamna editor Sanjay Raut said on Saturday that the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) should be opposed because it is against Hindus too and 30% Hindus will suffer when it is clubbed with the National Register of Citizens (NRC).

Speaking at a symposium held by Jamaat-e-Islami Hind (JIH) at Marathi Patrakar Sangh, Raut tried to allay fears among Muslims about the CAA, the NPR and the NRC. Using the popular Bollywood dialogue “Jo dar gaya so mar gaya”, Raut told the predominantly Muslim audience to get out of the fear syndrome. “We in Maharashtra just showed that we don’t fear anyone. We want you too to get out of fear,” he said.

Referring to Shiv Sena founder Balasaheb Thackeray, Raut said he would often say that the country belonged to all. “We all are one and this country belongs to every Indian who is loyal to the country,” he said.

Without naming Union home minister Amit Shah , who declared on Friday that he would not budge an inch on CAA, Raut said: “Aap kahte ho ek inch bhi nahin hathenge. Hum dhakka dekar hata denge (You say you will not budge an inch. We will push you out).” He said many in the media wondered if he would really attend a function held by the Jamaat-e-Islami. He said he had no problem attending the event as “we all are brothers and the programme is being held at Marathi Patrakar Sangh”.

Opposing a call by Justice (retired) Kolse Patil to “25 crore Muslims” to come on the streets against the CAA, NPR and NRC, Raut said people must not get divided in numbers.

Senior counsel Mihir Desai and Yusuf Muchchala discussed how the CAA was against the spirit of the constitution as it “discriminated” among citizens in the name of religion and after it is followed by NPR and NRC, all Indians will suffer.

Title: Mumbai’s first Ro-Ro to arrive from Greece on January 28
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

MUMBAI: The city’s first ship to carry passengers with their cars and buses (used for RoRo or roll-on-roll-off services) to Alibaug, Mandwa and other destinations across the harbour is arriving from Greece by January 28, subject to weather conditions.

The operations are expected to start before March. As per Greek Shipping Authority, the passenger Capacity of the ship is 1,000 during fair weather and 500 during four weather conditions, said MbPT chairman Sanjay Bhatia.

The ship can carry up to 200 cars in all weather conditions. Thus a Mumbaikar’s road trip to Alibaug by car which currently takes up to 3 hours, will soon take up to an hour from March.

The move will not only reduce traffic jams but also reduce pollution by saving fuel.

Title: Delhi Metro’s Blue Line to be extended in Ghaziabad till Mohan Nagar
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

304 trees need to be cut for Blue Line extension in Gzb

GHAZIABAD: The Dwarka-Vaishali Blue Line is on its way to becoming the Dwarka-Mohan Nagar Blue Line, adding 5km and four new stations to Delhi Metro ’s second-longest corridor.DMRC on Saturday submitted the detailed project report for the long-awaited extension of the Ghaziabad section of the Blue Line, which will see it converge with the Red Line at Mohan Nagar. The report pegs the construction cost of the project at Rs 1,808 crore, of which 74% will be borne by the UP government and 18% by the central government. Unlike in the Dilshad Garden-New Bus Adda metro project, DMRC will not contribute anything in the form of rolling stock in this project.The land requirement for the three new stations on the route — Prahlad Garhi, Vasundhara Sector 14 and Sahibabad — and for the elevated alignment will be 86,857 sq m.The land requirement for the three new stations and for the elevated alignment will be 86,857 sq m, which will also include private land that Ghaziabad Development Authority (GDA) will have to acquire. “There are a total of 304 trees that are coming in the way of the corridor and are required to be cut,” said VN Singh, chief engineer of GDA.According to the DPR, Sahibabad station will in future also serve as a major future transit hub as an RRTS (rapid rail) station will come up under the proposed Electronic City-Sahibabad corridor. Mohan Nagar already has a Red Line station on the Dilshad Garden-New Bus Adda line, which was made operational in March 2019, officials said. The Pink Line, metro’s longest, stretches 58.59km, though it’s currently a fragmented corridor.DMRC has set April 2020 as the likely commencement date of the project and hopes to complete it in April 2024. Though an approval from the UP government is a formality, raising money for the corridor is a concern for GDA, which has sought financial assistance from the state government.“As per the DPR, the project will take four years to complete,” said GDA chief engineer Singh. The DMRC has shared the funding pattern in the DPR. “Of Rs 1808.22 cr project cost, the Centre’s contribution has been pegged at Rs 210.67 crore while the state government will have to bear the remaining cost,” said Singh

Title: DMK to review local body results after assembly session
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The exercise will be carried out by senior leaders headed by party president M K Stalin.

CHENNAI: The DMK is all set to review its performance in the just-concluded rural local body polls. More importantly, the party wants to do an introspection to figure out what led to the defeat of the alliance in many seats considered sure-shot bastions going by the performance in earlier polls.

The exercise will be carried out by senior leaders headed by party president M K Stalin. “It will start after the coming assembly session. We will summon the party secretaries in districts where the party has fared badly,” said a senior DMK leader.

The differences with its ally Congress and the decision of the latter to go it alone cost the DMK dearly in Kanyakumari district. The AIADMK did not win even a single seat in Kanyakumari district in the 2016 assembly elections and it had lost deposit in Vilavancode assembly segment. But the ruling party made a comeback by securing 4 out of 11 district panchayat councillor seats and 16 out of 111 panchayat union councillor seats. Its ally BJP won 2 district panchayat seats and 31 PU council seats. The Congress, which snapped the alliance in Kanyakumari East district, won 5 district panchayat council seats, but the DMK came a cropper. However, the DMK won 21 and Congress 24 panchayat union council seats.

Another shocker was Tuticorin. In the hotbed of Sterlite protests, where DMK’s Kanimozhi swept the Lok Sabha polls, the principal opposition party could win only 5 out of 17 district panchayat seats. The party got only 61 panchayat union seats vis-à-vis AIADMK’s 63. “We are concerned about loss of ground in the fishermen belt, especially in Tuticorin district. Problems in seat-sharing cost us dear in Kanyakumari district. We should have swept the polls if the DMK and Congress had stayed together in Kanyakumari. A meeting of senior leaders will analyse the results,” said the leader.

Similarly, in Dharmapuri and Theni districts too, the party has fared poorly compared to its performance in the recent LS polls.

The DMK has captured Pudukottai district, including Viralimalai, state health minister C Vijaya Baskar’s constituency. “People in Pudukottai were unhappy with the ruling party leaders. It was evident during the campaign itself,” said the DMK leader.

Title: DMK to review local body results after assembly session
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

The exercise will be carried out by senior leaders headed by party president M K Stalin.

CHENNAI: The DMK is all set to review its performance in the just-concluded rural local body polls. More importantly, the party wants to do an introspection to figure out what led to the defeat of the alliance in many seats considered sure-shot bastions going by the performance in earlier polls.

The exercise will be carried out by senior leaders headed by party president M K Stalin. “It will start after the coming assembly session. We will summon the party secretaries in districts where the party has fared badly,” said a senior DMK leader.

The differences with its ally Congress and the decision of the latter to go it alone cost the DMK dearly in Kanyakumari district. The AIADMK did not win even a single seat in Kanyakumari district in the 2016 assembly elections and it had lost deposit in Vilavancode assembly segment. But the ruling party made a comeback by securing 4 out of 11 district panchayat councillor seats and 16 out of 111 panchayat union councillor seats. Its ally BJP won 2 district panchayat seats and 31 PU council seats. The Congress, which snapped the alliance in Kanyakumari East district, won 5 district panchayat council seats, but the DMK came a cropper. Title: Shilas may come out of closet for Ram temple
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Two worshipped stones (pujit shilas) locked in Faizabad district treasury during then PM Vajpayee’s stint at t... Read More

AYODHYA: Two worshipped stones ( pujit shilas ) locked in Faizabad district treasury during then PM Vajpayee’s stint at the Centre may finally be taken out of the closet after 18 years for the Ram temple, mandated by the Supreme Court verdict. The shilas were ritually worshipped by the two flagbearers of the temple movement, Ashok Singhal and Mahant Ramchandra Das Paramhans, both of whom have passed away.

The twin stone columns or ‘pujit shilas’ as termed by Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP), were deposited in Faizabad district treasury by then Atal Bihari Vajpayee government after the administration imposed curbs on VHP’s ‘shiladaan’ (stone donation) ceremony organised in March 2002, following Supreme Court’s directive for status quo at the disputed site.

Then president of Ram Janmabhoomi Nyas Ramchandra Das Paramhans and then working president of VHP Ashok Singhal worshipped the stones and performed ‘shila daan’ for temple construction. While Paramhans died in August 2003 at the age of 90, Singhal passed away in November 2015 at 89.

Now that the Supreme Court has cleared decks for temple construction in Ayodhya , the two ‘shilas’, 5-foot long and 2-foot wide, are likely to be taken out of the closet after the temple trust is constituted. VHP is likely to take a decision on the fate of the ‘pujit shilas’ at its Kendriya Margdarshak Mandal meeting during the upcoming Magh Mela in Allahabad.

Talking to TOI, next friend of Ram Lalla Triloki Nath Pandey said, “As a tribute to these two great leaders, the stones must be released from government treasury and used in the construction of Ram Mandir.” Central secretary of VHP Purushottam Narain Singh said the upcoming trust would take a decision on ‘shilas’.

Former president of VHP Praveen Togadia said, “All ‘pujit shilas’ donated by people, including the ones kept in Faizabad treasury, should be used in temple construction.”

Title: Makar Sankranti: #GoFlyAKite: A dummy’s guide to hosting the perfect patang party this Makar Sankranti
Content: Kites, food, music and masti — sums up the perfect patang party, doesn’t it? And with Makar Sankranti just ’round the corner, many a Hyderabadi peeps are already gearing up to throw their big, fat annual patang party.After all what’s Sankranti without a fun day of kite flying with friends and family, binging on some yummy goodies and dancing to some peppy beats? Haven’t gotten around planning yours yet? Worry not, we’ve got your back. Here’s all the ideas you need to throw a fun-filled patang party that your gang will remember for the whole year to come...The best part about a patang party is you can dress up or dress down, as long as comfort is the keyword. For an uber insta worthy party album, you could go for a common colour scheme as the dress code. Think whites paired with blue denims. Else, pick a broader theme — such as shuddh desi — and let your guests decide what they want to wear. Dress comfortably in a way that will not hinder your fun activities and dance/ kite flying movements.weet pongal, boorelu, paramannam, ariselu — Sankranti snacks are aplenty in every Telugu household. If yours still makes these from scratch, your guests are a lucky lot. If not, get some from the market. The roof top buffet spread should have lots of fuss-free finger foods and mason jars filled with refreshing drinks to keep guests fuelled up.There is no party without music and you’ve definitely gotta amp up the boom box to churn out some Bollywood numbers to get the party going. Some of our favourites would be, Udi Udi Jaaye (Raees), Manja (Kai-Po Che) Dheel De De (Hum Dil De Chuke Sanam), which are perfect patang numbers.Peppy Telugu beats, remixes of retro hits and even the odd club hits are must-haves on the playlist.As most patang parties are held on the terrace, the décor could be minimal yet traditional — think marigolds and mango leaf thorans with funky elements like a bedecked rickshaw, or a giant kite... A pretty shamiyana would be perfect for those who want to chill in the shade while the others are screaming ‘affffaaaa’. a picture booth, where guests can take goofy pictures with props, could be a fun addition!The Chinese manjas are razor sharp and a great eco hazard. The thread is made of nylon, plastic or other synthetic materials, laced with glass, metal and other sharp objects which could be extremely dangerous both for you and your guests. What’s more, they kill and maime hapless birds, which get entangled on the loose threads hanging on trees and poles. This kite season, don’t leave any stray manja hanging around!sustainable celebrations are the need of the hour. It’s best to opt for paper kites for your parties — they are classic and colourful. plastic patangs are a big ‘no’.While flying kites or dancing, be careful and mindful that you are on the rooftop. If alcohol is served, or if children are around, make sure someone’s keeping an eye on all the guests. Guard against injuries from sharp threads too. stay sun safe by donning hats, sunglasses and sunscreen. And, always keep afirst-aid box handy.

Title: When Rohit Sharma and Ritika meditated with Daaji in Hyderabad
Content: India’s opening batsman, Rohit Sharma was in Hyderabad on Friday with his wife, Ritika Sajdeh, to visit a meditation centre in Chegur. Rohit laid the foundation stone for an international cricket stadium and training centre which will be named after him.Raja yoga master, Kamlesh Patel , popularly known as Daaji, was delighted to have Rohit Sharma with him and also conducted a special ‘ heartfulness meditation ’ session for the couple. “Rohit Sharma is a great example of what the human mind is capable of doing when it becomes focussed. I am delighted that Rohit meditated with us. this should inspire many more to turn to meditation as a way of life,” said Daaji.Rohit too seemed equally happy. “My experience with meditation was amazing. I was quiet for a long time after that. I want to get some of my teammates to this pristine place someday,” said Rohit. The ‘Hitman’ was spotted taking in the lush green ambience as he went for a long walk around the centre.

Title: Bus mows down Jalpaiguri girl
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Jalpaiguri: A Class XII student was run over by a North Bengal State Transport Corporation bus in Jalpaiguri, leading to violent protests by locals on Saturday morning. Three government buses were set ablaze.

Trisha Chakraborty (17) was headed for tuition, riding pillion on a scooty with her brother. They encountered traffic congestion at Mohit Nagar due to a rail gate being closed on NH 31D. Here, a Siliguri-bound NBSTC bus hit the scooty head-on. Both were knocked off the vehicle; Trisha was run over and died on the spot. She was to take the HS exams this year.

Title: West Bengal: Two injured as entrance of Burdwan rail station collapses, search operations on
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

A chunk of the main entrance that was being repaired caved in at Burdwan railway station on Saturday

By: Md Asif

BURDWAN: A portion of the main entrance of Burdwan railway station collapsed on Saturday evening, injuring two persons. One of them is critical. Though there were no reports of any deaths till 10pm, an operation was underway to remove the rubble and ensure that no one was trapped beneath it.

According to an eyewitness, a chunk of the building’s facade that was being repaired fell around 7.50pm, triggering panic among passengers, hawkers, vendors and visitors as it is usually a very bustling section of the station complex. As people started running helter-skelter, bigger chunks fell off.

A big crowd had gathered at the spot and was taking photographs of the building with their cellphones when the entire section came crashing down like a pack of cards. The large neon signboard reading ‘Eastern Railway’ on the building’s terrace was reduced to just ‘Eastern’ within seconds.

Luckily, the time lapse between when the first chunk fell and the final portion collapsed allowed people to disperse to safety. The section that came down housed an inquiry office and the facade over the retiring room.

Also, fortunately, no local or major express train was running shortly before or after the incident. A civil defence team arrived around 9.30pm and began clearing the debris to check if anyone was trapped. Police personnel rushed to the spot to assist in search operations, and also to contain the huge crowd.

Two persons have been admitted to Burdwan Medical College & Hospital. One of them was identified as Hopna Tudu, a resident of Jharkhand. Tudu, who received an injury on his right leg, had come to see off his daughter.

“Train movement was normal as none of the platforms was affected due to the incident. We immediately opened an alternative entrance to the station for the convenience of passengers,” said Nikhil Chakraborty, CPRO, Eastern Railway.

“We have ordered an inquiry into the incident. Whether or not there was any lacunae in the maintenance will be ascertained thereafter. Our priority is to rescue and treat the injured,” he said.

Title: Kolkata priests in cassocks to march against CAA
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kolkata: Priests from the Kolkata Diocese of the Church of North India (CNI) will hit the streets in their white cassocks on January 20 to protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act and National Register of Citizens.

The Roman Catholic Church under the Archdiocese of Calcutta organised a similar walk on December 26 after the Christmas celebrations (though the clergy had not joined in then). Both the walks — the post-Christmas one and the one planned for January 20 — follow several heads of churches including “anti-discrimination and anti-CAA” messages in their Christmas sermons (reported by TOI on December 26).

Clergy from suburbs, including the Barrackpore Diocese, will join in the January 20 march, singing hymns in English and Bengali highlighting how Jesus “never supported divisive acts” and had urged Christians to stand united during crises. This protest walk will start from St Paul’s Cathedral and end at Mahatma Gandhi’s statue in the Maidan.

Kolkata Bishop Paritosh Canning expects the entire clergy to turn up at the march along with principals of schools that are under the administration of the diocese.

Principals have already received the proposal from the bishop and expressed their solidarity with the cause.

“It will be a very Christian thing to do... to walk peacefully, protesting against division. The country is being divided in the name of religion..., which negates the secular fabric of India,” Angela Ghosh, principal of the new campus of Scottish Church Collegiate School, said.

The bishop’s office said Canning decided to convene the march because he felt it was time for one minority community to stand by another when efforts were on to drive a wedge in society in the name of religion.

The CNI has also invited three other prominent Protestant churches not within its fold — the Methodist Church, the Baptist Church and the Assembly of God Church — to participate in the walk. Invitations have also been sent to the Roman Catholic Church.

Representatives of the clergy will submit memorandums to Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee and governor Jagdeep Dhankhar after the end of the march; copies will be sent to PM Narendra Modi and president Ram Nath Kovind.

“This is the first time that the CNI, under the bishop’s leadership, has convened an anti-CAA protest. He will lead the walk and the entire body of the clergy will walk with him. It is going to be a massive affair,” CNI Kolkata Diocese secretary John Ghosh said.

Title: MLA on dais with Dilip, TMC asks him to show cause
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Egra (West Midnapore): Trinamool Congress has asked its MLA from Egra to show cause why he shared a dais with Bengal BJP president and Midnapore MP Dilip Ghosh at the inauguration of Egra Mela on Friday.

TMC MLA Samaresh Das was present at the programme along with the Midnapore Municipality chairman.

The MLA not only attended the programme but spoke and referred to the atithi deva bhaba (guest is God) tradition while Ghosh sat on the dais.

“I won’t talk politics. I have never come across the courtesy shown to me today,” Ghosh said on Friday. District Trinamool leaders wondered how an MLA could share a dais with Ghosh when Trinamool chief Mamata Banerjee has crossed swords with BJP over the CAA-NRC issue.

Das was taken aback at the turn of events. “I had gone to the inauguration of Egra Mela, a traditional fair being held for the last 34 years. It was not a political platform. Neither I nor the BJP leader spoke about politics. I am told the party has showcaused me. I will definitely send my reply,” the MLA said.

Ghosh said: “It shows how intolerant Trinamool can be. They don’t have the courtesy to greet others. Worse, they crack the whip on their MLA for showing courtesy.”

Title: Shraddha Kapoor: Shraddha to play a prostitute in an upcoming family drama
Content: Actress Shraddha Das, who’s been trending on social media thanks to her bikini pictures from her recent vacation to Bali, will soon be doing a full-fledged Telugu film after three years. We have learnt that the actress will be playing the role of a prostitute in choreographer-turned-director Vidyasagar’s upcoming family drama. “Shraddha plays Jagapati Babu’s love interest in the film. Jagapati Babu plays an industrialist who heads a huge company that manufactures condoms. He hires prostitutes to feature in all the commercials for his products, which is when he meets Shraddha, and the duo gradually fall in love,” reveals a source.The film, that is set to go on floors on Sunday, is a family drama set in an urban backdrop. “Shraddha will be seen in the flashback portions of the film. Her character is vital to the plot and is instrumental in a key twist that takes place. Although, she plays a prostitute, she will be portrayed as an emotional girl and will be shown donning Indian attire,” shares the source. Shraddha’s last Telugu film was PSV Garuda Vega in 2017. She was since seen in a cameo role in the Karthikeya-starrer Hippi last year. “Shraddha wasn’t happy with the kind of offers that were coming her way in Telugu cinema and hence, she took up offers in Bengali and Kannada cinema. She has been waiting for something substantial to come her way in Tollywood, which has finally arrived,” adds the source.

Title: Processed venom seized in Malda
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Malda: Around 1kg of snake venom was seized from a hotel at English Bazar on Friday evening and three persons were arrested. Unlike previous seizures, the venom had been processed, which has led officers to suspect the presence of a laboratory around these parts.

A team of six personnel from the Malda police crime monitoring cell visited a hotel posing as customers. There, the team seized a crystal jar containing about 1kg venom.

The three accused are from Kaliachak — Rafik Ali and Asique Mandal of Bamantola village and Masud Sk of Akandabaria village. The trio was produced in court and taken into police custody on Saturday.

A forest official said: “We suspect the seized jar contains cobra venom, which has a high demand in markets, especially in China. The venom is also used to make narcotics, which are used in rave parties.”

The Indo-Bangla border in Malda and South Dinajpur has been used to smuggle snake poison of late. Last March, around 1.5kg of poison was seized from Gazole on its way to being smuggled to Bangladesh. In May, there were two seizures of venom from Tapan in South Dinajpur and Malda’s Doulatpur. And in April, a substantial amount of snake venom was seized near Balurghat.

Title: Kolkata raises a toast to 2020 with pricey whiskies, wines
Content:
The festive spirit and chilly weather led to uptake in consumption of premium liquor, said a restaurateur

‘More private parties pushed up Scotch sales’

KOLKATA: With the year-end party spirit spilling over to the New Year, Kolkatans said cheers to 2020 by splurging on more expensive liquor. Rather than low-end whisky or rum, tipplers have chosen to raise a toast with Scotch, premium whisky and wine across the city’s watering holes that have remained chock-a-block since December 31.Beer has been the preferred tipple in the afternoons while whisky has left other forms of liquor behind by a long way post-sundown. Off-shops, too, recorded a 20-25% spike in the sale of imported Scotch.The chill in the air has also led to a sharp spurt in the sale of room temperature beer and rum with warm water during the last week of the year, according to Hotel and Restaurants’ Association of Eastern India secretary Sudesh Poddar.“From New Year’s eve onwards, there has been a marked shift towards premium brands of India Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL), overseas spirits bottled in India (OSBI), wine and vodka. Instead of ‘prestige’ segment whisky, most have been ordering ‘premium’ ones that cost 30-40% more. While 80% of liquor sales in the evenings is whisky, 60% customers preferred beer during the day,” said Poddar.Liquor sale has seen a marginal slump across restaurants and bars during the festive period. This, however, is usual since most prefer to spend more on food than liquor. House parties are preferred for drinking, said HRAEI president Pranav Singh.Hotel and Restaurants’ Association of Eastern India president Pranav Singh said: “Though liquor sales did not rise sharply, sale of premium liquor did go up at the year-end with customers graduating to a higher category. This is particularly so among whisky drinkers who have moved from Indian made foreign liquor to overseas liquor bottled in India to bottled in origin.”But what came as a surprise was the sudden spurt in orders for premium segment whiskies like Blender’s Pride, Signature Premium, Sterling Reserve B10 and Antiquity Blue, which a saw a 25% jump in orders compared to the corresponding period of last year. Overseas spirit bottled in India (OSBI) like 100 Pipers, Teacher’s and Black Dog, too, saw a 15% spike. Liquor bottled in origin (BIO) and Scotch sales went up by 10%. Charles Mantosh, who owns multiple restaurants on Park Street, acknowledged the year-end festivities had seen a rise in sale of premium liquor.“Though the market is tepid, those who step out spend a bit more than they usually would. The festive spirit around this time of the year combined with the weather resulted in an uptake in consumption of premium liquor,” said Mantosh. He, though, is unhappy the revenue from food that has dipped 20% since last December 31 and January 1.The move to an upper bracket of liquor may have been prompted by a lean period that preceded the festive week, felt some. Political unrest and an economic slowdown led to a nosedive in footfall across Kolkata’s restaurants.Off-shops recorded 25% jump in scotch sales during the last 10-12 days of December compared to the corresponding period of 2018. Consumption of rum saw a 15-20% jump, while the premium and regular whisky segments witnessed a modest double-digit jump. Sources close to the excise department pointed out the jump in Scotch sales was largely due to more private parties. “This time, there were a lot of private parties, where high-end liquor was served. Excise department kept a vigil on the parties to ensure no illegal (duty free or bought from other states) liquor was served,” added sources. The overall jump in liquor sales was 15-20%.

Title: Makar Sankranti: #GoFlyAKite: A dummy’s guide to hosting the perfect patang party this Makar Sankranti
Content:
SHUDDH DESI DRESS CODE

FINGER FOOD, BOTTOMLESS DRINKS

ON THE PLAYLIST

QUIRKY DÉCOR

THINGS TO KEEP IN MIND AT YOUR KITE PARTY

Say no to Chinese manja:

Avoid plastic Patangs:

Be careful:

Kites, food, music and masti — sums up the perfect patang party, doesn’t it? And with Makar Sankranti just ’round the corner, many a Hyderabadi peeps are already gearing up to throw their big, fat annual patang party.After all what’s Sankranti without a fun day of kite flying with friends and family, binging on some yummy goodies and dancing to some peppy beats? Haven’t gotten around planning yours yet? Worry not, we’ve got your back. Here’s all the ideas you need to throw a fun-filled patang party that your gang will remember for the whole year to come...The best part about a patang party is you can dress up or dress down, as long as comfort is the keyword. For an uber insta worthy party album, you could go for a common colour scheme as the dress code. Think whites paired with blue denims. Else, pick a broader theme — such as shuddh desi — and let your guests decide what they want to wear. Dress comfortably in a way that will not hinder your fun activities and dance/ kite flying movements.weet pongal, boorelu, paramannam, ariselu — Sankranti snacks are aplenty in every Telugu household. If yours still makes these from scratch, your guests are a lucky lot. If not, get some from the market. The roof top buffet spread should have lots of fuss-free finger foods and mason jars filled with refreshing drinks to keep guests fuelled up.There is no party without music and you’ve definitely gotta amp up the boom box to churn out some Bollywood numbers to get the party going. Some of our favourites would be, Udi Udi Jaaye (Raees), Manja (Kai-Po Che) Dheel De De (Hum Dil De Chuke Sanam), which are perfect patang numbers.Peppy Telugu beats, remixes of retro hits and even the odd club hits are must-haves on the playlist.As most patang parties are held on the terrace, the décor could be minimal yet traditional — think marigolds and mango leaf thorans with funky elements like a bedecked rickshaw, or a giant kite... A pretty shamiyana would be perfect for those who want to chill in the shade while the others are screaming ‘affffaaaa’. a picture booth, where guests can take goofy pictures with props, could be a fun addition!The Chinese manjas are razor sharp and a great eco hazard. The thread is made of nylon, plastic or other synthetic materials, laced with glass, metal and other sharp objects which could be extremely dangerous both for you and your guests. What’s more, they kill and maime hapless birds, which get entangled on the loose threads hanging on trees and poles. This kite season, don’t leave any stray manja hanging around!sustainable celebrations are the need of the hour. It’s best to opt for paper kites for your parties — they are classic and colourful. plastic patangs are a big ‘no’.While flying kites or dancing, be careful and mindful that you are on the rooftop. If alcohol is served, or if children are around, make sure someone’s keeping an eye on all the guests. Guard against injuries from sharp threads too. stay sun safe by donning hats, sunglasses and sunscreen. And, always keep afirst-aid box handy.

Title: Refugee outreachby Bengal BJP
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kolkata: Bengal BJP leaders sat with party organisers and members of the IT cell on Saturday to focus on the refugee belts of Basirhat, Barrackpore and Barasat in North 24 Parganas, five days ahead of chief minister Mamata Banerjee’s rally from Barasat to Madhyamgram on January 9.

The purpose was to send out a message to the Hindu refugees to avail the window under the new citizenship law so that they don’t have to face the predicament that 14 lakh Hindus are facing in Assam.

“A self-declaration is enough for a citizenship application under CAA. There is no need to provide a document in support of the declaration. One can apply online as well,” said BJP state general secretary Sayantan Basu. He claimed that while making the ap-plication, legacy documents won’t have to be furnished .

Bengal BJP president Dilip Ghosh on Saturday reached out to the refugee settlements of Gopiballavpur in West Midnapore and reassured those who came to India in 1950 and later to apply under CAA. “The Hindu refugees who were forced to leave their homeland and come to India in 1950 and afterwards are our honoured citizens,” he said.

What if a person having ration card or Aadhaar number doesn’t apply for citizenship? Ghosh said they will mi-ss the opportunity and may be asked to provide valid documents for migration. BJP leaders said under Section 14 of the Foreigners Act and Section 3/12 of the Passport Act, the onus lies on the accused to prove his bona fides.

Bengal BJP, however, leaves out Muslim “infiltrators” in the state. “Muslim reside-nts of our country have nothi-ng to worry about. Our complaint is only against Muslims who sneaked into India and have been staying here surreptitiously,” Basu said.

BJP leaders cited a case State versus Fatma in Ghaziabad district in Uttar Pradesh where the lady and her husband had entered without valid documents from neighbouring Bangladesh. The accused made a false statement that she was a Haldia resident and her husband hailed from Kolkata. Both of them were convicted and sent to jail for three years.

The Bengal BJP has already activated its IT team to send bulk messages, giving the “right information” on CAA to the people. “The Act has nothing to do with those who are bona fide residents. It doesn’t affect the Indian-born Muslims,” Basu said.

Ends

Title: Divisive politics could harm the economy: Kaushik Basu
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kolkata: Divisive politics is affecting India and may impact the economy in the long term, former World Bank ch-ief economist Kaushik Basu said on the sidelines of a Ficci event here on Saturday.

Basu said three importa-nt institutions created in India since Independence — democracy, secularism and credible statistics — needed to be preserved. “Once institutions erode, that is a long-term problem,” he said.

While criticizing “hyper-nationalism”, he clarified that in India it is not linked to economic policies like in the US, which is raising tariffs and lowering migration. Rather, he said, it “erodes trust” and a “sense of belonging”.

About the economy, he said short-term issues could be dealt with through policy interventions. For instance, the National Infrastructure Pipeline is a “good idea” but, if not implemented properly, it could spark inflation. This apart, he said, Budget 2020 should look at better fiscal and monetary policy integration in order to boost demand. An interest rate cut, he maintained, can boost demand in the short run.

Commenting on the slowdown, he said India was going through “a very difficult economic phase” and 4.5% growth is “atrocious”.

Basu also said unemployment and the rural sector slowdown could be hurting consumption across the country. He cited the fall in automobile production and lower growth in electricity consumption.

Though he gave the government credit for pushing through goods and services tax (GST) and the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, he said the haste in implementing GST had seen small businesses take a hit.

Ficci chairman (eastern region) Rudra Chatterjee, who interacted with Basu, said the world economy was witnessing slow growth, but that could provide Indian businesses an opportunity to increase market share.

Title: Firecracker unit owner nabbed from hideout
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Naihati: Sheikh Nur Hossain, the fugitive owner of the illegal firecracker factory at Naihati’s Masjidpara in No-rth 24 Parganas, was arrested from an Amdanga hideout on Saturday. He was booked under IPC Section 304 (culpable homicide not amounting to murder) for the deaths of five factory workers after three explosions ignited a fire in the cracker unit on Friday afternoon.

The blasts had sent two bodies flying and shattered the windowpanes of neighbouring houses and shops. At least a dozen were seriously injured in the resultant fire as the entire structure was blown to smithereens.

Sources said Hossain earlier ran a cracker unit at his residence in Debak. “Later, he set up the factory on agricultural land at Masjidpara. He employed around 35 people, including a child, a woman and teenagers. It had no licence and there was no fire safety arrangement in the unit in which chemicals and explosives were stockpiled,” a resident said.

Forensic experts and Ba-rrackpore police commissioner Manoj Kr Verma visited the spot and collected samples from the debris.

Investigation revealed that nearly four dozen illegal firecracker units existed in Masjidpara-Debak-Mamudpur. “More than 50 such factories are running illegally inside houses in Masjidpara and Debak. Despite several police raids, locals started making firecrackers again,” a senior police official said.

“We will close down all such cracker units in the area permanently. Those people should be professionally rehabilitated soon,” Verma told TOI.

Full report on www.toi.in

Title: TMC & FB rally against CAA
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kolkata: The new citizensh-ip law is one issue that has brought all anti-BJP parties and organisations on the same page.

In a bid to keep up the anti-CAA tempo, Trinamool Congress supporters took out a rally from Subhas Sarobar at Beliaghata to Rajabazar on Saturday while Forward Bloc hit Central Avenue.

TMC, the Left and Congre-ss have been harping on BJP’s bid to “drive a wedge on religious lines” on the ground that the law is a direct affront to Articles 14-23 of the Constitution that guarantee equality irrespective of race, caste, creed, religion and sex. The Supreme Court will take up a host of PILs against CAA on January 22.

In the meantime, all three parties have been hitting the streets and have lapped up pu-blic support, particularly am-ong students, against the “divisive CAA”. The Left has given a general strike call against CAA-NPR-NRC and economic issues such as employment and PSU disinvestment on January 8.

“When citizens were celebrating the New Year, many came out in the cold to protest against CAA and NRC. This is unprecedented. Political parties, rights organisations, students and individuals have voiced their protest while home minister Amit Shah has announced that there will be no going back on CAA. This is authoritarianism,” said CPM politburo member Mohammad Selim.

Chief minister Mamata Banerjee, after leading four anti-CAA protests in the city and Siliguri, has announced she will walk from Barasat to Madhyamgram on January 9 and take out a protest rally in the Hills on January 22.

Title: Karnataka BJP MLA Somashekara Reddy booked for hate speech
Content:
G Somashekara Reddy

No secular-minded person will think like this: Zameer

BALLARI: G Somashekara Reddy, Ballari City BJP MLA and younger brother of tainted mining baron G Janardhana Reddy, was booked on Saturday for making an inflammatory speech and allegedly promoting enmity between two groups.His comments at a protest organised by BJP and ABVP in support of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act on Friday in Ballari drew flak from political parties and people alike.Police booked him under Section 153-A (promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion, race, place of birth, residence, language, etc., and doing acts prejudicial to maintenance of harmony) of the Indian Penal Code after P Vivek, president, Cantonment Block of the Congress, lodged a police complaint.Earlier on Saturday, thousands of Muslims led by Congress and JD(S) leaders assembled near Shaadimal and took out a rally on the main roads of Ballari, demanding action against Reddy. They also burnt his effigy over his remarks, particularly ‘We are 80 per cent, you are 17 per cent’.Ballari superintendent of police CK Baba asked protesters to maintain peace and assured them a case would be booked against Reddy.However, they continued raising slogans. They relented only after the SP showed them a copy of the FIR registered at Gandhinagar police station and promised to initiate action against the MLA.At a road work bhoomi puja on Saturday, Reddy told mediapersons: “I addressed those who are disturbing the law and order, peace and harmony of the land, not everyone. Those who respect the law of the land need not be afraid. I request all minorities to live in the country peacefully and happily with everyone.”Congress MLA from Chamarajpet B Z Zameer Ahmed Khan on Saturday slammed Reddy for his remark, saying, “No secular-minded person will think like that. He’s just trying to destroy peace in the country. India is a secular country where Hindu, Muslims, Christians and Sikhs live peacefully.”On Friday, Reddy had warned the Muslim community against participating in anti-CAA protests, saying the CAA will not be good for them and they will have to face serious repercussions. “Let me caution those who are protesting against the CAA. Imagine what will happen if we (Hindus) take charge,” Reddy had said.Police extended security to Reddy at his residence in Ashok Nagar in Ballari Rural limits. A team of 25 police constables has been deployed there.

Title: Ready to die: Asaduddin Owaisi riposte to BJP netas
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi

HYDERABAD: Reacting strongly to comments made by BJP MP D Arvind and MLA Raja Singh, Hyderabad MP Asaduddin Owaisi on Saturday said he wasn’t scared of such hollow threats by them and was “ready to die…I want to achieve martyrdom”. Speaking at an anti-Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) meeting in Sangareddy late on Saturday evening, Owaisi said: “Prime Minister Modi your people want to kill me…Some people from Sangh Parivar want to kill me…I dare them. Shoot me, I am not afraid, I roam around alone and will continue to do so.”

Earlier, Goshamahal legislator Raja Singh had issued death threats to anti-CAA protesters and hinted that this list included the Owaisi brothers as well. This was followed by another scathing attack from Nizamabad MP Dharmapuri Arvind who warned Owaisi of dire consequences if he continued to oppose the CAA.

Launching an attack on both these BJP lawmakers, the AIMIM chief said: “We are not the ones who jump into the sea and complain about its depth. We are not afraid of the wild creatures in it. Our ship will reach the shore with Allah's grace.”

Thousands gathered for the meeting where Owaisi urged people to collectively fight for the repeal of CAA. “Ahead of Republic Day, make a video of yourself reading from the Preamble of the Indian Constitution and post it on social media appealing to the Prime Minister to withdraw the 'evil' CAA,” Owaisi said.

Title: Kolkata: Dog loses life, couple lose cash as fraudsters strike
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Kanoria points to the spot in Salt Lake where the puppy was hit by the car and (R) a screengrab of the page th... Read More

KOLKATA: An investment banker, Anant Shroff, and his wife wanted to help a puppy that was hit by a car in Salt Lake. But instead, they not only lost the dog but also Rs 97,000 from their bank account when they were duped by a phishing site that opened when they were searching for an animal rescue team online. The incident happened on December 29.

Shroff (40), an investment banker from Delhi, had come to Kolkata to attend his sister-in-law’s wedding. Shroff said he had called an “animal helpline number” of a website, which had popped up first on the Google search, and accidentally ended up sharing his UPI PIN and the OTP over a text message when the caller on the other side of the helpline had asked him to transfer Rs 10 — a token amount before they send an animal rescue team.

Shroff lost Rs 97,000 in a span of five minutes and even saw the puppy suffer to death in front of his eyes at CL Block as none came to the spot.

Shroff and his wife have lodged complaints with Bidhannagar East PS and cyber crime department of Bidhannagar City Police and blocked their bank account. But the fraudsters could not be arrested till Saturday and the website — www.srikanta-sahoo.in — that claims to provide 24x7 support for animals is active till date. However, when TOI called the helpline number 8910760215, it was switched off. Caller identification app Truecaller flagged the number as a “fraud call”.

Shroff’s wife Tamanna Kanoria, who wrote about her ordeal on Bidhannagar Police’s Facebook page on Friday, said that on January 29 afternoon, she and her husband saw a sedan running over a puppy outside their house at CL Block.

“The puppy was in pain and we wanted to help it. But since we didn’t know any animal care facilities here, we searched Google and the website from where we were robbed, topped the search list. Hence, we had dialled the helpline number,” said Kanoria, who will be heading back to Delhi on Monday. Shroff is now in China for a business meet

Shroff, who has quit his job recently and ventured into entrepreneurship, dialled the number and sought their help. “The person, who received the phone, asked him to pay Rs 10 online as transaction fee, post which he promised to release the rescue team to attend to the dog,” said Kanoria. The caller forwarded the payment link that asked the duo to enter some banking details along with Shroff’s UPI ID.

“Since we were concerned about saving the puppy, we entered details along with the UPI ID. Shroff’s bank account was linked to a UPI payment gateway. We even shared the OTP as it never struck us that they could indulge in fraud,” said Kanoria. Within minutes, Rs 97,000 was deducted from Shroff’s account in three instalments — Rs 48,000, Rs 45,000 and Rs 4,000 respectively.

By the time they realised they were being duped, the caller had switched off the mobile.

Title: US Iran War: Donald Trump threatens to bomb Iranian cultural sites in move seen as war crime
Content:
....hundreds of Iranian protesters. He was already attacking our Embassy, and preparing for additional hits in othe… https://t.co/TM9PJtpX7V — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) 1578178325000

....targeted 52 Iranian sites (representing the 52 American hostages taken by Iran many years ago), some at a very… https://t.co/p1wqtpTcpt — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) 1578178325000

WASHINGTON: US President Donald Trump has warned that he will bomb sites important to Iranian culture if Tehran retaliates against the assassination of a top Iranian general that he ordered earlier this week.In an astounding threat, which is seen as amounting to a war crime if it is carried out, the US President raised the stakes in his confrontation with Iran to unprecedented levels.“Let this serve as a WARNING that if Iran strikes any Americans, or American assets, we have targeted 52 Iranian sites (representing the 52 American hostages taken by Iran many years ago), some at a very high level & important to Iran & the Iranian culture, and those targets, and Iran itself, WILL BE HIT VERY FAST AND VERY HARD. The USA wants no more threats!” Trump said in a set of tweets posted on Saturday evening.The US President prefaced the threat by explaining that “Iran is talking very boldly about targeting certain USA assets as revenge for our ridding the world of their terrorist leader who had just killed an American, & badly wounded many others, not to mention all of the people he (Gen.Suleimani) had killed over his lifetime, including recently...hundreds of Iranian protesters. He was already attacking our Embassy, and preparing for additional hits in other locations. Iran has been nothing but problems for many years.”The direct public threat to attack cultural targets, regardless of the provocation, is unheard of in modern diplomacy or warfare. While many analysts said it went beyond the legitimate targeting of military sites, the crude threat immediately invited comparisons to Taliban ’s wanton destruction of the Bamiyan Buddha, a UNESCO heritage site in Afghanistan .There was also skepticism if Trump could really carry out the threat. "For what it's worth, I find it hard to believe the Pentagon would provide Trump targeting options that include Iranian cultural sites. Trump may not care about the laws of war, but DoD planners and lawyers do...and targeting cultural sites is war crime," tweeted Colin Kahl, a former Obama administration official.Iran’s foreign minister Javed Zarif schooled Trump on international law – and English language, tweeting, “Having committed grave breaches of international law in Friday's cowardly assassinations, @realdonaldtrump threatens to commit again new breaches of JUS COGENS; -Targeting cultural sites is a WAR CRIME.”“Those masquerading as diplomats and those who shamelessly sat to identify Iranian cultural & civilian targets should not even bother to open a law dictionary. Jus cogens refers to peremptory norms of international law, i.e. international red lines. That is, a big(ly) "no no",” he added.Other agitated Twitterati pointed out that the U.S didn’t even nuke Kyoto during WWII to spare Japan’s cultural sites and treasures. "The fact that Trump can go on Twitter and threaten to target non-military sites that are very high level & important to Iran & the Iranian culture' is an outrageous terrorist threat," noted one observer.Trump administration officials have been trying to portray Qassim Suleimani, the general who Trump had assassinated with Hellfire missile delivered from Drones, as an anti-American warlord who directed the killing of US personnel. But there is growing skepticism about the Trump construct, particularly efforts to link him to 9/11, because Suleimani was a Shia who was a sworn enemy of the Sunni engendered al-Qaida and ISIS.In fact, ISIS was the common enemy of both US and Iran/Suleimani, and experts say few would be more happy with the Iranian general’s assassination than ISIS extremists.In Video: Will hit very fast and hard: President Trump warns Iran

Title: Karnataka high court quashes CM's authority to appoint parliamentary secretaries
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A chief minister can't appoint MLAs and MLCs, who could not be accommodated in the cabinet, as parliamentary secretaries with pay and allowances equivalent to those of a minister. The high court on Saturday struck down as 'unconstitutional' the Karnataka Parliamentary Secretaries (Salary, Allowances and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1963 and the amendment brought to it in 1999. The court also recalled that in Bimolangshu Roy's case, the Supreme Court had already taken a view that the state assembly lacked legislative competence to enact a law providing for appointment of parliamentary secretaries.

A division bench headed by chief justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka said the office of the parliamentary secretary has the trappings of posts of ministers of state without independent charge or at least deputy minister.

"The said Act will work as a device available to the chief minister to appoint members of the legislative assembly and legislative council of his choice as parliamentary secretary, who can't be made as minister due to constraints of Article 164(1-A) of the Constitution. This will completely defeat and nullify the upper ceiling imposed by Article 164(1-A) of the Constitution on the number of ministers," the bench added.

City-based social activist MB Adinarayana and advocate KB Vijayakumar had challenged the appointment of parliamentary secretaries. Adinarayana specifically challenged the decision by then CM HD Kumaraswamy to appoint eight MLAs/MLCs as parliamentary secretaries in January last year. He argued that the appointments virtually take the number of council of ministers beyond the stipulated 15% of the assembly strength.

Title: Boy found dead in Manesar was sodomised & tortured: Autopsy
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

GURUGRAM: A 9-year-old boy whose body was found in a Manesar village on Friday night was sexually assaulted and tortured before his death, an autopsy has revealed. The boy had multiple injuries on the head, which are suspected to have been caused by a blunt object.

Police are investigating if black magic was performed before the boy was killed, saying they had found a dead pigeon near the body. Some of the boy’s hair had been cut too, which, cops said, have strengthened the suspicion of sorcery.

A few pieces of bricks lay near the body — found just 300 metres from the boy’s home — and the police suspect the victim had been hit on the head with them.

Six police teams have been formed to investigate the case. Several people have been rounded up for questioning and the cops have recorded the statements of villagers and neighbours. According to sources, the investigation is centred around three angles — sexual assault, whether the boy was murdered as part of sorcery and if the accused was known to the boy’s family.

DCP (Manesar) Rajesh Singh said they were examining multiple CCTV clips of the area recorded between 9.20-9.40pm on Thursday. The boy is seen following a man in his thirties in one of the footage.

“The boy follows a man. It seems the man is known to the victim,” said Singh. He added the cops had not been able to identify the man as his face is not clear in the footage.

The officer said though there was evidence that black magic had been performed either before or after the murder, things will become clear only after the accused has been arrested. “The accused could be familiar with the boy’s family. We are recording statements of people in the neighbourhood,” Singh added.

According to the officer, the boy’s family has told the cops he was playing outside his home till 9pm on Thursday, but they could not find him after that. While CCTV footage shows the boy accompanying the man around 9.30pm, the autopsy report suggests he could have been killed around midnight. “This means the boy was killed hours after he was abducted,” an officer said.

The body of the 9-year-old was found during a combing operation of the area after police mounted a search. His parents thought he might have gone to a relative’s place. Relatives had also said the boy would often go to their houses.

Dr Deepak Mathur from the forensic department of Civil Hospital, who conducted the autopsy on the boy, said the nature of injuries suggested that the 9-year-old struggled to rescue himself as he was being tortured before being killed.

“It seems the boy was hit multiple times with a blunt object and subjected to torture . He struggled for a while. The boy was also assaulted sexually,” he said.

The doctor said samples had been sent to a forensic lab for further tests.

A relative of the boy said the family is originally from Bihar but had settled in Manesar 15 years ago.

The father runs a textile shop and lives in a rented accommodation.

“They had four children — two sons and two daughters. The elder son died of some ailment a few years ago. The son whose body was found was the second one. Now, they are left with two younger daughters.” the relative said.

He added that a number of children play in the area till late in the night, but there never had been any concern about their safety.

Title: Students worried as Haryana boards advanced to March
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

GURUGRAM: With the Board of the School Education Haryana bringing forward the dates for Class X and XII board exams this year, students are a harried lot.

Every year, the exams would be conducted in April and the results of it would be out in the fourth week of May. This year, the exams will begin on March 4.

The district education officer, Indu Boken, said on Saturday that the board had decided to hold exams early to speed up the application process that follows. “Results are delayed when exams are late. That causes a problem for students applying to other institutions or for higher education,” she said.

The students, however, would rather have more time to prepare.

“We usually get at least two months to study. This year, it’s already January and there is hardly any time to prepare,” said Sunil Yadav, a Class X student at Sector 4 Government School.

But even that problem comes later. Over the past few months, classes in many schools have been irregular because of the election or pollution.

“We are yet to finish everything on the syllabus. The exam schedule is also not a well-planned one. We don’t have enough time for the science exam, for instance,” said Sangita Kumari, a Class X student at Government School, Jacobpura.

The exam schedule is a problem for Class XII students as well. “We will get just two days for physics and maths. It will be very difficult for us. The board could have given us at least four days,” said Kamlesh Singh, a Class XII student at Government Senior Secondary School Boys, Civil Hospital.

Title: Haryana: Farmers, workers gear up for January 8 strike
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

GURUGRAM: Lakhs of farmers, industrial workers, daily wagers and other government employees across the state are gearing up to take part in a nationwide strike on January 8 against many of the Centre’s policies.

Led by groups like the All India Kisan Sangharsh Coordination Committee (AIKSCC), All India Trade Union Congress (AITUC), Centre for Indian Trade Union (CITU), the one-day strike will see many voices join in.

“There are four forces that make this strike strong — call by trade unions, support by farmers’ organisations, involvement of students’ groups and inclusion of the anti-CAA movement under the banner of We The People,” said political activist Yogendra Yadav. “This should not be seen as a litmust test, but a protest against the government’s policies. The good thing is that people are coming out. The whole idea is to bring a strong narrative around real issues,” he added.

The call for the strike was first given in September at a mass convention of workers. Soon AIKCC, an umbrella organisation for over 100 farmers’ groups, joined in. After the CAA was passed, more groups responded to the strike call. Though the protest will be spearheaded by the farmers’ union, several others like Manesar’s Honda employees’ union and groups of government employees from the roadways, health department and municipal corporations will lend unconditional support. Some of the issues they had been highlighting are privatisation, rising unemployment, agrarian crisis, closing of industries, etc.

“There are three main angles to the protest. First is the agrarian crisis, which has brought farmers, dairy and fishery workers, and share-croppers together. Second is the economic slowdown and dilution of labour rights, which has forced workers of banks and healthcare facilities to come out and protest. Third is the attack on the fundamentals of the Constitution and introduction of an Act. For long, the government has skirted discussions on basic problems,” said Rajiv Godara of AIKCC.

Besides farmers, workers, civil societies and student groups, over 20,000 members of the Haryana Roadways union have also decided to up the ante against the government over its kilometre scheme, under which private buses are allowed in the government fleet.

Title: Gurugram: Property tax can be filed till January 31
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

GURUGRAM: The deadline to file property tax has been extended by a month to January 31.

“Those who have not filed property tax can deposit it and avail a 10% tax rebate. Properties of defaulters will be sealed and, later, auctioned if they fail to deposit the property tax in time,” MCG chief Vinay Pratap Singh said.

Property tax can be filed online on the MCG website or at the MCG offices in Sector 34 and in front of the Civil Hospital, and the community centre in Sector 42.

The Haryana Municipal Corporation Act, 1994 mandates filing of property tax for vacant plots and all types of complexes. In case it is not filed, an interest of 18% is levied every year. The MCG has sent out 253 notices so far and recovered Rs 1.2 crore from defaulters.

“We are yet to recover Rs 90 crore,” an MCG official said, adding that most defaulters are builders. If dues are not paid even when properties are sealed, defaulters are given 15 days’ time. After that, their properties are auctioned.

Title: Bengaluru: Man attacked, burnt to death near Anekal
Content:
This story is from January 5, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: A 51-year-old man died after he was set ablaze by a few unidentified persons near Anekal on the outskirts of Bengaluru. The motive for the murder is yet to be ascertained.

The incident occurred on Friday night when M Jyothappa of Hosahalli village was riding back home from Hebbagodi. The assailants intercepted his bike near a temple in Renuka Colony around 10pm.

"Jyothappa fell down from his bike and miscreants attacked him with a blunt object. Before he could get up, they poured petrol and set him on fire and fled from the spot," police said. A farmer, Jyotappa is survived by homemaker wife and two children.

"His family has filed a complaint suspecting a money-related feud. We are probing all angles," police said.
